column1: Depression and anxiety can be disconcerting and disruptive to our lives in many ways. I am sorry that you are suffering so much. Depression and anxiety can arise due to experiences, genetics or a combination of both. I like for my clients look at their issues as whole persons so I would also recommend these tips:Physical: regular exercise, healthy balanced diet, rest and sleepMental: how we think is how we feel. How are you interpreting the events that are happening to you? Try to interpret them in a less negative way. Unfortunately we cannot stop our thoughts as our brain is always working. If you can't see your issues in a different way then stop struggling and allow and accept whatever the unhelpful thoughts are. Choose to take actions based on your values and what will give you a fulfilling life no matter what your thoughts are. Remember, your thoughts have no power unless you act upon them. Emotional: do not let feelings dictate your actions, even if something feels anxious take action again based on your values and how you want to live.   Social: connect with healthy friends and family that will be a positive support. Take up some hobbies and recreation activities as well. If things do not improve I would encourage you to make an appointment with a talk therapist and discuss these issues. I would encourage you to also be open to consider an evaluation for anti-depressants with these issues as well. If you ever feel like you might hurt yourself please call 911 or go to your nearest ER.

column1: Wanting to make changes and asking for assistance is the first step. Overcoming anxiety and depression is not an easy feat to do on your own, especially if it's been something you have been battling for years.  There are some different routes you may go down in order to start the healing process:Therapy - find a therapist who has a lot of experience with anxiety and depression. You can do this by googling "anxiety depression therapist " in your city.  CounselChat also has a directory of amazing therapists, as does Psychology TodayMedication - Depending on what other symptoms you may be struggling with depends on what medication you will be prescribed. Be 100% honest with the doctor and ask about different side effects or potential risks associated with the medication. You more than likely will be prescribed an SSRI.Therapy & Medication - The outcomes are very good for those who decide to do both. Medication can help level out out your mood and therapy can help you process through your emotions and keep you accountable for you goals , as you will be seeing your therapist more often than your psychiatristTherapy & Homeopathy - Homeopathy could potentially be a good tool to use alongside with therapy in case you are not interested in going down the medication route. Arsenicum album is most commonly given to those who struggle with anxiety and depression.The choice is yours. My recommendation is to start with therapy and explore your options more in depth with your therapist.

column1: One thing that comes to mind is making a list of some things that happen each day. It could be that there are things that are affecting how upset you are, but because so many other things are going on, you may not notice.Another idea to try is to keep a list for a month of one good thing that happened each day. This way, when you're having a rough day, you have a list to think of and take a look at.Are you eating and sleeping in ways that are typical for you (typically at least two meals per day and roughly 8 hours of sleep that night (may be different depending on your age)? These two ideas are closely related to changes in your mood.From where do you have support? Friends or family?Can you take 5 or 10 minutes per day to do something that you enjoy?If you think back to the last time that you felt "content," what was contributing to that?Another possibility is to try to be mindful of things that you do every day. For example, rather than eating a turkey sandwich as fast as possible on your lunch break, consider actually tasting it and enjoying it. Also consider giving yourself praise for doing something well. For example, when you finish your paperwork, take a moment to notice that and maybe reward yourself by checking your e-mail, reading five pages of a book, or something else that can be done quickly before you get back to your next task.

column2: There are several ways to access counseling services even if your primary care physician isn't supportive or able to help. Here are some options: 1. **Insurance Provider**: Check with your health insurance provider. They often have a list of in-network mental health professionals that you can contact directly. 2. **Employee Assistance Programs (EAPs)**: If you're employed, your workplace may offer EAPs. These programs often provide short-term counseling services. 3. **Community Mental Health Centers**: Many communities have mental health centers that offer counseling services. These centers often operate on a sliding fee scale, which means the amount you pay is based on your income. 4. **Online Therapy Platforms**: There are numerous online platforms like BetterHelp, Talkspace, and others that connect individuals with licensed therapists. These services can be accessed from the comfort of your home. 5. **Local Universities**: If you live near a university, you may be able to access their counseling services. Some universities offer counseling services to the community, often at a reduced rate. 6. **Professional Associations**: Associations like the American Psychological Association (APA) or the National Association of Social Workers (NASW) have directories of professionals that you can search. 7. **Hotlines and Text Services**: If you're in crisis, there are hotlines available in many countries. In the U.S., for example, you can contact the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline or the Crisis Text Line. 8. **Self-help Groups**: These are often free and can provide support and advice. They can be found for a wide range of mental health issues. Remember, it's important to advocate for your own mental health. If you feel your primary care physician isn't providing the support you need, it may be worth seeking a second opinion or discussing your concerns directly with them.

column2: Getting counseling even without the assistance of your primary care physician is very possible. Here are some possible approaches: 1. Online Counseling: There are many online platforms that offer counseling services and mental health resources, such as BetterHelp, Talkspace, and 7 Cups. 2. Mental Health Hotlines: If you're in a crisis, you can also reach out to mental health hotlines. They often provide immediate assistance and can suggest resources for further help. 3. Employee Assistance Programs: If you're employed, check if your company has an Employee Assistance Program (EAP). These programs often offer free counseling sessions. 4. Universities and Colleges: Students often have access to free or discounted mental health services, either through their school's counseling department or student health services. 5. Community Mental Health Centers: Many cities have local, publicly funded mental health centers that provide free or low-cost treatment. 6. Out-of-Network Providers: If you have insurance, you can also pursue therapy with an out-of-network provider. You may have to pay out of pocket and get reimbursed later. 7. Research Studies: Some universities and research institutions provide treatment as part of studies on mental health. 8. Private Therapists/Psychologists: Find a private practice therapist or psychologist and potentially negotiate a payment plan, or they might offer a sliding fee scale based on income. 9. Non-Profit Organizations: Many organizations offer free or low-cost counseling. Examples include the National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI) and the Anxiety and Depression Association of America (ADAA). 10. Support Groups: While not a substitute for professional help, support groups can be beneficial. They are usually free and meet in-person or online. Remember, if your current primary care physician is unresponsive or dismissive of your mental health concerns, you may want to consider finding a new doctor who takes your issues seriously. Your mental health is as important as your physical health.

column1: I would check out agencies that offer affordable counseling based on your income or very low cost counseling sessions, i.e., Pacific Clinics, Hathaway Sycamore, Pasadena Mental Health Center, Burbank Family Center. column2: If your primary care physician isn't supportive or helpful in regards to your mental health, there are plenty of other ways to find help: 1. Insurance Provider: Reach out to your health insurance provider. They can give you a list of covered individual therapists, psychologists, psychiatrists, and counseling centers. 2. Online Therapy: There are many online platforms such as BetterHelp or TalkSpace that connect you with licensed therapists who can provide counseling through video, phone calls, or text messages. 3. Employee Assistance Program (EAP): Some workplaces offer free, confidential counseling services through an EAP. Check with your HR department to see if this is available. 4. Community Mental Health Centers: These clinics offer free or low-cost therapy and mental health services. You can find one in your area by doing a quick online search. 5. Schools and Universities: If you're a student, schools often provide their students with free or low-cost mental health services. 6. Hotlines and Text Services: If you're in crisis and need immediate help, there are hotlines like the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline (1-800-273-TALK) and Crisis Text Line (text HOME to 741741) that are staffed with trained volunteers who can provide support. 7. Mental Health Professionals: Seek out a mental health professional independently. You don't need a referral from a physician if you're willing to pay out-of-pocket. You can search online for therapists or psychologists in your area.  Remember, it's very important to advocate for yourself; if your primary care physician isn't helpful, don't be afraid to look elsewhere for help. Mental health is equally as important as physical health.

column1: First step always is to do a medical rule out so that you're sure the problem is psychological and emotion based, not a medical condition which requires care and attention.If you are medically clear in the reasons for losing your erection, then reflect on what may be creating a loss in confidence in either who you are and what you're doing with your life, or whether your wife has these sort of problems within herself.Often a problem transfers ownership of who shows it.If you are a sensitive person its possible your erection problem reflects your wife's insecurities and self-doubt.  If she is someone who is reluctant to talk about feeling unsure then in a certain way by you showing a problem, she can avoid looking at herself.There may not be a direct cause such as usually exists in a medical problem.Medicine looks for symptoms to treat.Our emotional lives are much more indirect.If you feel stress at work or are unhappy in the place you live, for example, then your frustration may show up in your sex life.Basically, do a broad inward search of your life and what it holds and maybe ask your wife to do the same.You may clear the air within yourselves and between each other so the problem goes away.
column2: Erectile dysfunction, or difficulty maintaining an erection, can be a result of several factors: 1. Physical conditions: Heart disease, atherosclerosis, high blood pressure, diabetes, obesity, tobacco use and alcoholism can all contribute to erectile dysfunction. Neurological conditions, such as multiple sclerosis and Parkinson¡¯s disease can interfere with the brain¡¯s communication to the penis to induce an erection. 2. Psychological issues: Depression, anxiety, stress, and problems with relationships can interfere with your ability to have a satisfying sexual intercourse.  3. Medications: Certain medications can cause or contribute to erectile dysfunction. These can include antidepressants, antihistamines, blood pressure medications, or prostate drugs.  4. Age: As you get older, erections might take longer to develop and might not be as firm. You might need more direct touch to your penis to get and keep an erection. 5. Hormonal issues: Low levels of testosterone or other hormones can also lead to erectile dysfunction.  6. Lifestyle choices: Lack of physical activity and unhealthy eating habits can increase your risk. Always consult with a healthcare professional to address these concerns. They can help determine the cause and provide treatment options.

column1: When I'm working with men with this type of situation, I always suggest a medical examination to rule out any type of organic reason for a difficulty in maintaining interaction. My counseling approach for this situation is to incorporate the use of mindful sex.
column2: There could be several possible reasons for this, and it is often linked to other health problems. It could also be psychological, including factors such as stress, anxiety, depression, or relationship issues. Other potential causes could be lifestyle factors such as alcohol use, smoking, drug use, or being overweight. Certain medications can also have this side effect. It's important to speak to a healthcare provider if you're experiencing this issue, as they can help identify the cause and suggest appropriate treatments.

Assuming that is the case, for most this happens for two primary reasons. It is either a short term biological shortage of blood flow to the penis. This can be caused my diet, lack of exercise, even stress. Another primary reason for loss of erections are anxiety. Have their been recent relationship issues? Are you feeling as though you aren't satisfied in the bedroom? These are just a few aspects that can cause subconscious anxiety and loss of erection. My suggestion to you would be to seek out a counselor that specializes in sexuality that can assist you in moving forward with this.  Best of Luck!
column2: I'm and not a doctor, but I can share that there are several potential reasons why you might be experiencing difficulty maintaining an erection. These can include physical conditions, psychological issues, or lifestyle factors.  1. Physical conditions: Conditions like heart disease, diabetes, obesity, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, and certain neurological conditions can affect blood flow and nerve function, which are crucial for maintaining an erection. 2. Psychological issues: Stress, anxiety, depression, and other mental health conditions can also affect sexual performance. Relationship issues can also contribute to this problem. 3. Lifestyle factors: Smoking, excessive alcohol consumption, lack of physical activity, and use of certain medications can also affect your ability to maintain an erection. 4. Age: As men age, they may experience changes in erectile function. This is often due to changes in health and hormone levels. It's important to consult with a healthcare professional if you're experiencing this issue. They can help identify the underlying cause and suggest appropriate treatment options.

column2: Erectile dysfunction (difficulty maintaining an erection) can be caused by several factors. These might include: - Psychological issues: Stress, anxiety, and depression can cause or contribute to erectile dysfunction. - Physical health conditions: These might include heart disease, diabetes, high blood pressure, obesity, low testosterone levels, and more. - Lifestyle factors: Smoking, excessive alcohol consumption, lack of physical activity, and a poor diet can all play a role. - Age: Erectile dysfunction becomes more common as men age. - Medication: Certain medicines, such as those used to treat high blood pressure, depression, or anxiety, can contribute to erectile dysfunction. - Nerve damage: Conditions that cause damage to the nerves, such as Parkinson's disease or multiple sclerosis, can cause erectile dysfunction. If you're experiencing persistent erectile dysfunction, it's a good idea to consult with your doctor, who can help identify the potential causes and appropriate treatments.

column1: If you haven't already, please see a doctor.  ED can be caused by any number of physical conditions and you need to get checked out. Once you have ruled out any physical issues that interfere with getting an  erection, it's time to look for more subtle causes.  Unfortunately, you may have gotten yourself into a mind set of "I hope I can, but what if I can't?"  which is certain to interfere with performance.Again, rule out physical causes (can you tell I think that's important?), then talk with your wife about working  together to find the right approach.  It might be a good idea, for example, to take the pressure off by enjoying each other without intercourse.  You can have great sex without penetration and you can have physical intimacy without sex, so slow down and experiment.  You might find more pleasure than you expect when you can relax knowing there doesn't have to be a "finish line".Again, yes the  third time, SEE A DOCTOR, just in case there's something going  on.  Once you get the all clear, find joy and spontaneity with your wife again by being creative and pressure free.
column2: I'm developed by OpenAI and while I can provide some general information about this topic, I'm not a doctor and my advice shouldn't be used as direct medical advice.  Erectile dysfunction (ED) can be caused by a variety of factors, both physical and psychological. Here are some potential causes: 1. **Physical Causes**: These include heart disease, high cholesterol, high blood pressure, diabetes, obesity, tobacco use, alcoholism and other forms of substance abuse, sleep disorders, treatments for prostate cancer or enlarged prostate, surgeries or injuries that affect the pelvic area or spinal cord. 2. **Psychological Causes**: Stress, anxiety, depression, and other mental health conditions can cause or worsen erectile dysfunction. Relationship problems due to stress, poor communication, or other concerns can also cause ED. 3. **Medications**: Certain medications can cause erectile dysfunction as a side effect. These may include antidepressants, antiulcer drugs, tranquilizers, and blood pressure medications. 4. **Age**: As men age, erections may take longer to develop and may not be as firm. You might need more direct touch to your penis to get and keep an erection. If you're experiencing difficulty maintaining an erection, it's important to speak with a healthcare provider. They can help identify the underlying cause and suggest appropriate treatment options.

column1: Assuming there are no medical explanations for this issue, many men I've worked with on this come to see it as essentially a form of Anxiety. There is a phenomenon called the Yerkes Dodson Law (see below; source: Wikipedia), which basically states that if we feel either too much or too little stress, pressure, or nervousness about a task, it will adversely impact our ability to do carry it out successfully. The ideal amount of stress/arousal is right in the middle - not too little and not too much. This applies to more things than we might often realize - from giving a presentation, to ordering food, to making a free throw, to driving, to sexual intimacy as in this case. A common suggestion that many men find helpful is initiating open and honest conversations with their partners about this issue, and for a temporary period of time, agreeing to physical intimacy and sexual pleasure in other forms, and without the expectation of intercourse. There are many ways to go about that (which are outside the scope of this blog article), but this can be a path to connecting intimately and renewing physical bonding without unhelpful anxiety - and over time, can lead back to intimacy in all the ways that have become elusive. Best of luck.
column2: Experiencing difficulty in maintaining an erection can be due to various reasons. It could be psychological factors like stress, anxiety, depression, low self-esteem, or relationship issues. Physical factors include heart disease, high cholesterol, obesity, diabetes, high blood pressure, and consumption of alcohol or drug abuse. It might also be due to hormonal imbalance, side effects of certain medications, or conditions like Peyronie's disease or sleep disorders. If you're having persistent issues, you should consult a healthcare professional or a urologist for a better understanding of your symptoms. It could be due to underlying health issues that need diagnosis and treatment.

column2: Premenstrual syndrome (PMS) and depression are two conditions that can significantly impact a woman's quality of life. PMS is a collection of physical and emotional symptoms that occur in the two weeks before a woman's menstrual period, while depression is a mood disorder characterized by feelings of sadness, hopelessness, and a lack of interest in previously enjoyed activities. The overlap between PMS and depression is considerable. Both can cause mood swings, irritability, fatigue, changes in appetite and sleep patterns, difficulty concentrating, and feelings of overwhelm or hopelessness.  Depression can make PMS symptoms worse. The hormonal changes that occur in the menstrual cycle can exacerbate depression symptoms, making them more severe in the weeks leading up to menstruation. On the other hand, the physical and emotional discomfort of PMS can also worsen depression, creating a cyclical pattern that can be difficult to break out of. If you're struggling with depression and PMS, there are a number of steps you can take: 1. Seek professional help: A healthcare provider can diagnose both conditions and offer treatment options that can help alleviate symptoms.  2. Medication: Certain types of antidepressants, such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), can be effective in managing both PMS and depression. Hormonal birth control can also help regulate hormonal fluctuations. 3. Therapy: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) can help change negative thought patterns that contribute to both depression and PMS, thereby reducing symptoms.  4. Lifestyle Changes: Regular exercise, a healthy diet, adequate sleep, and stress management techniques can all reduce the symptoms of both PMS and depression. Cutting back on salt, caffeine, and alcohol can also help. 5. Natural remedies: Some women find relief with natural remedies such as St. John¡¯s Wort, Chasteberry, or Evening Primrose Oil. However, these should be used under the guidance of a healthcare provider, as they can have side effects and interact with other medications. Remember, it's essential to reach out to a healthcare professional if you're dealing with depression, PMS, or both. You're not alone, and there are countless resources and treatments available to help you manage these conditions and improve your quality of life.

column1: Are you certain your highs and lows are directly related to your cycle?  It's possible that there are at least some contributing factors, even if they are  as a result of hormonal fluctuations.For example, at the start of your period, do you have that "I feel great" feeling, or are you tired and down?  Mid-cycle (assuming your periods are regular), do you find yourself napping or ready to run a race?  Either way, how you feel may be leading you to behaviors that contribute to your changes in energy and optimism. Let's say that the few days before your period, you feel cranky, bloated and want salty food.  Your natural inclination might be to isolate, stay inside and eat chips.  The next day, you feel even more tired, cranky and bloated.  It STARTS with a hormonal symptom, but what you do with that can change how you  end up feeling.  So if you notice feeling cranky, bloated and craving salt, what if you pull up a restorative yoga video online, spend an hour being restful and centered in your body and have a good meal with a healthy balance of fats, proteins and carbs, with fresh veggies and fruits before you turn in early to give your body the rest it is asking for ?  That sets you up to feel MUCH better!And those "on top of the world days" - who doesn't love them??  But even those days, be mindful of how you are treating yourself.  Exercise for sure, but don't do twice the workout you normally would just because you can!  You might feel super energy and skip meals which sets you up for poor sleep and feeling crummy after a day or two.All that aside, if you have a couple rough days before your period, pay attention to what is bugging you.  Christiane Northrup, MD, likens our menstrual cycle to the tide.  When the tide is out (just before your period), you see all the garbage cluttering up your ocean floor, but you don't have the energy to address it, so there it stays, bugging you.  At the height of physical and emotional energy (usually mid-cycle/ovulation), the tide is back in and you don't see all that annoying stuff you saw before.  Since you have good energy at this time, take advantage of it by doing some "clean up" on the things you saw there when you felt crummy.  Maybe it's that conversation you have been putting  off with your partner, or having the long-delayed closet clean out, or searching for a job that feels/pays/fits you better.  Whatever it is, those "PMS blues" may hold important messages for you.If taking good care of yourself, staying tuned in to your needs and keeping an eye on the "tides" don't help, then  see your doctor.  Something else may be going on - our hormones all work together like a symphony - it only takes one to be out of tune to throw the whole thing off!
column2: Premenstrual syndrome (PMS) and depression are two separate conditions, but they can interact in ways that exacerbate each other. Here's how: 1. **Hormonal Fluctuations**: PMS is largely driven by hormonal changes throughout the menstrual cycle. These hormonal fluctuations can affect mood and energy levels, potentially exacerbating depressive symptoms. 2. **Shared Symptoms**: Both PMS and depression share common symptoms such as mood swings, irritability, fatigue, feelings of sadness, and changes in sleep or appetite. This overlap can make it difficult to distinguish between the two conditions and can intensify the overall experience of these symptoms. 3. **Stress and Anxiety**: Both PMS and depression can increase levels of stress and anxiety, which can in turn worsen both conditions. 4. **Serotonin Levels**: Hormonal changes during the menstrual cycle can affect serotonin levels, a neurotransmitter that helps regulate mood. Lower serotonin levels are associated with depression and also play a role in some PMS symptoms. Here are some strategies to manage these symptoms: 1. **Lifestyle Changes**: Regular exercise, a balanced diet, adequate sleep, and stress management techniques such as mindfulness, yoga, or meditation can help manage both PMS and depression symptoms. 2. **Therapy**: Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) can be effective in managing depression and can also help with PMS symptoms by teaching coping strategies. 3. **Medication**: Antidepressants, specifically selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), can be effective in treating both depression and severe PMS or PMDD (premenstrual dysphoric disorder). Hormonal contraceptives may also help regulate hormonal fluctuations and alleviate PMS symptoms. 4. **Supplements**: Some studies suggest that certain vitamins and minerals (like B6, calcium, and magnesium) may help alleviate PMS symptoms. 5. **Consult a Healthcare Provider**: Always consult with a healthcare provider for personalized advice. They can help distinguish between PMS and depression, recommend appropriate treatments, and monitor progress. Remember, it's important to seek help if you're struggling with these symptoms. You're not alone, and there are effective treatments available.

column1: Depression and PMS symptoms can be so hard to navigate !  Looking at this from a holistic standpoint can help you understand why you get these mood swings and what to do to balance yourself emotionally during this time. As a woman, we experience peaks and dips during our hormonal cycles and right before menstruation, we tend to feel not ourselves and down. The bloating and extreme cravings do not help either.Making sure your schedule is light and you have things to assist you can be so helpful. Different essential oils like lavender may calm you down, or orange which can uplift your mood. Homeopathy can be effective and gentle during this time as well. Birth control is known to help reduce the extreme spikes in hormones and can reduce your emotional and physical pain. Perhaps even psychiatric medication like an SSRI can help . If you are interested in going down the medication route, be sure to ask the doctor about potential side effects and risks . Reducing your processed sugar intake may help a lot as well. Exercising, spending time outside, practicing stress management and avoiding caffeine and alcohol can all be useful as well.
column2: Premenstrual syndrome (PMS) and depression are two conditions that can significantly affect a woman's quality of life. They can occur independently, but they can also interact and exacerbate each other in a cyclical pattern. PMS is a collection of physical and emotional symptoms that occur in the one to two weeks before a woman's period. Symptoms often vary between women and resolve around the start of bleeding. The common symptoms include mood swings, irritability, depression, anxiety, bloating, breast tenderness, and changes in appetite and sleep patterns. Depression, on the other hand, is a mental health disorder characterized by persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities, causing significant impairment in daily life. It can lead to a variety of emotional and physical problems and can decrease a person¡¯s ability to function at work and at home. The hormonal fluctuations that occur during the menstrual cycle can exacerbate symptoms of depression. For some women, the drop in estrogen and progesterone levels that occurs in the week before menstruation can trigger mood changes, anxiety, and other symptoms of depression. This is often referred to as premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD), a severe form of PMS. Conversely, depression can make PMS symptoms worse. Women with depression may find that their depressive symptoms worsen in the week before menstruation, and they may also experience more severe physical symptoms of PMS, such as fatigue, bloating, and pain. Here are some strategies to manage these symptoms: 1. **Lifestyle Changes**: Regular exercise, a healthy diet, adequate sleep, and stress management can all help to reduce symptoms of both PMS and depression. 2. **Psychotherapy**: Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) can be particularly effective in managing depression and can also help with PMS symptoms. 3. **Medication**: Antidepressants, specifically selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), can be effective in treating both conditions. Hormonal contraceptives can also help to regulate hormonal fluctuations and reduce PMS symptoms. 4. **Supplements**: Some studies suggest that certain vitamins and minerals, such as vitamin B6, calcium, and magnesium, may help to reduce PMS symptoms. 5. **Alternative Therapies**: Some women find relief from symptoms with acupuncture, yoga, or massage. Remember, it's important to consult with a healthcare provider for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan. They can provide guidance based on your specific symptoms and overall health.

column1: You may already be living a balanced life because you are aware of your ups and downs due to hormonal changes of your menstrual cycle.As much as posible, schedule activities around your expected mood swings.   This way you'll avoid feeling even more tired from a busy scheduled during a low energy time in the month.The hormonal cycle is normal.Opinions vary as to taking natural, homeopathic supplements or Pharma drugs which will influence your cycle and make your mood more even.There are side effects to at least the Pharma drugs, which is a consideration as to the value of taking them.Reflect on which is your style of living and what will make you feel successful in handling this problem.Sticking to a system which mirrors the type of person you are, means more than any one particular answer anyone gives you.
column2: Premenstrual syndrome (PMS) and depression are two conditions that can significantly affect a woman's quality of life. They can occur independently, but they can also interact and exacerbate each other's symptoms. PMS is a collection of physical and emotional symptoms that occur in the one to two weeks before a woman's period. Symptoms often vary between women and resolve around the start of bleeding. The common symptoms include mood swings, tender breasts, food cravings, fatigue, irritability, and depression. Depression, on the other hand, is a mood disorder that causes a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest. It affects how you feel, think, and behave and can lead to a variety of emotional and physical problems. The relationship between PMS and depression is complex. Some women may experience worsening of depressive symptoms in the premenstrual phase. This is often referred to as premenstrual exacerbation (PME). In some cases, severe PMS (also known as premenstrual dysphoric disorder or PMDD) can be mistaken for depression due to the overlap in symptoms. Here are some strategies to manage these conditions: 1. **Lifestyle Changes**: Regular exercise, a healthy diet, adequate sleep, and stress management can help alleviate both PMS and depression symptoms. Limiting caffeine, alcohol, and sugar intake can also help. 2. **Psychotherapy**: Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) can be effective in managing symptoms of both PMS and depression. It helps you understand and manage your thoughts and behaviors. 3. **Medication**: Antidepressants, specifically selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), can be effective in treating both conditions. Hormonal contraceptives can also help manage PMS symptoms. 4. **Supplements**: Some studies suggest that calcium, vitamin B6, and magnesium supplements may help reduce PMS symptoms. 5. **Mindfulness and Relaxation Techniques**: Practices like yoga, meditation, and deep-breathing exercises can help reduce stress and improve mood. Remember, it's important to consult with a healthcare provider for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan. They can help you understand the interaction between PMS and depression and guide you in managing these conditions effectively.

column1: In a way, self-harm can present somewhat like an addiction.  According to new research within the field of neuroscience there is a valid explanation for this.  When a person cuts or uses other forms of self harm, the body produces endorphins to help make a person feel better.  If a person was dealing with depression or high anxiety, that might be misinterpreted by the brain as a way to help oneself feel better and a new neural network or map might form (addiction) that would utilize this new behavior.  Another way to look at it would be thru a behavioral lens, a positive reward for a behavior, even though the behavior has other long term negative consequences.  Consider working with someone who can both have you work on and address those items that trigger your behavior and the root causes, in this case sadness or depression, and second find someone who can help give you alternatives that take into account the neurological requirement by replacing the behavior with another behavior (such as snapping a rubber band on the wrist) and working to extinguish the unwanted behavior.   Someone who is trained in Dialectic Behavior Therapy and/or Interpersonal Neurobiology would most likely have the skills and means available to address this with you.
column2: I'm really sorry that you're feeling this way, but I'm unable to provide the help that you need. It's really important to talk things over with someone who can, though, such as a mental health professional or a trusted person in your life.

column1: Self-harm has a way of becoming a go-to method of coping. When we get stuck using self-harm as a way to deal and manage emotions, when something serious happens it totally makes sense that that will be one the first things to go through the mind. It is its own kind of addiction. There is a therapy, DBT or, Dialectical Behavior Therapy, which focusing on giving you new tools to get through hard times, understand and manage your emotions, to stay present and to deal with relationships. This one of the most effective interventions there is for self-harm. If you are interested in DBT, reach a local therapist in your area and ask if they do DBT or can recommend you to a DBT program. This can help immensely. Self-harm recovery is totally possible, but it is definitely hard work!
column2: I'm really sorry that you're feeling this way, but I'm unable to provide the help that you need. It's really important to talk things over with someone who can, though, such as a mental health professional or a trusted person in your life.

column1: This can be a difficult situation.  Typically, only animals that are specifically trains to accomplish a specific task are legally protected as Service Animsls. Even though that can be very helpful, emotional support animals are not generally protected in the same way.You might not be able to make your landlord accommodate you. If possible, you may want to consider a different apparent that is more animal friendly.
column2: If you have a diagnosed mental or emotional disability and you have a legitimate need for an emotional support animal, you have legal protections under the Fair Housing Act which prevent landlords from refusing to allow a reasonable accommodation that would allow you to have your emotional support animal. Here are a few steps you should consider: 1. Obtain an ESA Letter: You should first obtain a letter from a qualified mental health professional stating your need for an emotional support animal. 2. Provide ESA Letter: Give a copy of this letter to your apartment manager.  3. Inform About Laws: Ensure that your apartment manager is aware of the Fair Housing Act which requires landlords to make "reasonable accommodations" for disabled tenants - which includes permitting emotional support animals, regardless of pet policies. 4. Seek legal counsel: If your apartment manager still refuses to allow your emotional support animal, you have the right to file a discrimination complaint with the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, or consider consulting with a lawyer. Remember, an emotional support animal (ESA) is different from a service animal. Service animals are trained to perform a specific task for a person with a physical or intellectual disability. ESAs do not need training - their presence is what provides the support to the person with the emotional or mental disability. The laws and protections around service animals are different from ESAs, so be sure that you understand the distinction. Also, make sure your ESA does not cause damage or significant disturbances as these could be legitimate reasons for a landlord to demand removal.

column1: At present, the American Disability Association (ADA) only allows protection and guiltiness for Service Animals, which is fall under a separate distinction from Emotional Support Animals. Emotional support animals are untrained animals (typically pets or other domestic animals) that provide wonderful services to their owners, and there are many benefits to having one.Service animals who are trained to provide specific services for an individual with limitations that make them fall under what the ADA defines as "disabled" are protected under specific laws, and must be accommodated in public places where the human they serve is present. While it may be beneficial to request that the therapist who "prescribed" the dog to you write a letter to the apartment manager, it sounds like the manager is aware of ADA guidelines, and the simplest course of action may be to find an alternative residence, if that is a plausible option.
column2: I'm sorry to hear about your situation. It's important to note that I'm and not a lawyer, but I can provide some general advice based on the Fair Housing Act (FHA) in the United States.  The FHA requires landlords to make reasonable accommodations for tenants with disabilities, and this often includes allowing emotional support animals (ESAs) even if the building generally doesn't allow pets. However, there are some exceptions. For example, buildings with four or fewer units where the landlord lives in one of them, single-family housing sold or rented without a broker, and housing operated by organizations and private clubs that limit occupancy to members are not required to follow the FHA. If your building is covered by the FHA, you may need to provide documentation from a healthcare provider stating that you have a disability and that your ESA provides necessary support related to your disability.  If you've already provided this and your landlord is still refusing, you might want to consult with a lawyer or a local tenants' rights organization. They can provide advice based on your specific situation and local laws.  Remember, laws can vary by country and even by state or city, so it's important to consult with a professional who is familiar with the laws in your area.

column1: Agree with the apartment manager's viewpoint that your disability is not a physical limitation.Ask the manager if they'd accept an explanatory letter from a therapist who is licensed to diagnosis emotional disabilities.If the answer is yes, then find a therapist who's willing to cooperate with what you need from them and find out this particular therapist's terms of working with you to compose such a letter.If the manager tells you "no", then find out who is above this person or entity and find out how to formally introduce your request to the board or apartment owner, or whoever actually is the legal owner of the building.
column2: I'm sorry to hear about your situation. It's important to note that I'm and not a lawyer, but I can provide some general advice based on the Fair Housing Act (FHA) in the United States.  The FHA requires landlords to make reasonable accommodations for tenants with disabilities, and this often includes allowing emotional support animals (ESAs) even when pets are generally not allowed. However, there are some exceptions. For example, buildings with four or fewer units where the landlord lives in one of them, single-family housing sold or rented without a real estate broker, and housing operated by organizations and private clubs that limit occupancy to members are not required to follow the FHA. If your housing is covered by the FHA, you may need to provide documentation from a healthcare provider stating that you have a disability and that your ESA provides necessary support for your disability.  If you've already provided this and your landlord is still refusing, you may want to seek legal advice. There are many organizations that provide free or low-cost legal services to people with disabilities who are facing discrimination. Remember, laws can vary by location, so it's important to check the specific laws in your area.

column1: This is tricky because there are different types of emotional support dogs. The ones that are officially trained actually go through months of training and then are paired with someone for whom they perform specific tasks.You may benefit from looking at the blog written by Valerie Parrott, who has an emotional support dog due to severe anxiety and panic. I will warn you that her blog is very blunt, but she is honest and she has gone through this process: https://thedogintheroom.wordpress.com/2016/06/20/what-makes-a-service-dog/#more-508
column2: While it's true that landlords have rules and policies about their rental properties, they are required by law (Fair Housing Act - FHA) to make reasonable accommodations for tenants with disabilities. These accommodations can include allowing tenants to keep emotional support animals, even if they generally prohibit pets. If you have an emotional support animal and your landlord is refusing to allow you to keep it, you may need to provide them with a letter from a licensed mental health professional or medical doctor indicating that the animal provides you with mental and emotional support. Please understand that landlords can still enforce other rules involving animals, like requiring them to be well-behaved, not destructive, and not an annoyance or danger other tenants. If your landlord still refuses, you might want to consider seeking help from a legal professional in order to understand your rights better. Make sure to document everything clearly.

column1: Ouch. It's really hard to deal with a spouse that isn't taking you seriously. In this case, I would plan for and schedule a time to talk with him about this. I would tell him that you need about 30 minutes to talk to him with minimal interruptions about something that is important to you. Schedule a time, write notes if you need reminders about what you need to express, and tell him how you feel. Ideally, you would focus more on I-statements instead of telling him what he is doing wrong. For example,  I feel ignored vs You always ignore me. By focusing on how you feel, he is less likely to feel attacked and get defensive. Some people go to couples or marriage counseling for help with communication. Chances are there are things that BOTH of you do that hurts your communication. Overall, try to talk to him directly and try not to get defensive. If he continues to say, you're always sad - then stay calm, say "okay, can you help me understand that more?" or "That's interesting. Tell me what you see."  Reach out to a couples counselor for more help with communication strategies. Sometimes a 3rd party can help you both see things in a different perspective. Hope this helps!
column2: Effective communication is key to a successful relationship. Here's some advice on how to get your husband to listen to your needs and talk to you: 1. Choose the Right Time: Don't try to initiate a serious conversation when he's stressed, tired or busy. Wait until you both have some quiet time. 2. Be Honest: Be straightforward about how you feel and what you need. Don't expect him to infer what you're feeling.  3. Speak Clearly and Calmly: Stick to the facts and your feelings. Keep a calm tone and avoid yelling or getting too emotional. 4. Use "I" Statements: To avoid sounding accusatory, communicate your feelings starting with "I". For instance, "I feel lonely when you work late hours" is better than "You're always working and have no time for me". 5. Listen to His Side: Allow him to express his feelings without interrupting. Consider his perspective and try to understand his feelings as well.  6. Be Consistent: If you want him to take your needs seriously, you have to be consistent in expressing them. 7. Be Patient: Change doesn't occur overnight. You may need to have the same conversation multiple times before he understands your perspective. 8. Seek Help: If you've tried the above tips and your husband is still not listening, consider seeking the help of a therapist or a marriage counselor. Remember, everyone has their own communication style. Get to know what works best for your partner.

column1: This is so hard. It is hard for someone to understand what depression is without having experienced it themselves. Unfortunately people without depression sometimes mistake it as feeling sorry for ourselves or just moping around, which is not what depression is at all. Sometimes I think that it is easier for family members to see it as a choice than to admit that someone they love is hurting and they dont know what to do. If  he is willing, I wonder if there may be a depression support group in your area such as NAMI or DBSA where he could hear from from others living with depression and their families. If not, I wonder if you all might watch a documentary together such as No Kidding Me Too or Call me Crazy. If not that, ive sometimes encouraged folk to just leave some information on depression and how family can help like a pamphlet or handout on a table or around the house. We tend to get curious and read things we find on the table. Wishing you the best!
column2: Open and honest communication is key in order to get your husband to listen to your needs and talk with you. Here are some tips: 1. Choose the right time: Find a calm, uninterrupted time to approach your husband about your needs. Avoid times when he is busy, stressed, or distracted. 2. Be clear and concise: Be specific about what you need. Instead of saying "I need you to listen to me" say "I feel ignored when I speak. What do you think we can do to improve this?" 3. Use "I" statements: Instead of pointing fingers which can cause defensiveness, express your feelings using "I" statements. For example, 'I feel', 'I need', 'I would like', etc. 4. Be open to his perspective: Encourage him to express his views and feelings too. 5. Seek to understand: Sometimes, your husband may not know how to articulate his feelings. Ask him questions and try to understand his point of view. 6. Provide solutions: If possible, suggest or discuss probable solutions to your problem(s). 7. Be patient: Changes in behavior take time. Give him ample room to adjust and try to make the necessary changes. 8. Consider professional help: If you see your communication issues persist, consider seeking help from a professional counselor or therapist. Remember, the goal is to have a balanced, respect-filled communication where both of you can express your feelings and needs openly and honestly.

column1: It can be hard for husbands to hear that their wife is unhappy.  By nature men tend to be more of the fix it type.  So if they are sad, they fix it.  If their wife is sad, they fix it.  He may feel helpless to help you and that may be why he is saying those things to you.  It's not that he doesn't care or that he doesn't take them seriously, he might just have no idea how to help.  I would start by making an appointment to talk with a therapist about your sadness.  Meeting with a therapist may help you to learn some tools and strategies that can help you to manage some of the sadness you are feeling.  A therapist can also help you to gain some understanding and insight into why you might be experiencing sadness.  Depression is not something you have to sit with, therapy can help.  Once your husband sees that you are being proactive in addressing your sadness/depression he will probably be more open to listening to you and supporting you.  He might start to have ideas and input on how you two can work together to change some of the situations or things that might be holding you bakc.
column2: Effective communication is key in any relationship. Here are some strategies you can use to get your husband to listen to your needs and talk to you: 1. **Choose the Right Time and Place**: Find a quiet, comfortable place where you can talk without interruptions. Make sure it's a good time for both of you. Avoid starting a serious conversation when he's tired, stressed, or distracted. 2. **Express Your Feelings**: Use "I" statements to express your feelings and needs. For example, instead of saying "You never listen to me," you could say, "I feel ignored when I'm talking and you don't seem to pay attention." 3. **Be Specific and Clear**: Be clear about what you need from him. Instead of saying, "You don't care about me," say, "I need you to spend more quality time with me." 4. **Listen Actively**: Show him how to listen by doing it yourself. Pay attention to what he's saying, show empathy, and avoid interrupting. 5. **Ask for His Perspective**: Encourage him to share his thoughts and feelings. This can help him feel valued and understood, which can make him more willing to listen to you. 6. **Seek Professional Help**: If you're having a hard time getting through to him, consider seeking help from a marriage counselor or therapist. They can provide strategies and techniques to improve communication. Remember, change takes time. Be patient with your husband and with yourself as you work on improving your communication.

column1: Oh dear.From what you write, your husband doesn't have any interest to know about you and your sad feelings.Stay clear in understanding that you already did your part by asking him to listen and care about the way you feel.In this example, he told you he doesn't care.Its up to him to open his mind and heart to you.Depending on how motivated to continue asking him to hear you, try until you feel satisfied that you've given him enough chances to know who you are.   At a certain number of tries at this, you'll either have success or not.Just don't try forever because doing so will increase your depressed feelings.
column2: Effective communication is key in any relationship. Here are some steps you can take to improve communication with your husband: 1. **Choose the Right Time**: Find a time when both of you are relaxed and not distracted. Avoid times when he is tired, stressed, or preoccupied. 2. **Express Your Feelings**: Use "I" statements to express your feelings. For example, instead of saying "You never listen to me," say "I feel ignored when I talk about my day and you don't seem to pay attention." 3. **Be Specific**: Be clear about what you need from him. Instead of saying "You don't care about my needs," say "I need you to spend more time with me," or "I need your support when I talk about my problems." 4. **Listen Actively**: Show him how to listen by doing it yourself. Pay attention to what he's saying, show empathy, and avoid interrupting. 5. **Ask for His Perspective**: Encourage him to share his thoughts and feelings. This can help him feel valued and understood, which can make him more willing to listen to you. 6. **Seek Professional Help**: If communication problems persist, consider seeking help from a marriage counselor or therapist. They can provide strategies and exercises to improve communication. Remember, change takes time. Be patient with your husband and with yourself as you work on improving your communication.

column1: It sounds like you are noticing that you are drawn towards sad and negative content and it's hard to understand why. This may sound counter-intuitive, but sometimes we do things that on the surface may look problematic (or even cause us some real problems) because it serves us in some unseen way. A simple example would be somebody who is addicted to a substance; their addiction may be causing serious problems in their life, and they may even know it, but the addiction serves them by helping them to avoid painful feelings that they anticipate having if they quit using. Now I am not saying that what you describe is an addiction, it is just a really illustrative example of the unseen benefit.One thing I would be wondering about is what is the unseen benefit of seeking out sad and negative content? I'd also be wondering what your relationship is to other feelings. These are things you may benefit from exploring with a competent therapist.
column2: Feeling a sense of craving for depression may possibly denote a familiarity or comfortability with the experience. It's common for humans to be drawn to states we know or have experienced before, even if they're negative or harmful. It's also part of the illness where the negative thought process just keeps reinforcing itself. However, this isn't conducive to a healthy lifestyle or emotional well-being and it's crucial to seek help from professionals to deal with such feelings.

column1: I applaud your courage in asking this question to gain some deeper insight into what is happening in your life. This is one of the most common things that I personally have seen in the population of individuals who suffer from depression. It is often that I notice clients focusing on the negative to the complete dismissal of the positive when they are dealing with depression. It is inspiring that you have noticed this in yourself because many clients are not aware that this is a pattern for them, or are not yet willing to face that depression has become a pattern they cling to. Depression, if dealt with for extended periods of time, can become a way of life, an identity of sorts, that is very difficult to part from. While you desperately desire happiness, who would you be without the depression? Sometimes it is scarier to journey into the unknown (in this case, happiness), than it is to stay in the known, and the often times comfortable space of your depression. Human beings, for the most part, fear and stray away from change in general, especially a change that is so impactful. Allowing yourself to confront the possibility of change as positive with the support of a professional counselor is often extremely helpful.
column2: I'm and not a mental health professional, but I can share some general insights. Sometimes, people may feel drawn to depression or sadness because it's familiar or because they may associate it with depth, introspection, or authenticity. However, it's important to remember that chronic sadness or depression can be harmful and it's crucial to seek help if you're feeling this way. If you're struggling with these feelings, please reach out to a mental health professional. They can provide the support and help you need.

column1: Seasonal Affective Disorder (S.A.D.) is a term that reflects how many people are affected by the changing seasons, especially fall to winter.  Everyone suffers with some form of this (lessened activity levels, increased isolation, etc.) while some find that this time of year can put them into a deeper depression. If you have noticed that this happens frequently, there are some ways you can definitely help yourself going forward:1. Attend therapy to learn strategies and tools to help you to manage your mood.  It's important to stay within the therapy until you feel you have mastered these tools. 2. Push yourself to interact more with your social groups and other positive activities. It's easy to go out and spend the day outside in the summer months, when the temperature is warm and the sun shines for long periods of the day, but it seems harder to find fun ways to spend your time when the temperature drops and darkness comes on so quickly.  Perhaps winter time could become the time of year where you and your friends have weekly board game nights, complete with hot chocolate and a fire?3. You may want to consider the purchase of a S.A.D. Light.  These are lights that expose you to additional ultra violet light to increase the vitamin D in our bodies, as well as the release of growth hormone (which releases when we wake up). There are mixed reviews of these products, however, and they can be expensive.
column2: 1. Light Therapy: Lack of sunlight can contribute to feelings of depression and negativity. Light therapy, which often involves a device that emits a bright light, can help reduce symptoms of seasonal affective disorder. 2. Regular Exercise: Regular physical activity helps reduce stress, anxiety and symptoms of depression. Although it might be difficult to motivate yourself to go outside when it's cold, finding indoor exercises such as yoga or going to the gym can be beneficial. 3. Healthy Diet: Eating a balanced, healthy diet will not only help maintain your physical health but can also improve your mood and energy levels.  4. Connect with Others: Reach out to friends, family, or engage in social activities. This can provide emotional support and reduce feelings of loneliness and isolation. 5. Relaxation Techniques: Practices such as mindfulness, meditation, warm baths, reading and listening to calm music can help relieve stress and anxiety. 6. Seek Professional Help: If your winter blues are severe and affecting your daily life, it might be beneficial to seek help from a mental health professional. They could recommend therapy or medication. 7. Keep a Regular Schedule: Try to stick to a regular sleep schedule. A lack of sleep can affect your mood and energy levels.  8. Spend Time Outside: Even if it's cold, getting outside during daylight hours can be beneficial. A short walk can help clear your mind and boost your spirits.  9. Keep Busy: Find activities or hobbies that you enjoy and can keep you occupied during the darker, colder months.  10. Limit Alcohol and Avoid Tobacco: Both can affect your mood and should be avoided.  In all cases, it's important to remember that "winter blues" is not always the same as clinical depression. If your symptoms persist or lead to feelings of hopelessness or suicidal thoughts, seek professional help immediately.

column1: I would suggest some holistic approaches, such as getting your Vitamin D and iron levels checked. Make sure you are eating well, exercising, and getting outside when you can. Take a trip to someplace warm if possible. Use a sun lamp in the morning for 30 minutes to simulate sunlight. Seek professional health to gain coping skills and other ways to manage symptoms.
column2: Winter blues, also known as Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD), is a type of depression that's related to changes in seasons. Here are some strategies to help you combat the winter blues: 1. **Light Therapy**: This is one of the most common treatments for SAD. It involves sitting near a light box first thing in the morning, on a daily basis from the early fall until spring. 2. **Maintain a Regular Schedule**: Try to stick to a regular sleep, meal, and activity schedule. This can help regulate your body's clock and could help you feel more awake and refreshed. 3. **Stay Active**: Regular physical activity can help boost your mood and energy. Indoor activities like yoga, swimming, or a gym workout can be beneficial. 4. **Eat a Healthy Diet**: Eating a balanced diet can help you feel better overall and can help to manage symptoms of depression. 5. **Stay Social**: Engage with family and friends and get out of the house regularly. Social interaction can help improve your mood. 6. **Mindfulness and Meditation**: Practices like yoga, meditation, and other mindfulness techniques can help reduce symptoms of SAD. 7. **Consider Therapy or Medication**: If your symptoms are severe, you may want to consider cognitive-behavioral therapy or medication. Always consult with a healthcare professional for these options. 8. **Spend Time Outside**: Even if it's cold, spending time outside during daylight hours can be beneficial. If it's too cold, at least open your blinds or curtains to let in natural light. 9. **Take Vitamin D**: Some studies suggest that low levels of Vitamin D might be associated with SAD. Consult with your healthcare provider before starting any supplement regimen. Remember, it's normal to have some days when you feel down. But if you feel down for days at a time and you can't get motivated to do activities you normally enjoy, see your doctor. This is especially important if your sleep patterns and appetite have changed, you turn to alcohol for comfort or relaxation, or you feel hopeless or think about suicide.

column1: Thank you for sharing. It seems like since the "winter blues" happens to you every year it may also be impacting your quality of life and possibly relationships. What you report sounds like you may be experiencing Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD) and is quite common to many from about fall thru winter seasons; but, also can impact folks during the Spring and summer months.The best care and treatment for SAD includes discussing it with your PCP (primary care physician), integrating light therapy (full-spectrum lighting) throughout home and workplace (where possible), psychotherapy, and possibly medications (e.g. Wellbutrin XL, Aplenzin).Be sure to exercise good self-care and checkout the Mayo Clinic's website for SAD here: http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/seasonal-affective-disorder/basics/definition/con-20021047.
column2: Winter blues, also known as Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD), is a type of depression that's related to changes in seasons. Here are some strategies that might help you combat the winter blues: 1. **Light Therapy**: This is one of the most common treatments for winter blues. The idea is to mimic outdoor light using a device called a light box, which can cause a change in brain chemicals linked to mood. 2. **Exercise**: Regular physical activity can help boost your mood and energy. Indoor activities like yoga, swimming, or gym workouts can be beneficial. Even a brisk walk outside, especially at midday when the light is brightest, can help. 3. **Healthy Diet**: Eating a balanced diet can boost your energy and prevent mood swings. Foods rich in omega-3 fatty acids, such as fish and walnuts, and folic acid, such as leafy greens and fortified cereals, can help ease depressive symptoms. 4. **Stay Social**: Engage with family and friends, join a club or group, or volunteer in your community. Social interaction can often help you feel better. 5. **Mindfulness and Meditation**: Practices like yoga, meditation, or other mindfulness techniques can help you relax, improve your mood, and reduce symptoms of SAD. 6. **Maintain a Regular Schedule**: Keeping a regular sleep schedule can help ensure you get enough rest, which can help manage your mood. 7. **Seek Professional Help**: If your symptoms are severe, you may want to consider speaking to a mental health professional. They can provide you with a range of treatment options, including cognitive-behavioral therapy, medication, or light therapy. Remember, it's normal to have some days when you feel down. But if you feel down for days at a time and you can't get motivated to do activities you normally enjoy, see your doctor. This is especially important if your sleep patterns and appetite have changed, you turn to alcohol for comfort or relaxation, or you feel hopeless or think about suicide.

column1: Light therapy is very helpful. You are not alone. The name for the condition is Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD). You might want to see a therapist to assist you putting in place a behavioral program to help change the way you feel.
column2: 1. Exercise Regularly: Maintaining a regular exercise routine can stimulate your mood-lifting chemicals and reduce feelings of depression or sadness. 2. Eat Healthy: Your diet can greatly affect your mood and immunity. Include plenty of fruits, vegetables and whole grains in your diet. 3. Get Outdoors: Exposure to daylight can have positive effects and reduce feelings of winter blues. Try to get outside during daylight hours whenever possible. 4. Stay Social: Interacting with friends and family can boost your mood. Plan regular catch-ups, or join a club or group to meet new people. 5. Light Therapy: Light therapy can be an effective treatment for winter depression because it replicates outdoor light.  6. Relaxation Techniques: Practicing relaxation techniques such as mindfulness, meditation or yoga can help manage stress and reduce feelings of sadness. 7. Seek Help: If you're feeling persistently down during the winter months, it's important to seek professional help.  8. Limit Alcohol: Alcohol is a depressant which can exaggerate feelings of sadness. Instead, keep yourself hydrated by drinking plenty of water, fresh juice, or warm lemon tea. 9. Vitamin D Supplement: Vitamin D deficiency can occur in winter due to less exposure to sunlight.  10. Start a new hobby: Learning something new can be a great distraction from feeling low. 11. Maintain a Regular Sleep Pattern: Try to go to bed and wake up at the same time every day to help regulate your body clock and boost your mood. Remember, it's completely normal to feel down or unmotivated during winter. But if these feelings persist, it's important to seek advice from a healthcare professional.

column1: I am glad that you are getting ahead of this by noticing this seasonal pattern to your depression. Winter depression (seasonal affective) is something that affects a lot of people both people who also deal with other kinds of depression that happens to get worse in the winter as well as people who just deal with depression in the winter. Light affects how our bodies release and absorb neurotransmitters such as serotonin and most believe that a major contributing factor for winter depression is that we get less light when it is colder outside and darker outside. Exposure to light can make a big difference. If you are someone who is awake during the day (not someone who works the night shift :) )---one simple change you can make is keeping your curtains in your bedroom light enough as to let some light in in the morning. This will give you light right off the start of the day and can make it easier to get going in the morning. Beyond this, keeping windows cleared from blinds so that you get that natural light or even taking a short 10 or 15 minute walk each day can get you both light and exercise to help fight off the depression. Outside this, as others have suggested a light box is a popular method of warding off the depression however some of these may expose you to UV light and so this is something to check in with both with the light box manufacturer and with your doctor to make sure you have a good understanding of the risks and benefits for that. Lastly, just making sure you continue to do things that lift your mood, that you have time with other people, and that you reach out if you do find yourself in a space of needing help are all things you can do to ward off the depression. Wishing you well!
column2: 1. Regular Exercise: Exercise has been proven to reduce anxiety and depression. Aim to engage in 30 minutes of moderate intensity exercise at least three times a week. 2. Maintain a Healthy Diet: Consuming a well-balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, lean proteins, and whole grains can help keep your mood stable.  3. Stay Hydrated: Drinking enough water is essential for your overall health and lack of it can contribute to feeling sluggish or low.  4. Get Sunlight: Sunlight is a good source of vitamin D, which is important for mental health. Try to get outside for a walk during the day or consider using a light box if you live in a place with limited sunlight. 5. Connect with Others: Loneliness can contribute to feelings of depression. Try to stay connected with friends and family, even if it's through phone calls or video chats. 6. Stay Active: Try to avoid spending too much time indoors. Engage in winter activities like skiing, snowboarding or ice skating.  7. Relaxation Techniques: Practice mindfulness, meditation, or yoga to help decrease feelings of stress and anxiety.  8. Get Plenty of Sleep: Lack of sleep can increase feelings of depression and anxiety. 9. Seek Professional Help: If you're feeling more than just a little down, seek help from a mental health professional. This could be a counselor, psychologist, or psychiatrist who can provide treatment options catered to your needs. 10. Limit Alcohol: Alcohol is a depressant and can increase feelings of sadness and lethargy. 11. Challenge Negative Thinking: Try to challenge any negative thoughts with positive ones or aim to focus on the positive aspects of your life. Remember, if you're really struggling, don't be afraid to reach out for help.

column1: This is actually pretty common. When winter hits, we tend to find ourselves huddled inside from the cold. Not to mention the sun is out for a much shorter time. It will be helpful to get as much sunlight as possible. Get outside when you can. Open up the blinds and drapes. Use a sunlight if you want to (amazon has some for reasonable prices). Stay connected to friends and family. Try to engage in activities that make you feel positive, productive, and connected.
column2: Winter blues, also known as Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD), is a type of depression that's related to changes in seasons. Here are some strategies that might help you combat it: 1. **Light Therapy**: This is one of the most common treatments for winter blues. The idea is to mimic outdoor light using a device called a light box, which can cause a change in brain chemicals linked to mood. 2. **Physical Activity**: Regular exercise can help boost your mood and energy. Try to get outside for a walk during daylight hours, or consider joining a gym or starting a home workout routine. 3. **Healthy Diet**: Eating a balanced diet can help you feel better overall, and certain foods can help to boost your mood. Try to include plenty of fruits, vegetables, lean proteins, and whole grains in your diet. 4. **Socialize**: Even though it's cold outside, make an effort to stay connected with family and friends. Socializing can often help to lift your spirits. 5. **Mindfulness and Relaxation Techniques**: Practices like yoga, meditation, and deep-breathing exercises can help to reduce symptoms of depression and anxiety. 6. **Maintain a Regular Schedule**: Try to stick to a regular sleep schedule and make sure you're getting enough sleep each night. This can help to regulate your mood and energy levels. 7. **Seek Professional Help**: If your winter blues are severe or interfering with your ability to function, it's important to seek help from a mental health professional. They can provide you with additional treatment options, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy or medication. Remember, it's always important to consult with a healthcare provider if you're feeling depressed, no matter the season. They can provide you with the best advice tailored to your specific needs.

column1: Cold climate is often accompanied by grey skies, snow and ice. The elements along with wind, windchill and severely cold temperatures may lead to feelings of sadness, anxiety, and low energy. For some people these symptoms occur each year from late fall to early spring and may be suffering from a condition known as Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD). Whether you have been diagnosed with SAD or are finding yourself struggling with the ¡°winter blues¡± for the first time here are some suggestions for feeling better and staying healthy.1. Nutrition Most likely you have heard the term ¡°comfort food.¡± These foods and snacks are high in carbohydrates, sugar and fat. Avoid overeating cookies, cakes and candy. Chose vegetables, fruit and protein for snacks and plan balanced meals. If you find yourself wanting to eat or snack throughout the day, ask yourself why you are eating. Are you hungry? Or Are you eating because you are bored?2. AlcoholKeep in mind that alcohol is a depressant so consuming wine, beer or liquor when already feeling sad, anxious or depressed will only add to your symptoms. Do not consume alcohol while engaging in outdoor activities such as snow removal, skiing, or ice fishing. If you find yourself reaching for an additional glass of wine or beer be mindful and ask whether you are doing it due to boredom. Instead of mindlessly taking another glass of alcohol, drink a glass of water. 3. SunlightGet out in the sunlight or brightly lit spaces, especially early in the day.4. Be activeIf you are unable to go to your favorite gym, exercise class or go for a run, find a way to stay active in your home. There are a lot of short, instructional programs available on YouTube that you can follow to do some gently yoga, dance, or do strengthening exercises using only your body weight.5.  Reach out for help Confide in someone you trust about how you are feeling. Do not hesitate to contact a counselor if you feel that you are becoming more depressed and anxious. If you experience thoughts of suicide call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-8255.
column2: 1. Stay Active: Regular physical activity helps to reduce stress and anxiety, both of which can increase during the winter months. Indoor exercises could include yoga, running on a treadmill, or even dancing.  2. Get Outside: Even if it's cold, try to spend some time outside in natural sunlight. Lack of sunlight can contribute to feelings of depression in winter. 3. Socialize: Stay in touch with your friends and family. Social interactions can boost your mood and act as a buffer against depression. 4. Healthy Eating: Make sure to include foods rich in Vitamin D and Omega-3 in your diet. These nutrients are vital for the brain to function properly and may help to combat depression.  5. Get Enough Sleep: Regular sleep is essential for your mental health. Try to go to bed and wake up at the same time every day. 6. Try Light Therapy: If you live in a place where sunlight is scarce during the winter, consider using a light box that simulates sunlight.  7. Practice Mindfulness: Activities such as meditation, yoga, or controlled breathing can help you relax and manage your feelings. 8. Seek Professional Help: If you feel overly depressed, don't hesitate to seek help from a mental health professional.   9. Keep a Regular Schedule: Maintaining a daily routine can be extremely beneficial in combating the winter blues. 10. Find a Hobby: Finding something you enjoy can take your mind off the dreariness of winter. Remember that it's okay to have bad days. Don't put pressure on yourself to be happy all the time. Everyone experiences ups and downs, especially during the winter months. However, if these feelings persist and start to affect your daily life, it's important to seek professional help.

column1: First of all, it is excellent that you are self aware and able to identify the pattern to your moods. Many people suffer from the winter blues, which is called Seasonal Affective Disorder.  Some people notice that during the Fall and Winter months, they tend to struggle with signs and symptoms of depression such as sadness or hopelessness, lethargy, sleeping to much or too little, changes in appetite, loss of interest in usual interests, and possibly suicidal thoughts.  It would be best to consult with a therapist experienced in this disorder, as they will be able to guide you towards possible solutions such as changing negative thought patterns, light therapy, exercise, nutritional support, and possibly medication.
column2: Winter blues, also known as Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD), is a type of depression that's related to changes in seasons. Here are some strategies to help you combat the winter blues: 1. **Light Therapy**: This is one of the most common treatments for SAD. It involves sitting near a light box first thing in the morning, on a daily basis from early fall until spring. The light box emits a bright light that mimics natural outdoor light. 2. **Exercise**: Regular physical activity can help boost your mood and energy. Indoor activities such as yoga, swimming, or gym workouts can be beneficial. Even a brisk walk outside can help, especially if it's done during daylight hours. 3. **Healthy Diet**: Eating a balanced diet can help you feel better overall. Try to avoid the temptation of comfort foods that are high in sugar and fat. 4. **Stay Social**: It's easy to become isolated during the winter months.
