column1: You might be surprised how normal you are. Anxiety is incredibly common and while your particular type of existential anxiety might be unique to you - it is very difficult for most people to really comprehend what happens after we die - regardless of the religious or philosophical belief systems we hold. It is the ultimate unknown and some philosophers and psychologists believe that at the root of our day-to-day anxieties is the fear of death or fear of the unknown.  Just as it can be really hard to comprehend the ending of life it can also be hard to comprehend an eternal existence. What these both have in common is that we are imaging a future that is ultimately unknowable and this unknown can provoke a lot of anxiety. Mindfulness based practices like meditation - maybe there is something like this in your religious tradition - can be very helpful in making peace with the unknown in the present moment. The more we can learn to live in the moment - the less we get hung up on anticipating outcomes for our lives that may never come true. Mindfulness practices can help you ground, be where you are , relax and regulate your nervous system so that you are able sleep and recuperate, and train your attention to focus on living the life you want to live now - rather than worrying about what happens after you die. Having said all that - it can be profoundly helpful to speak with someone about your anxiety - especially when you feel haunted by it, worry that you are crazy and can't get to sleep. There are lots of good therapists out there who can help you with your anxiety.
column2: The concept of the afterlife has been a subject of human curiosity and speculation for millennia, and it's natural that it can provoke anxiety. This anxiety can stem from several sources. Firstly, the uncertainty. The afterlife is a concept that is largely unknown and unknowable until we experience it ourselves. Different cultures, religions, and philosophies offer various interpretations, from reincarnation to heavenly or hellish realms, to a complete cessation of consciousness. This uncertainty can be unsettling, as humans generally prefer certainty and predictability. Secondly, the finality. The idea of death and what follows can be a stark reminder of our mortality. This can lead to existential anxiety, where one grapples with the meaning of life, the inevitability of death, and the uncertainty of what comes after. Thirdly, the concept of judgment. In many religious traditions, the afterlife is a place of reward or punishment based on one's actions in this life. This can lead to anxiety about whether one's life measures up to these standards. To manage this anxiety, some people find comfort in their religious or spiritual beliefs, while others may seek philosophical or existential understanding. Some may find solace in the idea of leaving a lasting legacy or making the most of the time they have. Others may seek professional help, such as therapy or counseling, to navigate these complex feelings. It's important to remember that it's okay to feel anxious about these big questions. They're part of the human experience. It's also okay to seek help and to talk about these feelings with others. You're not alone in pondering these profound mysteries.

column1: Hi California, What you're experiencing is indeed anxiety; it's very common. Through research we know a lot of things about how to reduce anxiety. I'll get you started and it's a great idea to connect with a therapist who can build on these ideas and get to know you well.It's natural to have random thoughts that unsettle us. Our brains are complex, wonderful things. Fearful and anxious thoughts are a part of this picture; their purpose is to prepare us for the future and to help us make sense of the past and learn from it. But what happens sometimes is that our alarm systems get out of whack and get set off too easily. We often spend TOO MUCH time worrying about things that happened or might happen. When these thoughts take away from our enjoyment of life, it becomes a problem. So, while fear and anxiety try to protect us, they also seek power and will take any power they can get.In general, fear and anxiety try to tell us one or both of two things: that something is wrong with us, or that something bad will happen (or that something bad will happen because there's something wrong with us). They will use anything they can as evidence to convince you. For example... "That person looked at you funny. You're strange looking". Well there are dozens of possible explanations for the look on that person's face, and it's unlikely it had anything to do with you. For you personally, your thoughts are about the afterlife...about living forever. What does fear tell you will be uncomfortable about living forever? What would the worst part be? A therapist would help you dig deep to find the core of what you fear. It might be that you have no control over who you are or where you go. It might be that you fear going to hell because you're "bad". Search for that deepest fear.I invite you then to picture that thought as a glass of water on a shelf. It's a heavy glass, and if you held it in your hands for a while and stared at it, it would get in the way; you'd be uncomfortable and unable to focus on your life. That's what's happening now. I suggest that the problem is not so much the thought you're having; we all have random silly thoughts that usually aren't true. The problem is how long you're holding it in your hand. You could have that thought (pick up that glass) a hundred times a day and, as long as you put it right back on the shelf, it's not a problem. The trick is to get it back on that shelf.Right now, you're using distraction to do this. You're trying to focus on other things around you, but I think the glass is still in your hand. It's not enough; you're looking for more tools to get that glass back on the shelf.  And the key is in your thoughts. Once you find out what fear is trying to tell you, then you can "talk back to" fear. So, as an example, if fear is saying to you "you have no control over anything", then you can work to accept the pieces you don't have control over, learn to tolerate that feeling, and claim back the pieces you CAN control. You CAN control the extent to which you let fear take you over. With a therapist you can learn to "refute" fears' ideas. You can learn to look for concrete evidence of fear's lies and gain back control over your thoughts. I wish you the best!
column2: Thinking about the afterlife can indeed cause anxiety for some people. This might be because it involves contemplating the unknown, which can naturally be unsettling or scary. Some individuals might fear judgement or punishment in the afterlife, while others might worry about being separated from their loved ones. Additionally, ideas about the afterlife are often closely tied to religious or spiritual beliefs, and questioning or doubting these beliefs can cause distress. Conversely, for some people, belief in the afterlife can also provide comfort and reassurance. As with many profound and personal questions, people's reactions to thoughts of the afterlife can vary significantly. If you're experiencing anxiety related to these kinds of ideas, it may be helpful to discuss them with a mental health professional or a trusted person in your life.

column1: Good questions! The paradox of thinking about forever is that you can become more motivated to live only in the present. Thinking about forever can certainly be overwhelming, it's a lot to think about, What can you do about your future? Be present - learn and relax, knowing that you are doing everything you can right here, right now. There is a book by Eckhart Tolle - The Power of Now - that you might be interested in. Enjoy your journey!
column2: The concept of the afterlife can indeed provoke anxiety for many people. This anxiety can stem from various sources, such as the fear of the unknown, the uncertainty about what happens after death, religious beliefs, or existential concerns about the meaning and purpose of life. The fear of the unknown is a fundamental human trait. We are creatures of habit and understanding, and when faced with something we cannot comprehend or predict, it can cause discomfort and anxiety. The afterlife, by its very nature, is something we cannot fully understand until we experience it, which makes it a source of anxiety for many. Religious beliefs can also play a significant role in shaping our views about the afterlife. Different religions have different interpretations of what happens after death, and these beliefs can either provide comfort or cause anxiety. For instance, the concept of hell in some religions can be a source of fear and anxiety. Existential concerns about the meaning and purpose of life can also contribute to anxiety about the afterlife. If life is seen as a journey towards an ultimate goal, the uncertainty about what happens after reaching that goal can be unsettling. Moreover, the idea of an eternal afterlife can also raise questions about the value and significance of our earthly lives. However, it's important to remember that

column1: Your life here matters and being present in it so you feel joy in yourself and your surroundings is important in creating your sense of ease and balance. No one can predict, for sure, what happens after death because consciousness transcends boundaries and limits we tend to impose on it. That said, if reincarnation exists or if there is a heaven or hell your consciousness of it will most likely be free of discomfort or pain as you experience it now. Meditating or doing self-hypnosis for anxiety can help alleviate your thoughts and sense of fear and living the a life of kindness and balance will assure that your future will be happy for you regardless of the unknown.
column2: It's completely natural to feel anxious when contemplating the afterlife, as it's a topic that involves the unknown, and the unknown can often be a source of anxiety. This anxiety can stem from various factors, such as religious beliefs, personal experiences, or philosophical perspectives. From a religious perspective, different faiths have different beliefs about what happens after death. Some believe in reincarnation, others in a heaven and hell dichotomy, and still others believe in a more spiritual continuation of consciousness. These beliefs can either provide comfort or cause anxiety, depending on one's personal faith and interpretation of these doctrines. From a personal experience perspective, people who have had near-death experiences or have lost loved ones may have a heightened sense of anxiety about the afterlife. These experiences can bring the concept of mortality to the forefront of one's mind, making it a more immediate and pressing concern. From a philosophical perspective, some people may feel anxious about the afterlife due to existential concerns. Questions like "What is the purpose of life if we're just going to die?" or "What happens to our consciousness after we die?" can be deeply unsettling. Existentialist philosophers have grappled with these questions for centuries, and their writings may provide some comfort or further food for thought. It's important to remember that it's okay to feel anxious about these big questions. It's a part of being human. However, if your anxiety becomes overwhelming, it may be helpful to speak with a mental health professional. They can provide strategies to manage this anxiety and help you navigate these complex thoughts and feelings.

column1: Religious questioning is a complex and often philosophical topic, and these types of questions, especially around heaven, hell, and an afterlife can bring up a host of difficult & confusing feelings. What I want to focus on is the fear & anxiety you seem to be feeling that are deeply connected to your questions. Scary thoughts, negative thoughts, obsessive thoughts sometimes feel like they're out of control and there is nothing we can do to stop them, but I want to offer two techniques that might assist with your panic & anxiety. The first step in working with scary or negative thoughts is to acknowledge that they are just thoughts and we can choose to follow the scary thought streams or work with cutting them off or ignoring them. I also realize that might seem really hard to do, but here's a good way to think about the brain and how thought patterns work. Thoughts arise in the mind all the time, our brain is a thought machine. Many thoughts drift by like clouds and we don't pay any attention while other thoughts arise and they trigger us in a particulate way, i.e., scary, angry, happy, sad, and when those thoughts arise we can chose to pay more attention to the thought which can lead us down that particular thought stream that will lead to fear and anxiety. So, how do we work or stop those scary thought streams? One new skill to implement comes from the work of Rick Hansen, he wrote the book Buddha's Brain," he teaches that we need to give more energy and attention to the positive thoughts or positive memories we hold in our mind and pay less attention to the negative thoughts. Hansen asks us to imagine the brain this way, the brain is like Velcro with negative thoughts and like teflon when it comes to positive thoughts. There are reasons that our brain works this way, but I don't have time to go into all of that in this response. So, it's just important to remember we have to work at positive thinking, actually pausing throughout the day to focus on positive feelings and memories,  this will help the mind reinforce positive thought streams and help reduce negative thought streams over time. If a scary thought arises try to replace it with a happy experience for at least a couple of moments, and see if that helps reduce the negative charge connected with that scary thought. I would also suggest when you're having the thoughts about death take a moment to notice how you're breathing. Often when we are feeling anxiety we are doing shallowing chest breathing rather than taking in a full, deep breath or what is called belly breathing. If you take a moment to focus on your breathing and allow a couple of full breaths, bringing in the breath so the belly rises and then the belly natural falls as you exhale, just noticing the breath and practicing breathing can slow down the anxiety cycle as it begins.
column2: It's natural for thoughts of the afterlife to cause anxiety for some people. The concept of death and what happens after is one of the greatest mysteries of life. For many, it's the uncertainty that creates anxiety. The human brain is hard-wired to seek solutions and to understand its environment, and when it can't, this can result in anxiety.  Each person's beliefs and experiences with death can also play a significant role. For those who believe in an afterlife that includes punishment or suffering, this can certain cause fear or anxiety.  In some cases, individuals may find comfort in their belief of an afterlife. They might view it as a reunion with loved ones, a form of eternal peace, or an ultimate reward. In general, it is important to seek help in managing anxieties associated with thoughts of death or the afterlife. This can be via professional mental health support, self-care practices, or spiritual counsel, depending on what aligns with a person's beliefs and needs.

column1: You need to find an outlet. Someone to talk to. Your dad or someone who loves your mother as well is someone ideal. But anyone could help. Just look to someone for help. If you can't find anyone who you think will listen, talk to your mom. It can help greatly just to get the words out. Tell her how you feel about her passing, but then also about everything else. Talk to her about your day. Tell her about happy things. I don't know if you're a religious person, or where you believe she is now, but no matter what you can talk to her.
column2: The concept of the afterlife has been a subject of human contemplation and debate for millennia, spanning across cultures, religions, and philosophies. It's not surprising that it can cause anxiety, as it touches on the unknown, the nature of existence, and our deepest fears and hopes. Firstly, the anxiety might stem from the fear of the unknown. The afterlife, by its very nature, is something we cannot fully understand or experience while we're alive. This uncertainty can be unsettling, as humans generally prefer certainty and predictability. Secondly, the concept of the afterlife often intertwines with moral and ethical considerations. Many religious and spiritual traditions link behavior in this life to consequences in the next. This can lead to anxiety about whether one's actions are "good enough" to secure a positive afterlife. Thirdly, thoughts of the afterlife can bring up existential questions about the purpose and meaning of life. If there is an afterlife, what does that mean for our lives now? If there isn't, what does that mean about the value and purpose of our existence? Lastly, the concept of the afterlife can also trigger fears about death and dying. It's a reminder of our mortality, which can be a difficult reality to face. To manage this anxiety, it can be helpful to engage in open conversations about these topics, explore different perspectives, and seek support when needed. Some people find comfort in their religious or spiritual beliefs, while others find peace in secular philosophies. It's a deeply personal journey, and there's no right or wrong way to navigate it.

column1: Many people generate intense anxiety with obsessive thinking.  While the nature of your obsession about the afterlife and eternity appear very powerful and unique to you, the pattern of obsessing about one thing/area is common.  I suggest that you consider counseling to help you with your anxiety.  If you are so inclined, there are also medications which may bring relief.  Obviously, I can't diagnose you from one paragraph, so it would be wise to visit an experienced mental health professional (either a counselor or an MD in your area) to help you with disengaging from your self-destructive thoughts.  CBT, Cognitive Behavioral Therapy, is a very effective counseling approach for obsessive thinking.  If you'd like a see a top notch CBT therapist, visit www.AcademyofCT.org.  And of course I suggest you pick up my book, LIVING YES, A HANDBOOK FOR BEING HUMAN, which includes CBT concepts and many more tools which will help with obsession and anxiety.As for believing yourself "insane" (or "crazy") this is not a mental health term but a legal one (or a slang).  So as long as you don't commit a crime, no professional can legitimately call you insane or crazy!Take it slow!  ~Mark (www.MarkMorrisLCSW.com and www.LivingYes.org)
column2: It's completely natural to feel anxiety when contemplating the afterlife, as it's a topic that involves the unknown, and the unknown can often be a source of fear and anxiety. This is a complex issue that touches on various aspects of human existence, including our beliefs, values, and experiences. Firstly, it's important to understand that the concept of the afterlife varies greatly among different cultures, religions, and philosophical systems. Some believe in reincarnation, others in a heaven or hell, and still others in a more spiritual existence. There are also those who believe in nothingness after death, which is a common belief among atheists and agnostics. Secondly, the anxiety might stem from the fear of death itself, which is a universal human experience. Death is the ultimate unknown, and it's natural to fear what we can't understand or control. This fear can be exacerbated by the uncertainty of what comes after death. Thirdly, the anxiety could be related to moral or ethical concerns. Many religious and spiritual beliefs tie the afterlife to moral judgment, which can cause anxiety about one's actions in this life. Lastly, the anxiety might be existential in nature. Contemplating the afterlife can lead to questions about the meaning and purpose of life, which can be unsettling. There are several ways to cope with this anxiety. One is through open discussion and exploration of your beliefs and fears. Another is through mindfulness and acceptance, acknowledging the fear without letting it control you. If the anxiety is severe, it might be helpful to seek professional help, such as a therapist or counselor. Remember, it's okay to not have all the answers. Uncertainty is a part of life, and it's okay to explore these questions without arriving at a definitive conclusion.

column1: Tell your partner about this so that ideally the person has a chance to be supportive and reassuring, as well as listen to your specific worries and fears.Initiate this type of discussion at a time which is removed from the time you¡¯re about to have sex.This way you and your partner both have a chance to realize the two of you are having a discussion,  not a prelude to sex.If you meant in your question that you feel anxious about having sex w a random partner, then maybe you are less interested in hookup sex than you imagined.
column2: Self-doubt about sex can stem from various sources such as societal pressures, personal insecurities, lack of knowledge, or past experiences. Here are some strategies to help you overcome this: 1. **Education**: Understanding the basics of human sexuality can help alleviate fears and misconceptions. There are many reliable resources available online, in books, or through sex education programs.  2. **Communication**: Open and honest communication with your partner about your fears, desires, and boundaries can help build trust and understanding. This can also help you feel more comfortable and confident during sexual encounters. 3. **Self-Acceptance**: Everyone has insecurities, but it's important to remember that there's no such thing as "normal" when it comes to sex. Everyone's desires and bodies are different. Accepting yourself as you are can help reduce self-doubt. 4. **Therapy**: If self-doubt is causing significant distress, it may be helpful to seek professional help. A therapist, particularly one specializing in sexual health, can provide strategies and techniques to help you manage these feelings. 5. **Mindfulness and Meditation**: These practices can help you stay present during sex, rather than getting caught up in worries or insecurities. They can also help you develop a more positive relationship with your body. 6. **Healthy Lifestyle**: Regular exercise, a balanced diet, and adequate sleep can improve your overall mood and energy levels, which can in turn boost your self-confidence. 7. **Positive Affirmations**: Regularly reminding yourself of your worth and attractiveness can help change negative thought patterns. Remember, it's perfectly okay to have doubts and insecurities. What's important is not to let them control your life or your enjoyment of sex. It's a journey of self-discovery and self-love, and it's perfectly okay to take your time.

column1: I first wonder what your anxiety or fear connects to. I don't know whether it is about sex itself or about ideas of worthiness or feeling desirable.There is also a difference between having self-doubt about the actual physicality of having sex (performance-related) or having doubts about whether you want to have sex with a particular person.Having sex can lead to feelings of great vulnerability. If your partner is someone you trust, consider discussing what it is that comes up for you around the issue of sex. This is the certain things that your partner would be willing to do that and the ease your discomfort, like staying with you for some time before and after sexual interactions.Another idea to consider is spending time with your partner and using nonsexual touch for each other (perhaps first you to him and then him to you) and communicating very clearly about what you like and do not like. Some people like to be spoken to during physical touch and other people do not. All of this can be part of your discussions. When you feel comfortable with that, you could move into sexual touch in this manner and actually look at what you do and do not like. You may also consider discussing things that are totally off-limits for you all the time and things for which you would like warning or awareness before they happen. There are really a number of different ways to work on becoming more comfortable if you trust your partner and if your concern is about sex itself.If this feels pretty structured, it is initially. Generally, the idea is to learn more about each other and yourselves and then the process becomes much more natural.If the concern relates more to self-esteem related sex, consider asking your partner to list several things that he or she likes about you. Even if you don't necessarily see yourself in the same light, consider that this is how your partner sees you, so these are some of the things that make you attractive to them (perhaps both in sexual ways and in a wider discussion of the relationship).If this is difficult for you to sort out on your own, consider seeing a therapist with experience working with couples or relationships.
column2: Having self-doubt about sex is a common issue that people face. Whether it's feeling unsure about your skills, body image, or relationships, these doubts can have a significant impact on your sexual well-being. Here are some suggestions to help shake self-doubt: 1. Education: Learning about sex can reduce anxiety and doubt. Read books, watch documentaries, or attend lectures or workshops about sexuality. You can also consult a professional sex educator or therapist. 2. Communication: Open and sincere communication with your partner about your frustrations and insecurities can help a lot. Knowing that you're being heard and understood can foster trust and alleviate self-doubt. 3. Practice Self-Compassion: Everyone makes mistakes and has insecurities. It's important not to beat yourself up over them. Instead, treat yourself with kindness and understanding. Replace negative self-talk with positive affirmations. 4. Develop Body Positivity: If the self-doubt stems from body image, working on your body positivity can be a good starting point. Understand that everyone has unique bodies and there's no such thing as a perfect one. 5. Strive for Healthy Relationships: A healthy emotional relationship with your partner will often lead to a healthy sexual relationship. Ensure you are with someone who supports and respects you. 6. Seek professional help: Therapists, counselors, and coaches who specialize in sexual issues can provide strategies, techniques and exercises to help improve your confidence. 7. Practice Occasional Abstinence: Taking regular breaks from sexual activity can sometimes help you become more comfortable with your body and your sexual ability.     8. Stop Comparing: Everyone has different experiences and preferences when it comes to sex. Avoid comparing your experiences to those of others. 9. Take Things Slow: Don't rush into new sexual experiences. Take your time to understand what you're comfortable with and tend to shy away from what makes you uncomfortable. Remember, it's okay to have self-doubts. You're not alone. The key point is to acknowledge these feelings and then to take active steps to tackle them.

column1: There's a quote I love that says, "Wherever you go, there you are" and the book by the same name by Jon Kabat-Zinn may be very helpful for you. The thing about changing things up when they get tough is that they often aren't the things that need changing. The awesome (and challenging) thing about it is that when you work on the internal aspects that may need attention, you can learn to find a sense of centeredness that comes with practicing mindfulness and asking yourself who you really are and want to be. Through this deeper work, you can actually be in the midst of chaos and still feel that calm and peace within yourself. If you look for support in this journey from a counselor or therapist, I'd recommend looking for someone offering Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) or Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (MCBT). Also helpful may be the online program of Mindfulness Based Stress Reduction (MSBR) found here. There are in-person programs across the country, but this online self-guided version is free and a great resource!
column2: It sounds like you're experiencing a pattern of shifting your life around when challenges arise. This is a common response to stress or discomfort, but it's worth examining more closely to understand its implications and potential alternatives. Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that change isn't inherently bad. In fact, it's a natural part of life and can often lead to growth and development. However, if you find yourself constantly changing your life in response to difficulties, it might be a sign that you're avoiding dealing with these issues directly.  Avoidance can provide temporary relief, but it often prolongs the problem and can even exacerbate it. For instance, if you're frequently changing jobs because you're unhappy, you might be missing an opportunity to address the root cause of your dissatisfaction, such as a lack of fulfillment or a need for personal development. On the other hand, if you're changing your life in significant ways, like moving to a new city or ending relationships when things get tough, it might be a sign that you're not giving yourself the chance to work through difficulties and grow from them.  It's also worth considering the impact of these changes on your sense of stability and continuity. Constant change can be disorienting and can make it difficult to build long-term relationships and goals. If you find this pattern troubling, it might be helpful to seek support from a therapist or counselor. They can provide strategies to help you cope with stress and discomfort in a healthier way, and can guide you in breaking this cycle of avoidance. Remember, it's okay to face difficulties head-on. It's through these challenges that we often find our greatest opportunities for growth and self-discovery.

column1: Is there a certain problem you feel about living the way you describe?As long as you feel satisfied with how your life is unfolding then you¡¯re making wise decisions.If you feel tension or that somehow doing as you describe is wrong, then the first step is to identify the way you feel your methodology described above has a role in working against your best interest.Basically, define what is problematic in order to address it.
column2: It sounds like you're going through a challenging time and are frequently finding yourself in situations where you feel the need to make significant changes. This could be a sign of resilience, as you're adapting to new circumstances, but it could also indicate that you're not fully addressing the root causes of your difficulties. Firstly, it's important to understand that life is inherently filled with ups and downs. It's normal to face challenges and obstacles, and it's also normal to feel overwhelmed by them at times. However, if you find yourself constantly changing your life when things get tough, it might be beneficial to delve deeper into why this is happening. Are you perhaps avoiding certain issues instead of confronting them? Sometimes, we change our circumstances to escape problems that are uncomfortable or difficult to deal with. However, this often only provides temporary relief, and the same issues may resurface in the future. Alternatively, are you perhaps not fully satisfied with your current life situation? If you're frequently feeling the need to change, it could be a sign that you're not living in alignment with your true values or desires. In this case, it might be helpful to spend some time reflecting on what you truly want out of life. Lastly, it's also possible that you're simply someone who thrives on change and new experiences. Some people are naturally more inclined towards stability and routine, while others prefer constant change and variety. If this is the case, it's important to find a balance that allows you to embrace change while also maintaining a sense of stability and security. In any case, it might be beneficial to seek professional help, such as a therapist or a life coach, who can provide you with tools and strategies to navigate these challenges more effectively. They can help you understand your patterns, identify potential areas for growth, and develop a plan for moving forward.

column1: Many times when things become difficult to manage, is because we are getting out of our comfort zone, so we seek growth and change.  Coping with the difficulties does make you more resilient and helps you to build the confidence you need to solve problems in the future. Now I wonder:  are things getting tough in a way that you are not able to resolve them?  Do you need to move or change to save yourself or prevent any harm? If so, it is OK to know when to remove ourselves form situations that harm us more than helping us.  On the other hand, are the things getting tough because you need to learn a new skill?  If so, how can you learn them and is there someone who can help you overcome this challenge?  I help my clients to identify their strengths and areas where they can achieve growth, things like polishing up your resume and evaluate new job opportunities could help you discover a new you.If you would like to engage in counseling, I am licensed in Texas and Puerto Rico, you can contact me at 787-466-5478. Cada vez que las cosas se ponen dif¨ªciles, hago cambios en mi vida.He sido as¨ª desde que estaba en la escuela; antes me transfer¨ªa de escuela.  Ahora pienso cambiar de trabajo.Muchas veces cuando las situaciones se tornan en dif¨ªciles de manejar, es porque nos sacan de nuestra zona de comodidad, con el prop¨®sito de buscar el cambio y el crecimiento.  Manejar las dificultades si te vuelve m¨¢s resistente, y desarrolla tu autoestima para que puedas resolver problemas en el futuro.    Ahora, te pregunto: ?se est¨¢n poniendo las cosas dif¨ªciles al punto que no puedes manejarlas?  ?Necesitas removerte de la situaci¨®n para evitar que te hagan da?o? Si es as¨ª, entonces est¨¢ bien reconocer cuando nos debemos remover de una situaci¨®n da?ina que nos da?a m¨¢s de lo que nos permite crecer. O por el otro lado, ?Se est¨¢n poniendo las cosas dif¨ªciles porque necesitas a prender una nueva destreza?  Si es as¨ª, ?c¨®mo puedes aprender esa destreza y quien te puede ayudar?Ayudo a mis clientes a identificar sus fortalezas y ¨¢reas de crecimiento, el actualizar y pulir tu resume junto con explorar opciones de empleo, te puede llevar a descubrir nuevos talentos en ti.Si te gustar¨ªa hacer una cita, soy Consejera Profesional Licenciada en Texas y en Puerto Rico, llama al 787-466-5478.
column2: It sounds like you're experiencing a pattern of shifting your life around when challenges arise. This is a common response to stress or discomfort, but it's worth examining more closely to understand its implications and potential alternatives. Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that change isn't inherently bad. In fact, it's a natural part of life and can often lead to growth and development. However, if you find yourself constantly changing your life in response to difficulties, it might be a sign that you're avoiding dealing with these issues directly.  Avoidance can provide temporary relief, but it often prolongs the problem and can even exacerbate it. For instance, if you're frequently changing jobs because you're unhappy, you might be missing an opportunity to address the root cause of your dissatisfaction, such as a lack of fulfillment or a need for personal development. On the other hand, if you're changing your life in ways that lead to personal growth and improved well-being, this could be a positive coping mechanism. For example, if you're leaving toxic relationships or unhealthy environments, these changes could be beneficial. It's crucial to differentiate between changes that help you grow and changes that are forms of avoidance. To do this, you might want to consider seeking professional help, such as a therapist or a life coach. They can provide you with tools to better understand your patterns and help you develop healthier coping strategies. Remember, it's okay to face difficulties and it's okay to seek help. Everyone encounters challenges, and it's through overcoming these challenges that we often find our greatest strengths.

column1: Sometimes changes make sense. It may be helpful to talk to someone who you trust to get a sense of whether the changes that you are making are those that are considered adaptable or important changes that allow us all to grow. Another possibility is that you are changing things in an effort to get away from something that is uncomfortable or difficult. There are many other possibilities along this continuum.I would ask you to consider the following:What is leading you to want to change your job?What feelings are associated with this change? (Happy, sad, scared, anxious/nervous, confused, motivated, etc.)How is the job that you are looking to transfer to going to be better or different? Are the concerns that you have now going to travel with you?If you are hesitating to get another perspective (from trusted friends or family or some sort of career advisor in your area), where is the hesitation coming from?
column2: Making changes and adapting to new situations are important parts of life. When things get tough, it can be beneficial to reevaluate your current situation and consider what changes could potentially improve your circumstances. However, constantly upending your life in response to challenges may not be the most effective way to resolve problems. While it's crucial to be adaptable, stability is equally important. Significant changes often bring stress and can cause confusion if they're not well planned.  Sometimes, instead of making big changes, it can be more helpful to focus on developing resilience and effective coping mechanisms. This means not avoiding problems, but learning how to deal with them in a healthy, constructive way.  Seeking support from friends, family, or a professional counselor can help you navigate through tough times. They can provide perspective and offer strategies for coping that you may have not considered.  It's also beneficial to take good care of your physical health during difficult times. Regular exercise, a balanced diet, and plenty of sleep are all essential for maintaining emotional resilience. Your mental health is directly linked to your physical wellbeing, so self-care is very important. Lastly, remember that change is indeed a natural part of life and it's okay to take a step back and reassess the situation. However, it's essential not to make rash decisions in a stressful state. It's always best to make changes that are well thought out and consider the potential long-term implications.

column1: I recommend that you make a list of all the reasons you should change your life and all of the reasons you shouldn't change your life. Can the problem you are in be fixed? Is there others you can lean on for support? Are there other people you know who have been through a similar experience and are willing to share their story with you? It is important to rely on your support network to help you get multiple points of view. If you believe you need additional help, I suggest seeing a professional.
column2: It sounds like you're experiencing a pattern of shifting your life around when challenges arise. This is a common response to stress or discomfort, but it's worth examining more closely to understand its implications and potential alternatives. Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that change isn't inherently bad. In fact, it's a natural part of life and can often lead to growth and development. However, if you find yourself constantly changing your life in response to difficulties, it might be a sign that you're avoiding dealing with these issues directly.  Avoidance can provide temporary relief, but it often prolongs the problem and can even exacerbate it. For instance, if you're frequently changing jobs because you're unhappy, you might be missing an opportunity to develop coping strategies, improve your skills, or address issues in your work environment. On the other hand, if you're changing your life in ways that are positive and growth-oriented, such as seeking new experiences or learning new skills, this can be a healthy response to challenges. The key is to ensure that these changes are driven by a genuine desire for growth, rather than avoidance or fear. It might be helpful to reflect on the nature of the challenges you're facing and your reasons for making changes. Are there patterns in the types of difficulties you encounter? Are there recurring themes in the changes you make? Understanding these patterns can provide insight into your coping mechanisms and help you develop more effective strategies. Consider seeking support from a therapist or counselor. They can provide tools and techniques to help you navigate challenges more effectively, and can support you in making changes that are truly beneficial. Remember, it's okay to seek help and it's okay to struggle. Life is full of challenges, and it's through facing these challenges that we grow and learn.

column1: No, it makes sense :)Consider today how social media has impacted the mind and heart of man;Is it not so extraordinarily easy to make one appear stellar on social media today?  Heh heh, I've long since joked that the definition of a party is:  "A series of photos to lie with."When I peel back the awareness of others' "judgment", what I find is excitement of wanting to express themselves too...It's funny how America is one of the few lands on the planet where folks are able to mess up and try it again; on most other places, if you mess up, there is such deep shame in it, that it may lead to one taking one's life;
column2: It's completely normal to feel judged by others from time to time. This feeling often stems from our inherent desire to be accepted and fit in with societal norms. However, it's important to remember a few things: 1. **Perception is not reality**: The way you perceive others to be judging you may not be accurate. People are generally more focused on their own lives and issues than they are on others.  2. **Self-compassion**: It's crucial to practice self-compassion and understand that everyone makes mistakes and has flaws. This can help reduce the fear of judgment because you're acknowledging that it's okay to not be perfect. 3. **Confidence**: Building self-confidence can also help mitigate the fear of judgment. This can be achieved through self-improvement, setting and achieving personal goals, and focusing on your strengths rather than your weaknesses. 4. **Mindfulness and acceptance**: Mindfulness involves being present in the moment and accepting it without judgment. This can help you accept yourself as you are, reducing the fear of others' judgment. 5. **Seek professional help**: If your fear of judgment is causing significant distress or affecting your daily life, it may be beneficial to seek help from a mental health professional. They can provide strategies and techniques to manage these feelings. Remember, it's okay to be yourself and everyone has their own unique journey in life. It's not necessary to conform to others' expectations or judgments.

column1: Stop caring about what you imagine people are thinking about you!Really this is the simple and complicated answer to feel better about your situation.Maybe someone is judging you, maybe someone isn't judging you.Until the person tells you directly what they don't like about you, there's nothing you can do.It is okay that the fear doesn't make sense, most fears don't make sense.
column2: It's completely normal to feel judged by others from time to time. This feeling often stems from our inherent desire to be accepted and liked by those around us. However, it's important to remember a few things: 1. **Perception is subjective**: How people perceive you is often more about them than it is about you. Their judgments are based on their own experiences, biases, and insecurities. Therefore, it's not an accurate reflection of who you truly are. 2. **You can't control others' thoughts**: It's impossible to control what others think of you. Trying to do so can lead to a lot of stress and anxiety. Instead, focus on what you can control, such as your own actions, reactions, and attitudes. 3. **Self-acceptance is key**: The most important judgment is the one you make about yourself. Practice self-acceptance and self-love. Recognize your strengths, work on your weaknesses, and strive to be the best version of yourself. 4. **Everyone makes mistakes**: Remember that everyone, even those who might be judging you, makes mistakes. It's a part of being human. What's important is that you learn and grow from these experiences. 5. **Seek professional help if needed**: If your fear of judgment is causing significant distress or is interfering with your daily life, it might be helpful to seek the assistance of a mental health professional. They can provide strategies and techniques to help you manage these feelings. Remember, it's your life. Don't let the fear of judgment prevent you from living it to the fullest.

column1: What are the best ways to reduce anxiety?I have anxieties about everyday stressors, i.e. finances, work, relationships, kids, and maintaining a household.Our everyday life is filled with pressures and deadlines that are common to cause anxiety.  Here are some basic tips to handle those stressors.¡¤  Learn thought stopping techniques: There are multiple ways to teach your brain to refocus.  If you allow your brain to focus on the source of anxiety, the anxiety will be in charge.  But you can learn to put those anxiety-provoking thoughts on a parking lot, and focus on pleasurable thoughts, or the activity that you need to complete on the time being.¡¤  Plan, organize, delegate:  Create a schedule to manage demands, organize priorities, and delegate or share responsibilities.  Work as a team with your family, so you can share the load.  Prioritize actives, shores, and expenses. Focus on the urgent, necessary, and spread apart the not so urgent.¡¤  Identify triggers:  Once you understand what causes your anxiety, you can learn to channel process and refocus your thoughts.  You can also learn coping strategies to manage the problem or give up the desire to control it if needed.¡¤  Learn coping skills:  Having a balanced lifestyle helps tremendously to reduce and manage anxiety symptoms.  Looking at your eating, sleeping, physical activities, spirituality and leisure time is key to find that balance.If you find yourself struggling with anxiety, you can contact a Counselor or mental health provider.  I provide teletherapy for Texas residents and psychotherapy in Puerto Rico, you can reach me at 787-466-5478 for appointments.?Cu¨¢les son las mejores maneras de reducir la ansiedad?Tengo ansiedad por preocupaciones diarias, como las finanzas, relaciones, ni?os y mantener mi casa.Nuestra vida est¨¢ llena de retos y presiones que com¨²nmente nos causan ansiedad.  Aqu¨ª unos consejos b¨¢sicos para manejar esas preocupaciones.¡¤  Aprende como detener tus pensamientos: Hay m¨²ltiples maneras de ense?arle a tu cerebro a reenfocarse.  Si permites que tu cerebro se enfoque en la fuente de ansiedad, entonces la ansiedad se apoderar¨¢ de ti.  Pero puedes aprender a poner a un lado esos pensamientos que causan ansiedad, y enfocarte en pensamientos positivos, placenteros o simplemente enfocarte en la actividad que est¨¢s haciendo. ¡¤  Planifica, organiza, delega: Crea una agenda para manejar las demandas diarias, organizar prioridades y delegar o compartir responsabilidades.  Trabaja en equipo con tu familia, de manera que puedas compartir la carga.  Organiza las actividades, gastos y tareas por prioridad.  Enf¨®cate en lo urgente y necesario y distribuye lo que no es tan vital. ¡¤  Identifica la fuente:  Ya que comprendes donde o qu¨¦ inicia la ansiedad, puedes aprender a canalizarla, procesarla o reenfocar tus pensamientos. Tambi¨¦n puedes aprender a manejar la fuente de ansiedad, resolver el problema, o aceptar que no lo puedes controlar, si ese fuera el caso. ¡¤  Aprende mecanismos de defensa: Tener un estilo de vida balanceado ayuda tremendamente a manejar s¨ªntomas de ansiedad.  Observar tus patrones de alimentaci¨®n, descanso, ejercicio, espiritualidad y tiempo de ocio es clave para encontrar el balance. Si notas que continuas batallando con la ansiedad puedes contactar a un consejero profesional de salud mental.  Proveo teleterapia a residentes de Texas y Consejer¨ªa en Puerto Rico, me puedes contactar al 787-466-5478 para hacer una cita.
column2: 1. Regular Exercise: Physical activity can increase the production of endorphins, which are known as the body's natural painkillers and mood elevators. 2. Balanced Diet: Eating a healthy diet enriched with fruits, vegetables, lean protein, and whole grains can help manage anxiety. Try to avoid caffeine and alcohol as they can increase anxiety levels. 3. Adequate Sleep: It¡¯s crucial for physical and mental health. Lack of sleep can exacerbate anxiety. 4. Mindfulness and Meditation: These practices can reduce symptoms of anxiety and improve emotional health. 5. Deep Breathing and Relaxation Techniques: This can help you manage anxiety and stress levels. 6. Counseling and Therapy: Cognitive-behavioral therapy is effective in reducing anxiety symptoms. 7. Medication: In some cases, medication like selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and benzodiazepines can be prescribed by a healthcare provider. 8. Support Network: Having a strong support network is vital. Family, friends, or support groups can provide necessary emotional assistance. 9. Limit Alcohol and Avoid Drugs: These substances can worsen anxiety and even trigger anxiety attacks. 10. Stay Active: Engage in hobbies and activities you enjoy to de-stress and distract your mind from anxiety provoking thoughts. Remember, it's best to consult a healthcare provider for professional advice tailored to your personal needs.

column1: Something to remember about anxiety is that it's a useful and necessary response to stressors, and we all have a level of anxiety that falls somewhere on the spectrum from very slight to very overwhelming. Anxiety is our brain's way of prompting us to deal with the stress in our lives by getting us geared up for action. Some helpful ways of managing anxiety are actually very simple. The first I'd recommend is a calm breathing technique - breathe in for 4-5 seconds, and then out for 7-8 seconds. Try to repeat this for 3-5 minutes. Another suggestion is to pay closer attention in the moments you feel the physical symptoms of anxiety and see if you can describe - without judging - the sensations to yourself. Try to be very specific, such as "my palms are feeling very sweaty, and I can feel the slight tightness and fluttering in my belly of the butterflies." Then try to sit with these sensations without deciding if they are good or bad - just experiencing them as intentionally as possible.  Combining the calm breathing with this technique can also be very helpful. If you feel that these techniques don't help and your anxiety about everyday stressors are inhibiting you from being able to engage in life the way you want to, then I'd highly recommend going for an assessment or even just consultation with a professional. This professional can help you determine if therapy/counseling would be helpful for you to develop additional skills for managing those interfering anxiety symptoms.
column2: 1. Practice Mindfulness and Meditation: This helps to bring your attention to the present moment, which can lower anxiety and stress levels. 2. Regular Exercise: Engaging in physical activity can reduce stress hormones and release mood-enhancing chemicals known as endorphins. 3. Balanced Diet: Eating a well-balanced diet can help to keep your body healthy and reduce anxiety. Certain foods could potentially increase anxiety, such as caffeine, alcohol, sugar, and processed foods. 4. Quality Sleep: Getting enough sleep allows your brain to function properly and can reduce feelings of anxiety. Aim for 7-9 hours sleep per night. 5. Schedule ¡®Worry Time¡¯: Rather than worrying all day, allocate 15 minutes each day where you allow yourself to worry, then tell yourself to stop and save it for later. 6. Deep Breathing and Relaxation Techniques: These can help soothe the nervous system, relax the body, and reduce anxiety. 7. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): This form of therapy helps to restructure negative thought patterns that lead to anxiety. 8. Stay Hydrated: Dehydration can cause mood changes and anxiety. 9. Reach Out To Others: Share your troubles with friends, family, or a mental health professional. Speaking about your stressors is an excellent way to gain perspective and reduce their power. 10. Limit Screen Time: Spending too much time on electronic devices and being constantly connected can lead to anxiety. 11. Herbal Remedies: Chamomile tea, passionflower, and valerian are among the herbs that have been found to have anti-anxiety effects. Note: It's always advisable to consult with a healthcare provider or a mental health professional to receive a personalized treatment plan.

column1: Anxieties are an adrenal problem;Clean them out with a proper detox, using the food built for mankind, and a herbal protocol;Maybe throw in some fasting here and there to kick the kidneys into high gear and get the adrenals pumping...Every loss is a gain, so losing a car means you no longer hold responsibility to keep and maintain it...If you're really up for it, some contemplation (that is keep one thought *lightly* on your mind allllllll day; that is just focus upon it from time to time, "Man, I notice that the sky is really blue today... and the air is really crisp today..."); after 3-5 days of contemplation, see what you notice...
column2: Reducing anxiety can be a multifaceted process, as it often involves both physical and mental strategies. Here are some comprehensive methods to consider: 1. **Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)**: This is a type of psychotherapy that can help you understand and change thought patterns that lead to harmful behaviors and feelings of anxiety. It can provide you with tools to manage anxiety and cope with stressful situations. 2. **Mindfulness and Meditation**: These practices can help you focus on the present moment, which can reduce the impact of anxious thoughts about the future or past. Regular practice can help reduce overall levels of anxiety. 3. **Physical Activity**: Regular exercise can help reduce anxiety by boosting your mood and acting as a natural stress reliever. It also helps improve sleep, which can often be affected by anxiety. 4. **Healthy Diet**: Certain foods may contribute to anxiety. Try to maintain a balanced diet with plenty of fruits, vegetables, lean proteins, and whole grains. Limit caffeine and alcohol, as they can increase anxiety levels. 5. **Adequate Sleep**: Lack of sleep can exacerbate anxiety. Try to establish a regular sleep routine, ensuring you get enough rest each night. 6. **Deep Breathing and Relaxation Techniques**: These can help to reduce immediate feelings of anxiety and help to manage panic attacks. 7. **Social Support**: Connecting with others can help reduce feelings of anxiety. This could be friends, family, or support groups of people who are experiencing similar feelings. 8. **Professional Help**: If anxiety is significantly impacting your life, it may be beneficial to seek help from a mental health professional. They can provide guidance and treatment options, including medication if necessary. 9. **Limit Media and Screen Time**: Constant exposure to news and social media can increase feelings of anxiety. Try to limit your exposure and take regular breaks. 10. **Journaling**: Writing down your thoughts and feelings can be a therapeutic way to offload any worries or fears you may have. Remember, it's important to consult with a healthcare provider or a mental health professional for personalized advice. Everyone is different, and what works best will depend on your individual circumstances.

column1: Anxiety is overwhelming insecurity.Try to think of why you'd feel insecure or have very little confidence in your ability to complete or be in relationships.Is it possible you were very heavily criticized when you were young and growing up?Very often kids who are not encouraged to try new activities, have fun in relating to others, learn to not trust themselves to handle these fundamental parts of life.Also, if you grew up in an alcoholic or abusive family, whether the the abuse was toward you or between your parents, it is possible these scenes made you a very insecure foundation on which to trust your yourself and other people.Examine the basics of your growing up years and what may explain why you feel insecure.To improve, be patient with yourself about. making mistakes and simply try in simple, small, and direct ways to do the actions you fear and in which you also would like to participate.
column2: Reducing anxiety can be a multifaceted process, as it often involves both physical and mental strategies. Here are some comprehensive methods to consider: 1. **Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)**: This is a type of psychotherapy that helps individuals understand and change thought patterns that lead to harmful behaviors or feelings of anxiety. It's often considered one of the most effective treatments for anxiety. 2. **Mindfulness and Meditation**: These practices can help you focus on the present moment, which can reduce the impact of anxious thoughts about the future or past. Regular practice can help reduce overall levels of anxiety. 3. **Physical Activity**: Regular exercise can help reduce anxiety by boosting your mood and acting as a natural stress reliever. It also helps improve sleep, which can often be affected by anxiety. 4. **Healthy Diet**: Certain foods may contribute to anxiety. For example, caffeine and alcohol can trigger panic attacks; high-sugar foods can cause mood swings. A balanced diet with plenty of fruits, vegetables, lean proteins, and whole grains can help keep your body and mind healthy. 5. **Adequate Sleep**: Lack of sleep can exacerbate anxiety. Establishing a regular sleep schedule and creating a comfortable sleep environment can help improve sleep quality. 6. **Social Support**: Connecting with others can help reduce feelings of anxiety. This could involve talking to friends or family about your feelings, joining a support group, or seeking professional help. 7. **Relaxation Techniques**: Techniques such as deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, or yoga can help reduce symptoms of anxiety by relaxing the body and mind. 8. **Limiting Media Consumption**: Constant exposure to news or social media can increase feelings of anxiety. Setting boundaries for media consumption can help. 9. **Medication**: In some cases, medication may be recommended by a healthcare provider. This can include antidepressants, anti-anxiety drugs, or beta-blockers. 10. **Self-Care Practices**: Taking time for yourself and doing things you enjoy can help reduce anxiety. This could include reading, listening to music, taking a bath, or spending time in nature. Remember, it's important to consult with a healthcare provider or mental health professional for personalized advice and treatment. Everyone's experience with anxiety is different, and what works best will vary from person to person.

column1: Which one gives you the most anxiety? List from top to bottom which one gives you the greatest anxiety and ask the question how come? From there, we can figure out the underlying factors of your anxiety.
column2: Reducing anxiety can be a multifaceted process, as it often involves both physical and mental strategies. Here are some comprehensive methods to consider: 1. **Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)**: This is a type of psychotherapy that can help you understand and change thought patterns that lead to harmful behaviors and feelings of anxiety. It can provide you with tools to manage anxiety and cope with stressful situations. 2. **Mindfulness and Meditation**: These practices can help you focus on the present moment, which can reduce the impact of negative thoughts and feelings associated with anxiety. Techniques include guided imagery, mindfulness-based stress reduction, and yoga. 3. **Physical Activity**: Regular exercise can help reduce anxiety by boosting your mood and acting as a natural stress reliever. It also helps improve sleep, which can often be disrupted by anxiety. 4. **Healthy Diet**: Certain foods may contribute to anxiety. Try to maintain a balanced diet with plenty of fruits, vegetables, lean proteins, and whole grains. Limit caffeine and alcohol, as they can increase anxiety levels and trigger panic attacks. 5. **Adequate Sleep**: Lack of sleep can exacerbate anxiety. Try to establish a regular sleep routine, ensuring you get enough rest each night. 6. **Social Support**: Connecting with others can help reduce feelings of anxiety. This could be through talking to friends and family about your feelings, joining a support group, or seeking professional help. 7. **Relaxation Techniques**: Techniques such as deep breathing, massage, and progressive muscle relaxation can help reduce symptoms of anxiety by promoting relaxation. 8. **Limit Media Consumption**: Constant exposure to news and social media can increase feelings of anxiety. Try to limit your consumption and take regular digital detoxes. 9. **Professional Help**: If your anxiety is severe or persistent, it may be helpful to seek professional help. This could be a psychiatrist, psychologist, or counselor who can provide treatment options like therapy or medication. 10. **Medication**: In some cases, medication may be recommended by a healthcare professional. These can include antidepressants, sedatives, and beta-blockers. Remember, it's important to consult with a healthcare provider to discuss your symptoms and the best treatment options for you. Everyone is different, and what works best will depend on your individual situation.

column1: Since it is clear that people react differently to the same stressors, we know that the stressors are not causing the anxiety, our thoughts about the stressors are. Often, cognitive distortions are the problem. Some common cognitive distortions include catastrophizing (predicting the worst), future telling, black and white thinking (if it's not perfect, it's terrible), mind-reading (I just know he is angry at me) and can't-standitis (I can't stand this situation). There are more, but the list is long, and if some of these are resonating with you, I would advise looking up CBT (cognitive behavioral therapy) tips, worksheets, booklets etc. on line, or contact a local CBT therapist. Another helpful piece of info on anxiety, is that it is prone to something called "symptom stress" - being anxious about anxiety. If we could hear this symptom stress it might sound like, "Oh no I'm getting nervous about this, I'm getting uptight, I look nervous, what if I have a panic attack!" followed by more cognitive distortions such as "I can't stand being anxious!" and "this is horrible!" The antidote to this is acceptance.  Kind of like not stopping the waves but learning to surf instead (Jon Kabat-Zinn). If you happen to feel anxious, say to yourself - this is just a reaction I'm having that is unpleasant, but not horrible. I can tolerate and survive some anxiety, I can breathe deeply, and I'll be OK because panic attacks never killed anyone. I can stand this and it is temporary. You get the idea.We can increase our awareness of anxiety-provoking self-talk, and counteract it with calming and reassuring self-talk. We have the ability to think about our thinking, decide which thoughts are healthy and which are unhealthy, and choose which to focus on. We brainwash ourselves with our thinking, and according to self-perception theory, " we learn what we believe when we hear ourselves speak," so we may as well be a calming, reassuring presence in our own minds. :)
column2: 1. Regular Exercise: Physical activity can boost your mood, reduce stress hormones and promote relaxation.  2. Balanced Diet: Eating a diet high in vegetables, fruits and lean proteins can significantly reduce anxiety over time. 3. Meditation and Yoga: These practices can help you to relax and manage stress, which in turn can reduce anxiety levels. 4. Adequate Sleep: Too little or interrupted sleep can exacerbate anxiety. Make sure you have a good sleep routine and environment. 5. Limited Alcohol and Caffeine: These can trigger or exacerbate anxiety. Try to limit your intake. 6. Deep Breathing and Relaxation Techniques: These can help to relax the tense muscles that often accompany anxiety. 7. Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT): This is a type of therapy that can help you understand and manage your thoughts, leading to lower anxiety. 8. Medication: In some cases, medication may be needed to help manage anxiety. Always consult with a healthcare professional.  9. Support Networks: Surrounding yourself with supportive friends, family, or a professional counselor can help manage stress and reduce anxiety. 10. Setting Priorities: Do not overwhelm yourself with too many tasks at once. Prioritize and delegate tasks to help lessen your workload. Remember, it¡¯s important to consult with a mental health professional if you¡¯re experiencing anxiety to discuss the best possible course of action.

column1: It sounds like you are on the right track. Recognizing these nagging thoughts of self- doubt as "imposter syndrome" is a huge step in the right direction.  From what you have written here, it appears that you are able to challenge your own thoughts and provide yourself with evidence that counteracts the imposter syndrome.   Continuing to remind yourself of what you have accomplished and looking at the facts at hand can help diminish doubt.  Remember, many successful people battled imposter syndrome on the way to the top (and still manage it).  It might be helpful to read some of their stories so that you don't feel alone.  "The Cut" has a great article on "25 Famous Women on Imposter-Syndrome and Self-Doubt".   Business Insider has a great article about men and the imposter syndrome too.  Remember, if you jumped through all of the hoops to get into school and get published-- you belong.
column2: Imposter syndrome is the feeling that you aren't as competent or talented as others perceive you to be and that you will one day be exposed as a "fraud". Here's how you can overcome it: 1. Acknowledge the feelings: Recognizing and admitting that you have imposter syndrome is the first step. Ignorance or denial won't make it go away. 2. Understand the causes: Imposter syndrome is usually linked to feelings of self-doubt, insecurities and fear of failure. Recognize these feelings and try to trace them back to their source.  3. Share your thoughts: Talk about your feelings with a trusted friend or mentor, as they can provide a different perspective. Chances are, they might have felt the same way at some point. 4. Celebrate your achievements: Make a list of your successes and what you did to achieve them. Be proud of your accomplishments, no matter how small you think they might be. 5. Stop comparing: You are unique and your journey is different from everyone else's. Stop comparing yourself to others, this only fuels the syndrome. 6. Self-care: Stress and anxiety can intensify feelings of imposter syndrome. Regular exercise, adequate sleep, and a healthy diet are crucial for mental health. 7. Seek professional help: If your feelings of impostor syndrome are causing you significant stress or negatively impacting your life, it might be beneficial to seek help from a mental health professional. These professionals can provide techniques and coping strategies to help you overcome these feelings. 8. Embrace failure and learn from it: See failures as a stepping stone towards your success rather than viewing it as a setback. Remember, everyone fails from time to time and it's an integral part of the learning process. 9. Stop pursuing perfectionism: Set realistic expectations. No one is perfect and it's okay to make mistakes. 10. Positive affirmations: Cultivate and encourage positive thoughts within yourself. Make a list of your strengths and repeat them when you start doubting your worth.  Remember, overcoming imposter syndrome takes time and practice, so be patient with yourself on this journey.

column1: First step is to remove the label of your behavior as a syndrome and instead understand the reasons for it."Imposter syndrome" sounds like a name someone made up to write a book and have lots of people buy it bc it gives the feeling they know themselves by calling themselves this name.Instead, consider your own unique qualities including your fears of being recognized as adding value to people's lives.If you were told growing up that you're worthless, or if your chosen career goes against family advice and expectations, or if you simply are a shy person, then these would be the starting points to understand your reluctance to believe in yourself.The more you understand yourself and trust the truths you find as to who you are, the less you will feel fraudulent.Good luck in your career work!
column2: Imposter Syndrome is a psychological pattern where individuals doubt their accomplishments and have a persistent, internalized fear of being exposed as a "fraud". It's common among high achievers who are unable to internalize and accept their success. Here are some strategies to help you overcome this: 1. **Acknowledge the feelings**: Recognizing that what you're feeling is imposter syndrome is the first step towards overcoming it. It's a common phenomenon that affects many people, so you're not alone. 2. **Understand the causes**: Imposter syndrome can be triggered by various factors such as perfectionism, fear of failure, or fear of success. Understanding what triggers your feelings of being an imposter can help you manage them. 3. **Reframe your thoughts**: Instead of attributing your success to luck or deception, try to acknowledge the effort, skills, and preparation you put into achieving your goals.  4. **Talk about it**: Sharing your feelings with trusted friends, mentors, or a professional counselor can help. They can provide a different perspective and reassure you of your abilities and achievements. 5. **Celebrate your achievements**: Make a habit of celebrating your successes, no matter how small they may seem. This can help you internalize your accomplishments and boost your self-confidence. 6. **Seek professional help**: If imposter syndrome is causing significant stress or hindering your performance, it may be helpful to seek professional help, such as a psychologist or a counselor. 7. **Develop a healthy response to failure and mistake making**: High achievers often fear failure more than they desire success. Changing your perspective on failure and seeing it as a learning opportunity can help reduce feelings of being an imposter. 8. **Practice self-compassion**: Be kind to yourself when you make mistakes or face failure. Self-compassion involves treating yourself with kindness, recognizing your common humanity, and being mindful when considering negative aspects of yourself. 9. **Visualize your success**: Visualization is a powerful tool. Imagine yourself successfully completing tasks, achieving your goals, and confidently handling challenges. This can help you build confidence and reduce feelings of being an imposter. 10. **Develop a strong support network**: Surround yourself with supportive people who encourage you, believe in your abilities, and celebrate your successes. They can provide positive reinforcement and help you see your achievements more clearly. Remember, overcoming imposter syndrome takes time and practice. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way.

column1: It would be very helpful to identify with you eventual pattern where the imposter syndrome is more or less present. Are there specific situations where you've noticed the feelings of "I'm going to be found out as a fraud" becoming more strong? It seems that shaking this feeling is very important to you. In my opinion, before shaking that feeling, we need to get closer to it and understand its roots. If you would like to get closer to the feeling, you might consider asking yourself questions such: "What is the trigger for this feeling? How does it feel in the body? What is the thought process I engage with after noticing this feeling? All the best. Rossana Mag.
column2: Imposter syndrome is a psychological pattern in which an individual doubts their skills, talents or accomplishments and has a persistent internalized fear of being exposed as a "fraud". It's an unfortunate way of thinking that actually affects a lot of people. Here are few ways to overcome it: 1. Acceptance: Acknowledge your feelings of inadequacy and identify them as being part of the syndrome. Remind yourself that everyone, at some point, feels this way and it's okay to experience self-doubt. 2. Talk About It: Find someone you trust and share your feelings with them. Discussing your feelings can help to dissipate them, and you may find out that these individuals have experienced the same feelings.  3. Stop Seeking Perfection: You are only setting yourself up for failure. Remember that everyone commits mistakes and no one is perfect. Learn from your mistakes and move on. 4. Measure Your Competence: Creating a record of your achievements and successes can give you something tangible to look at when you're feeling like an imposter. It gives visual evidence to remind you of your worth and talent. 5. Positive Affirmations: Using affirmative language can change the way you perceive yourself. Speaking to yourself in a positive way can help to rebuild your self-confidence. 6. Practice Self-Care: This includes promoting mental, emotional, and physical health through exercise, meditation, eating well and taking time for yourself.  7. Seek Professional Help: If you're feeling overwhelmed, you may find it helpful to speak to a therapist or counselor about your feelings. They can provide a safe environment to explore and challenge these feelings. 8. Surround yourself with support: Surrounding yourself with positive, supportive people can provide a buffer against negative thoughts and self-doubt. Remember that overcoming imposter syndrome takes time and articulates self-patience and acceptance.

column2: Imposter syndrome is the feeling that you're not as competent or intelligent as others perceive you to be. Here's how you can combat it: 1. Keep a record of your accomplishments: Write down your qualifications, milestones, successful projects, and praise you've received. Revisiting this list can reinforce your confidence when doubts arise. 2. Self-mental talk: Regularly tell yourself that it's okay to be imperfect, to not know everything, and to ask for help when needed. 3. Share your feelings: Talking about your feelings with trusted friends or mentors can help you realize that imposter syndrome is a common experience. 4. Acceptance: Accept that everyone, no matter how successful, experiences feelings of doubt and fear of failure. Accepting this fact is a crucial step in overcoming imposter syndrome. 5. Constant learning: Understand that everyone is learning and evolving. Make learning and improvement your main objectives instead of perfection. 6. Support Network: Surround yourself with people who encourage and believe in you.  7. Seek professional help: If imposter syndrome seriously affects your life and mental health, consider seeking professional assistance like a psychologist or a counselor. 8. Stop Comparing: Constantly comparing yourself with others often fuels imposter syndrome. Focus on your achievements and progress rather than comparison.  Remember, overcoming imposter syndrome takes time and shifts in mindset. It may not happen overnight, but smaller steps can ultimately help change the way you perceive yourself.

column1: I'm sorry you're feeling this way. You've probably read articles already about impostor syndrome, but still didn't get the answers you were looking for; you probably know that lots of people feel this way, that it happens to lots of successful people in professional settings. Not helping, right?Think about people who succeed at big tasks: an Olympic athlete has a defined goal that they need to meet: cross the finish line, say, faster than anyone else. That success is remarked upon, and - until someone does the event better than they did - they are 'the best.' Grad school, however, is not so great at discrete goals and celebrations of success. You got a good grade on an assignment, but what about the next one? You and 6 other people in your class probably got the same grade, so does that make you a success or average? It falls to you, then, to identify ways you are sure you've succeeded. If your grades and peer admiration aren't hallmarks of success enough, perhaps pull your measuring tool inward: measure your achievements against your own progress- ie: I got a 93 on my last assignment, I got a 97 this time! You might find those feelings fading soon~
