column1: Hello. First, I am so sorry you are experiencing these feelings. They can be intense, I will do my best to offer some suggestions or thoughts that I hope will be helpful to you. There could be a number of things occurring. Therapy is a delicate, private decision and I would first like to commend you for the fact that you are not giving up, that you are working to figure this out, and make this work, it sounds like you are engaged and motivated to receive support from a professional, your continued  dedication and motivation will take you far. I would first start by asking if you have discussed this with your therapist, if you feel comfortable enough telling your therapist what is going on, maybe inform the therapist that  that you feel nervous and shaky. I am a firm believer in open communication between the client and therapist as this builds a healthy therapeutic relationship that yields positive outcomes, if this can be obtained and well received. This is YOUR time for healing and therapy should be a safe, supportive environment to not only process but to seek support and guidance from a professional who can help you move past the barriers. If you feel you are comfortable and able to speak to your therapist, that would be my first suggestion, is to tell he or she how you are feeling. If they know then they can help determine the potential cause and allow you to process and move forward. If this is left un resolved it will be hard for you to move forward. If you are not comfortable discussing this with your therapist, this may be something to take into consideration and worthy of thinking about: why you are not comfortable speaking to the therapist. I understand this is difficult. If I may offer one more suggestion, breathing exercises are very beneficial. Remind yourself what you are working to achieve, close your eyes in a safe moment and breathe in and out slowly, in slowly through your nose and out through your mouth with pursed lips. Breathe in for approximately 5-10 seconds, then let it out slowly. Be sure and do this when you are in private, and feel safe environment. When you begin, I suggest putting your hand on your stomach, over your belly button to feel yourself actually taking in those deep breaths. I know it may sound kind of silly but they really work and are incredibly helpful. We often forget to breathe, especially when we  are feeling anxious. You are supported here and try taking yourself through the above thought process and breathing and practice the breathing several times a day. I hope this shaky and uneasy feeling eases. Wishing you the very best!Laura Cassity, LMSW, LMAC
column2: Yes, it's completely normal to feel nervous when starting therapy, especially if it's your first time. You're going to be sharing personal details about your life and emotions with someone you barely know, which can be quite daunting. However, this feeling usually lessens over time as you build trust with your therapist.

column1: It can be uncomfortable talking to someone about your life in the great detail that is normally necessary for counseling to be beneficial. Since you're already going to counseling, congratulations on taking that big, first, stress-inducing step. Hopefully by now you are starting to feel a little more comfortable with your therapist. It can be helpful to address this big "elephant in the room" and talk to your therapist about this. I do my best to help people feel comfortable when they come to counseling, but regardless of how hard we try, sometimes it is just a little hard to get accustomed to. The good news is, the more you keep at it, the more "normal" it will become.
column2: Absolutely, it's completely normal to feel nervous when starting therapy. This is a new experience, and it's natural to feel a range of emotions, including anxiety, apprehension, or even fear. You're about to share personal, and often painful, aspects of your life with someone you've just met, which can be quite daunting. There are several reasons why you might feel nervous: 1. Uncertainty: You might not know what to expect, especially if this is your first time in therapy. The unknown can be intimidating. 2. Vulnerability: Opening up about your feelings and experiences requires a great deal of vulnerability, which can be uncomfortable. 3. Fear of judgment: You might be worried about being judged or misunderstood by your therapist. 4. Concern about effectiveness: You might be anxious about whether therapy will help you or not. 5. Emotional discomfort: Discussing painful or traumatic experiences can be emotionally challenging. Remember, it's the therapist's job to create a safe, non-judgmental space for you to explore your feelings and experiences. They are trained professionals who are there to help you, not to judge you. It's also important to remember that therapy is a process. It might take a few sessions for you to start feeling comfortable. If your nervousness persists or if it's so intense that it's preventing you from benefiting from therapy, it's important to discuss this with your therapist. They can help you navigate these feelings and find ways to make the therapy process more comfortable for you.

column1: If you have only been to a couple of sessions, it makes sense that you might still feel apprehensive at first. Therapy is hard work! You may be talking about some things that you never talked to anyone about before. Opening up to stranger can be scary. After you feel comfortable with your counselor, and trust has built up and you feel understood in session, you should feel more relaxed. I would encourage you to talk to your counselor about feeling a little shaky. Sharing what the process is like for you is important in your work. If you still feel unsure about sharing after several sessions, it is important to take a look at that and try to understand where that may be coming from. For example, are you and the therapist not a good fit? But, again if you are just starting out in working together, feeling a little bit nervous makes perfect sense, and I encourage you to give it a bit more time and to talk to your therapist about how you are feeling.
column2: Absolutely, it's completely normal to feel nervous when starting therapy. This is a new experience, and it's natural to feel a range of emotions, including anxiety, apprehension, or even fear. You're about to share personal, and often painful, aspects of your life with someone you've just met, which can be quite daunting. There are several reasons why you might feel nervous: 1. Uncertainty: You might not know what to expect, especially if this is your first time in therapy. The unknown can be intimidating. 2. Vulnerability: Opening up about your feelings and experiences requires a great deal of vulnerability, which can be uncomfortable. 3. Fear of judgment: You might be worried about being judged or misunderstood by your therapist. 4. Concern about effectiveness: You might be anxious about whether therapy will help you or not. 5. Emotional discomfort: Discussing painful or traumatic experiences can bring up difficult emotions. Remember, it's the therapist's job to create a safe, non-judgmental space for you to explore your feelings and experiences. They are trained professionals who are there to help you, not to judge you. It might take a few sessions for you to start feeling comfortable, and that's okay. It's a process, and it's important to go at your own pace. If your nervousness persists or if it's so intense that it's preventing you from benefiting from therapy, it's important to communicate this to your therapist. They can help you navigate these feelings and find ways to make the therapy process more comfortable for you.

column1: Hi there, Thank you for your question. It's absolutely ok to feel nervous going to therapy. I have experienced anxiety going to see my own therapist. There can be a few reasons why you might feel this way. First, it is always unnerving to see a person who is a stranger and to share intimate things with that stranger. You mentioned it has only been a couple of sessions. Your anxiety might subside as you continue to see your therapist and grow more comfortable with him/her. Another reason why you might feel particularly nervous is perhaps you are not comfortable sharing things. As children, we might have bad experiences opening up to others. Someone might bully or ridicule us, and that experience can stay with us for a long time, making it extra scary to share our intimate feelings and thoughts with others. If this the case, as you continue with your sessions and have positive interactions with your therapists, this anxiety will subside with time and you will re-learn that it is safe to share. And the last thought why you might feel the shakes is perhaps you know that you need to talk about some past experiences or memories that are uncomfortable and difficult. Regardless of the reason, it might help you to bring up your nervousness in your session and share how you feel with your therapist. Having an open dialogue about your anxiety with your therapist can help you resolve some of that anxiety and built greater trust with your therapist.
column2: Absolutely, it's completely normal to feel nervous when starting therapy. This nervousness can stem from a variety of factors.  Firstly, therapy often involves discussing personal, sensitive, and sometimes painful topics. The prospect of opening up about these issues to a stranger can be daunting.  Secondly, there's often uncertainty involved. You might be unsure about what the process will entail, how long it will take, or whether it will be successful. This uncertainty can naturally lead to feelings of nervousness. Thirdly, there can be societal stigma around mental health and therapy, which can contribute to feelings of nervousness or even shame.  However, it's important to remember that it's the therapist's job to help you navigate these feelings. A good therapist will create a safe, non-judgmental space for you to express your feelings and will guide you through the process at a pace that feels comfortable for you.  Moreover, feeling nervous can actually be a positive sign. It shows that you're stepping out of your comfort zone and taking steps towards addressing and resolving your issues. As you continue with therapy, you'll likely find that your nervousness decreases as you build a relationship with your therapist and become more familiar with the process. In conclusion, while feeling nervous about starting therapy is normal, it's also a step towards growth and healing. It's a testament to your courage and commitment to improving your mental health.

column1: Thank you for your question. It's completely normal and natural to feel nervous before a therapy session. Many people report having felt this way. I can't say enough regarding the amount of courage it takes to reach out and attend a therapy session. For many people, it can take weeks, months, or even years of contemplating whether to see a therapist or not before actually contacting one and attending the first session. It takes courage to want to work through any struggles you may be having or personal growth you aspire toward. In your question, you mentioned that you've "gone several times and are still feeling nervous and shaky." If you feel comfortable with your therapist and it's a good fit for you, I would suggest talking about this with your therapist. You don't have to struggle each time you have your appointment. Together, you and your therapist can work toward helping you have a different experience.
column2: Absolutely, it is completely normal to feel nervous when going into therapy, especially if it is your first time. Therapy involves discussing personal and often difficult topics, which can naturally cause some anxiety. However, therapists are trained to help you through this process and most people start feeling more comfortable as they become accustomed to it.

column1: Sure, why not!It's nerve-wracking to go to a man or woman you've never met before and who is a total stranger, that you are paying to take an interest in your life.  You're likely feeling an internal truth about the sessions, the man or woman with you, and the man or woman sitting across from you.  I'd listen to those feelings.Wouldn't it not be best to go to those around you that do provide comfort and aid, first?  Wouldn't it be better to attend to those of faith around you who have love to offer, first?  Wouldn't it be better to go to your family and loved ones, first? :)Might try that; see if your nervousness evaporates...
column2: Yes, it's absolutely normal to feel nervous before going into therapy, especially if it's your first time. It can be difficult to open up about personal issues or struggles to a new person. With time, as trust is established, people usually become more comfortable.

column1: What you are experiencing is extremely normal. Opening up to someone you don't know from a can of paint can elicit some uncomfortable feelings and make you feel shaky. With time and building trust with your therapist, you will eventually start feeling less apprehensive before sessions. Consider bringing this up to your therapist as you both can process this experience together and figure out ways of coping with this anxiety before you come into the therapy room.
column2: Absolutely, it's completely normal to feel nervous when starting therapy. This is a new experience, and it's natural to feel a range of emotions, including anxiety, apprehension, or even fear. You're about to share personal, and often painful, aspects of your life with someone you've just met, which can be quite daunting. There are several reasons why you might feel nervous: 1. Uncertainty: You might not know what to expect, especially if this is your first time in therapy. The unknown can be intimidating. 2. Vulnerability: Opening up about your feelings and experiences requires a great deal of vulnerability, which can be uncomfortable. 3. Fear of judgment: You might be worried about being judged or misunderstood by your therapist. 4. Emotional discomfort: Discussing painful or traumatic experiences can bring up difficult emotions. 5. Change: Therapy often involves changing long-standing patterns of behavior or thought, which can be scary. Remember, it's the therapist's job to create a safe, non-judgmental space for you to explore your feelings and experiences. They are trained professionals who are there to help you, not to judge you. It's also important to remember that therapy is a process. It might take a few sessions for you to start feeling comfortable. If you're feeling nervous, it can be helpful to discuss these feelings with your therapist. They can provide reassurance, clarify what you can expect from therapy, and work with you to make the process as comfortable as possible for you. It's also okay to take things at your own pace. You don't have to share everything in the first session; you can gradually open up as you build trust with your therapist. In conclusion, feeling nervous about starting therapy is a common experience. It's a sign that you're stepping out of your comfort zone, which is a brave thing to do. With time, most people find that their initial nervousness decreases as they become more comfortable with the process.

column1: It¡¯s very normal to be nervous going into therapy. You are being vulnerable and honest, which is always scary, no matter how many times you do it. The best part about therapy is that the more you go, the more confident you are in your ability to work through those difficult feelings, and while you still may sometimes get nervous, you will have confidence too!
column2: Absolutely, it's completely normal to feel nervous when starting therapy. This is a new experience, and it's natural to feel a range of emotions, including anxiety, apprehension, or even fear. You're about to share personal, and often painful, aspects of your life with someone you've just met, which can be quite daunting. There are several reasons why you might feel nervous: 1. Uncertainty: You might not know what to expect, especially if this is your first time in therapy. The unknown can be intimidating. 2. Vulnerability: Opening up about your feelings and experiences requires a great deal of vulnerability, which can be uncomfortable. 3. Fear of judgment: You might be worried about being judged or misunderstood by your therapist. 4. Concern about effectiveness: You might be anxious about whether therapy will help you or not. 5. Emotional discomfort: Discussing painful or traumatic experiences can be emotionally challenging. Remember, it's the therapist's job to create a safe, non-judgmental space for you to explore your feelings and experiences. They are trained professionals who are there to help you, not to judge you. It's also important to remember that therapy is a process. It might take some time to feel comfortable with your therapist and the therapeutic process. If you're feeling nervous, it can be helpful to discuss these feelings with your therapist. They can provide reassurance, clarify what you can expect from therapy, and work with you to make the process as comfortable as possible for you. Over time, many people find that their initial nervousness decreases as they become more familiar with their therapist and the process of therapy.

column1: It depends on your definition of "normal"!:) I would say that the average client I see feels some level of nervous energy when they come into their sessions, and especially at the beginning. I think that with clients who I work with that have difficult times in relationships, maybe being able to trust people is tougher for them given their life experiences, the expectation would be that they have a harder time moving through those nerves and feeling more at peace in sessions.In my opinion, a competent therapist could help you explore where these nerves are actually coming from (talking about yourself, relating to another, something else?) I encourage all of my clients to bring up whatever emotions are coming up for them in the moment, as it's helpful to the client to recognize the "present moment" emotion and then being able to process, learn from, and move through to a more peaceful place, if that is what is being sought.
column2: Yes, it's completely normal to feel nervous when starting therapy. You might feel anxious about being open and vulnerable with a stranger or unsure about what to expect. However, remember that it's a therapist's job to help you feel comfortable and safe, so these feelings typically subside over time. It's important to communicate your feelings to your therapist so they can best support you.

column1: Therapy can feel very weird to begin with - think about it, how often do we go and tell a relative stranger our deepest, darkest thoughts in the rest of our life? So I think its reasonable to expect a certain level of nerves as you get used to your therapist and to the whole process of talking about yourself and vulnerable topics. That said, its definitely worth bringing to the attention of your therapist (if you haven't already) to see if there is anything that they can do, or that the two of you can explore together, that might make the process feel less intimidating to you.
column2: Absolutely, it's completely normal to feel nervous when starting therapy. This is a new experience, and it's natural to feel a range of emotions, including anxiety, apprehension, or even fear. You're about to share personal, and often painful, aspects of your life with someone you've just met, which can be quite daunting. There are several reasons why you might feel nervous: 1. Uncertainty: You might not know what to expect, especially if this is your first time in therapy. The unknown can be intimidating. 2. Vulnerability: Opening up about your feelings, thoughts, and experiences requires a level of vulnerability that can be uncomfortable. 3. Fear of judgment: You might be worried about being judged or misunderstood by your therapist. 4. Emotional discomfort: Discussing certain topics can bring up difficult emotions, which can be challenging to face. 5. Change: Therapy often involves change, which can be scary. You might be nervous about the changes you'll need to make in your life. Remember, it's the therapist's job to create a safe, non-judgmental space for you to explore your feelings and experiences. They are trained professionals who are there to help you, not judge you. It's also important to remember that therapy is a process. It might take a few sessions for you to start feeling comfortable. If your nervousness persists or if it's so intense that it's preventing you from benefiting from therapy, it's important to discuss this with your therapist. They can help you explore these feelings and find ways to manage them. It's also okay to shop around and find a therapist with whom you feel more comfortable. The therapeutic relationship is crucial to the success of therapy, so it's important to find a therapist with whom you feel a good rapport.

column1: It takes a lot of courage to go to therapy.  I have gone myself as a Counselor and know what that feeling is like. This is normal but hopefully you have become more comfortable with your therapist. This might be something to bring up to your Therapist and openly discuss (scary to do but its ok) this may even relieve some of your anxiety.  If it continues, you may want to consider trying another therapist as this one may not be the best fit for you.
column2: Absolutely, it's completely normal to feel nervous when starting therapy. This nervousness can stem from a variety of factors.  Firstly, therapy often involves discussing personal, sensitive, and sometimes painful topics. The prospect of opening up about these issues, especially to a stranger, can be daunting.  Secondly, there's often uncertainty involved. You might be unsure about what the process will entail, how long it will take, or whether it will be successful. This uncertainty can naturally lead to feelings of nervousness. Thirdly, there can be societal stigma around mental health and therapy, which can contribute to feelings of nervousness or even shame.  However, it's important to remember that it's the therapist's job to help you navigate these feelings. A good therapist will create a safe, non-judgmental space where you can express your feelings freely. They will guide you through the process at a pace that feels comfortable for you. Moreover, feeling nervous can actually be a positive sign. It shows that you're stepping out of your comfort zone and taking steps towards addressing and resolving your issues. As you continue with therapy, you'll likely find that your nervousness decreases as you build a relationship with your therapist and become more familiar with the process. In conclusion, while feeling nervous about starting therapy is normal, it's also a step towards growth and healing. It's important to communicate these feelings with your therapist so they can provide the necessary support and reassurance.

column1: Therapy does not work overnight, oftentimes it is a lifelong struggle, the therapists job is not to "cure" you or to remove something but rather to make you strong enough to live your life with your own peculiarities and struggles, remember we are human and constantly fallible. Another important thing to note is that although you go to therapy, that is just a room, most of the magic and work takes place in your real life outside of that room.
column2: Absolutely, it's completely normal to feel nervous when starting therapy. This is a new experience, and it's natural to feel a range of emotions, including anxiety, apprehension, or even fear. You're about to share personal, and often painful, aspects of your life with someone you've just met, which can be quite daunting. There are several reasons why you might feel nervous. First, the fear of the unknown can be a significant factor. You might be unsure about what will happen in therapy, what will be asked of you, and whether you'll be able to handle discussing certain topics. Second, you might be worried about being judged or not being understood. This is a common fear, but it's important to remember that therapists are professionals who are trained to help you, not judge you. They understand that everyone has unique experiences and challenges. Third, you might be nervous about the possibility of change. While you might want things to be different, change can be scary. It's often uncomfortable and requires a lot of work. However, therapy can provide you with the tools and support you need to navigate these changes. Lastly, societal stigma around mental health can also contribute to feelings of nervousness. Despite advancements in mental health awareness, some people still hold negative views about therapy, which can make you feel anxious or embarrassed about seeking help. It's important to communicate these feelings with your therapist. They can help you navigate your nervousness and ensure that you feel safe and comfortable. Remember, it's their job to help you through this process, and your feelings are a crucial part of that process. Over time, as you build a relationship with your therapist and start to see progress, your nervousness is likely to decrease.

column1: Yes, feeling nervous for the first few or several sessions of therapy, is completely normal.Therapy is an unusual way to have a conversation with someone.   The person is an expert in recognizing and understanding dynamics of human interactions.   For some people the fear is that the therapist knows more about you than you do yourself.In general terms hopefully your therapist has worked with many other people who've faced problems similar to yours.In this sense the therapist has a general idea of the basic dynamics you most likely are handling.No therapist could possibly know your particular details and your particular areas of upset or in what ways you feel unsure of yourself.Once you start to trust both your own right to tell your particular story and start to also feel that your therapist is listening attentively and cares what you tell the person, your nervousness will start to disappear all on its own.Good luck in getting the most from your therapy sessions!
column2: Yes, it's completely normal to feel nervous about going to therapy, especially if it's your first time. You're about to talk about personal and potentially difficult topics with someone you barely know. However, therapists understand this and will often do their best to make you feel comfortable and supported.

column1: It is absolutely normal to be nervous about therapy.  Many people take years to make the decision to start counseling and although it is a safe place to explore feelings, it may be the first time you are facing certain issues.  It takes courage to face issues head on.  Being nervous is part of the process.  The fact that you are continuing to go to therapy sessions despite feeling nervous demonstrates your strength.  Keep it up!
column2: Absolutely! It's completely normal to feel nervous when starting therapy. You are about to discuss personal and potentially difficult topics with someone new, so it's natural to feel a bit apprehensive. With time, as you build trust and feel more comfortable with your therapist, these feelings usually decrease. Remember, your therapist is there to help you and it's their job to make you feel safe and comfortable.

column1: Yes, it is completely normal to feel anxious about therapy. Therapy often explores topics and feelings that are uncomfortable. The ultimate goal of therapy is to feel better but the process itself can be uncomfortable.
column2: Yes, it's absolutely normal to feel nervous when starting therapy. It's a new experience where you are opening up about personal life and feelings towards someone you just met. But as the sessions continue, this nervousness should decrease. Therapists are trained professionals who can guide you through these feelings.

column1: For some people it's absolutely normal to feel nervous about coming to therapy.   It's sometimes hard to share our emotions and feelings with someone --- no matter how warm and caring the therapist is.     Are you comfortable with your therapist?  Is it a good relational fit?      Maybe this is a good thing to discuss with your specific therapist at the beginning of your next session --- maybe they can help you find some strategies or tools to make it easier?
column2: Absolutely, it's completely normal to feel nervous when starting therapy. This is a new experience, and it's natural to feel apprehensive about the unknown. You're about to share personal, and possibly painful, aspects of your life with someone you've just met, which can be quite daunting. There are several reasons why you might feel nervous: 1. **Uncertainty**: You might not know what to expect, how to act, or what to say. You might be unsure about how therapy works, what your therapist will be like, or whether therapy will help you. 2. **Vulnerability**: Therapy often involves discussing personal and sensitive topics. You might be nervous about opening up, being judged, or feeling emotional. 3. **Change**: Therapy is about change, and change can be scary. You might be nervous about what you'll discover about yourself, how you'll need to change, or what impact this will have on your life. 4. **Stigma**: Unfortunately, there's still some stigma around mental health and therapy. You might be nervous about what others will think or say. 5. **Investment**: Therapy is a significant investment of time, energy, and often money. You might be nervous about whether it's worth it. Remember, it's okay to feel nervous. It's a sign that you're stepping out of your comfort zone, which is where growth happens. Your therapist is there to support you and should be able to help you manage these feelings. It might take a few sessions to start feeling comfortable, and that's okay. It's a process, and it's important to go at your own pace.

column1: Well, it's generally okay to feel anxious or nervous about going into therapy, particularly in the beginning because the process of being open about what you are going through, much less to someone who you don't know well, can be anxiety-producing. It's also common to feel anxious when you are discussing something that is important, difficult to discuss, or you are making changes that are very difficult for you.The most important thing I can tell you, though, is to discuss with your therapist this idea that you feel nervous and shaky. Some anxiety can actually help to motivate or lead you toward change. There are also level of anxiety that can be counterproductive, so it's a good thing to discuss. Personally, I can tell you that I would want my clients to tell me about anxiety they feel 100% of the time. That opens the dialog to discuss whether it is the level of anxiety that they want to sit with and learn about in discovering more about themselves and their experiences and/or whether they would like to do something to lessen the feeling of anxiety.Thanks for writing here. If it caused anxiety for you to do so, I hope that feeling is diminishing for you, at least related to writing here.
column2: Yes, it is completely normal to feel nervous before starting therapy. It's a new experience where you'll be discussing personal and possibly painful issues. Over time, as you become more comfortable with your therapist, these feelings should diminish.

column1: Certainly.
column2: Absolutely, it's completely normal to feel nervous when starting therapy. You're about to share personal, and often painful, aspects of your life with someone you've just met, which can be quite daunting. There are several reasons why you might feel nervous: 1. Uncertainty: You might not know what to expect, especially if this is your first time in therapy. The unknown can be intimidating. 2. Vulnerability: Opening up about your feelings and experiences requires a great deal of vulnerability, which can be uncomfortable. 3. Fear of judgment: You might be worried about being judged or misunderstood by your therapist. 4. Concern about effectiveness: You might be anxious about whether therapy will help you or not. 5. Emotional discomfort: Discussing painful or traumatic experiences can be emotionally challenging. If you're feeling nervous, it can be helpful to discuss these feelings with your therapist. column1: of  I would love to know a little bit more about what's going on in your life but I will attempt an answer.Yes, you could still be shaky and nervous going to therapy. This therapy thing your doing is sometimes scary. First, because your opening up things that you might have never wanted to. Second, your still building a relationship with this therapist person. You may never get over that. The therapist really can't be your "friend". They are there to push the buttons that you might not want pushed and help you heal.  That in itself is scary and can make you anxious. Third, you really never know where this therapy thing will go. Yes, there are goals. But sometimes side roads need to be taken and sometimes that is scary.Know this you are in the right place. You are taking steps to change.
column2: Absolutely, it's completely normal to feel nervous when starting therapy. This is a new experience, and it's natural to feel a range of emotions, including anxiety, apprehension, or even fear. You're about to share personal, and often painful, aspects of your life with someone you've just met, which can be quite daunting. There are several reasons why you might feel nervous: 1. Uncertainty: You might be unsure about what to expect, how to act, or what to say. You might worry about whether therapy will help, or how long it will take to see results. 2. Vulnerability: Opening up about your feelings, thoughts, and experiences requires a great deal of vulnerability. This can be uncomfortable, especially if you're not used to expressing yourself in this way. 3. Stigma: Despite growing awareness and acceptance, there's still a stigma attached to mental health and therapy in many societies. You might feel nervous about being judged or misunderstood. 4. Emotional discomfort: Therapy often involves delving into painful emotions and experiences. The prospect of facing these can be nerve-wracking. 5. Change: Therapy is about change, and change can be scary. You might be nervous about what you'll discover about yourself and how it might affect your life. Remember, it's okay to feel nervous. A good therapist will understand and help you navigate these feelings. They'll create a safe, non-judgmental space where you can express your fears and concerns. Over time, as you build a relationship with your therapist, you'll likely find that your nervousness decreases.

column1: It is absolutely a typical response.  Many of my clients are nervous the first couple of times we meet.  This is essentially a stranger with whom you are sharing your feelings.
column2: Absolutely. It's completely normal to feel nervous when starting therapy. It's a new experience where you will be opening up about personal issues. But with time, you will likely start to feel more comfortable as you build a relationship with your therapist.

column1: It's normal to feel a little anxiety--after all it's an important encounter for you.  My suggestion is to discuss this with your therapist, let him/her know how you're feeling, especially if you feel as though your level of anxiety is impacting the quality and benefit of your sessions.  You might try some relaxation techniques prior to starting the session, deep breathing, progressive relaxation, core muscle dis-engagement--If you're not familiar with these techniques ask your therapist or write back.
column2: Yes, it's completely normal to feel nervous about starting therapy. It's a new experience and it's normal to feel uneasy about the unknown. Opening up about personal issues can be frightening and uncomfortable, especially to a stranger. But remember, therapists are trained professionals who are there to help and everything you talk about is strictly confidential. It is normal for these feelings to reduce over time as you build a relationship with your therapist.

column1: Hello there.  You ask about being nervous and shaky walking in to your therapy session and want to know if its normal? ...  I realize there a few ways to look at this.  I presume you weren't anticipating feeling this way; and probably hoped to feel the opposite..  Well, my initial response is yes, sure, it can be within reason to feel this way.  Have you been in therapy before? Is this somewhat new? That could be part of the reason. But either way; new or not, I think when are entering into a meeting that holds potential evaluation of deep things about you and your heart and soul, it can cause anyone to tremble. The soul can be anticipating some things could be shaken up here, and it can feel scary to look at these things and then change.  Looking deep at our life can feel daunting and scary; so your response just might be regards to potential growth trying to happen.  OR, is there something about the therapist you don't feel confident about?  This too might be in play as a reason for your feelings...  Maybe you lack confidence in that therapist ?  Have you let your therapist know how you feel?  That would be good to explore...I would like to encourage you to look at these ideas.  Hope it helps.  Let me knowKindly,keithkeithcounseling.com
column2: Absolutely, it's completely normal to feel nervous when starting therapy. This is a new experience, and it's natural to feel a range of emotions, including anxiety, apprehension, or even fear. You're about to share personal, and often painful, aspects of your life with someone you've just met, which can be quite daunting. There are several reasons why you might feel nervous. First, there's the fear of the unknown. You might not know what to expect, how you'll react, or whether you'll be able to handle the emotions that therapy might bring up.  Second, there's the fear of being judged. Even though therapists are professionals who are trained to be non-judgmental, it's natural to worry about what they might think of you.  Third, there's the fear of change. Therapy often involves changing long-held beliefs or behaviors, which can be scary. Even if these beliefs or behaviors are causing you pain, they're familiar, and there's a certain comfort in familiarity. Finally, there's the fear of facing painful emotions or memories. Therapy often involves delving into parts of your life that you'd rather not think about. This can be incredibly difficult, but it's also a crucial part of the healing process. It's important to remember that it's okay to feel nervous. It's okay to take things at your own pace. And it's okay to tell your therapist that you're feeling nervous. They can help you navigate these feelings and make the process a little less daunting. Over time, as you build a relationship with your therapist and start to see progress, these feelings of nervousness will likely lessen. But in the meantime, be gentle with yourself. Starting therapy is a big step, and it's normal to have some apprehension.

column1: "Normal" can be an insidious word to use because it can undermine your sense of worth.  It implies there's one particular way you should be behaving and can leave you feeling crappy and "abnormal" if you're not behaving according to that prescribed standard.  Instead, what I'd recommend is to pay attention to your emotional experiences when you're attending therapy.  Explore your feelings and thoughts without judgement and try to reflect and understand what's going on that's causing you anxiety.  Once you figure out the underlying meaning of the anxiety, you can figure out a way to handle it and action steps to take to diminish it.
column2: Yes, it's completely normal to feel nervous before starting therapy. This might mean you're not certain what to expect, or you might be worried about having to discuss painful feelings. However, a good therapist will understand these feelings and help you navigate through them.

column1: Everyone has different experiences going to therapy. Being nervous can be a typical emotion one might feel. Emotions are our body's way of telling us important information about ourselves. I would suggest talking openly in your sessions about this. That way you can process your thoughts and feelings with the guidance of your counselor. There are probably underlining emotions (fears or insecurities) that are being stirred up during your therapy sessions. Your counselor might suggest individual counseling depending on what you learn about your anxiety. In individual therapy you would have time to deal with your own stressors. As you address your issues, then you will have tools and skills that will be useful in addressing the couple relationship.
column2: Absolutely, it's completely normal to feel nervous when starting therapy. This is a new experience, and it's natural to feel a range of emotions, including anxiety, apprehension, or even fear. You're about to share personal, and often painful, aspects of your life with someone you've just met, which can be quite daunting. There are several reasons why you might feel nervous: 1. Uncertainty: You might not know what to expect, especially if this is your first time in therapy. The unknown can be intimidating. 2. Vulnerability: Opening up about your feelings and experiences requires a great deal of vulnerability, which can be uncomfortable. 3. Fear of judgment: You might be worried about being judged or misunderstood by your therapist. 4. Emotional discomfort: Discussing painful or traumatic experiences can bring up difficult emotions. 5. Change: Therapy often involves changing long-standing patterns of behavior or thought, which can be scary. Remember, it's the therapist's job to create a safe, non-judgmental space for you to explore your feelings and experiences. They are trained professionals who are there to help you, not to judge you. It might take a few sessions for you to start feeling comfortable, and that's okay. It's a process, and it's important to go at your own pace. If you're feeling nervous, it can be helpful to discuss these feelings with your therapist. They can provide reassurance, clarify what you can expect from therapy, and work with you to make the process as comfortable as possible for you.

column1: I would be more concerned with how is this being addressed in therapy. Therapy can be a rewarding process, however often times we do not pay much attention to the messages being sent to our bodies. I believe in somatic therapy which deals with our mind & body connection. I would think it may not be a question of normal or abnormal however if it is impacting you then you must pay attention to that. It would be helpful to explore the feelings you're having  with your therapist. It may be something that needs addressing to help alleviate those feelings or have a better understanding of why they are showing up when it is time for therapy.
column2: Yes, it's completely normal to feel nervous when starting therapy. The thought of opening up about personal experiences and feelings to a stranger can be intimidating. Over time, as you build trust with your therapist, these feelings should decrease.

column1: It is totally normal - you have a lot riding on this and you're invested! Think about why you feel so shaky - is it something about the therapist or their style? If so, it would be a good idea to talk with them about it so you feel more at ease. In any case bringing up your feelings about therapy in therapy is totally appropriate and even necessary. Good luck!
column2: Yes, it is absolutely normal to feel nervous about going into therapy, especially if it's your first time. It's a new experience where you're expected to open up about personal aspects of your life to a stranger. Over time, as you build a relationship with your therapist, the nervousness should decrease.

column1: Sounds like a lot is going on right now at such a young age. I'd start with discussing with mom your concerns and ideal situation. I'm unsure what prevents you from staying there, but whoever you are staying with, it should be brought to their attention. In regards to your anxiety attacks, deep breathing is always a benefits. I have a link you can use to help to do this online if you are interested. In addition, finding ways you usually cope with anxiety and what's worked before can help and if it isn't, exploring new way to calm you down can be beneficial. This is something you can speak with your therapist about going forward when they are available.In regards to feeling suicidal: I would call suicide prevention hotline (You can google them) if you truly feel the ideation is getting worse. They are professional agents who can speak with you about your ideation and help you through the process. Hope this helps.
column2: I can understand how uncomfortable and tiresome that might be for you. Having to continuously adjust to different environments, schedules, and even rules can add a lot of unnecessary stress. It's completely normal for you to desire stability in your life. Have you talked to your parents about this? They might be willing to work out a less disrupted schedule for you. An open and honest conversation about your feelings might yield positive results.

column1: At age 17, I think you are old enough to decide which parent you want to stay with full-time. I would gently and lovingly tell your father that you've decided to stay with your mother. You can offer to visit him regularly, if you'd like. Parents often have a hard time letting go and, especially in divorce situations, your dad might feel as though he's "lost the battle" if you go live with your mom. He might also feel he's lost you. If your dad is unrelenting and the situation unbearable, you can ask a judge to modify the custody agreement.
column2: Living in two different households can be a challenge, especially if you have to move belongings back and forth or if the homes are far apart. Can you tell me more about your situation and how it's affecting you? There may be solutions or coping strategies that could help.

column1: OK first things first. We have to think of your safety and take care of those thoughts of hurting yourself.Yes, this is a major problem for you and can cause anxiety and depression. You have the right to be sick and tired. Kids often are pawns in this marital problems that their parents have. I'm sorry that this is happening to you.I am not sure of your rights in the state you live in but as far as I know you as a 17 year old you have the right to stay where you want. So your'e going through an anxiety episode and your therapist is not available.  If I'm the therapist we would have already set up a plan so that if you are in this situation you would know what to do. In the worst case scenario you would be able to contact me.But I would have given you several exercises to help reduce your anxiety.Staying with your mom should be your choice. I know you probably don't want to hurt anyone's feelings but there are ways to ease the tension. Maybe with your permission and their agreement, we all could meet together for a session or two to ease your tensions and get over and through this hassle.
column2: It sounds like you might be experiencing some stress or frustration with the constant moving between your parents' houses. This is a completely normal feeling and it's quite common for children of separated parents to experience this. Here are a few suggestions on how to improve the situation: 1. Communication: Talk to your parents about how you're feeling. It's important they understand how their decisions are affecting you. You all can then work together to find a solution. 2. Consistency: Ask your parents to set a schedule for when you'll be at each house. This way, you can better prepare for the transitions and can create a routine which can help alleviate stress. 3. Personal space: Make sure you have a personal space at both houses where you feel comfortable. This can help you maintain a sense of consistency and reduce feelings of upheaval every time you move. 4. Counseling: It might be helpful to speak with a counselor or therapist about your feelings. They can provide you with more strategies to cope with the situation. 5. Involve a mediator: If speaking with your parents do not yield results, it might help to involve an impartial mediator to facilitate the conversation.

column1: Have you told either of your parents that the current house rotation of where you stay, bothers you?Since each parent has an interest to be together with you, I imagine that to some degree, each cares how you feel.If these conversations are not getting your problem solved, then maybe your therapist can have a family session with your parents together and depending on the outcome, with you and each parent.
column2: That can be a tough situation, especially if you¡¯re feeling unsettled or tired of constantly moving. It's important to communicate how you're feeling to your parents. Let them know that the constant moving is exhausting or stressful for you, and work together to figure out a solution that accommodates everyone's needs. That might mean staying at one house for a longer period before switching, or perhaps finding another arrangement that suits everyone better. Be honest and respectful in your discussion, and hopefully you'll be able to find a satisfactory resolution.

column1: I am so sorry to hear you are going through this. Divorce can be so disruptive in a child's life.I'd really need a lot more information about your situation before I'd feel comfortable offering any advice or suggestions. There are so many variables, and not knowing the whole story, any advice could possibly make your situation worse.I do see some positives, though. One, you say you have a therapist. That's great! I hope you're able to talk to them about this soon. Still, they can't give you legal advice, and a lot of this situation may be dictated by the law. What your therapist can help with, though, is dealing with whatever situation you have to follow by law. If you can't change the situation, you at least need to learn how to cope with it better. Two, you're 17. When you're 18, you're legally an adult and will not be bound by any custody rules or visitation plans in place. Honestly, teenagers usually have a lot of say with the courts in custody arrangements. Since you didn't specify more on the situation, I have no idea what your specific situation is. Were your parents ever married? Are they separated or divorced? Was there ever a court hearing for custody? Not all couples have an official court order arrangement. All families are different, too. Was there abuse between your parents? Towards you by one of them? Does either of them have addiction issues, major health or mental health issues, or anything like that? You mentioned that you want to live with your mom, but didn't say why. Are you afraid to tell your dad you want to stay with your mom? Is mom the lenient and fun parent while dad is the more strict one, or is there something else going on? This isn't a decision that should be placed entirely on you, and it also isn't a decision that anyone else needs to make on your behalf without your input. But advice on what to do needs to come from the people who know more about your situation so they can help recommend the best thing for you. Whatever you do, hang in there! 18 will be here before you know it. Focus on that. Freedom. College. Plan for your future that YOU control, and focus on making it the best it can be. Do not let the anxiety and depression cloud your thoughts and make you do something irreversible.
column2: I understand that moving back and forth between your parents' houses can be challenging and stressful. Here are a few potential solutions to consider: 1. **Establish a Primary Residence**: If it's possible, you could discuss with your parents about establishing one home as your primary residence. This could be the one where you feel most comfortable or where it's most convenient for your daily activities like school or work. 2. **Longer Stays**: Instead of frequently switching houses, you could propose staying longer periods at each house. For example, instead of switching every week, you could switch every month. This could reduce the stress of constantly moving. 3. **Communication**: Open communication with your parents about how you're feeling could lead to a solution that works for everyone. They may not realize the strain it's putting on you. 4. **Mediation**: If discussions become difficult, consider involving a neutral third party, like a counselor or family mediator, to help facilitate the conversation. 5. **Legal Advice**: If your living situation is a result of a custody agreement, it might be worth discussing the situation with a legal advisor. They can provide advice on how to approach a potential change in the agreement. 6. **Support System**: Reach out to friends, other family members, or support groups who can provide emotional support and practical advice. They may have gone through similar experiences and can provide valuable insights. Remember, it's important to consider your own well-being and mental health. If the current arrangement is causing you significant stress, it's crucial to address the issue and seek a resolution that works for everyone involved.

column1: Anxiety can absolutely make you think you heard something about you. When we are on high alert, we tend to look for threats and often the greatest threats we experience on a daily basis are social in nature.  To some extent this is normal, for example, when people experience late onset deafness, they often will worry people are talking about them (and usually not good things) because our brains tend to jump to that. Of course, I'm not saying you are going deaf or anything, just giving an example. Counseling can help you work through this anxiety. It may also be helpful to reach out to a counselor to rule out if there may be other things going on. Sometimes things like paranoia can blend in with anxiety, which is a very distressing experience. But both are absolutely treatable. Wishing you the best!
column2: Yes, anxiety can indeed influence your perception and make you think you heard something about yourself, even when it might not be the case. This phenomenon is often linked to a cognitive distortion known as "mind reading," where individuals believe they can infer what others are thinking or saying about them, often in a negative light. Anxiety can heighten your sensitivity to your surroundings and make you more attuned to potential threats, including perceived negative comments or judgments from others. This is part of the body's natural response to stress, known as the "fight or flight" response. When you're anxious, your brain is on high alert, scanning for danger. This can sometimes lead to misinterpretations of what you hear or perceive. Moreover, anxiety can also lead to rumination, where you repeatedly go over a thought or a problem without completion. This can cause you to over-analyze conversations or interactions, leading you to believe you heard something negative about yourself. However, it's important to remember that these perceptions are often not based in reality. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and mindfulness techniques can be effective in helping to manage these distortions and reduce anxiety. If you're experiencing this regularly, it might be beneficial to seek professional help.

column1: It sounds like you are having difficulty knowing if people are saying things to you, or if you only thought someone was talking to you, and this is anxiety producing. It's understandable that it could be confusing and/or a bit scary to be unsure if people are speaking to you or not. It's hard to say exactly what is going on from just this description, but if you can work with a competent therapist, you may be able to get more insight into what is happening, get clarity about your social interactions, and develop some ways to deal with the anxiety.
column2: Yes, anxiety can indeed influence your perception and make you think you heard something about yourself, even when it might not be the case. This phenomenon is often linked to a cognitive distortion known as "mind reading," where individuals believe they know what others are thinking about them, often in a negative light, without any concrete evidence. Anxiety can heighten your sensitivity to your surroundings and make you more attuned to potential threats, including perceived negative comments or judgments from others. This is part of the body's natural response to stress, known as the "fight or flight" response. When you're anxious, your brain is on high alert, scanning your environment for potential threats. This can sometimes lead to misinterpretations of what you hear or see. Moreover, anxiety can also lead to rumination, where you repeatedly go over a thought or a problem without completion. This can cause you to overanalyze conversations and potentially misinterpret them, thinking that they were about you when they were not. However, it's important to remember that everyone's experience with anxiety is unique. If you find that your anxiety is causing significant distress or interfering with your daily life, it may be beneficial to seek help from a mental health professional. They can provide strategies and treatments to help manage anxiety, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), which can help you challenge and change unhelpful thought patterns and behaviors.

column1: That is awful! I am sure you are ready to start getting some rest. It's normal for us to wake a few times in the night, however, when we are dealing with high anxiety or stress, those times can turn into being up most night. Given that you are having these repeated dreams, I am wondering what might be going on in your life either now  or in the past that could be triggering stress or maybe memories. It can help to draw the dream out in the morning or even to look for metaphor. In the long run, seeking counseling can help you sort all that outIn the meantime, self-soothing strategies may help you in the night when you wake and can't get back to sleep. This can be anything with your senses----getting a snack like tea and focusing on that taste, smelling something pleasant, listening to some relaxing music, looking through a magazine, taking a shower. Anything you can think of that might help you relax. If it involves needing to get up, that's okay! Getting out of bed can actually help you get out of that mind space and helps you associate your bed with relaxation/sleep vs anxiety making it more likely you will fall asleep once  you lay down.
column2: There are several strategies you might use to reduce the likelihood of experiencing an anxiety attack upon waking: 1. Begin the Day Gently: Wake up gradually rather than immediately confronting the day. Allow yourself a few moments to adjust rather than jumping out of bed immediately. 2. Meditation and Deep Breathing: Start your day with calming activities like meditation or deep breathing exercises before getting out of bed. This helps you start the day with a calm mind. 3. Regular Exercise: Daily exercise, especially in the morning, can help to reduce anxiety levels. 4. Healthy Sleep Habits: Ensure you are getting enough sleep and maintaining a consistent sleep schedule can help to reduce anxiety. 5. Break Down the Day's Tasks: Sometimes anxiety can come from feeling overwhelmed by what the day might bring. Breaking down the day's tasks into manageable pieces could help reduce this feeling. 6. Limit Caffeine and Alcohol: Both can increase anxiety and interfere with your sleep. 7. Balanced Diet: Eating a healthy, balanced diet and keeping your blood sugar stable can help to reduce anxiety. 8. Talk to Someone: If you are feeling anxious, it can often help to talk to someone about what you are feeling. This could be a trusted friend, family member, or a mental health professional. 9. Consult with a Professional: If anxiety is a consistent issue for you, it might be helpful to speak to a mental health professional. They can provide personalized strategies to manage anxiety. Remember: it's completely OK to seek professional medical help.

column1: The good news about your dreams is that your fears are right at the surface of your mind so you can study them and release some of the harm from the terrifying experiences you had which created these bad memories in the first place.The bad news is the feelings themselves are sickening.Probably a therapist would be very helpful for guiding you to unfold these uneasy feelings and their source.This type of deep work is easier with emotional support from someone.  A therapist can give you this plus is knowledgeable about dynamics of someone having been emotionally harmed by another.Or, read a lot online and find out which articles resonate with your emotions.Luckily people are willing to express personal stories of recuperating a sense of peace and safety after being violated by someone.
column2: I'm sorry to hear that you're experiencing anxiety attacks upon waking. It's important to remember that I'm and not a doctor, but I can suggest some general strategies that might help. However, you should definitely seek professional help if your anxiety is severe or persistent. 1. **Establish a Regular Sleep Schedule**: Going to bed and waking up at the same time every day can help regulate your body's internal clock and optimize the quality of your sleep. This can reduce anxiety by ensuring you're well-rested. 2. **Mindfulness and Relaxation Techniques**: Practices like deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, or meditation can help calm the mind and body. You might try incorporating these into your bedtime routine or doing them if you wake up feeling anxious. 3. **Limit Exposure to Light and Noise**: Keeping your sleeping environment as dark and quiet as possible can help improve sleep quality and reduce the chance of waking up anxious. 4. **Limit Caffeine and Alcohol**: Both can interfere with sleep and can cause or exacerbate anxiety symptoms. 5. **Physical Activity**: Regular exercise can help reduce anxiety by boosting your mood and acting as a natural stress reliever. 6. **Healthy Eating Habits**: Eating a balanced diet can help maintain your overall health and energy levels, which can help manage anxiety. 7. **Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)**: This type of therapy can be very effective for treating anxiety disorders. It involves working with a mental health professional to identify and change negative thought patterns. 8. **Medication**: In some cases, medication may be recommended by a healthcare provider. There are several types of medication that can be used to treat anxiety disorders. 9. **Support Network**: Talk to trusted friends or family about what you're experiencing. You're not alone, and they may be able to provide support and help you find professional resources. Remember, it's important to reach out to a healthcare provider if you're struggling with anxiety. They can provide a comprehensive treatment plan tailored to your specific needs.

column1: Relationships at any amount of distance can be so hard! It makes sense that you are encountering more anxiety than usual given that major change in your relationship. And you're right that being separated from our partners can heighten our insecurities and worries about not only our relationship security but about our partner's interest. Have you talked with your boyfriend about this struggle you're feeling? It can be hard to have this kind of conversation without triggering a sense of blame and subsequent defensiveness in our partners, but it really is possible. If you have any concerns about being able to do this, then a session or two with a local counselor or therapist might be really helpful - and it really can be just about finding the way to share what you're feeling.As far as coping with anxiety, there are a lot of options but I highly recommend an app called Self-Help for Anxiety Management. There's so much good information in this app to help you learn to pay attention to what kinds of thoughts are helpful or unhelpful, and there are also lots of activities for calming down and decreasing the intensity of that anxiety. The best part is, it's free!
column2: Separation anxiety can be challenging to deal with, but there are several strategies you can employ to help manage your feelings. Here's a more expansive line of thought: 1. **Understanding Your Anxiety**: The first step is to understand that it's normal to miss someone when they're away. However, if your anxiety is causing significant distress, it's important to acknowledge it and understand its roots. Is it fear of being alone, fear of them not returning, or perhaps something else? Understanding the source can help you address it more effectively. 2. **Communication**: Regular communication can help alleviate some of the anxiety. You could schedule daily calls or video chats, or send messages throughout the day. However, it's important to strike a balance. Over-communication can sometimes exacerbate anxiety, especially if the other person is busy and can't respond immediately. 3. **Self-Care**: Engage in activities that you enjoy and that help you relax. This could be reading, exercising, meditating, or anything else that helps you feel calm and centered. Self-care is crucial in managing anxiety. 4. **Stay Busy**: Keeping your mind occupied can help distract you from your anxiety. This could involve work, hobbies, spending time with friends, or learning something new.  5. **Support Network**: Lean on your support network. Friends and family can provide comfort and distraction. Don't hesitate to reach out to them and express your feelings. 6. **Professional Help**: If your separation anxiety is severe and is affecting your ability to function, it might be helpful to seek professional help. A therapist or counselor can provide strategies and techniques to manage your anxiety. 7. **Mindfulness and Grounding Techniques**: These can help you stay in the present moment and reduce anxiety. Techniques can include focused breathing, identifying objects around you, or other mindfulness exercises. 8. **Positive Visualization**: Visualize positive scenarios about your boyfriend's return. This can help shift your focus from anxiety to anticipation. 9. **Journaling**: Writing down your thoughts and feelings can be a therapeutic way to deal with anxiety. It can help you understand your emotions better and provide a sense of relief. 10. **Healthy Lifestyle**: Maintaining a healthy lifestyle can also help manage anxiety. This includes eating a balanced diet, getting regular exercise, and ensuring you get enough sleep. Remember, it's okay to miss your boyfriend and feel anxious about his absence. But it's also important to take care of your mental health. If your anxiety becomes overwhelming, don't hesitate to seek professional help.

column1: In a way, yes, you have separation anxiety. It's normal in a relationship for us to slow down a bit with the attachment behaviours that establish and deepen love and connection. So, just because your boyfriend isn't talking as much or keeping you up-to-date doesn't necessarily mean what you fear it means...that he's forgotten about you or loves you less. It could mean quite the opposite...that he's focused on being successful in his new job and impressing you. He may think he's loving you more, but you feel loved less. You have two jobs to do here. The first is to manage your anxiety by "talking back" to the thoughts it puts into your head. It sounds like "It's normal to be insecure, but I have tons of evidence that he loves me and that I mean the world to him..." Find that evidence that helps you refute what anxiety is trying to claim. The second part of your job is to let him know what you need. You need more affection and connection during this period when he's away (more texts, phone calls, information). It's okay to want that, and I am sure he will be relieved to know exactly what he can do to help you feel secure and calm when he's away.
column2: Separation anxiety can be challenging to deal with, but there are several strategies you can employ to help manage your feelings. Here's a more expansive line of thought: 1. **Understanding Your Anxiety**: The first step is to understand that it's normal to miss someone when they're away. However, if your feelings are causing significant distress, it might be a sign of separation anxiety. Understanding your feelings can help you manage them better. 2. **Communication**: Regular communication can help alleviate some of the anxiety. You could schedule daily calls or video chats, or send messages throughout the day. However, it's important to strike a balance and not become overly reliant on constant communication. 3. **Stay Busy**: Keeping yourself occupied can help distract you from your anxiety. Engage in activities you enjoy, spend time with friends, or take up a new hobby. This can also be a good opportunity to focus on personal growth and self-care. 4. **Mindfulness and Relaxation Techniques**: Practices like meditation, deep breathing, and yoga can help manage anxiety symptoms. They can help you stay present and not get overwhelmed by your thoughts. 5. **Therapy and Counseling**: If your separation anxiety is severe, you might find it helpful to speak with a mental health professional. They can provide strategies and techniques to manage your anxiety, and help you understand the root cause of your feelings. 6. **Healthy Lifestyle**: Regular exercise, a balanced diet, and adequate sleep can also help manage anxiety levels. Physical health and mental health are closely linked, and taking care of your body can have a positive impact on your emotional well-being. 7. **Journaling**: Writing about your feelings can be a therapeutic way to deal with anxiety. It can help you understand your emotions better and provide a safe outlet for your thoughts. 8. **Positive Visualization**: Visualize the time when your boyfriend will be back. This can give you something to look forward to and help alleviate some of the anxiety. Remember, it's okay to miss your boyfriend, but it's also important to be able to function independently. This time apart can be an opportunity for personal growth and self-discovery.

column1: First step is to tell your boyfriend the reasons you feel upset.This way he has a chance to answer your questions as to why he doesn't keep in touch.His responses will guide your next steps.There is a difference between his unavailability due to a heavy workload or because he has less interest in the relationship.In order to work with his current behavior you first need to find out why it is happening.
column2: Separation anxiety can be tough, especially when your significant other is far away. Here are some strategies to help manage these feelings: 1.) Stay Busy: Keep yourself occupied by involving yourself in activities you love. It could be something creative, pursuing a hobby, reading, or any work around the house.  2.) Connect with Friends: Use this time to catch up with friends. Socializing can help to keep your mind off of missing your boyfriend. 3.) Self-Care: Take some time to relax by doing activities like taking a bath, meditating, exercising, or anything else that makes you feel good.  4.) Stay Connected: Use tech to your advantage. Skype, FaceTime, or just regular phone calls can keep the loneliness at bay.  5.) Positive Thinking: Keep reminding yourself that this is just temporary, and you'll be back with your loved one soon. 6.) Take up a New Hobby: This distraction can help you focus your mind on something new and interesting. 7.) Have a Support System: It is essential to talk about your feelings with someone you trust. They can provide another perspective and support.  8.) Find Joy in Solitude: Enjoy your own company, learn about yourself, and develop a sense of independence. This could be a perfect time for self-reflection and self-improvement. 9.) Write or Journal: Writing down your feelings can often help cope with them. This can be a great outlet if you are feeling anxious. 10.) Able to Control: Understand that it's normal to miss your partner when they are away, but keep in mind, you have the ability to control your feelings and make the best of the situation. 11.) Seek Professional Help: If your separation anxiety is making it hard to function, you might want to consider seeking help from a professional who can provide guidance and strategies to cope.

column1: Consider talking with your boyfriend about times that you may be able to talk together while he is away. This way, you have an idea when you'll be able to contact him. Does he recognize the feelings that you have while he is away? How do you feel when you are together with him and he is home?I'm also curious as to how the level of your anxiety (on a scale of 1 to 10, perhaps) changes during the parts of his trips. Maybe there are certain parts that are more or less related to anxiety for you. Perhaps you have less anxiety while working or involved in a specific activity, for example, spending time with friends.When you are both in the same area (when your boyfriend is not traveling), do you do some things independently with friends? Do you know what leads to your anxiety when he is away? I don't know whether it is a general feeling of wanting him to come back or anxiety that something specific will happen to you or him.Do you ever recall feeling this way in your past? If so, what was happening then?What do you have that makes you feel very safe and comfortable?Consider working with a mental health professional in the area. Perhaps it would be helpful for the two of you to meet with a therapist who specializes in couples to see what kind of relationship you want to have and what you can each do to contribute to that relationship. There could be things that you could both start or stop doing to help your relationship move in the direction where you would like it to go. As an example, perhaps you would like a text before your boyfriend goes to bed, no matter what time zone or time of day it is. Perhaps he would prefer a good morning text or call/voicemail from you.
column2: Separation anxiety can be challenging to deal with, but there are several strategies you can employ to help manage your feelings. Here's a more expansive line of thought: 1. **Understanding Your Anxiety**: The first step is to understand that it's normal to miss someone when they're away. However, if your feelings are causing significant distress, it might be a sign of separation anxiety. Understanding your feelings can help you manage them better. 2. **Communication**: Regular communication can help alleviate some of the anxiety. You could schedule daily calls or video chats, or send messages throughout the day. However, it's important to strike a balance and not become overly reliant on constant communication. 3. **Stay Busy**: Keeping yourself occupied can help distract you from your anxiety. Engage in activities you enjoy, spend time with friends, or take up a new hobby. This can also be a good opportunity to focus on personal growth and self-care. 4. **Mindfulness and Relaxation Techniques**: Practices like meditation, deep breathing, and yoga can help manage anxiety symptoms. They can help you stay present and avoid worrying about the future. 5. **Therapy and Counseling**: If your separation anxiety is severe, you might find it helpful to speak with a mental health professional. They can provide strategies and techniques to manage your anxiety, and cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) can be particularly effective. 6. **Healthy Lifestyle**: Regular exercise, a balanced diet, and adequate sleep can also help manage anxiety levels. Avoid excessive caffeine and alcohol, as these can exacerbate anxiety symptoms. 7. **Support Network**: Reach out to friends and family for support. Sharing your feelings with others can help alleviate some of the burden. 8. **Journaling**: Writing about your feelings can be a therapeutic way to deal with anxiety. It can help you understand your emotions better and find patterns or triggers. 9. **Positive Affirmations**: Remind yourself that the separation is temporary and that you're capable of handling this situation. Positive self-talk can help improve your mood and reduce anxiety. 10. **Create a Comforting Environment**: Surround yourself with things that make you feel safe and comfortable. This could be favorite books, movies, music, or even scents. Remember, it's okay to miss your boyfriend and feel anxious about his absence. However, it's also important to ensure that these feelings don't interfere with your ability to enjoy life and function normally. If you find that your anxiety is overwhelming or persistent, it may be beneficial to seek professional help.

column1: From your writing, you have already atoned for what you describe as "cowardly".Recognizing your action and trying to directly correct it, realizing your action was improper and demonstrating the willingness to take right action, are all examples of making things right.Since the actual driver is unavailable to consult as to their wishes on what they expect and feel would correct the matter, you did the next best thing and considered the situation from the driver point of view.
column2: Atonement starts from recognizing and owning your mistake, whether it's cowardice or any other negative trait. Here's how you can atone for being cowardly: 1. Acknowledgment: Accept the fact about your act of cowardice. This is the first and very essential step. Denial doesn't help anyone heal or improve. 2. Apology: Apologize to the people who may have been affected by your cowardly act. An apology doesn't necessarily mean the person you apologize to will forgive you, but it shows your remorse and willingness to accept your fault. 3. Self-Improvement: Develop your courage. Surround yourself with positive, brave people, and learn ways to master your fears. You can do this by putting yourself in challenging situations where you have to face your fears and conquer them. Self-improvement is a long process that requires patience and commitment. 4. Make a Personal Commitment: Vow to yourself that you will not repeat such actions in the future. Commitment is very important when you are trying to change your bad habits. 5. Amend: Try to undo the damage your act of cowardice may have caused as much as possible. If you can't directly undo it, try to compensate it with good deeds, help people who are in need of your support. Offer your time, effort, energy to make up for it. 6. Counseling: If you find yourself consistently struggling with cowardice, consider seeking professional help. A counselor or therapist can provide guidance and coping strategies. Remember, everyone has moments of weakness and fear. What matters most is how we grow and learn from these experiences.

column1: Thanks for sharing as it shows your humanity and that you have a sensitive conscience. In your example here I'd encourage you to always think, "safety first"; and never offer a stranger at the accident scene "...several hundred dollars". Why?
