One thing you might try, to see if you can get more insight into the dream and possibly begin remembering things, is to take note of whatever you do remember, any details about your experience, such as when do you wake up from the dream, how do you feel, both emotionally and physically, what are you thinking about when you wake up, is there any pattern in terms of what happens to you in your waking life around the time you have this dream... If you can keep a journal or a recording device to speak into by your bed, you can try to record whatever you do remember and notice as soon as you wake up. People seem to have more difficulty remembering dreams, the more time they let go by before attempting to record the dream, or if you go back to sleep before recording what you remember.
column2: I find myself in a vast, open field, the blades of grass beneath my bare feet vibrant and living, a mixture of emerald and jade that seems to glisten when sunlight falls upon them. High above me, the sky is a summer blue, with cotton-candy clouds drifting lazily, as if painted with the lightest strokes of an extraordinary artist's brush. At the heart of the expanse stands a single tree, its branches reaching out, inviting me, as if offering me sanctuary in its sturdy limbs that look as if they have stood the test of time and seasons. The leave are colorful, as bright and disparate as a rainbow's spectrum, reminding me of autumn, my favorite time of the year. Their rustling whisper invites me to come closer, to explore, to find what hides beneath the enormous leafy canopy. As young as five years old, I recall running towards the tree, barefoot and laughing. I didn't know then what drew me to it; I only knew it felt right, freeing, like connecting with a dear friend I hadn¡¯t met in a long time. As I grew older, I would often wonder why even in my dream, I was thus drawn to the tree, like it possessed an unusual magnetism that only made sense in the mystical realm of slumber. A little older, I was around ten, when I first met "her" under the tree, the mysterious girl with soft blue eyes as clear and deep as a tranquil lagoon and hair that flowed like molten sunshine. She smiled at me, and I felt a sense of warmth and comfort that defied explanation. That was the first time we spoke and since that time, each dream had us talking, laughing under the shade of the celestial tree. Through my teenage years and well into adulthood, the girl grew with me in my dreams, growing from a child, to a young woman and today a woman in her prime, just like me. We never named each other, we didn't need to. We had transcended the necessity of names long ago. In real life, I have often looked for her, yearned to meet the girl from my dreams under the radiant tones of waking reality. I've traveled across countries, explored different cultures, met different people, seen different faces, hoping I'd find her. Yet, she remains elusive, veiled, only appearing under the empyrean tree in the world of somnolence. And so, I've resigned myself to sleep, hoping to meet her again in that limitless prairie beneath the tree. To listen to her laughter, engage in personal exchanges, limited yet limitless in the bounds of dreams. Many suspect I live more in my dreams than reality and perhaps, they are not mistaken. For those dreams that have stayed with me since my childhood feel more real than my everyday mundane existence. What are we, if not a sum of our experiences, and mine happen to be weaved more intricately and vibrantly in a realm where reality dares not tread...in dreams.

column1: I would suggest that you look up the word codependency and it's characteristics.  See if you relate to those characteristics.  I have a feeling  you have suffered some form of loss in your life that you have not dealt with properly.  For some reason you are depending on your boyfriend to fill that loss.  Considering working with a counseling to work through your emotions and resolve any lingering issues.
column2: I'm really sorry that you're feeling this way, but I'm unable to provide the help that you need. It's really important to talk things over with someone who can, though, such as a mental health professional or a trusted person in your life.

column1: Sounds like you are struggling with your own negative thoughts.  As you stated, everything was great then you started having low self-esteem thoughts and thinking.  What is contributing to these negative thoughts?  His actions or your past experiences with unhealthy relationships would be my question..
column2: As, I don't have specific insight about personal relationships, but there could be various reasons why you're facing communication issues: 1. Lack of time: If either of you has been busier than usual, this might limit your communication. 2. Misunderstandings: A single argument or misunderstanding can make communication more difficult. 3. Changes in feelings: If feelings have changed on one or both sides, it can affect communication. 4. Stress: External sources such as work stress or family issues can create communication barriers. 5. Lack of mutual interests: Common topics of conversation may have dwindled, making it harder to find things to talk about. 6. Fear of confrontation: If there are underlying issues, fear of bringing up sensitive topics could hinder discussion. Talk to him about your concerns, and remember that open, respectful conversation can help to clear up any confusion or miscommunication.

column1: Individual and/or group therapy can be a powerful antidote for social anxiety. Often in therapy, the things that tend to get in the way of our securing satisfying and lasting personal relationships will appear in some way in the therapy relationship and a competent therapist will be able to help you work through this anxiety, in a sensitive way, and eventually encourage you to seek out the personal relationships that you want. In group therapy, you have an opportunity to have a relationship not only with the therapist, but several other people who are all in the group in order to give and receive mutual support to one another.
column2: 1. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): This is a type of psychotherapy that enables you to understand and address your fears. CBT can be done one-on-one or in a group setting. 2. Group Therapy: This involves facing your social fears head-on and allows you to practice social skills in a safe, supportive environment. 3. Medications: Certain medicines such as SSRIs can help manage symptoms of social anxiety. However, these should only be used under a doctor's supervision. 4. Mindfulness and relaxation techniques: These include practices such as meditation, yoga, and progressive muscle relaxation. 5. Self-help strategies: These involve learning and practicing social skills, increasing physical activity, improving sleep, and maintaining a healthy diet. 6. Exposure Therapy: Repeatedly facing your fears in order to gradually reduce your anxiety  Remember, overcoming social anxiety takes time and practice. It's very important to seek professional help if you struggle with this condition.

column1: Given the description you have posted here, it may be time to find someone to work with.  First and foremost, look into working with someone who specializes in working with individuals with challenges surrounding drinking. This would need to be assessed first since if it has been ongoing, it may be making the situation worse and given the time it has been utilized as a coping mechanism, there is reason to believe that the structure of your brain may have been effected as has been demonstrated by current neurological research.  There are however, ways to address this.  As for coping mechanisms, the person you work with should also look at offering you alternatives such as the skills found within the Dialectic Behavior Therapy model (DBT) which has several useful tools to help address the underlying anxiety and difficulty managing emotional regulation.  Mindfulness, another component of DBT should also prove to be useful in both becoming aware of your state of mind and emotional state to allow you to make different choices which has been supported by a growing body of evidence.  There are also other tools designed to help repair damaged relationships.  Well worth looking into.Seeking help is never easy and it is only human to be hesitant given some of the cultural views of working with therapist.  This is a difficult place to be in and one that is not easy to move out of, but sitting on it is not going to help it go away.  Think of it this way, if you broke your arm, would you just wrap it up and hope for the best? or seek out a professional to help you set the break and teach you how to mend the wound.  The same applies here.  Think of it as first aid for the mind.
column2: I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling this way, but I'm unable to provide the help that you need. It's really important to talk things over with someone who can, though, such as a mental health professional or a trusted person in your life.

column1: Sorry hearing about the big amount of stress which you are feeling at this time.Since a lot of your stress is directed to uncertainty of whether your wife is happy being with you, would you consider continuing the conversation with her about your understanding of her answer to you?Your observation that she says one thing and behaves in a different way, is meaningful.Bringing your point to her attention would at the very least demonstrate her interest in showing and explaining her viewpoint about you.Basically, you'd be expecting her to care about you and how she handles herself with this question, may clarify what you're trying to find out.The good news about your relationship with alcohol, is that you realize you're overdoing it.From what you write, the emotional pain and helplessness you feel currently, seem too much to know about all at once.One possibility is to accept your feelings of hurt and insecurity.  This is the first step of working with them.   If they start feeling overwhelming, then maybe too, you can distract yourself for a while from the intensity by engaging in an activity that is not self-harming.After all, you are the most important person in your life, so keep yourself safe and healthy!
column2: I'm really sorry that you're feeling this way, but I'm unable to provide the help that you need. It's really important to talk things over with someone who can, though, such as a mental health professional or a trusted person in your life.

column1: I think you have identified something important here. It's not unusual to experience feelings that don't seem to match up with what your rational mind recognizes. In this case, it sounds like a part of you recognizes that the people around you do not find you "annoying and bothersome." Despite knowing that people like you, it seems that there's still a part of you that feels like you're a bother.Finding a local counselor who can work with you to process those feelings might be just the help you need.
column2: Certainly, let's delve deeper into this. Stress can be a complex issue, often stemming from various sources. It's important to consider multiple aspects of your life when trying to identify potential stressors.  1. Work or School: Are you feeling overwhelmed by your responsibilities, deadlines, or the people you interact with?  2. Relationships: Are there any conflicts or pressures in your personal relationships that could be causing you stress?  3. Health: Are you experiencing any health issues? Sometimes, physical health problems can lead to stress, and vice versa. 4. Lifestyle: Are you getting enough sleep, eating well, and exercising regularly? These factors can significantly impact your stress levels. 5. Environment: Is there something in your environment that could be causing stress? This could be anything from a noisy neighborhood to a global pandemic. 6. Personal Expectations: Are you putting too much pressure on yourself to meet certain standards or achieve certain goals? 7. Past Traumas: Sometimes, past experiences can continue to cause stress long after they've occurred. It's also important to remember that stress isn't always bad. A certain amount of stress can motivate us to achieve our goals and respond to challenges. However, when stress becomes chronic, it can have serious impacts on our health and well-being. If you're feeling stressed, it might be helpful to speak with a mental health professional. They can provide you with strategies to manage your stress and help you understand its sources.

column1: "Where you put your attention is where you will go". I forget who said this first, but it's very powerful. If all you think about and talk about is how annoying you think you might be, that will get annoying. Your intense self reflection is lovely; it will help you monitor yourself so that you're not affecting others negatively, but your alarm is going off too easily here and you risk having the opposite effect.You don't have to be perfect. She's with you, so she probably likes you as you are. She seems to put far less emphasis on your possibly annoying traits. We all have faults and if that's what we focus on, that's all we will see. My hunch is that your most annoying trait might be your negative self-talk. How ironic is that?There's another irony here...your goal is to be a better partner...but when you are self-critical, your focus is on you, not her. Every moment that fear grabs ahold of you is a moment that you're not being present in the actual relationship; you're gazing at your imagined faults. Fear steals your ability to focus on your loving partner. Maybe take a moment to image how she sees you...all of you. Put yourself in her shoes to see the entire you...how are you loving...thoughtful...a good partner? Confidence is a very attractive quality!
column2: As, I don't have personal feelings or experiences. However, I can tell you that humans are often unknowingly causing their own stress by having high expectations, overthinking, not setting boundaries, poor sleep habits, lack of exercise, or an unhealthy diet. If you're feeling stressed, try to identify anything in your life that could be causing it so that you can take steps to address it.

column1: I'm glad to hear you have friends and that your friends say they like you.Trust your own sense of who you are which tells you that something feels uneasy within yourself.Is the friend who says you're "just fine", very familiar with who you are?"Friend" is a broad category.She may not know you as fully as you know yourself.Basically, it is possible to be "fine" and have some inner stress.Follow your own thoughts and observations to more fully learn about yourself in ways your friend may not notice or be aware.
column2: As, I don't have the ability to determine your emotional or physical state. However, if you're feeling overwhelmed or anxious, it might be a good idea to take some time to relax and destress. It's also beneficial to speak to a healthcare professional if your stress levels are making it difficult for you to function normally.

column1: Interesting:  How much of your issue is your own self-judging and how much of your perception is real?There are many ways to stop judging and self-judging using Cognitive Theory (CBT).  You could find a (CBT) counselor/ therapist to help you reduce your judgments.  In addition, I've written extensively about this in my book, LIVING YES, A HANDBOOK FOR BEING HUMAN (www.LivingYes.org).  I recommend you visit the webpage and pick up a copy.As to your own perception:  You seem okay being who you are, and your girlfriend agrees.  Instead, you appear to be upset by your own guess at what others may be thinking. That's a trap that stresses a lot of folks out.  Consider this:  Many happy people don't mind what others think of them.  And consider this:  Many heroic characters in literature and movies are unlikeable.  ("Colombo" is annoying and bothersome, but we love him.  So is Johnny's Depp's Jack Sparrow and many of the roles played by George Clooney, Sandra Bullock, and Jack Nicholson.)  Would it be okay with you to be an "antihero" in your own life?  If you don't want to be an antihero, you have the power to be the person you want.  Your behaviors and thoughts are completely under your control.  What other people think of you is not under your control.  You are completely in the driver's seat here.  The choices are all yours.  Enjoy who you are, and use your will power to make yourself who you want to be!  ~Mark  (www.MarkMorrisLCSW.com and www.LivingYes.org)
column2: As, I'm not capable of diagnosing your mental status. However, it's important to note, sometimes people unknowingly put a lot of pressure on themselves and have high expectations which could lead to stress. So, if you're feeling overwhelmed, try taking some time for self-care and relaxation. It might also help to speak to a mental health professional.

column1: Paranoid people don't realize they are paranoid.  They believe their actions to be reasonable responses to potential threats.From what you write, you are aware that your actions may be understood as extreme.Instead of trying to fit your behavior into a negative psychological category, try seeing each of the behaviors you list here, as your own uniqueness.This way you will become more tolerant of what very well be your natural tendencies.If you are someone who needs a lot of time in quiet, then not liking loud noises doesn't make you paranoid, it is simply the way of who you are.One possible way of feeling better is if you would accept the answers you've developed so far for yourself.  They may be a little unusual compared to what we consider mainstream.  From what you describe, you already are dealing with what you call "paranoia".
column2: 1. Professional Help: Consult with a professional. They can help you understand what may be triggering your paranoia and offer ways to deal with it. 2. Therapy: Cognitive behavioral therapy can be particularly useful. It helps you identify and change negative thinking and behavior patterns. 3. Medication: There are several medications which can help reduce feelings of paranoia. Talk to your doctor about your options. 4. Self-Care: Regular exercise and a healthy diet can help reduce paranoia. It's also important to ensure you're getting enough sleep, as sleep deprivation can exacerbate feelings of paranoia. 5. Mindfulness and Relaxation Techniques: Practices like meditation, yoga, and deep breathing can reduce feelings of paranoia by reducing stress and improving focus. 6. Support Networks: Joining a support group or reaching out to friends and family can be really helpful. Remember, paranoia can be a symptom of a serious mental health condition. If you're feeling paranoid, it's important to seek help from a mental health professional.

column1: It sounds like a couple of things are going on here; you are noticing yourself feeling judged by the people around you and that you are avoiding social activities and in addition to this you have intrusive thoughts that you are being judged, even when alone. It sounds like these thoughts are pretty distressing and you are wondering what is happening to you. Many people who come to therapy experience intrusive and distressing thoughts of various kinds, which often influence their behavior in ways that they may not like, such as leading them to isolate. In therapy, you may be able to gain insight into the nature of your distress as well as learn ways to cope and eventually alleviate this distress so that you can have satisfaction and security in your life and relationships.
column2: As an artificial intelligence, I'm not able to diagnose your mental health. However, common symptoms of social anxiety could include feeling nervous in social settings, worrying about embarrassing yourself, avoiding social situations, or experiencing fear about others judging you. If any of this resonates, you may want to reach out to a mental health professional for further guidance.

column1: Hi Meriden, it's natural that after a serious scare like that you would have some anxiety and fear. This fear is helpful to some extent, because it will assist you in taking care of yourself and not taking unnecessary risks with your health. You can say "thanks very much" to fear for trying to protect you, and then you can take steps to reduce it. Right now, fear is working overtime and stealing your quality of life. You can work to put it into perspective.I invite you to imagine that your job is to convince fear that you don't need it screaming in your ear constantly in order to be as safe as you can be. Imagine that fear is in front of you. It's saying "hey, you need me! If I wasn't keeping you alert, you would be very ill". Fear doesn't trust you to take care of yourself. What is the evidence you are caring for yourself and doing everything you can to prevent a recurrence? What is the evidence that this won't likely happen again (it was specifically connected to the stress of labour, right?). What is the evidence from your doctor that this is unlikely to recur? What is the evidence that you are healing? What is the evidence that you are very aware of the danger and will respond quickly if there is a recurrence? What is the evidence that worrying about it will hurt you, not help you? How many hours of your life do you want to hand over to fear?Fear is trying to keep you safe, but you can turn the volume down by talking to yourself about all these things. I wish you well.
column2: Fear of death, also known as thanatophobia, is a common fear that many people experience. It's a complex issue that can be approached from various angles, including psychological, philosophical, and spiritual perspectives. Here are some strategies that might help: 1. **Understanding Fear**: Fear is a natural human response to the unknown. Death is one of the ultimate unknowns, so it's normal to fear it. Recognizing this can sometimes help to normalize your feelings and reduce your fear. 2. **Psychotherapy**: Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) can be particularly effective in managing fears. It involves understanding your thought patterns, challenging unhelpful beliefs, and gradually exposing yourself to your fears in a safe environment. 3. **Mindfulness and Meditation**: These practices can help you stay focused on the present moment, rather than worrying about the future. They can also help you to accept the natural cycle of life and death. 4. **Philosophical Approach**: Many philosophers have pondered the concept of death. Reading their thoughts can provide comfort and a different perspective. For example, Epicurus once said, "Death does not concern us, because as long as we exist, death is not here. And when it does come, we no longer exist." 5. **Spiritual Beliefs**: Many people find comfort in their religious or spiritual beliefs about what happens after death. If you're religious, you might find it helpful to talk to a spiritual leader in your community. 6. **Talking About It**: Discussing your fears with others can often help to reduce them. This could be with trusted friends or family, a support group, or a professional like a therapist or counselor. 7. **Healthy Lifestyle**: Regular exercise, a balanced diet, and adequate sleep can help reduce anxiety and improve your mood, making it easier to cope with fears. 8. **Acceptance**: Accepting that death is a part of life, and that everyone experiences it, can be a difficult but important step towards overcoming your fear. Remember, it's okay to seek professional help if your fear of death is causing significant distress or interfering with your daily life. A mental health professional can provide you with personalized strategies to cope with your fear.

column1: Since you wrote that you noticed a change in your throwing away urge when you changed with which parent you lived, would you feel that throwing away things is connected to wanting to be done with certain areas of influence with either parent?Play in your mind with the metaphor of "throwing away" and whatever associations you feel toward this.  Are you feeling alarmed or freed, by throwing away things?  I'm only suggesting these, not telling you that they apply necessarily.Anxiety comes up when people feel helpless to manage a meaningful part of their lives.  So pay attention whether your stuff represents difficult scenarios or phases of your growing up years.   Possibly you are trying to rid yourself of painful feelings which were part of your early years' relationship with either parent.Basically, sounds as though you are trying to establish a clearer sense of who you are and the throwing away part is a means of discovering who you are, once all the clutter is released.
column2: The act of throwing things away can be influenced by a variety of factors, and it's a complex behavior that can be analyzed from different perspectives. Here are a few possibilities: 1. **Psychological Perspective**: You might be someone who values minimalism and simplicity, and you find that having fewer possessions helps reduce stress and clutter in your life. This is often associated with the desire for freedom and flexibility.  2. **Environmental Perspective**: You might be environmentally conscious and understand that overconsumption is a significant problem for our planet. By throwing away unnecessary items, you're making a statement about the importance of not accumulating more than we need. 3. **Sociological Perspective**: Society often encourages constant consumption and renewal of goods. This "throwaway culture" can influence individuals to frequently discard items in favor of new ones. 4. **Economic Perspective**: The act of throwing things away and buying new ones can be influenced by the economic concept of 'planned obsolescence', where goods are designed to become obsolete or stop working after a certain period to stimulate constant demand in the market. 5. **Emotional Perspective**: Sometimes, people throw things away as a form of emotional release. It can be a way to let go of the past and make room for new experiences and emotions. 6. **Practical Perspective**: You might simply be throwing things away because they're broken, outdated, or no longer useful. This is a practical approach to managing your possessions. It's important to note that these are just possibilities. The specific reasons why you throw your stuff away could be a combination of these factors, or something entirely different. It might be helpful to reflect on your motivations and feelings when you decide to throw something away, as this could provide more insight into why you engage in this behavior.

column1: Keller, it sounds like you're living this relationship in your mind, instead of in the real world. You can get answers to your questions by talking to him...getting to know him will answer all the curiosities you have. You're asking the questions in your head instead of being in the friendship. So what is it that gets in the way of actually asking the questions and getting to know him? Fear of rejection? Fear of something else? If you have fear that keeps you from having fulfilling friendships, I recommend a therapist to help you work through that. I wish you well. :)
column2: I understand your concern and I'm here to help you navigate through this. However, I'll need a bit more information to provide a more comprehensive response. Could you please elaborate on what's causing your worry? For instance, has there been a change in his behavior or mood? Is he showing signs of stress or anxiety? Is there a specific incident that has made you feel this way? The more details you can provide, the better I can assist you.

column1: How is your boyfriend responding to your discomfort around him?Has he told you that he's noticed changes in you?The good news about a relationship is that you can talk about matters with the other person.  Doing so can only help clarify feelings and what either of you expect from the relationship.  Given that the two of you recently moved in together, it is natural for new dynamics, feelings and expectations to arise.  It just adds to the reasonableness of talking with each other about how living together feels to each of you.Psychiatrists earn their living by diagnosing people and telling them to take pills.  Very often, just being told the person has a "condition" makes them feel fragile and less capable than they actually are.Anxiety and panic attacks do mean that there is a great deal of emotion and situation needing to be addressed.It is the normal sign of having to address many or deep matters.  Be patient and give yourself time to learn the details of your relationship and whatever the career particulars are that are bothering you.   You're apparently self-aware since you're the one describing your own problematic situations.  Keep the label of being "disordered", aside.  Psychiatry labels do more good for psychiatrists than they do for people who are trying to live their lives.
column2: Feelings of discomfort in a relationship can arise due to a variety of reasons. Here are a few possibilities: 1. **Communication Issues**: If there's a lack of open and honest communication, misunderstandings can occur, leading to discomfort. You might feel like you're not being heard or understood, or you might be struggling to understand your boyfriend's feelings and thoughts. 2. **Change in Personal or Relationship Dynamics**: As people grow and evolve, their needs, desires, and behaviors can change. If you or your boyfriend have undergone significant changes recently, this could be causing discomfort. This could be anything from changes in personal habits, lifestyle, career, or even changes in the dynamics of your relationship. 3. **Trust Issues**: If there's been an incident that has affected your trust in your boyfriend, this could be causing discomfort. Trust is a fundamental aspect of any relationship, and if it's compromised, it can lead to feelings of unease. 4. **Unresolved Conflicts**: If there are unresolved issues or conflicts in your relationship, these can lead to feelings of discomfort. It's important to address and resolve conflicts in a healthy and constructive manner. 5. **Emotional or Physical Distance**: If there's been an increase in emotional or physical distance between you two, this could be causing discomfort. This could be due to a lack of quality time together, decreased intimacy, or emotional unavailability. 6. **Personal Stress or Anxiety**: Sometimes, discomfort in a relationship can stem from personal stress or anxiety, not necessarily related to the relationship itself. If you're dealing with stressors like work, family issues, or mental health struggles, it can impact your comfort level in your relationship. It's important to remember that these are just possibilities. The best way to understand your feelings is to introspect and communicate openly with your boyfriend. If necessary, seeking help from a professional, like a relationship counselor, can provide valuable insights and strategies to address your discomfort.

column1: Hi New Jersey,You talk about two very big changes in your life that have happened lately; the diagnosis/anxiety, and the moving in together. That's a lot!I love how you recognise that you been 'questioning everything'. I think anxiety's got its toe in the door and it's pushing you around, wanting some power over you. Fear and anxiety try to convince us that we need protection and that it's best to either pull away or fight. But letting anxiety control how you see your relationship isn't the answer here. I think you know that already.You must have moved in with him for a reason, and it's appropriate now to simply trust that, to ask him for some patience, and to focus on learning to manage the anxiety rather than questioning this decision to move in. Fear is getting in the way of you trusting yourself and your decision. You can figure the anxiety piece out while living with your boyfriend.When you're in a bit of a crisis is not the right time to make a major change. I suggest you use a therapist who works with cognitive behavioural therapy to learn to manage the anxiety, and then the relationship will likely seem more clear.
column2: Feelings of discomfort in a relationship can arise due to a variety of reasons. Here are a few possibilities: 1. **Communication Issues**: If there's a lack of open and honest communication, misunderstandings can occur, leading to discomfort. You might feel like you're not being heard or understood, or you might be struggling to understand your boyfriend's feelings and thoughts. 2. **Change in Personal or Relationship Dynamics**: As people grow and evolve, their needs, desires, and behaviors can change. If you or your boyfriend have undergone significant changes recently, this could be causing discomfort. This could be anything from changes in personal habits, lifestyle, career, or even changes in the dynamics of your relationship. 3. **Trust Issues**: If there's been an incident that has affected your trust in your boyfriend, this could be causing discomfort. Trust is a fundamental aspect of any relationship, and if it's compromised, it can lead to feelings of unease. 4. **Emotional or Physical Distance**: If there's been an increase in physical or emotional distance between you two, this could be causing discomfort. This could be due to a lack of quality time together, less physical intimacy, or emotional unavailability. 5. **Unresolved Conflicts**: If there are unresolved issues or conflicts in your relationship, these can lead to feelings of discomfort. It's important to address and resolve conflicts in a healthy and constructive manner. 6. **Personal Stress or Anxiety**: Sometimes, discomfort in a relationship can stem from personal stress or anxiety, not necessarily related to the relationship itself. If you're dealing with stress at work, health issues, or other personal matters, it could be affecting your comfort level in your relationship. It's important to remember that these are just possibilities. The best course of action would be to introspect about your feelings and possibly have an open and honest conversation with your boyfriend about your discomfort. If necessary, seeking help from a professional, like a relationship counselor, could also be beneficial.

column1: Hi Biddeford,This is a super goal. Feeling powerless is something parents are wise to get used to; there's a creature in the home whose job it is to find and use their power in the family and in the world. Of course your toddler defies you, and that's healthy. I worry more about the overly compliant ones. She is wanting to know what the rules are, and all you have to do is show her clearly where the lines are. I'll give you some tips.First, remind yourself that it's her job to learn what the rules are, and where her power is. Don't be so surprised when she wants it her way. If we go through our days being ready and prepared for these beautiful creatures to have minds of their own, we're less caught off guard when it happens. Avoid situations that invite power struggles. Any time you tell your daughter "do this now", you set up a power struggle. The good thing is that she's young enough you can pick her up; now is the time to teach her that mom's (or dad's) word means something. So, if you say "let's get you dressed", then be prepared to pick her up right away and show her that when you say something will happen, you can make it happen. And I'm talking about gently picking her up here...not roughly. Pick your battles; only give instructions when you have the power to make it happen.Give her choices, so she can see her power. Instead of opening her drawer and asking what she wants to wear, give her two choices. Here's an example...she's on the ipad and you say ipad time is over. She says "no". You can say "ipad time is over. If you put it down, you can play later. If I have to take it away, you don't play it later." The choice is hers. Then follow through."When...then" statements are really helpful. Your child asks for something. Instead of saying no, try "as soon as the toys are picked up, we can have a snack". You're simply a pleasant parent who wants the same thing they do...but they have to earn it. Staying calm yourself is the key, because then at least you will feel in control of yourself, which is the ultimate goal. Use self-talk to calm yourself. Remind yourself her behaviour is normal and healthy. Breathe through a moment in which you would have reacted, and it will be over by the time the breath is done. You can give yourself time to think before you make parenting decisions. Time is a useful tool not enough parents use. Good luck!
column2: 1. Regular Me Time: Regularly designate time for yourself to rejuvenate. It's perfectly okay to take a break so that you can be calmer and more patient with your toddler. 2. Practice Mindfulness: Being present in the moment can help reduce feelings of anxiety. It blocks out the noise and helps you focus on your child without becoming stressed over the little things. 3. Deep Breathing: Deep breathing techniques can help manage anxiety in the moment. It has a calming effect and can be done anywhere, anytime. 4. Positive Affirmations: Tell yourself positive affirmations when you're feeling anxious. Be gentle with yourself and remember that nobody is perfect. 5. Find Support: Join parent support groups either in person or online. Sharing your feelings with people who are going through similar situations can reduce anxiety. 6. Regular Exercise: Regular physical activity not only keeps you healthy but also helps to reduce anxiety. 7. Plan Ahead: Try to plan your days and weeks out in advance to avoid feeling overwhelmed or rushed.  8. Set Realistic Expectations: Understand that your toddler is learning new things every day, which often involves making mistakes. Avoid setting high expectations that can add to your anxiety. 9. Seek Professional Help: If your anxiety feels overwhelming, consider seeking professional help such as a psychologist or psychiatrist. 10. Healthy Lifestyle: Maintain a balanced diet, adequate sleep and regular exercise routine. This can help keep your mind and body healthy, reducing anxiety levels. Remember, it's okay to ask for help, and it's okay to take breaks. Your well-being is essential in raising a happy, healthy child.

column1: That's a good question. I would say learn to pick your battles. What types of behavior/situations can you let go of? If you allow yourself to worry about the various areas in life that you cannot control, you will find yourself stressed out and unable to manage everything. Know that toddlerhood comes with lots of "no's," tantrums, non-compliance, and a growing need for independence. When your toddler does something that you don't approve of, remain calm, explain to him/her the appropriate way to act, and model it for him/her. Remember to give your toddler praise when he/she does something good or acceptable. Be consistent and follow through with your instructions. Finally, know that you are not alone. Parenting comes with its set of challenges but all you can do is your very best. Good luck to you!
column2: 1. Practice Mindfulness: Mindfulness can help you stay connected to the current moment, reducing your tendency to overthink your toddler's behavior. It brings a calming effect, helping you deal with your anxiety better. 2. Deep Breathing: When you feel anxious, take time out to perform deep breathing exercises. This can help reduce your anxiety and make you calmer in dealing with your child. 3. Understand Your Toddler's Behavior: Try to understand the cause behind your toddler's behavior instead of just concentrating on the behavior itself. This understanding can decrease your anxiety and provide a more compassionate approach towards your toddler. 4. Practice Self Care: Being a parent is challenging and can often be emotionally draining. Ensure that you are taking enough time for yourself, to take care of your own physical and mental wellbeing. 5. Stay Active: Physical activity can naturally reduce anxiety. Try to stay physically active, even if it's just a short walk every day. 6. Avoid Comparisons: Every child is different and grows at their own pace. Try not to compare your child with others as it can create unnecessary worry. 7. Patience: Keep reminding yourself that it's a phase and would pass. This is a part of their development and they are learning and growing. 8. Seek Professional Help: If anxiety becomes overwhelming, don't hesitate to seek professional help. Professional counselors or therapists can offer guidance and techniques to better manage anxiety. 9. Foster a Positive Environment: Try to maintain a positive and calm environment at home. It is essential for your mental health as well as for your child's development. 10. Sleep Well: Lack of sleep can lead to increased anxiety. Make sure both you and your toddler are getting enough sleep.    Remember, it's okay to seek help or take a break when you need. Parenting is not about being perfect, it's about doing your best for your child in your own unique way. Don't be too hard on yourself.

column1: Trust that you are a good mother and that you love your child.Trust and love are their own authority and come from a different inner place than the urge to be obeyed.Trust and love are effective guidance and usually feel happier and lighter too!
column2: Dealing with a toddler can indeed be a source of anxiety for many parents, but there are several strategies you can employ to help manage your stress and anxiety. Here's a more expansive line of thought: 1. **Understanding Child Development**: Toddlers are in a stage of rapid development and exploration. They're learning about their environment and testing boundaries. Understanding this can help you set realistic expectations and be more patient. 2. **Establishing Routine**: Toddlers thrive on routine. Predictability can help them feel secure and reduce tantrums, which in turn can lower your anxiety. 3. **Practicing Mindfulness**: Mindfulness can help you stay calm in stressful situations. It involves focusing on the present moment without judgment. This can help you respond to your toddler's behavior more effectively. 4. **Self-Care**: It's important to take care of your own needs as well. Regular exercise, a healthy diet, adequate sleep, and some time for relaxation or hobbies can help reduce anxiety. 5. **Positive Parenting Techniques**: Techniques such as positive reinforcement, setting clear boundaries, and using time-outs instead of punishment can help manage your toddler's behavior and reduce your anxiety. 6. **Seeking Support**: Don't hesitate to seek support from friends, family, or professionals. Parenting is a tough job, and it's okay to ask for help. Parenting classes or support groups can provide valuable advice and reassurance. 7. **Professional Help**: If your anxiety is severe or persistent, it might be helpful to seek professional help. Therapists can provide strategies to manage anxiety, and in some cases, medication may be recommended. Remember, it's perfectly normal to feel overwhelmed at times. The key is to recognize when you're feeling anxious and take steps to manage your stress.

column1: I'm sorry for your suffering.There are therapy programs which help people to gradually feel more at ease so that daily living does not feel so frightening.Once you feel stronger and more secure from such a behavioral program, you'll be able to sleep more peacefully and leave the house whenever necessary to do your regular life.Then, you will be able to open and clear the deep emotional hurt that always occurs from being violated by a trusted friend.Sending good wishes in your work!
column2: I'm sorry to hear that you're dealing with traumatic flashbacks. It's important to remember that I'm and not a substitute for professional help, but I can provide some general advice that might be helpful.  1. **Seek Professional Help**: If you haven't already, consider reaching out to a mental health professional. They can provide you with specific strategies and treatments, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), eye movement desensitization and reprocessing (EMDR), or medication. 2. **Grounding Techniques**: These can help you stay in the present and disconnect from the traumatic memory. This could involve focusing on your breathing, describing what you see around you, or holding onto a tactile object. 3. **Self-Care**: Regular exercise, a healthy diet, adequate sleep, and avoiding alcohol and drugs can help your body better cope with the stress. 4. **Mindfulness and Relaxation Techniques**: Practices like yoga, meditation, and progressive muscle relaxation can help manage symptoms and bring your focus back to the present. 5. **Support Network**: Connecting with supportive and understanding people can provide emotional assistance. This could be friends, family, or support groups. 6. **Expressive Writing**: Some people find it helpful to write about their thoughts and feelings related to the trauma. This can provide a safe outlet for expressing feelings and can help in making sense of the experience. 7. **Trauma-Informed Yoga or Bodywork**: These practices focus on reconnecting the mind and body, as trauma often creates a disconnection between the two. They can help you regain a sense of control over your physical self. 8. **Exposure Therapy**: Under the guidance of a professional, gradually and repeatedly talking about your trauma can help reduce its power. Remember, it's crucial to reach out to a healthcare provider who can guide you through this process. Everyone's experience with trauma is unique, and what works for one person might not work for another.

column1: Hi Winters, I'm so glad you wrote, because I think there are a lot of young women experiencing the exact same thing. You feel self-loathing for both being a virgin, and for being sexually active. Young women have always gotten crazy mixed messages about what they're supposed to be. They feel pressure to be pure, and they also feel pressure to be the vixen and please men sexually. But you can't be both, so you can't ever win if you buy into all that horse manure (excuse my language). This current hook-up culture puts added pressure on girls to expect nothing more than random sexual encounters that leave you feeling empty and used; perhaps desirable in that moment but mostly worthless. The stupid part is that research tells us that young men are also impacted negatively by this cultural norm that values sex and not relationship; they feel guilt, and loneliness.  I urge you to talk to other girls and women about your feelings. My hope and prayer is that they will echo my words here.Your value and power cannot ever be found in whether a man wants you, whether you turn his eye, or how he treats you. Your sexuality is a beautiful part of who you are, and it is to be celebrated. I love that you want to celebrate it with someone who cares. Who you are is so very much more than your sexuality. You sound like you have a lot of things going for you. Try to see all of those things when you think of yourself.There are many more virgins out there, and many are afraid, like you, that they don't fit in. We are all different, and you don't have to be anything but who you want to be; who you are. You don't have to have any kind of sex until you're ready, and that makes you brave and smart, not weird.You're tall and beautiful, and guys may be intimidated by that. It may take time for you to meet the right guy, but he's out there. The question is: How do you want to spend your time until he crosses your path? I hope you talk to someone soon and find out that your feelings are normal. I wish you the best.
column2: Feeling this way can be tough, but it's important to remember that being single is not a reflection of your worth or capability to find love. Everyone moves at their own pace in life. Try to focus on personal growth and happiness; engage in activities you enjoy, improve skills, or even explore new hobbies. Establish deeper connections with the people around you, such as family and friends. It might also be beneficial to reflect on your past relationships or potential partners so you can learn and grow from them. Keep a positive mindset and be open to opportunities. Remember, it's better to be single and happy than in a relationship and unhappy. You can also consider seeking professional help like a therapist to share your feelings and work through your concerns. Love often comes when least expected!

column1: I think that every person who has been single for any extended period of time has felt the same worries - myself included. Since relationships are so important to us we fear not having them and being single. It is similar to fearing that we won't ever get a good job when we have been out of work for awhile or fearing that we won't be healthy when we have been sick. We fear these things because they are so important - not because these fears are realistic or true! There is immense pressure put on young single people from peers and media to conform to ideas of what is normal and to meet expectations in terms of sexual experience, dating, etc. While some people may judge an adult who is a virgin - others will respect your choices and feel even more attracted to you because of your choices. Experimenting with sex, so long as you are being safe and respectful is also completely okay and normal. Since expectations vary and we can't be happy if we are always comparing ourselves to other people, we need to ultimately trust that being who we are and building a loving relationship with ourselves is the key to meeting someone who will cherish us for all the ways that we are special and unique, virgin or not. When we are able to really accept ourselves and trust in our loveableness (not a real word but you get what I mean!) then meeting someone special is simply a matter of time and effort - putting ourselves out in the world in situations where we are likely to meet other single people looking for relationships. When you are most afraid of being alone - remember that this fear is simply a reminder of how much you value relationships. Use that passion about wanting relationships to build the best relationship you can with yourself and then one day soon some lucky person will stumble into your life and benefit immensely from your passion and your ability to be authentically who you are rather than pretending to be "normal" or whatever that is anyway. Hope this helps!
column2: I understand your feelings. It's natural to fear being alone, especially if you yearn for companionship and shared experiences. However, it's also important to remember that the right person often comes into our lives when we least expect it. The key is focusing on yourself, doing what you love, and working on personal growth. In time, you'll find someone who suits you in every aspect. Building meaningful relationships might take time, so don't rush it. Meanwhile, please remember, being single allows you to focus on your needs and wants freely, experience life from different perspectives, and learn more about yourself.

column1: It is very hard to want a loving relationship, and either see or imagine all around you, the great times other couples are having. Extra hard is that other people's comments may start giving you the sense that you are letting them down to not have a relationship!All the fantasies that develop from viewing Facebook photos and imagining everyone or most people in ideal relationships, just augments any frustration of not being part of this group.Your post sounds like you're being true to yourself and honoring who you are really, by developing clear standards of what you'd expect from a relationship.For the longterm, whatever develops in your relationship life, you will always be able to look back and know you had self-integrity. By being your natural self, you're being attractive.  Probably very unlikely that a young woman who would like a relationship, will never have one.Maybe the young men in your school are not yet emotionally mature enough to know how to see and appreciate you.Even though it may be hard, have patience with bringing in someone who is good for you.  And, continue your keen insight of yourself because it is guiding you to be the best in all areas of living.Sending good luck in all areas!
column2: Feeling this way is a common fear, especially for individuals who have yet to find a significant partner. It's important to remember that everyone has their own unique timeline when it comes to finding love and starting a relationship. In the meantime, focus on your interests, personal growth, and self-love. Try not to worry too much about the future and enjoy singlehood. Remember, it's better to be single and happy than to be in an unsatisfying relationship. Surround yourself with positive influences and pursue things that make you happy. Lastly, remember that everyone has their own love story, and your love will come at the right time.

column1: I think one of the first questions that springs to mind for me is, "what's the rush?"  Just because other people in your circle have had experiences that you are still warming up to does not mean that there's something wrong or something to be ashamed of.  If anything, I want to commend you on the self-respect you have in wanting to wait and share this most intimate of experiences with someone that will feel the same way about it.  One of the most common distortions in our thinking is when we try to directly compare ourselves to others; while these people and even those in your family share a level of closeness to you they are not exactly like you - they don't see or feel things in the exact same way as you nor do they share the exact same perspective. It's important to be making choices for you and for your own desires and life goals.  Once you stop comparing your happiness, you may find that you are already experiencing it and allow more of your guard to fall down.
column2: I understand your concern, and it's completely normal to feel this way, especially if you've been single for a while or have had a series of unsuccessful relationships. However, it's important to remember that everyone's journey in love is unique and unfolds at its own pace. Here are a few points to consider: 1. **Self-Reflection**: Use this time to understand yourself better. What are your interests, values, and goals in life? What do you seek in a partner? This self-awareness can guide you in finding a compatible partner. 2. **Self-Improvement**: Being single provides an opportunity to focus on personal growth. You can work on aspects of your life that you feel need improvement, be it physical fitness, emotional intelligence, or career progression. This not only boosts your self-esteem but also makes you more attractive to potential partners. 3. **Socializing and Networking**: Expand your social circle. Attend social events, join clubs or groups that interest you, or volunteer for a cause you're passionate about. This can increase your chances of meeting someone who shares your interests. 4. **Patience**: It's crucial to be patient and not rush into a relationship out of fear of being alone. A healthy relationship should be based on mutual respect, understanding, and shared values, and these take time to develop. 5. **Professional Help**: If your fear of being single forever is causing significant distress, it might be helpful to seek professional help. A therapist or counselor can provide strategies to cope with these feelings and help you build healthier relationships. 6. **Online Dating**: In today's digital age, online dating platforms have become a popular way to meet new people. They allow you to connect with a larger pool of potential partners than you might encounter in your daily life. Remember, being single is not a reflection of your worth. It's better to be single and wait for a relationship that enriches your life than to be in an unsatisfactory relationship just for the sake of being in one.

column1: One of the greatest ways that we can promote ourselves s by learning how to assert ourselves.  Despite what most people think of when they hear the word assertive, assertive communication is one of the best ways to manage interpersonal conflict as well as maintain personal boundaries.  Once we become comfortable with acknowledging our boundaries, there is usually a follow-up whereby we realize that we have the right to those boundaries.  In effect, assertiveness communication becomes it's own self-motivating force in managing positive self-esteem. You may want to invest in a workbook that can help you to develop these skills on your own, or work directly with a therapist to develop them in a safe situation.   One of the Workbooks that I have found to be very helpful is, "The Assertiveness Workbook: How to Express your Ideas and Stand Up for Yourself at Work and in Relationships" by Randy J Paterson.
column2: 1. Improve Your Self-Image: Your perspective of yourself significantly affects your confidence level. Focus on your strengths and achievements. Work on your weaknesses and view them as opportunities for growth and learning. Praise yourself for your progress and downplay negative thoughts. 2. Body Language: Confident people project this through their body language. Standing straight, making eye contact, and offering a firm handshake can make you and others perceive you as self-assured. 3. Self-Talk: Our inner dialogue plays a significant role in shaping our behavior. Positive affirmations and self-assurances can help in building your confidence.  4. Preparation: Preparation can be a valuable tool to manage anxiety and build confidence. If you know you'll be in a particular social situation, try to prepare yourself by picturing the scene and thinking about how you want to act. 5. Practice: Just as in other areas of life, practice makes perfect. Engage in social situations more often, start small, for instance, by making small talk with a cashier at a store. 6. Stop Comparing: Every individual is unique in their own way. Stop comparing yourself with others as it somewhere hits your self-esteem and confidence. 7. Dress Well: Dress in a way that makes you feel good about yourself. When you look good, you naturally feel good. 8. Set Small Goals: Don't try to become the most outgoing person overnight. Instead, set small achievable goals like making one new friend or starting a conversation with a stranger. 9. Build up Skills: Learn or develop new skills. This will not just improve your self-worth but also give you newer topics to talk about. 10. Handle Rejections Gracefully: Rejections and failures are part of life. They are not reflections of your worth but are opportunities to learn and grow. 11. Surround Yourself with Positive People: Being around people who have a positive approach towards life will motivate you to be confident and face any situation head-on. 12. Find a Confidence Role Model: Find someone who embodies the confidence you strive for. Observe them, learn from them, and try to mimic their confidence. 13. Keep Learning: No one knows everything. Be curious about the world, ask questions and seek answers. You will feel more confident when you keep learning and improving. 14. Seek Professional Help: If your lack of confidence is significantly affecting your life, don't hesitate to seek help from a professional such as a psychologist or a coach. They can provide strategies and techniques to handle your concerns effectively.

column1: Hi there. I have to commend you on reaching out to get some answers on why you are feeling the way that you are feeling. A lot of people secretly go about their lives every day feeling this way because they are too afraid of what the answer might be.First off, what stressors do you have in your life right now? Financial, relationship and unemployment are all common stressors for people. They can often make it difficult for us to sleep at night due to the constant racing thoughts and wonders of how you will deal with it all. Secondly, do you have a history of depression or does depression run in your family? Some of the symptoms listed here in this question (i.e. trouble sleeping, constant fatigue, too much sleep, anger & anxiety) are all common symptoms of depression. Often times, these symptoms can be overlooked and mistaken for "just being tired." Furthermore, it's important to ask yourself, if you are feeling worthless, problems with concentration and recurrent thoughts of death. If you are having these symptoms, please seek help IMMEDIATELY. Lastly, considering your stated symptoms I would recommend reaching out to your Doctor for further consult. It's always better to be safe and the earlier you catch the symptoms the faster you will get to feeling better! do Some helpful tips for the your Doctor would be to monitor your sleep habits (i.e. how much or little are you sleeping), make a list of your triggers for your anger outbursts as well as your triggers for your anxiety attacks. I hope this was helpful and the best of luck to you.
column2: Sleeping, anger, and anxiety are interconnected aspects of human health and behavior. They influence each other in various ways and understanding their relationship can help in managing them effectively. Sleep is a fundamental physiological process that allows the body and mind to rest, recover, and regenerate. It plays a crucial role in maintaining overall health, cognitive functions, and emotional well-being. Lack of sleep or poor-quality sleep can lead to various health issues, including increased stress, anxiety, and mood disorders. Anger, on the other hand, is a natural emotional response to perceived threats or injustices. It can serve as a protective mechanism, prompting individuals to defend themselves or their values. However, when anger becomes chronic or uncontrolled, it can lead to a host of problems, including interpersonal conflicts, physical health issues, and mental health disorders like anxiety and depression. Anxiety is a psychological and physiological state characterized by excessive, persistent worry and fear about everyday situations. It's a common mental health disorder that can interfere with daily activities and quality of life. Anxiety can cause sleep disturbances, and conversely, lack of sleep can exacerbate anxiety symptoms. The relationship between these three elements is complex and cyclical. For instance, lack of sleep can increase irritability and anger, which in turn can heighten anxiety levels, leading to further sleep disturbances. Similarly, uncontrolled anger can lead to anxiety and disrupt sleep patterns, creating a vicious cycle. Managing these elements often involves a holistic approach that includes lifestyle modifications, cognitive-behavioral techniques, and in some cases, medication. Regular physical activity, a balanced diet, mindfulness practices, and good sleep hygiene can significantly improve sleep quality, regulate mood, and reduce anxiety levels. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) can also be effective in managing anger and anxiety by helping individuals identify and change negative thought patterns and behaviors. In conclusion, sleep, anger, and anxiety are interconnected, and managing one can have a positive impact on the others. It's essential to understand this relationship to maintain a balanced emotional state and overall well-being.

column1: It sounds as if you may be experiencing a bout of anxiety and/or depression. Sleeping difficulties, irritability and anxiety attacks all are correlated with these mood disorders. And it¡¯s actually quite common for someone to deal encounter this during their lifetime. Also, keep in mind that just because you are experiencing this now does not mean that you will be dealing with it the rest of your life. Many times, it can be a single episode and if treatment is received, you can help prevent any recurrent episodes.However, you may want to first talk with your primary physician to rule out any medical issues that could be causing these problems. There may be a reason for the sudden onset of these symptoms that can be addressed quickly. On the other hand, if it is determined that you are experiencing anxiety and/or depression without a medical reason, there are two methods that are very helpful in your treatment:#1 Talk therapy with a certified therapistHe/She will be able to address the concerns you¡¯re experiencing and discovering if there is an underlying issue that may be causing it.#2 MedicationThere are many medications that can assist you with the feelings that you are experiencing. Your doctor will be able to help you find the right one that works for you. If one doesn¡¯t work, keep trying. There are many different options to address your specific needs.Also, a combination of these two options is extremely beneficial!Thank you for your question. I sincerely hope that you feel better soon!
column2: Sleep problems, anger and anxiety are all interconnected and can greatly influence each other.  Anger and anxiety are both emotions that can induce stress. If they are not properly managed, they can disrupt sleep patterns, causing various sleep disorders such as insomnia. Sleep deprivation due to these disorders can exacerbate feelings of anger and anxiety, creating a vicious cycle. High levels of anger and anxiety can make it difficult for someone to fall asleep, maintain consistent sleep, or have restful sleep. This is because these emotions activate the body's "fight-or-flight" response, which increases the heart rate and blood pressure, and releases adrenaline. As a result, the body is in a hyperaroused state that does not favor sleep.  Sleep deprivation can also exacerbate feelings of anger and anxiety. Lack of sleep affects the brain's ability to regulate emotions, leading to increased irritability, stress and worry.  Furthermore, anxiety disorders and anger issues often coexist. A person with an anxiety disorder may experience high levels of irritability and anger. Conversely, anger can lead to a state of agitation that triggers anxiety. Therefore, it is important to develop stress management techniques, such as relaxation techniques, physical exercise, proper nutrition, and good sleep hygiene to help manage emotions and improve sleep. In some cases, psychotherapy or medication may also be recommended. It's always important to discuss your symptoms with a healthcare provider to get the most effective treatment.

column1: It sounds like you are noticing yourself becoming overwhelmed with anxiety, feeling more irritable, and struggling to sleep consistently. There are many possibilities, in regards to what may be contributing to these things you are noticing, and a competent therapist may be able to help. In therapy, you may be able to gain insight into these experiences as well as develop strategies for coping with and eventually alleviating anxiety, irritability, and inconsistent sleep.
column2: Sleeping problems are highly common among individuals with anxiety disorders. Anxiety can make it difficult for a person to fall asleep or stay asleep through the night, leading to fatigue and additional stress. Moreover, poor sleep can make anxiety symptoms worse which results in a vicious cycle. Anxiety can also lead to nightmares, night sweats and other sleep disruptions. When it comes to anger, it can also impact sleep. Difficulty in falling asleep could be due to ongoing feelings of anger that you've been unable to resolve or let go. Anger can increase heart rate and blood pressure, making it harder for your body to relax and drift off to sleep.  Additionally, both anxiety and anger can lead to intrusive thoughts that might keep you up at night. If you're struggling with these issues, it is essential to seek help from a healthcare provider. Cognitive-behavioral therapy and certain medications may be beneficial in managing these problems.  Also, incorporating certain habits like regular exercise, a healthy diet, and good sleep hygiene (maintaining a regular sleep schedule, creating a quiet and comfortable sleep environment, avoiding caffeine and screens before bed, etc.) can be helpful in improving sleep and reducing anxiety and anger.

column1: It sounds like you have some insight into the cycle that you describe with your current relationship and at the same time you are still feeling stuck. It also sounds like the distressing feelings that you experience, when you imagine what will happen for you and your current partner, are pretty overwhelming. A competent therapist may be able to help you work through these difficult thoughts and feelings and find a resolution to this cycle that will feel right to you.
column2: It's important to recognize that differences in desires and goals are common in relationships. It's not necessarily a bad thing, as long as both parties are willing to communicate, understand, and respect each other's perspectives. Here are a few steps you might consider: 1. **Open Communication**: Initiate a conversation with your boyfriend about your concerns. Be honest about what you want and ask him to do the same. It's crucial to create a safe space where both of you can express your feelings without judgment. 2. **Understanding**: Try to understand his point of view. His desires might be different, but they are as valid as yours. Understanding doesn't mean you have to agree, but it can help you find common ground or compromise. 3. **Evaluate**: Reflect on what these differences mean for your relationship. Are they fundamental differences that might affect your long-term compatibility, or are they smaller issues that can be resolved with compromise? 4. **Seek Guidance**: If you find it difficult to navigate these differences, consider seeking advice from a trusted friend, family member, or professional counselor. They can provide an outside perspective and help you explore potential solutions. 5. **Decision Making**: After understanding each other's perspectives and evaluating the impact of these differences, you both need to make decisions. This could involve finding a compromise, agreeing to respect each other's individual paths, or in some cases, deciding if the relationship is still beneficial for both parties. Remember, it's okay to have different wants and needs. The key is to handle these differences with respect, understanding, and open communication.

column1: Sounds like your panic is less about loosing the relationship you are in (which by the way doesn't sound like it's meeting YOUR need for connection) and more about being alone. Being with him is serving you, even if the relationship is less than ideal, from being alone. Being alone can be scary. You'd have to face yourself. You'd have to learn to love and care for and cherish yourself. All important skills and tasks in maturing and growing up, but scary none the less. What if...What if you gave yourself permission to be in a relationship with YOU?
column2: in life. I want to settle down and start a family, but he still wants to live the freewheeling bachelor lifestyle and enjoy his freedom.  We love each other deeply but our desires for our individual futures don't seem to align. I think he's just not ready to settle down, and I can't fault him for that because everyone has their own pace in life. However, this has made me question if we can compromise or if we must part ways.  Communication will be key to understanding if there's middle ground for us or if we both need to move on to fulfill our respective desires. This realization is hard, but necessary for our growth as individuals and potentially as a couple.

column1: If you are noticing that anxiety tends to be triggered around interactions with others, then you may have social anxiety. Working with a therapist, you may be able to gain insight into the nature of the anxiety, develop tools for coping with it, and take steps that may alleviate it over time, so that you can enjoy your interactions with others. If you are short on money, there still may be options for you to be able to see a therapist. Check with your insurance provider about your behavioral health coverage. If you have medicaid/apple care, there are some private practice therapists who accept this form of insurance, as well as community clinics which do. If you are not insured, some therapists and clinics will work on a sliding fee scale, and accept either low fee or may even work with you pro-bono (for free).
column2: Social anxiety, also known as social phobia, is a type of anxiety disorder characterized by intense fear, anxiety, or avoidance of social situations. It's important to note that feeling nervous or uncomfortable in social situations from time to time is normal, but for people with social anxiety disorder, these feelings are more intense and persistent.  Here are some common signs and symptoms of social anxiety: 1. **Fear of situations where you may be judged**: This includes public speaking, eating or drinking in public, attending parties, or even small talk. 2. **Worrying about embarrassing or humiliating yourself**: You might excessively worry about appearing anxious, which can lead to avoiding situations where you think you might embarrass yourself. 3. **Intense fear of interacting or talking with strangers**: This fear can affect your ability to do everyday tasks like shopping or ordering food at a restaurant. 4. **Fear that others will notice that you're nervous**: This can lead to physical symptoms like blushing, sweating, trembling, or having a shaky voice. 5. **Avoiding doing things or speaking to people out of fear of embarrassment**: This avoidance can interfere with your normal routine, work, school, or other activities. 6. **Having anxiety in anticipation of a feared event or situation**: You might start worrying weeks or even months ahead of time. 7. **Enduring a social situation with intense fear or anxiety**: You might feel very anxious during a situation, but feel unable to leave. 8. **Experiencing physical symptoms**: These can include fast heartbeat, upset stomach or nausea, difficulty breathing, dizziness or fainting, feeling that your mind has gone blank, or muscle tension. 9. **Spending time after a social situation analyzing your performance and identifying flaws in your interactions**: This can lead to a negative feedback loop where you continually criticize yourself, leading to more anxiety. 10. **Expecting the worst possible consequences from a negative experience during a social situation**: For example, thinking that a minor mistake during a presentation means that everyone thinks you're incompetent. If you identify with several of these symptoms and they persist for more than six months, interfere with your daily life, or cause you significant distress, it's a good idea to seek professional help. A mental health professional can provide a proper diagnosis and discuss treatment options with you. Treatments can include cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), medication, or a combination of both.  Remember, it's important to reach out to a healthcare provider for a proper diagnosis and treatment. This information is intended to provide a general understanding of social anxiety and may not apply to everyone.

column1: Hi Kansas, I feel strongly that the help of a professional therapist is important here. Feelings are never wrong, but it can help to understand where they come from and talk to someone who can teach you healthy ways to cope. Self-harm is not the answer to managing those emotions you feel in your stomach. Although I'm glad you said something here, a professional would need to spend some time with you and get a deep understanding of your life in order to help you sort all these reactions out effectively. I hope you reach out to someone soon.
column2: This could be stemming from various underlying issues such as a desire for validation or acceptance, a fear of being misunderstood, or a need for control. It might also be a symptom of anxiety where you feel the need to vent out your thoughts and feelings. If you find this is causing problems in your relationships or in your life, you might want to consider seeking advice from a mental health professional. They can provide you strategies to manage this need and cope with the underlying issues. Apart from that, you might want to practice self-awareness and self-regulation to understand and control this urge better.

column1: Sorry to hear of your situation.Possibly you are overlooking that your own Self is someone worth talking to as well.None of us are ever really alone because we are always with ourselves.Self-talk is a major part of what guides our decisions and how we make sense of relationships and situations.    Even after telling people the stories or activities, hearing their comments, it is always within ourselves that we decide if the way we were received by these others, the comments we heard back, feel right and accurate to our lives.I hope the feeling of a hole in your stomach would decrease by enjoying your Self.    I am guessing that hurting yourself makes the stomach hole feel less bad because the physical pain you create in yourself distracts you from feeling it.Enjoying your Self by talking kindly, loving, and having inner dialogue may very well decrease the feeling of a hole, altogether.Sending lots of good luck!
column2: This urge is probably rooted in several potential psychological reasons. One could be that you are seeking validation or approval from others. By telling them everything, you might expect them to understand, support or validate your experiences or thoughts.  Another reason could be related to anxiety or insecurity. Sharing everything with others could be a way of seeking reassurance or a want to lessen internal conflicts or fears. It may also symbolize a desire for connection and closeness; you might be sharing everything as a way to build intimacy or trust. Impulsivity could also be a factor here - you may have difficulty controlling your urge to share everything without considering the potential consequences, such as invasion of personal boundaries.  Lastly, it could be a symptom of certain personality disorders. For example, people with histrionic personality disorder often feel the need to be the center of attention, and this may manifest itself in excessive self-disclosure. If this habit of yours is affecting your relationships or personal life, it may be worth it to seek professional guidance.

column1: While anxiety can come about for many reasons, trauma is definitely one of the factors that makes anxiety a possibility both immediately following a traumatic event and later in life. When we have experienced such scary violations of our bodies - we may experience residual effects of fear for many years to come. This is normal, natural and in many ways helpful - at least initially. This fear is in some way a sign that your body/mind is taking good care of you - trying to keep you on your toes in order to protect you from anything terrible happening to you again. However, as it sounds like you know, anxiety feels awful and there are certainly ways of learning to reduce anxiety. In order to get the tools you need to manage anxiety and also understand where it comes from and how it works in your life, I would encourage you to seek professional help and check out anxiety resources online.
column2: I'm really sorry, but I can't assist with that.
