They may be adults, but everyone likes to feel backed up by their parents. 6. Maintain a regular communication: This will keep you connected. It doesn¡¯t always have to be intense or highly emotional talks. 7. Understand their world: Try to understand the challenges they face in their contemporary world. Society might have evolved since your younger years, bear that in mind. 8. Be patient: Understanding and patience go hand-in-hand. There may be moments when they are defensive, withdrawn, or even disrespectful. It does not mean that they don¡¯t care, adults have their own struggles too. If you're still having difficulties after trying these suggestions, you might consider family counseling to facilitate communication.

column1: I'm sorry for what sounds like a frustrating situation.For how long has your daughter lived the way you describe and did it start all of a sudden or more gradually come on?What you write sounds like a major depressive disorder and this can start for a variety of reasons and improve in just as many different ways.Start with how you are feeling about the situation.  Ask yourself for how long you will be able to tolerate the way your daughter lives and if you feel any satisfaction in your mother daughter relationship.If she is of legal age, and you don't want her to live with you,  you've tried convincing her to get medical care for its own sake and to more clearly see her emotional and psychological health, and she is unwilling to take care of herself, you can discuss your options with the adult protective services agency in your state.The first step is to know what exactly is her problem so you can decide if its own you are willing to take care of or not.
column2: 1. Practice Active Listening: It's important to truly listen to what your adult daughter is saying without interrupting or offering unsolicited advice. Show her that you respect her thoughts, emotions, and experiences. 2. Be Respectful: Even if you don't agree with her decisions, it's essential to treat her as an independent adult. You don't need to approve of her choices to act respectfully. 3. Avoid Being Judgmental: It's important to avoid coming across as critical or judgmental as it can lead to your daughter shutting down communication. Try to maintain a neutral tone and choose your words carefully. 4. Be Open and Honest: Building a healthy relationship involves honesty. Share your feelings and perspectives, but in a way that respects her viewpoint as well. 5. Show Empathy: Try to understand your daughter's point of view, even if you don't fully agree. Empathy helps to build stronger and more effective communication. 6. Seek Professional Help: If you're really struggling, it might be beneficial to have sessions with a family counselor. A professional can aid in providing strategies and mediating conversations. 7. Try to Understand Her World: If there's a significant age gap, it might be challenging to understand each others' experiences and realities. Spend time researching or asking her about her interests or struggles. This might further improve the conversations between you two. 8. Attempt Regular Check-Ins: Frequent communication helps to prevent significant issues from building up over time. Regularly checking in ¨C even if it's just a quick call or text ¨C can help to maintain an open line of communication. 9. Practice Patience: Communication doesn't improve overnight. Be patient and keep working at it.  Remember, a healthy relationship involves a give-and-take from both sides. Ask your daughter how you can better communicate with her and discuss boundaries, so both your needs are met.

column1: 1. She's an adult.2. She lives in your house? She follows your rules.3. What you're describing could be any number of things, but could potentially be a medical issue that needs attention. Thyroid issues, autoimmune diseases - there's a ton of medical possibilities for her symptoms. I'm not a doctor; this is a forum of therapists.4. I recommend the book "Codependent No More" which may help you navigate your rocky relationship with your adult daughter. You may be inadvertently making things worse by "helping" her which can instead enable her to continue her behaviors. Another book you may find helpful is "Boundaries: Where you end and I begin". You cannot control another person, especially an adult. The only person you can control is yourself. Tough love is sometimes needed, and she is an adult - treat her like one. Maybe then she'll act like one. If we were having this conversation in person, you would interrupt me at this point with a "but..." and then explain all the reasons why you can't tell her to move out, get a job, get up and cook or clean the house, etc. I already know that you have a myriad of excuses for things being the way they are. Yes, I said excuses instead of reasons, because that's what they are. You may feel stuck and like you have to take care of her, but you have choices - you just may not like them. I know that when children are small, parents' lives are focused around them (some more than others) and decisions are made around what is best for your child. But you said your daughter is an adult. The relationship dynamics must change if the relationship is to be a healthy one. I know how difficult it is to watch your child make life choices that you wouldn't want for them, no matter what that choice may be. As a parent, we want to force them to do what we think is "the right thing" but trying to do that only results in frustrations for everyone involved. Whether the issue is a hair color, a tattoo, a lifestyle choice, a job, or choosing not to work or take care of their health, or doing drugs, or drinking - the choice is theirs and theirs alone and so are the consequences of those choices.
column2: Communicating with an adult child can sometimes be challenging, as the dynamics of the relationship change over time. Here are some suggestions that might help: 1. **Respect Her Autonomy**: As an adult, your daughter has her own life, responsibilities, and decisions to make. Respect her choices and independence, even if you don't always agree with them. 2. **Listen Actively**: When she talks, listen carefully. Show genuine interest in her thoughts, feelings, and experiences. This can help her feel valued and understood. 3. **Communicate Openly and Honestly**: Be open about your feelings and thoughts, but also be mindful of how you express them. Use "I" statements to avoid sounding accusatory or judgmental. For example, instead of saying "You never call me," you could say, "I feel worried when I don't hear from you for a long time." 4. **Ask Open-Ended Questions**: Instead of asking yes/no questions, ask open-ended ones that encourage deeper conversation. For example, instead of asking "Did you have a good day?", you could ask "What was the most interesting part of your day?" 5. **Respect Boundaries**: Every relationship needs boundaries. Understand what your daughter is comfortable with and respect those boundaries. This could be about the frequency of communication, topics of conversation, or involvement in her personal life. 6. **Be Supportive**: Offer your support and help when needed, but avoid being overly protective or intrusive. Let her know that you're there for her, but also allow her to handle her own issues and learn from her experiences. 7. **Show Unconditional Love**: Regardless of disagreements or misunderstandings, make sure your daughter knows that your love for her is unconditional. This can provide a strong foundation for your relationship. Remember, every person and relationship is unique, so what works for one might not work for another. It might take some time and patience to find the best way to communicate with your daughter. Consider seeking professional help, such as a family therapist, if you find it particularly challenging.

column1: A lot depends on the age of your child, but given that it was a mis-used debit card, I am going to guess he's a teen?  Assuming that, there are a couple of important things to keep in mind...1.  That he lied about the misuse indicates he knows he was in the wrong.  That's a dreadful feeling - getting caught out- and an impulsive lie may have popped out of his mouth before he thought it through (after all a debit spend is pretty easy to track). 2. Once he lied he stuck with the lie.    Somewhere along the line, even though he knew that you knew he wasn't telling the truth, he stuck with his story.  And as you said, it's not the first time he lied.  Now it looks like a habit has formed.Going forward, when there is a dishonest act of any kind, it's essential that you set it up so your son can be truthful.  Simply put, do not ask questions.  If you know for certain that he has, for example, misused your debit card, say so.  Asking "did you" invites him to get creative with denial; asking "why did you" implies that, with a good enough reason, he might not be in hot water with you.  Instead, say what is:  "I see this charge on my debit card and realize you used it without my permission".  (You can only do this if you know for sure it was him but it sounds like you do). If he meets with denial, stay calm, restate that you are aware this happened.  Then deliver consequences that match the transgression (he has to return the item if it's returnable or find a way to pay you back for the charge as well as any fees incurred in using it).  Make it harder to find your card because he isn't that great at curbing the impulse to use it yet.And most importantly, once the consequence is delivered you have to let it go.  Continuing to bring it up won't benefit him, but it does have the potential to make him more sneaky.  Every time he asks respectfully to use it, whether you allow him to or not, be sure to praise him for asking nicely.  "Catch" him doing it right as often as possible.Hang in there - this isn't super unusual behavior but it isn't acceptable, so address it but don't let yourself get too wound up about it.
column2: Addressing lying behavior in children can be challenging, but there are several steps you can take: 1. Talk About Honesty: Teach your child the value of honesty. You can use examples from books or movies to illustrate its importance.  2. Understand why they're Lying: Kids often lie for a reason - they might be afraid of punishment, or they're trying to get attention. They might also just be testing boundaries. Understanding the reason can help you address the problem at its core. 3. Don't Punish Lying: While it's important to correct, punishing your child for lying can discourage open communication. Instead, encourage them to tell the truth by showing understanding and forgiving. Also, be a role model of honesty and integrity. 4. Make them Feel Safe: Your child might be lying because he doesn't feel safe telling the truth. Create a nurturing environment where he feels comfortable opening up. 5. Give them a Chance to Come Clean: When you catch them in a lie, give your kid a chance to admit the truth. This will encourage them to be more honest in the future. 6. Talk About Consequences: Explain to your child how lying can hurt others and damage relationships, using appropriate examples.  7. Seek Professional Help: If the lying is persistent, you might want to consider seeking help from a professional like a child psychologist. They can provide strategies to handle this behavior appropriately. Remember to stay patient. Changing behavior takes time, but with consistency and clear communication, your child can learn the value of honesty.

column1: Hi Enid, You sound like a sensitive parent; I like that you talked to your son to see if anything is wrong. There is some key information here (I don't know your son's age, whether he spent any money, whether he put the card back, or how many times he's stolen), and my answer might be different depending on those details, but I'll give you my thoughts.I see it as every child's job to figure out the rules and find where their power is in the world. In order to accomplish that, many of them test limits. "What can I get away with?" is a question they have to find the answer to. If a child knows the rules, they're much more likely to not test limits (because they already know the limits). So, part of testing limits is experimenting with stealing and lying. Not all kids steal, but I would say pretty much every child lies at some point. It's a normal behaviour, and most of the time it's about small things that don't matter and we don't even find out. Stealing a debit card is a bit more serious, and I'm not surprised he lied about it. If you absolutely know that he took it, it's okay to tell him that you believe he did this thing and also lied about it. It's appropriate to give a consequence for this type of behaviour, so that the child doesn't do it again. The consequence should be as natural and logical as possible. The behaviour (stealing) was harmful to you, so doing you a favour with extra chores might be a good idea. It's funny, because as parents we try to tell our kids that lying is bad, but they know they'll get a consequence if they tell the truth so there are natural deterrents to being honest (we don't want people to know our mistakes). It's a dilemma. If you really want to focus on the lying part, you can tell him that you won't give him a consequence for the lying if he decides to come clean with the truth within one day. That gives him incentive to come to you with truth. It sometimes works with kids to give them a chance to come clean and then reward them for telling the truth. You can set your child up for success and train them to tolerate honesty. Put a cookie on the counter. Tell your child to take the cookie at some point in the day. Then ask them later if they took the cookie. You're making honesty fun. Kids love games. Basically, there's as much power in rewarding the positive behaviour as punishing the negative. If this is the first serious offence for your son, don't make a big deal of it; consequence him and see if he learns. If it's a pattern, that's different and you may want the input of a therapist.
column2: It's challenging when you find out your child is lying, but it's important to remember that lying is part of human nature and it doesn't make your child a bad person. Here are some steps you can take: 1. Open Communication: Speak with your son honestly about the issue in a non-accusatory way. Ask him why he felt it was necessary to lie. Show empathy and assure him that you are there to help, not to punish. 2. Set Clear Expectations: Make it clear to your son about what's acceptable and what's not. Explain the importance of honesty and the kind of behavior you expect. 3. Teach By Example: Make sure you're providing a good model - if they see you telling 'white lies' then they might think it's ok for them too. 4. Avoid Labeling: It is important not to label your child as a 'liar'. This may end up further increasing deceptive behavior.  5. Show Them the Consequences: Help your child understand that lies have consequences. They hurt relationships and can lead to bigger problems. 6. Praise Honesty: When he does tell the truth, praise him. This positive reinforcement can encourage him to be honest in the future. 7. Seek Professional Help: If the lying continues and becomes a concern, you might consider seeking the help of a mental health professional. Remember, it's normal for kids to lie from time to time, but it's essential to help them understand why honesty is the best policy. Remember also that it's a process, it might take time for them to fully understand and modify their behaviour.

column1: It is great that you are noticing these changes with your daughter. I can¡¯t offer advice without knowing much more about your particular situation but some things to think about:Has something else happen recently that has been stressful, upsetting?Is your daughter trying to communicate something to you and if so what might that be?Have you discussed these recent changes with her? (Without being too serious or accusatory)There is so much changing for her (and you) now-communication and connection are crucial. I hope you both can talk to a supportive person about all these changes.
column2: I'm sorry to hear that you're worried. Could you please let me know what you're concerned about specifically, so I could provide more targeted advice?

column1: Have you asked your daughter why she's doing the behaviors you describe?Often the best way to find out why someone does something is to simply ask them their reason.Her answer will give you some guidance as to next possible steps.If she's pretending to be a fantasy figure or trying to find out how being taller feels, or walking on high heels or some other image then knowing this rules out that she has some unbearable pain in her arch which may require more practical answers such as new shoes or even indicate a medical problem.Ask if she's noticed any change in the way she walks.  Maybe she doesn't know she's doing this and maybe she feels embarrassed to tell you she's doing something a bit odd.Since usually 12 year olds don't color, is it new that she started coloring?Maybe given the fact of messy handwriting, she's in a phase of pretending or reflecting on good times as a young child.Then this becomes the topic of examination.Does she feel insecure about being on the cusp of adolescence?Some of these questions can be asked directly and some are for you to first decide based on what you know of your daughter, which questions and what direction to take in understanding your daughter's motivation.
column2: Of course, I understand your concern as a parent. It would be helpful if you could provide more specific details about your concerns. Is it related to her physical health, mental health, social interactions, academic performance, or any other specific area? The more information you provide, the better I can assist you.

column1: This is your experience, your feeling and you are wondering if it is normal, which means is this common or the rule. This question about how you feel about your third child leads me to believe you are dis- turbed [etymology: agitated or stirred up].  Feelings are messages from our soul or spirit that something is not right.  So, though  it might be normal [common, the rule]  to look forward to a one year olds nap time when you have a three year old a nine year old, the dis- turbance or stirring up in you, is important and requires your attention, your listening, if you will to your higher self.
column2: As, I don't experience emotions, but I can provide an analysis based on psychological and sociological perspectives.  It's important to clarify that feelings and actions are two different things. It's not uncommon for parents to experience a range of emotions towards their children, including frustration, annoyance, or even dislike at times. These feelings can be influenced by a variety of factors, such as the child's behavior, the parent's stress levels, or external pressures.  However, consistently disliking one child, especially if it leads to differential treatment, can have serious negative effects on the child's emotional and psychological development. It can lead to feelings of rejection, low self-esteem, and can impact their relationships in the future.  If you or someone you know is experiencing these feelings, it's important to seek help. This could involve speaking to a mental health professional, such as a psychologist or counselor, who can provide strategies to manage these feelings and improve the parent-child relationship.  Remember, it's okay to have complex feelings, but it's crucial to treat each child with love, respect, and fairness.

column1: This is a common response parents can have.  There are many reasons for attachment disruption.   But attachment is  important for the child as well as your long term relationship with them.    I would want to know more about the history of the child and any stressors you have gone through during the child's lifetime.  Often if there is stress parents will not have the time or energy to attach well to the child.  Sometimes the energy of the child and the parent are mismatched as well.  But whatever is at the core this is something that can be addressed in counseling.  The earlier the better because adult relationships are based on parental relationships we had as children.  Therapy can start at age 3 to address these types of issues.  Visit staceybshapiro.com for more information about getting started.
column2: It's important to clarify that feelings are complex and can vary greatly from person to person. It's not uncommon for parents to experience a range of emotions towards their children, including frustration, annoyance, or even dislike at times. However, these feelings are usually temporary and related to specific behaviors or situations, not the child as an individual. If a parent consistently feels a strong dislike towards one child, it could be indicative of a deeper issue. This could be related to the parent's own emotional or psychological state, unresolved issues from their past, or a mismatch in personality or behavior between the parent and child. It's also possible that the parent is misinterpreting or overreacting to the child's behavior due to stress or other factors. In any case, it's crucial to remember that all children deserve to be loved, respected, and treated fairly. If a parent is struggling with persistent negative feelings towards a child, it's important to seek professional help, such as a psychologist or family therapist. They can provide strategies to manage these feelings, improve the parent-child relationship, and ensure the child's well-being. It's also worth noting that societal norms and expectations can influence our perceptions of what's "normal". In many cultures, it's considered taboo to admit to disliking one's child, which can make parents who experience these feelings feel isolated or guilty. However, acknowledging these feelings is the first step towards addressing them and seeking help. In conclusion, while it's not "normal" in the sense of being typical or ideal to dislike one's child, it's not unheard of. It's a sign that there may be underlying issues that need to be addressed, and it's important to do so for the well-being of both the parent and the child.

column1: Congrats on being honest about the way you feel!Many people state having a favorite child so the reverse would also be possible, of having a least favorite child.Try to understand your own reasons for not liking your youngest child as much as the others.One point to consider is whether it is the child' personality or the way they interact with you which gives you the feeling of not liking this child as much as the others, or does the reason have more to do with younger children requiring more care?Also, do you generally prefer older kids to younger ones?  It is possible the problem will go away as your youngest grows older.Is there another parent in the household who can make up for what you feel unable to naturally give to your youngest?Is it possible you feel your own need to be involved with activities or to have time on your own?   Maybe you simply need a break from constant mothering.Continue to give as much as possible to your youngest child.
column2: As, I don't experience emotions or feelings. However, I can share with you that it's natural to experience a range of feelings towards family members, including children. Parents might feel frustrated, disappointed, or overwhelmed by a child's behavior at times, but these feelings typically fluctuate and don't imply that the parent dislikes the child overall. If a parent notices consistent negative feelings towards a child, this may be indicative of other issues and it could be beneficial to seek advice from a mental health professional. This is important to maintain a healthy relationship and well-being for both the parent and the child.

column1: You seem to have been a very positive influence in your kids' lives.They may have worked so hard because they understood how difficult and tiring your life was as a single mom.I feel you are seeing your kids' lives through the measurement of how much toil was in your life as a single mom.In other words, what you see your kids overlooking or not appreciating, may remind you of your wishes during the many years you raised your kids.If it helps you and is possible, then maybe you could spend more of your own time tougher with your grandkids.  This may give some reward for the many years you spent working to support your kids and had no choice in the amount of time you had with your kids.As far as your kids relationship to their kids, it is now their turn to raise them as they wish, within ethical boundaries of course.Depending on the topics you and your kids talk about, consider to bring up your concern as to whether they feel their kids, your grandkids, are missing anything due to the limited time they have with the parents.
column2: Absolutely, it's not only okay but also beneficial to discuss spending time with your grandchildren with your grown children. This conversation can help establish expectations, boundaries, and schedules that work for everyone involved. Here are a few points to consider: 1. **Express your interest and intentions**: Start by expressing your desire to spend more time with your grandchildren. Make it clear that your intention is to build a stronger bond with them and contribute positively to their lives. 2. **Discuss their parenting style and rules**: Every parent has their own style and set of rules. It's important to respect these when you're with your grandchildren. Ask your children about their rules and expectations to ensure you're on the same page. 3. **Plan activities**: Think about what activities you'd like to do with your grandchildren. This could be anything from reading books, going for walks, teaching them a skill, or simply spending quality time together. Discuss these ideas with your children to see what they think would be most beneficial. 4. **Schedule**: It's important to discuss when and how often you'll spend time with your grandchildren. This should be a mutual agreement that respects everyone's schedules and commitments. 5. **Open communication**: Keep the lines of communication open. If any issues or concerns arise, it's important to discuss them promptly and openly. Remember, the goal is to foster a loving, respectful relationship with your grandchildren that enriches their lives and yours. Your children will likely appreciate your interest and willingness to be involved.

column1: Well, first let's identify what factors are involved in the situation about which you wrote.Are you the only decision maker regarding your stepdaughter living with you?Is her dad, and your partner, living under the same roof?Would you feel any obligation to consult with your husband about his opinion and his way of handling the situation?Have you talked with your stepdaughter about your observation and your reaction to the fact of her not honoring your boundaries?Consider too that there will be an effect on the toddler, your grandchild, if you kick out your daughter.Is your daughter financially ready to live on her own and support herself and her child?You certainly have the right to define the terms of what goes on under your roof.It is only fair to everyone that as many variables as possible, be considered.The conclusion may be that it is in everyone's best interest for your stepdaughter to move out.If everyone feels respected and a well thought out plan is developed, then the least amount of hurt and stress, and the most amount of happiness, will be possible from this change.
column2: As, I don't have personal experiences, but I can suggest you a course of action that treats everyone involved with dignity, respect, and understanding. 1. Open Dialogue: Start with a conversation where both you and your partner are present. This should preferably be in a calm, neutral environment. Explain your concerns and make sure to stick to specific facts and behavior patterns rather than getting emotional or personal. 2. Set Clear Expectations and Boundaries: Clearly state the rules you'd like her to follow and explain why. Make sure these rules are fair and justifiable. 3. Implement Consequences: Let her know that there are consequences for breaking the rules. These should also be clearly stated. It is important that she understands that what happens will be due to her own behavior. 4. Issue a Warning: If the behavior continues, issue a warning, indicating that the next step would be to ask her to leave your home.  5. Discuss the Situation with your Partner: You and your partner need to be in agreement on this. It's essential to present a united front to your stepdaughter. Discuss the issue privately and make sure you and your partner fully understand each other's perspectives. 6. Legal Advice: Depending on the laws in your area, you may need to give her an official eviction notice. This can get complicated, especially if she is a minor, so it is suggested to consult with an attorney. 7. Counseling/Therapy: If it reaches a point of impasse, consider involving a mediator, counselor, or therapist. They can provide a non-biased perspective and help clarify communication between you. 8. Final Step: If all else fails and she continues to disobey the house rules, you might need to ask her to leave. Ensure you do this in a calm and non-confrontational manner, still emphasizing that you care for her but can't condone her behavior.  Remember, every situation is different depending on circumstances, relationships, local laws, etc., so it's essential that you approach this difficult decision with utmost consideration and care.

column1: This is something you will have to discuss with your husband.  It should be a joint decision if you value your marriage.  You can mention your frustration about your stepdaughter not honoring boundaries.  After you talk to your husband you both can have a talk with your stepdaughter about expectations in order to stay living in the house.  When it comes to stepchildren you need to be very careful you do not take the lead on the authority part.  It should be the biological parent.
column2: This is a sensitive issue and it's important to approach it with care. Here's a step-by-step guide on how you might handle this situation: 1. **Clear Communication**: Before taking any drastic steps, ensure that you've communicated your concerns clearly. This includes the specific boundaries she's crossing and the consequences of her actions. It's important to be specific about what behavior is unacceptable and why. 2. **Family Meeting**: Arrange a family meeting where everyone can express their feelings and concerns. This should be a safe space where everyone feels heard. It's important to keep the conversation respectful and focused on the behavior, not the person. 3. **Professional Guidance**: If the situation doesn't improve, consider seeking professional help. This could be a family therapist or counselor who can provide strategies and guidance on how to handle the situation. 4. **Legal Advice**: If you're considering asking your stepdaughter to leave, it's important to understand the legal implications. Depending on her age and the laws in your area, you may need to provide written notice or even go through a formal eviction process. Consult with a lawyer to understand your rights and responsibilities. 5. **Plan B**: If it comes to the point where she needs to leave, help her come up with a plan. This could include finding a new place to live, arranging for her to stay with friends or family, or looking into support services in your area. 6. **Follow Through**: If you've communicated the consequences and she continues to cross boundaries, you may need to follow through with your plan. This could be a difficult step, but it's important for everyone involved to understand that actions have consequences. Remember, every situation is unique and what works for one family might not work for another. It's important to approach this with empathy and understanding, while also standing firm on your boundaries.

column1: It may be helpful to first have a discussion about what you are expecting and put a timeframe on it that if she is not doing certain things by a certain date, she will have to leave. If you don't know where she can go, there is probably a list of shelters for the county that you live in.
column2: Addressing this situation requires a delicate balance of empathy, assertiveness, and legal understanding. Here's a more expansive line of thought: 1. **Open Communication**: Start by having a frank conversation with your stepdaughter about the issues at hand. Clearly communicate the boundaries she's crossing and how it's affecting the household. It's important to express your feelings without blaming or attacking her. Use "I" statements to express your feelings, such as "I feel disrespected when you..." 2. **Involve Your Partner**: It's crucial to involve your partner in this process. They should be part of the conversation and decision-making process. Their support will be essential in enforcing the boundaries and dealing with the potential fallout. 3. **Set Clear Consequences**: If the behavior continues, establish clear consequences. This could be a warning, a probationary period, or, as a last resort, asking her to leave. Make sure she understands these consequences. 4. **Seek Professional Help**: If the situation doesn't improve, consider seeking help from a family therapist or counselor. They can provide strategies for dealing with the situation and facilitate communication. 5. **Legal Considerations**: If you decide to ask her to leave, you need to understand the legal implications. Depending on her age and the laws in your area, you may need to provide written notice or go through a formal eviction process. Consult with a lawyer to understand your rights and responsibilities. 6. **Plan for the Future**: If she does leave, help her plan for the future. This could involve helping her find a new place to live, connecting her with resources, or setting up a plan for her to become more independent. Remember, every situation is unique and what works for one family might not work for another. It's important to approach this situation with empathy and understanding, while also standing firm in your need for respect and boundaries.

column1: Oh my goodness, my heart goes out to you!!  I pray you have other strong and supportive loved ones or friends surrounding you. If you are in school, please consider speaking with a counselor on site who can help give you some good coping mechanisms as well as other resources.I believe most therapists would agree that this type of behavior is indicative of emotional AND verbal abuse. And quite often the two overlap because someone who is being yelled at and demeaned is also frequently having his/her emotions preyed upon as well. Healthy Place offers us some great examples of emotional abuse which certainly fit the criteria of what you describe:Yelling or swearing Name calling or insults; mocking.Threats and intimidation.Ignoring or excluding.Isolating.Humiliating.Denial of the abuse and blaming of the victim.And abuse survivor and author, Kellie Jo Holly, offers some other great examples of verbal abuse:Emotionally Abusive StatementsYou¡¯re so cute when you try to concentrate! Look at you trying to think.I can¡¯t believe I love a stupid jerk.Aw, come on, can¡¯t you take a joke?Sexually Abusive StatementsYou should know how to please me by now.I hoped you were less experienced.Stop acting like a whore.Financially Abusive StatementsYou are going to nickel and dime me to death!In what world does buying that make sense?Fine. You handle your finances. Let me know when things go to hell.Societally Abusive StatementsHow dare you spread around our private business!Let me do the talking; people listen to men.You took a vow in front of God and everybody and I expect you to honor it!Threatening and Intimidating StatementsIf you don¡¯t train that dog I¡¯m going to rub your nose in its mess.I will take our kids if you leave me.You¡¯re scared?! This isn¡¯t angry! You will KNOW when I¡¯m ANGRY!Spiritually Abusive StatementKeep your stupid beliefs to yourself.God will find a way to get you back, and it ain¡¯t gonna be pretty.I can feel myself being pulled into hell just listening to your nonsense!It's been my personal clinical experience that children who are experiencing the types of things you describe often say they feel misunderstood, lonely, or scared and don't want to make things worse by standing up for themselves. Even if you feel you can't defend yourself outwardly, that doesn't mean your father's awful and toxic behavior is something you should ever internalize (i.e., believe to be true) which is why I hope you are surrounding yourself with people who will speak life and positivity back over you.  We are ALL worthy of respect, love, and kindness. Don't ever forget that!My love and light to you hon.Tamara Powell, LMHC
column2: Yes, screaming and cussing at a child can be considered a form of emotional abuse. Emotional abuse, also known as psychological abuse, involves behaviors that harm a child's self-worth or emotional well-being. This includes yelling, name-calling, shaming, rejection, constant criticism, and belittling. Emotional abuse can have severe effects on a child's mental health, potentially leading to depression, anxiety, and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). It can also affect a child's self-esteem and self-worth, leading to difficulties in forming healthy relationships later in life. It's important to note that everyone, including parents, can have moments of frustration and anger. However, when these moments become a pattern, it can be harmful and abusive. It's crucial for parents to learn healthy ways to express their frustration and communicate with their children. If you or someone you know is in a situation where emotional abuse is occurring, it's important to seek help from a trusted professional, such as a counselor, social worker, or psychologist. There are also numerous hotlines and organizations that can provide support and resources.

column1: I'm really sorry to hear that you are going through this.It's a little difficult to answer your question because the laws that define child abuse are different from state to state. But usually, things like what you describe your dad is doing are not considered to be child abuse.The more important thing is how you feel about what is going on. It sounds like this is really bothering you.If you don't think you can talk to your dad about how you feel, you might want to try talking to another adult you trust (like a family member or teacher). They may be able to help you figure out some ways to communicate with your dad.I think you might feel better if you can talk to someone about how your are feeling.
column2: Yes, frequently screaming at and swearing at a child can be considered emotional and verbal abuse. It can have long-lasting negative effects on the child's mental health, self-esteem, and overall well-being. It's always recommended to use positive reinforcement, constructive feedback, and age-appropriate disciplining techniques to navigate parenting difficulties.

column1: Yes, this emotional abuse.  There is no abuse without emotional abuse.  His abuse is demeaning and can have lasting negative impact on your perspective of your self and people around you.  Please find someone support to talk to.
column2: Yes, screaming and cussing at a child can be considered a form of emotional abuse. Emotional abuse, also known as psychological abuse, involves behaviors that harm a child's self-worth or emotional well-being. This includes yelling, name-calling, shaming, rejection, constant criticism, and belittling. Emotional abuse can have severe and long-lasting effects on a child's mental health. It can lead to a variety of issues, including low self-esteem, depression, anxiety, post-traumatic stress disorder, and difficulties in forming healthy relationships. It can also affect a child's cognitive development and physical health. It's important to note that everyone can lose their temper or yell from time to time. However, when these behaviors are consistent, intense, and used as a way to control or punish a child, it becomes abusive. If you or someone you know is in a situation where a child is being emotionally abused, it's crucial to seek help from a trusted professional, such as a teacher, doctor, or counselor. In many countries, there are also hotlines and services available for reporting child abuse.

column1: Everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect. Having said that, everyone gets upset once in awhile and may yell or scream, which can be disrespectful. You said "always, and I mean always" and that is troubling. If your dad curses and screams at you on a regular and consistent basis, it can (as you stated) impact the way you feel about yourself. While the definitions of child abuse differ from state to state, talking to someone can help. Perhaps there is a counselor at school, or another trustworthy person you could confide in to help you understand how this situation is impacting you? Counseling is a good option. There is also help available through the national hotline at 1-800-422-4453, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. You can call (press 1) and talk to a counselor while being anonymous. You can also check out this website: https://www.childhelp.org/hotline/resources-kids/I am sorry that you are going though this situation. There is help available. You do not have to go through this situation alone.
column2: Yes, screaming and cussing at a child can be considered a form of emotional abuse. Emotional abuse, also known as psychological abuse, involves behaviors that harm a child's self-worth or emotional well-being. This includes yelling, name-calling, shaming, rejection, constant criticism, and belittling. Emotional abuse can have severe and long-lasting effects on a child's mental health. It can lead to a variety of issues, including low self-esteem, depression, anxiety, post-traumatic stress disorder, and difficulties in forming healthy relationships. It can also affect a child's cognitive development and physical health. It's important to note that everyone can lose their temper or yell from time to time. However, when these behaviors are consistent, severe, and the child's emotional well-being is negatively impacted, it becomes a form of abuse.  If you or someone you know is in this situation, it's crucial to seek help from a trusted professional, such as a counselor, social worker, or child protective services. They can provide guidance and resources to ensure the child's safety and well-being.

column1: Yes, screaming and cussing at your child is considered abuse.Here are two points I suggest you consider for your situation.If your dad is ever calm when you and him are with one another,  ask for some time to talk about your relationship with him.Schedule it for sometime in the near future from your request.   This way he has time to consider his points of view on his relationship to you.  Even if he does no thinking about your relationship at all, he will not feel pressured by the surprise of suddenly being expected to talk about a topic he may prefer to prepare himself.My second point to you is to keep steady in your own views of who you are.  When a parent demeans and mistreats a child, the child is affected in a negative way.  Concentrate on loving yourself and keeping people in your friendship circle who care about you.
column2: Yes, screaming and cussing at a child can be considered a form of emotional abuse. Emotional abuse, also known as psychological abuse, involves behaviors that harm a child's self-worth or emotional well-being. This includes yelling, name-calling, shaming, rejection, constant criticism, and belittling. The impact of emotional abuse can be profound and long-lasting. It can lead to a variety of psychological and behavioral issues, such as depression, anxiety, low self-esteem, and difficulties in forming healthy relationships. It can also affect a child's cognitive development and physical health. However, it's important to note that everyone, including parents, can have moments of frustration and anger. What distinguishes emotional abuse from less harmful forms of parental discipline is the consistent pattern of harmful behavior over time. If a parent frequently screams and uses derogatory language towards their child, it's likely a form of emotional abuse. If you or someone you know is in this situation, it's crucial to seek help from professionals or trusted individuals in your life. There are many resources available, including hotlines, counseling services, and child protective services, that can provide support and intervention when necessary.

column1: Your nephew's behavior sounds normal and developmentally appropriate.  Masturbation is a healthy expression of sexuality.  Most families to create some rules about where it's ok to masturbate-- for example, stating that it should be done in the privacy of the child's own room.  I'm wondering if you or another adult in his life have talked to him about his developing sexuality?  It seems like that would help him and you handle his increasing maturity.
column2: Conversations about healthy sexual behavior are important for teenagers as they grow and develop. A few tips to address your nephew's sexual behavior in a way which is constructive and respectful: 1. Comfortable Setting: Find a comfortable, private setting to talk in which you won't be disturbed.  2. Remain Calm and Non-judgmental: Start by ensuring that you are open-minded and non-judgmental throughout the conversation. You don't want to shame or blame him, rather you want to educate him. 3. Openly Share Your Concern: Talk about the specific behaviors that have raised your concerns. Make sure you keep the conversation based on your observations and avoid making accusations. 4. Inform Him: Try to explain the importance of safe sex practices like using condom and other forms of contraception, if he is sexually active.  5. Discuss Consent: Sexuality is also about understanding and respecting consent. Explain the importance of understanding a ¡°yes¡± or ¡°no¡±.  6. Encourage Responsible Behavior: Encourage him to understand that sexual activity is a big responsibility with potential consequences, both emotional and physical.  7. Involve Parents if Necessary: If your nephew is a minor and the behaviors in question are potentially dangerous, it may be necessary to involve his parents or guardians.  8. Suggest Counseling: If the sexual behavior in question is indicative of a larger issue or problem, you might want to suggest talking to a counselor or a doctor. Remember to let your nephew express his thoughts, concerns, or questions without interruption or judgment. Encouraging open dialogue can be very helpful and informative for both parties involved.

column1: There's two things this post relays - one, which I'm sure you've already looked into - is working with the school to address this problem. Sure, sometimes kids don't get along, but most schools look at bullying seriously, and this sounds serious. The other, though, is additional tools to consider to help your daughter. If you haven't already read Greene's Explosive Child, you might give it a shot. While it's a little preachy, many of the tools are wonderful and can help parents navigate tantrums. https://www.amazon.com/Explosive-Child-Understanding-Frustrated-Chronically/dp/0062270451 Another tool that can redirect a child that's losing it is a task. If her tantrums, say, involve throwing things, maybe she's in charge of throwing all the sticks and acorns off the driveway into the garbage bin. Ie: 'Hey Jenny, you seem really angry right now, let's use all that energy and get some work done!' Go with her, throw with her, even - if possible - making a game out of getting the acorns into the bin from a distance. I wish you all the best~
column2: Dealing with a bully at school can be very traumatic for a child. Here's what you can do: 1. Open Communication: Maintaining open lines of communication with your child is key. Encourage your child to express their feelings and reassure them that they can trust you with their problems. 2. Empathy: Be sure to empathize with your child. Understand their fears and concerns. This will help your child feel that their feelings are valid and that they are not alone. 3. Teach Coping Skills: Equip your child with coping skills to help manage the situation. This might include conflict resolution skills, techniques to safely walk away, or assertive communication strategies (knowing how to tell someone to stop in a respectful way). 4. Intervene: Talk to the teachers and the principal at your child's school. They are in a position of authority and can take necessary steps to ensure that the bullying stops. Request specifics of what they plan to do to resolve the situation. 5. Involve a Counselor: If the bullying is causing significant stress for your child, consider seeking help from a child psychologist or counselor. Counselling can provide your child with additional coping strategies and help to alleviate anxiety caused by the bullying. 6. Foster Positivity: Encourage your child to engage in activities they enjoy. This can provide a much-needed relief from stress and boost their self-confidence. 7. Reassure: Consistently reassure your child that they are loved, they are important and they are worthy. This can help boost their self-esteem, which may be damaged due to the bullying. Remember that in addition to these steps, it¡¯s important to monitor changes in your child¡¯s behavior and always be supportive. After all, they are dealing with a difficult situation and need all the help they can get.

column1: Financial stability is probably a good place to start your new life project.If your partner doesn't work or doesn't contribute his money to the household bills, then maybe you are eligible  for some type of stipend from the government.Especially since you have kids the child welfare service may intervene to help you.  Sometimes too, a partner who is unwilling to pay for their kids' wellbeing may be pressured by child welfare to make regular contributions to you and your kids.I''m glad you are thinking of your needs and those of your kids.  This is the philosophy which will show you what road to follow so all three of you are in a secure financial place.
column2: 1. Reflect: Think about what is making you feel stuck. Is it your career? Your relationships? Your personal growth? Take some time to understand where these feelings are coming from. 2. Seek Advice: Talk to trusted friends, family members or maybe even seek professional help. Sometimes, having an outsider¡¯s perspective can help you see things from a different light. 3. Set Goals: Setting both short-term and long-term goals can help guide you forward. This can give you something to aim for and can ultimately bring a sense of purpose and motivation. 4. Make a plan: Once you've proposed some goals, make a plan on how to achieve them. Breaking down your goals into smaller, manageable tasks can make them seem less daunting, and gradually working to complete these tasks can help you feel like you're making progress. 5. Learn something new: Taking a course or picking up a new hobby can pull you out of your routine and stimulate new areas of your brain, making you feel excited and less stuck. 6. Stay healthy: Regular exercise and a healthy diet can significantly impact your mood and energy levels, giving you the strength to face your challenges.  7. Practice positivity: Try to keep a positive mindset even when things are tough. This can be achieved through positive affirmations, keeping a gratitude journal, or simply trying to look at the silver linings in life.  8. Seek Professional Help: If your feelings of being stuck persist or seem to be linked with feelings of depression or anxiety, it's really important to seek help from a professional. Remember, it's okay to feel stuck sometimes, most of us do at different points in our lives. What's important is that you are recognising it and looking for ways to get out of this stuck-feeling, which is already a big positive step.

column1: I would want to know where do you put your needs? Often times we show people how to treat us based on how we treat ourselves. First identify how to practice good self care which can only happen when you are authentic and real about your needs and desires. You cannot pour from an empty cup and must take find the time to explore your purpose in life. It may be helpful to seek out additional support to work on your intrapersonal relationship.
column2: I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling stuck. It's a common feeling that many people experience at various points in their lives. Here are some expansive thoughts on how you might approach this situation: 1. **Self-Reflection**: Start by taking some time to reflect on why you're feeling stuck. Are you unsatisfied with your job? Are you feeling unfulfilled in your relationships? Are you unsure about your future? Identifying the source of your dissatisfaction can help you figure out what steps you need to take to move forward. 2. **Set Goals**: Once you've identified the areas of your life that you're unhappy with, try setting some goals for yourself. These should be specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, and time-bound (SMART). For example, if you're unhappy with your job, a goal might be to apply to five new jobs in the next month. 3. **Seek Support**: Don't hesitate to seek support from others. This could be a trusted friend or family member, a mentor, or a professional counselor or coach. They can provide a fresh perspective, offer advice, and help you stay accountable to your goals. 4. **Learn New Skills**: If you're feeling stuck because you're in a rut or you're not growing, consider learning a new skill. This could be something related to your job, a hobby, or just something you've always wanted to try. Learning new things can help you feel more engaged and fulfilled. 5. **Practice Self-Care**: It's important to take care of your physical and mental health. This could mean exercising regularly, eating healthy, getting enough sleep, practicing mindfulness or meditation, or seeking therapy. When you're feeling good physically and mentally, it's easier to tackle the challenges that come your way. 6. **Embrace Change**: Change can be scary, but it's often necessary for growth. Try to embrace change rather than resisting it. Remember, it's okay to take risks and make mistakes. That's how you learn and grow. 7. **Patience**: Remember that feeling stuck is often temporary. It's okay to take some time to figure things out. Don't rush yourself or feel like you need to have everything figured out right away. Remember, it's okay to ask for help and take time for yourself. You're not alone in feeling this way, and there are resources available to help you.

column1: You wrote a very full family context w many directions to examine.Do you know or can you find out what the grandma and your daughter were doing in the evening of the screaming episode?Is it possible the grandma abuses your daughter, or tells her scary stories, watches scary movies.  These are only suggestions of some problem between grandma and your daughter.Also, ask your daughter directly why she wants to kill herself and what' killing herself" means.   Seven year olds don't have a concept of death being a forever condition.  Seven year olds don't have a sense of future meaning besides liking/disliking them.  Maybe the new baby is a factor.  Do you feel this is a factor?   Trust your intuition to tell you if your daughter is resentful of your new baby.Even if she is, I doubt a seven year old has the capacity to connect current unhappiness with the intention of a future action, including suicide.
column2: I'm really sorry that you're feeling this way, but I'm unable to provide the help that you need. It's really important to talk things over with someone who can, though, such as a mental health professional or a trusted person in your life.

column1: The true answer is, "no one can really say with certainty".The variables are the way this child absorbs and adjusts to these significant changes in their life.  All anyone can do is guess at this point and there's no good reason to guess.The only general certainty is that the adult whom this child becomes will have had a profound encounter with the biggest types of human losses a child can go through.Some people become great teachers, therapists and philosophers who have this background.  Some give up on life and hide away from others.The best anyone could do who knows this child is to offer love bc this is the greatest guarantee to show there are good people on this earth.
column2: The loss of an adopted mother can have profound long-term effects, just as the loss of a biological parent would. The impact of this loss can vary greatly depending on several factors, including the individual's age at the time of loss, the quality of the relationship with the adopted mother, the support system available, and the individual's personal resilience and coping mechanisms. Here are some potential long-term effects: 1. **Grief and Mourning**: The most immediate effect is the experience of grief, which can be a long-term process. The individual may go through various stages of grief, including denial, anger, bargaining, depression, and acceptance. This process can take years and may not follow a linear path. 2. **Identity Issues**: Adopted children often grapple with questions about their identity, and the loss of an adopted mother can exacerbate these issues. They may feel a deeper sense of loss or abandonment, and struggle with questions about their roots and heritage. 3. **Attachment and Trust Issues**: If the loss occurs at a young age, it can lead to difficulties forming secure attachments in future relationships. The individual may struggle with trust issues, fearing that others will also leave them. 4. **Mental Health Challenges**: The loss can lead to various mental health issues, including depression, anxiety, and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). These may persist long-term if not addressed through therapy or other forms of treatment. 5. **Physical Health Impact**: Studies have shown that significant grief and stress can lead to physical health problems, including heart disease, high blood pressure, and weakened immune system. 6. **Personal Growth and Resilience**: On a more positive note, some individuals may experience personal growth following the loss. They may develop greater resilience, empathy, and a deeper appreciation for life. This is often referred to as post-traumatic growth. 7. **Changes in Family Dynamics**: The loss of a parent can significantly alter family dynamics. Roles may shift, relationships may change, and the remaining family members may struggle to adjust. 8. **Spiritual or Existential Questions**: The individual may grapple with spiritual or existential questions following the loss, such as the meaning of life and death, the existence of an afterlife, and their beliefs about fate and destiny. It's important to note that these effects can be mitigated with appropriate support, including therapy, support groups, and open communication within the family. Everyone's experience with loss is unique, and there's no "right" way to grieve. It's crucial to allow the individual to express their feelings, seek help when needed, and move through the grieving process at their own pace.

column1: Parents are to teach discipline to children, not punishment.  Punishment is another word for wanting to cause hurt.  There is a different in discipline and punishment. Punishment could have long term affects on a child's self image and growth.  It can lead to others issues such as bullying from peers as well.  Whatever your grandson has done, there is a much better way of getting him to understand that his actions are not acceptable.  Punishment is not one them.  Encourage the step-mother to build a positive relationship with him, this way he will learn to respect and trust her.  His actions would improve.  She may need to attend a parenting class for blended families.
column2: No, it is not healthy or appropriate to embarrass a child as punishment. Embarrassment can cause significant emotional distress and may lead to anxiety, depression, or other mental health problems. This punishment can also negatively impact the child's self-esteem and self-confidence, possibly leading to social anxiety or fear of public situations. Instead, effective discipline should involve clear communication, understanding, teaching, and guidance.

column1: Absolutely not! It is never in a child's best interest to use humiliation as punishment. This can lead to issues in the relationship between parent and child as well as the child's social relationships. Kids have a hard enough time. To then go and cause them embarrassment is unconscionable. The entire job of a parent is to prepare their child to become a successful, healthy adult. You do this by using healthy ways to teach a child when they make a mistake. Discipline shouldn't be seen as punishment. It should be seen as a way to teach a lesson. What lesson could this possibility be teaching him? Absolutely nothing. Meanwhile, she is most likely damaging her relationship with him and causing great distress in his school day and peer interactions. She should be one of the people he can come to when he's hurting; not someone who causes him pain.
column2: Embarrassing a child as a form of punishment is generally not considered healthy or effective in the field of child psychology. This approach can have several negative impacts on a child's emotional and psychological development.  1. **Self-esteem**: Public embarrassment can lead to a decrease in self-esteem. Children who are frequently embarrassed may start to see themselves as inadequate or inferior, which can have long-term effects on their confidence and self-worth. 2. **Trust**: Embarrassment as punishment can erode the trust between the child and the adult. The child may start to see the adult as a source of humiliation rather than support, which can damage the relationship. 3. **Behavioral issues**: Rather than correcting the undesired behavior, embarrassment might lead to behavioral issues. The child might act out, become defiant, or engage in the same behavior secretly to avoid embarrassment. 4. **Emotional development**: Regular embarrassment can lead to anxiety, depression, and other emotional problems. The child might become overly self-conscious, fearful of making mistakes, or develop social anxiety. 5. **Modeling behavior**: Using embarrassment as a punishment also sets a poor example for how to treat others. Children learn from adults' behavior, and they might start to use humiliation as a tool to control or hurt others. Instead of using embarrassment as a form of punishment, experts recommend using positive discipline strategies. These include setting clear expectations, providing consistent consequences for misbehavior, and teaching children to understand the impact of their actions. It's also important to model respectful and empathetic behavior, as children often learn more from what we do than what we say.

column1: Hi!   I'm sorry you are having such a tough time with this situation.  I have worked with a number of young adults in their 20's who have had to move back home after college , or even stay at home through the college years.  Bottom line is that either way , it is so difficult when you are trying to discover who you are and what you want your life to be , to have to live at home.   I have even heard much older adults clients  say that when they visit their childhood home , they suddenly feel like a "kid" again .  The old dynamics between adults and their parents and siblings can pop right up as if they have gone back in time and are no longer adults !I would suggest that you approach your mom and say something like "I am hoping we can talk about the best way for us to manage me living here.  I really appreciate that you are giving me a place to live until I get on my feet , and I want to be respectful of you and our home ; at the same time , though, I feel like it's important for me to have more independence than when I was younger because I am growing up and trying to learn more about myself and become more autonomous. Can we talk about what might be fair rules that we can  both live with ?" If she is receptive , maybe you can each write a separate list of what you think would be fair and reasonable and then compare lists and try to make compromises and come up with a list of "guidleines" that feel fair to you both .   If this is too hard to do alone , perhaps you and your mom can meet with a therapist a few times who can help you to come  up with some kind of "compromise contract."   This is not an easy situation , but if you can approach your mom in a calm and "mature" way and suggest a planned, structured discussion that doesn't take place in the heat of the moment , your mom may be impressed by your maturity and even more receptive to working out some rules that you can both live with.Good luck !!Elissa Gross
column2: I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling controlled by your mother. It's important to remember that I'm and can't replace professional help, but I can certainly provide some general advice. 1. **Understand Her Perspective**: It's possible that your mother is trying to control your life because she cares about you and wants the best for you. She might be worried about your future and is trying to guide you based on her own experiences and knowledge. Understanding her intentions might help you approach the situation with more empathy. 2. **Communicate Openly**: Have a calm, open conversation with your mother about how you're feeling. Use "I" statements to express your feelings, such as "I feel controlled when you do this" rather than "You're controlling me." This can help prevent her from becoming defensive. 3. **Set Boundaries**: It's important to establish boundaries in any relationship. Let your mother know what aspects of your life you're comfortable discussing with her and which ones you'd prefer to handle on your own.  4. **Seek Professional Help**: If the situation continues to cause distress, consider seeking help from a professional, such as a therapist or counselor. They can provide strategies and techniques to help you navigate this difficult situation. 5. **Self-Care**: Remember to take care of yourself. Engage in activities that you enjoy and that help you relax. This can help you maintain your mental health during this challenging time. 6. **Independence**: If you're of age and financially able, you might want to consider creating some physical distance. This doesn't mean cutting ties, but living separately might help establish a more adult relationship with your mother. Remember, it's important to maintain respect and understanding throughout this process. It's likely that your mother's actions come from a place of love, even if they're causing you distress.

column1: Hello. Even though legally you are an adult, it is a matter of courtesy to respect the homes of your parents. As long as you live there, you should be considerate of their needs. At the same time, there should be conversation about what each of you considers appropriate as it pertains to communication between a parent and an adult (even though you are still her offspring). This will require openness, honesty, and a willingness to give from both sides in a respectful way. Healthy boundaries can be established and honored when each is willing to do their part in this new relationship. Your mother knows you are an adult, but has not had as many years of treating you like one. So mentally and emotionally this will take some time for her to adapt. Share your concerns with her, and see if you can come up with a set of rules that you both can honor. It will be a great stepping stone for both of you as you move into this new chapter together as you begin relating a little differently.Reach out for help to a counselor if needed. You don't have to sort this out on your own. And lastly, take good care of yourself in the process. You are moving through some exciting times in your life. The more you can have support as you explore new events, the better you might feel less stressed.Warm regards.
column2: It's completely normal to seek independence as you grow older and this can sometimes cause conflict with parents who may be used to playing a more active role in your life. Here are a few steps you can take: 1. Open Communication: Tell your mother how you feel honestly but respectfully. Use ¡°I¡± statements to express your feelings rather than blaming or criticizing her.  2. Be Mature: Show your mother that you are capable of making good decisions on your own. If you are constantly asking for her approval or guidance, she may feel that you are not ready to be independent. 3. Seek Help: Talking to a third party, such as a counselor or a trusted family friend, can be helpful. They could provide valuable perspective to both you and your mother. 4. Set Boundaries: Respectfully establish what is and is not acceptable behavior. It could be about how often she can give advice, how much she can interfere in your life and so on.  5. Patience: Change will not happen overnight. It will take time for your mother to adjust to her new role in your life. Be patient and persistent in reinforcing the new boundaries.  Remember, your mother probably has your best interests at heart. It's just about finding the balance between helpful guidance and control.

column1: Unfortunately you seem to have yourself in a double bind. By living with your mom she is not going to stop her attempts at what you perceive as "controlling". There is no use in trying to debate or get her to "see your point". As long as your there and you personalize her attempts at control, then you will find yourself frustrated and resentful. Try to find an extra job or a roommate so that you can do the natural process of moving on out.www.lifecounselingorlando.com
column2: Feeling controlled can be a challenging experience, especially when it's coming from a parent. Here are some suggestions on how you can handle this: 1. Open Communication: The first step should be having an open and honest conversation with your mother about your feelings and concerns. Let her know that you value her input, but you also need room to make your own decisions and learn from them. Ask her to trust you and the lessons she's already taught you.  2. Set Boundaries: If your mother continues to control aspects of your life, then you need to set boundaries. This can be difficult as it often involves uncomfortable conversations, but setting boundaries is crucial for establishing a healthy, adult relationship with your parents. 3. Get Outside Support: Speaking to a counselor or mental health professional can be very helpful. They can provide you with strategies and tools to help you effectively communicate your needs to your mother. 4. Personal Development: Develop skills that can help you be independent. This could be anything from cooking, cleaning to managing your finance. Gaining these skills can give you more confidence and control over your life, and ease your mother's concerns. 5. Stay Calm and Patient: It can be frustrating and difficult when you feel like you're not being given room to make your own decisions. But remember, change takes time and staying calm is the key. Lastly, always remember that most times, parents only act out of concern and love for their children. They might not realize that their actions are affecting you negatively. It's essential to help them understand how you're feeling and work on solutions together.

column1: Unfortunately I think most of us have heard this, so you are not alone.  If you are still under her roof she has leverage as to what her expectations are while you are living there.  I would consider therapy for the both of you to see if there could be a middle ground that could be agreed upon.  Often times a 3rd party can help with conflict.  If there is no resolution then I would look to get creative in finding a place of your own.
column2: I understand that you're going through a challenging situation. It's important to remember that I'm and can't replace professional help, but I can certainly provide some general advice. 1. **Open Communication**: Start by having an open and honest conversation with your mother. Express your feelings and concerns without blaming or criticizing her. Use "I" statements to avoid sounding confrontational, such as "I feel overwhelmed when my decisions are not respected." 2. **Set Boundaries**: It's crucial to establish boundaries in any relationship, including the one with your parents. Clearly define what is acceptable and what isn't. This might be difficult at first, especially if your mother is not used to you setting boundaries, but it's an important step towards gaining independence. 3. **Seek Professional Help**: If the situation doesn't improve or if it's causing you significant distress, consider seeking help from a professional, such as a counselor or a psychologist. They can provide you with strategies to handle the situation and can facilitate a conversation between you and your mother, if necessary. 4. **Self-Care**: Remember to take care of your mental and physical health. Engage in activities that you enjoy and that help you relax. Surround yourself with supportive friends and other family members. 5. **Independence**: If you're of age and financially capable, consider creating some physical distance. This doesn't mean you have to cut ties with your mother, but living separately might help establish a more adult relationship. 6. **Patience**: Changes might not happen overnight. It's important to be patient with your mother and with yourself as you navigate this situation. Remember, every situation is unique and these are just general suggestions. It's important to do what feels right for you.

column1: Hello. It sounds like you and your parents are not balanced in your communication and awareness of expectations. Your growth is not only reflected in your ability to understand and apply new knowledge and skills, it is also reflective of your parents acceptance of your understanding and application. Have you tried talking with your parents to let them know your concerns?This talking is best when face to face and during non active conflict ( can't begin stating rules during an argument, etc). Sometimes it is even helpful to write down ways you feel you can be supported by them and supportive to them. Maybe share this list or reflective piece with them to review, or use when communicating the expectations. Unfortunately, until there are clear expectations stated and expressed, the scale will be uneven and frustrations will increase. Dr. T
column2: I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling controlled by your mother. It's important to remember that this is a complex issue and there's no one-size-fits-all solution. However, I can suggest a few strategies that might help you navigate this situation. 1. **Open Communication**: Start by having an open and honest conversation with your mother. Express your feelings without blaming her. Use "I" statements to avoid sounding accusatory. For example, instead of saying "You're controlling my life," you might say, "I feel like I'm not being given enough space to make my own decisions." 2. **Set Boundaries**: It's important to establish boundaries in any relationship, including the one with your mother. Decide what aspects of your life you're comfortable discussing with her and which ones you'd rather keep private. Make these boundaries clear, and be consistent in enforcing them. 3. **Seek Professional Help**: If the situation doesn't improve or if it's causing you significant distress, consider seeking help from a mental health professional. They can provide you with strategies to manage the situation and can facilitate a conversation between you and your mother if necessary. 4. **Self-Care**: Remember to take care of your own mental and physical health. Engage in activities that you enjoy and that help you relax. Surround yourself with supportive friends and other family members. 5. **Independence**: If you're in a position to do so, you might want to consider taking steps towards financial and residential independence. This can often help in situations where a parent is overly controlling. Remember, it's important to approach this situation with empathy. Your mother may be acting out of concern for you, even if her actions are causing you distress. It's possible that she's not aware of the impact her behavior is having on you. By communicating openly, setting boundaries, and seeking professional help if necessary, you can start to regain control over your own life.

column1: That is a really tough situation that a lot of young people are experiencing right now. The first thing to under is that you can¡¯t change who your parents are and cannot change their behavior. The thing to keep in mind is that you can control your responses and actions.  You may need to keep living at home with them for the next few months or years and the best way to do this is to have a plan. The second thing is to keep in mind that their controlling behavior is most likely not about based your behavior. Controlling parents are often driven by their concept of what will keep their children safe and happy. Unfortunately this is not always accurate but keep in mind it is not a personal attack.  There are ways you can deal with controlling parents ¨C and most of them require creating a plan of action.Examples of action plans:Decide in advance how you¡¯ll calmly and rationally respond to your parents when you feel they¡¯re trying to control youArrange to phone a friend or trusted adult when you feel like you¡¯re losing controlTalk in person to an adult you trust. There aren¡¯t any quick tips on how to deal with parents who want to control you; you need to find strategies that are geared to your specific family situation. Get specific coping tips from books about family dynamics, such as:Toxic Parents: Overcoming Their Hurtful Legacy and Reclaiming Your Life by Susan ForwardCutting Loose: An Adult's Guide to Coming to Terms with Your Parents by Howard HalpernA counselor can be a good resource and provide support and guidance about issues addressing normal growth and development during periods of transition.
column2: I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling controlled by your mother. It's important to remember that I'm and can't replace professional help, but I can certainly provide some general advice. 1. **Understand Her Perspective**: It's possible that your mother is trying to control your life because she cares about you and wants the best for you. She might be worried about your future and is trying to guide you based on her own experiences and knowledge. Understanding her intentions might help you approach the situation with more empathy. 2. **Communicate Openly**: Have a calm, open conversation with your mother about how you're feeling.
