Loss of a relationship touches a primal need we have to belong.  It makes us feel insecure, unanchored.  In truth, we are ok, safe even.  This experience will open different perspectives for you.  There are lessons you'll take from it that will add another facet to you as a person.  Maybe in time, you'll even appreciate this experience.  I'm sorry you're hurting right now.  Best wishes to you, Allison
column2: Moving on can be difficult depending on the situation, whether it's moving on from a relationship, a job, death, or any deep emotional event. Here's how you can do it: 1. Acknowledge your feelings: It's okay to feel sad or depressed. Don't suppress your emotions because it's a healthy part of the healing process.      2. Seek Support: You don't have to go through this time alone. Turn to family and friends for support. You can also seek professional help if you're finding it hard to handle the process. 3. Express yourself: Keeping your thoughts and feelings trapped inside can make it more difficult. Write down your thoughts. This can help you better understand what you're going through. 4. Focus on self-care: It¡¯s important to focus on your physical well-being as well. Eat well, exercise, try to maintain a regular sleep schedule, and engage in activities that you enjoy. 5. Find a new focus: Discover new hobbies, make new friends, undertake a new adventure. Be consistent in doing things that will keep your mind focused on something other than what you're trying to move on from. 6. Practice mindfulness and meditation: This can help keep you focused on the present, and avoid rehashing the past or worrying about the future. 7. Allow time to heal: Moving on doesn't happen overnight. Allow yourself to grieve and heal at your own pace. 8. Forgive: If your circumstance involves someone who hurt you, try to forgive them. Holding onto anger only perpetuates the pain and impedes the healing process. Now, these are general suggestions. Depending on your specific situation, some strategies may be more applicable or beneficial than others. If your feelings of sadness become overwhelming, leading to depression or thoughts of suicide, it's very important to seek help from a mental health professional immediately.

column1: Dealing with a breakup is difficult. We have high hopes and then those hopes and dreams are dashed and we feel at a loss for how to deal with this sudden change in our lives. First, it is important to acknowledge that losing a relationship is a loss and we need to grieve that loss. If we don't allow ourselves time to process and move through the grieving process, we may remain stuck and it may make it hard to move on. So in some ways, you don't want to move on too soon by just trying to ignore your feelings. Instead, take good care of yourself, talk to friends and give your self time to heal. The second most important thing is to forgive yourself; this is also an important part of taking care of yourself. You might be blaming yourself and re-living moments when you wish you would have done things differently. By replaying those thoughts you remain stuck. When we begin to forgive ourselves, we truly begin to heal. Lastly, in my experience the people who have the most difficulty moving on have not really severed all ties with their ex. They are still following them on social media or even checking in with texts. This is probably the hardest part for some people, but to move forward there needs to be a clear boundary and a clear ending. If you have a clear ending, you can have a new beginning. I hope this helps. Take good care of yourself!
column2: Moving on can be challenging, especially when you are dealing with intense feelings or major life changes. Here are some steps that might help, depending on your specific situation: 1. Acknowledge your feelings: Suppressing what you truly feel may only prolong the healing process. Accept the pain, grief, or disappointment and allow yourself to express these emotions. 2. Seek support: Reach out to friends, family or perhaps a professional like a counselor or a psychologist if you're comfortable. They can provide a listening ear, advice, or coping strategies. 3. Practice self-care: Eat healthily, get regular exercise and make sure you're getting enough sleep. This can help to improve your mood and energy levels. 4. Embrace change: Try to accept change as a part of life and try to embrace them instead of fighting them.  5. Find a new interest or hobby: This can be a great distraction and can also lead to self-discovery and personal growth. 6. Set goals: Having something to work towards can provide you with a sense of purpose and can help to keep your mind off the past. 7. Limit contact: If it's a person you're trying to move on from, it may help to limit or cut off contact, at least for a while. 8. Practice mindfulness: Engage in activities that help you stay present and focused, such as yoga or meditation.  9. Forgive: Easier said than done, but forgiving can often help in the moving on process. This includes forgiving yourself, if necessary. 10. Be patient: Moving on takes time. Don't rush yourself. When in doubt, don't hesitate to seek help from a mental health professional. Everyone's process for moving on is different and there's no universal solution.

column1: Relationships can be extremely enjoyable and satisfying.  When relationships end, however, it can be devastating.  It is normal to go through a grieving process after a breakup.  Denial, bargaining, sadness, anger and eventually acceptance are all normal stages of grief.  You may experience these feelings all at once or one at a time.  Allow yourself time to grieve by expressing your emotions - talk to a friend or write in a journal.  Take care of yourself during this time by exercising, eating and sleeping well and spending time with friends.  After some time you should start feeling better.  If you feel like you're not feeling better and you don't know what to do, you can see a therapist to help you get through this difficult time.
column2: Moving on from something, whether it's a relationship, a loss, or any other type of challenging life event, can be hard, but it's an important part of healing and growth. Here are a few steps to help you in the process: 1. Acceptance: Recognize that it's okay to feel pain and to grieve over what has happened. It is a natural process which helps to make sense of what's happened. 2. Self-Care: Make sure to take care of yourself. This includes both physical and emotional care. Exercise regularly, eat well, and try to get enough sleep. Also, don't hesitate to speak to a professional if necessary. 3. Support System: Lean on your support system. Friends, family, and therapists can all offer help and advice, or simply lend a listening ear. 4. Distraction: Find ways to distract yourself like taking up a new hobby, diving into work, or learning a new skill. 5. Forgiveness: If someone else was involved in your pain, find a way to forgive them. This doesn't mean you're excusing what they did, but it does allow you to move on. 6. Positivity: Try to focus on the good aspects of your life. Remember that there's still a lot to be thankful for. 7. Remove Reminders: It may help you to remove or limit reminders of whatever is causing you pain.  8. Give Yourself Time: Healing takes time. Know that it's okay to not feel okay all the time and you may have setbacks.  9. New Goals: Setting new goals can give you something positive to focus on and help motivate you. 10. Rebuild: Start to rebuild your life. This could mean making new friends, picking up a new hobby, or just starting fresh. While this advice is quite general, it may be helpful. If you're dealing with something specific such as a breakup, bereavement, or loss of job, it's best to seek advice tailored to your situation.

column1: Breaking up can be a very difficult thing.  I'm sorry you're feeling badly.    The first thing is to be really sure you are taking care of yourself --- that means eating well, exercising, getting good sleep, spending time with friends/family and making sure you are taking care of important things like work, rent, bills etc.    Secondly, it's important to do things that make you feel better and not worse.   If looking up your ex on social media makes you feel worse stop doing it!   It's important to concentrate on you and not them.    Thirdly, it's super important to make sure you're really looking at the situation accurately and look for the good things that still exist in your life ---  what is still good?   Even though your emotions are hurting and you are feeling badly, can you see the light at the end of the tunnel?  Do you feel hope?  If you do try to concentrate on that hope feeling.   If the obsessing continues and really gets in the way of living your life?   Maybe contact a therapist or counsellor that can help you through this difficult time?
column2: Moving on can refer to overcoming various types of situations like heartbreak, loss of a loved one, job loss, or any traumatic event. Here are some general steps: 1. Acceptance: You can't move on if you're still clinging to the past. Accept that whatever happened has happened and that there's no going way back. 2. Allow yourself to grieve: Allow yourself to feel and express your emotions. Denial or suppression of feelings can cause emotional blockages. 3. Seek help: If you're finding it hard to cope, don't hesitate to seek professional help. Counselors and therapists can offer valuable insight and proven techniques to help you heal.  4. Practice self-care: Take care of your mental and physical health. Eat well, sleep well, and keep active. Consider meditation to help clear your mind and relieve stress. 5. Reach out to friends and loved ones: Loneliness can make moving on harder. Don't hesitate to lean on the people who care about you. 6. Let go of the past: You can't change the past, but you can shape your future. Instead of dwelling on things that went wrong, start working on things that can make it right for you. 7. Pursue a passion: A new hobby or interest can keep you busy and divert your attention from negative thoughts. 8. Stay positive: Practice optimism and gratitude each day. Try to focus on the good in every situation. 9. Patience: Recovery takes time. Don't rush the process and be gentle with yourself. 10. Forgive: If somebody has hurt you, forgiveness will help you move on. It doesn't mean what happened was OK, but it's about healing and letting go of resentment.  Remember everyone moves at their own pace, and that's okay. It's an individual journey. Don¡¯t be hard on yourself if you're not as far down the path as you think you should be.

column1: Hi, Break ups can be very devastating and even traumatic. Recovering from one is a process that is unique for everyone person and will take time. It's important that you don't compare yourself to others. Each and every person will experience this grieving process differently. Here are a few tips to help with your recovery: 1. Make sure you surround yourself with people who love you and support you, friends and family. Even though you might feel like being alone, make an effort to be around them. 2. Although you might not feel like it, try to take care of yourself as much as possible: eat healthily, get regular sleep, & vigorous or gentle exercise (depending on your mood). The last thing that we want to do when we are physically sick (e.g. flu) is to take care of ourselves even thought that's what we need the most. But when we do get that chicken broth, sleep and vitamins we recover much faster and with less discomfort. That's exactly the same when it comes to emotional pain. Take care of yourself, keep yourself strong and healthy so you can recover faster. 3. As much as possible, put away reminders of the relationship. You might not be ready to throw things out, but try to put them away in a box in the storage or in a closet. And also block Social Media reminders. There is a lot of wisdom in the saying "Out of Sight, Out of Mind." 4. Once the initial shock and intensity of the break up wear off, try out something new. In a relationship, we often forget and give up on things that we always wanted to do or to try. Now it's time to bring out that dusty bucket list and start trying something new. 5. If possible, change your scenery by going away on vacation with a friend or even by yourself. Changing your surroundings can really help you change your thoughts, mindset and forget your ex even if just for a few hours. Even a weekend getaway with a couple of girlfriends can do wonders. 6. In addition, to help you make sense of your past relationship and what went wrong, I would highly recommend seeing a professional counsellor or therapist.
column2: Moving on from a situation, feelings, or relationship depends on your specific circumstances. However, here are some general steps that might help: 1. Acceptance: Acknowledge and accept the situation or feelings. Ignoring or denying them might make the healing process longer. 2. Allow Yourself to Feel: Experience the emotions that come with it, whether sadness, anger, or frustration. It's okay to grieve.  3. Self-Care: Make sure to take care of yourself physically and mentally. Eating right, exercising and getting enough sleep are vital.  4. Seek Support: Reach out to friends and family who can offer comfort and support. You may also consider consulting with a mental health professional. 5. Forgive: Try to forgive the person or situation that's causing you pain. Holding on to negativity only hurts you further. 6. Focus on the Future: Instead of dwelling on the past, focus on what you can do right now to improve your future. 7. Find New Interests: Pursuing new activities or hobbies can help distract you from negative thoughts and provide a fresh start. 8. Practice Mindfulness: Meditating or practicing mindfulness or breathing exercises can help you stay focused on the present. 9. Set New Goals: Focus on personal growth, set new goals and work on achieving them. Remember, moving on takes time and patience. Be gentle with yourself during this process.

column1: The best way to move on is to give yourself sufficient time and space away from your ex so you can heal.  That means no checking out your ex on social media platforms and no contact.  In order to move on and diminish the obsessions, help yourself recognize and accept that the relationship is over, and make sure to get sufficient support in processing all your feelings.  Once that takes place, it can be useful to explore and process with a professional the meaning of the relationship and to understand your part in what transpired.Sometimes people obsess because they have difficulties accepting what's already taken place and want things to be different.  The key to moving forward is to be loving toward yourself, to give yourself permission to grieve the loss, and to start cultivating new and healthy habits/patterns.  Reengage in your present life, ask yourself what you want your life to look like, and start creating goals and taking small steps to create the amazing life you want for yourself.
column2: Moving on can be challenging but here's a basic guide: 1. Acknowledge your Current Feelings: Acceptance is the first step. We can't move on without acknowledging what we feel. 2. Share your Thoughts: Talk to someone you trust about the situation. It could be a friend, family member, or counselor. This can help to provide perspective and perhaps advice. 3. Identify why you need to Move On: Realizing the reasons will motivate you to take the necessary step.  4. Set Clear Goals: Identify what you want to achieve or where you want to be. Setting goals can help you progress and give you something to look forward to. 5. Engage in new Activities: Start doing something new which you've never done before, this will divert your mind and feel excited. 6. Practise Mindfulness: It's normal for your mind wander back to the past, mindfulness helps you to focus on the present moment. 7. Seek Professional Help: It's okay to seek help from professionals like a therapist or mental health counselor if your feelings are too overwhelming to handle on your own.  Remember, moving on isn't linear. There will be good days and bad days; the important thing is to keep trying to move forward. Last but not least, time heals everything. Try to be patient.

column1: Let yourself know what you feel.  There is no timetable or known length of how much time a particular person requires in order to feel that the dissolved relationship is behind them.Probably the more you allow yourself to acknowledge your sadness from seeing the reminders, the sooner you will feel fresh and new again.
column2: Moving on from a hardship, whether it's a breakup, loss of a loved one, or a major setback, often comes down to accepting what has happened, allowing yourself to feel, and finding ways to rebuild your life. Here's a few steps to start: 1. Acknowledging and Owning your Feelings: Start by giving yourself permission to feel pain, grief, frustration, or whatever emotions come up. It is a normal part of the healing process. It's okay to not be okay sometimes.  2. Seek Support: Lean on your family and friends for moral support. Reach out to them, talk about what you're going through. If it seems tough, don't hesitate to seek professional help like a therapist or a counselor. 3. Self Care: Take care of yourself physically. Regular exercise, a balanced diet, and getting enough sleep can significantly help you cope with stress and anxiety. 4. Engage in Activities: Engage in activities that you love and enjoy doing, like reading, listening to music, painting, hiking, etc. 5. Mindfulness: Mindfulness activities such as meditation and yoga could also help in healing.  6. Forgive: Depending on the situation, forgiveness might be part of your journey too. It's more for your benefit to release the pain, not necessarily that the other person deserves it. 7. Set Goals for the Future: Remember, one bad chapter doesn't mean your story is over. Have goals for yourself and make a plan to achieve them. 8. Give it Time: Time is a natural healer. With time, the pain will lessen, and although you might never forget what happened, it won't be as devastating. 9. Don¡¯t rush: Moving forward after a major event takes time. Don¡¯t force yourself to get over something. Remember, it's normal to feel pain and grieve. But if your feelings become too much to handle, consider seeking professional help to guide you through the process.

column1: Sorry for so much emotional pain from the combination of the divorce and your sister not supporting you in the way you wish.When you feel ready and if you feel this would help, then consider to talk to your sister from perspective to improve the relationship the two of you have.Since the ex is gone and the sister is an ongoing person in your life, this particular incident is only one in many which the two of you will have with each other.The disappointment you feel now as to how she handled herself, is a point to bring up to her for the sake of clarifying the type of relationship you each would like to build with each other.As to your specific question as to why she did what she did, she is the only person who has the answer.Start with finding out if she wants to improve the relationship altogether.   Then you can use her lack of support with the ex, as an example of how meaningful her support of you is to you.
column2: As, I can't provide a direct reason as I don't have personal data about your sister's motives or emotions. However, I can suggest that people might not defend another in such a situation for various reasons. These could include fear of confrontation, not wanting to get involved, having a closer relationship with the other person involved, or even agreement with the things said. It's always beneficial to communicate your feelings with your sister directly to understand her viewpoint.

column1: Unfortunately, I can't tell you what your sister was feeling or why she reacted that way.I can say that divorces can be difficult or confusing for everyone involved. While the divorce is most impactful for the couple going through it, the divorce itself also changes extended family dynamics. Also, a lot of people don't act the same way around extended family (or other people) as they do at home behind closed doors, so there are times when divorce is a real shock to everyone who was not directly involved in it.I wonder if you are at a place where you can shift your focus into looking at your relationship with your sister, how she is treating you, how you feel around her now, etc. I do not know how close you were before all of this and how close you feel now, but perhaps if you can assess your overall relationship, you could find a time when you could ask about this (why she didn't convey that to him from the beginning) in a way that is calm, not defensive, and is honestly looking for an answer from your sister, not looking to defend yourself at that moment. If that conversation can happen, it may be quite a difficult one, so it may be good to have something to think of to remind yourself that you are trying to gather information from her and him that conversation, it's not about you, but is about where she was coming from. After you think you understand that (I'm saying that you understand where she's coming from, not that you agree with what she's saying), you could see if she's willing to listen to how you feel about it.
column2: As, I don't have specific information on personal matters. However, possible reasons might include she didn't want to get involved in a conflict, she might agree with your ex-husband's point of view, she might not feel it is her place to defend you, or she might not know how to handle the situation. To get a real answer, you would need to ask your sister directly.

column1: Given the short amount of time you know this girlfriend, there is no history on which to make a judgment about the likelihood of what she will do next.Certainly she is confusing by telling you she likes you and is with someone new.  And not giving you any explanation as to why she made her decision.I'd suggest two possibilities.Speak with her and ask her if she considers opening your relationship with her.Or, simply wait and see what she does when you contact her in a friendly way.Pay attention to your own satisfaction level.If you get more answers from her which aren't agreeable with you, then it is time to put the hope for this relationship behind you.Then you'll have clear space to find someone who is as interested in you as you are in them!
column2: Rekindling a romantic relationship with an ex-partner can be challenging and complicated, but here are some steps you might consider: 1. Understand and Accept the Break-up: Try to understand why the relationship ended in the first place. Understand her reasons, respect them, and give her the space she needs. 2. Reflect and Learn: Reflect on what went wrong. Can those issues be fixed? Learn how to change the behaviors and habits that led to problems.  3. Improve Yourself: Show her that you've changed and grown since the breakup. Focus on any areas she mentioned as problems such as getting organized, getting fit, or addressing emotional issues. 4. Reconnect as Friends: Once you feel you have made positive changes and feel emotionally ready, reach out to her casually. Be sure to keep the communication light and friendly. 5. Apologize if Needed: If you were at fault for the break-up, genuinely apologize. Be clear that you understand your mistakes and have learned from them. 6. Show Genuine Interest: Show her that you're still interested in her life. Ask her about her day-to-day activities, aspirations, or whatever she likes to talk about. 7. Be Patient and Respectful: It may take time for her to trust you again. Respect her feelings and decisions. Don't rush or pressure her into anything. 8. Make Her Feel Special: Show her that she's important to you. You can do this by sending her thoughtful messages, or by doing nice things for her. 9. Be Honest: Talk frankly about wanting to be together again. Discuss the issues you had previously and how you plan to address them. 10. Seek Professional Help: If the issues that led to the break-up were severe (e.g., trust issues or infidelity), a relationship coach or counselor might be able to provide guidance. Remember, there's no guarantee you can you can reignite a past relationship. It's ultimately her decision whether or not to give the relationship another chance. Also, it's necessary to consider whether getting back together is really the best choice for both of you. Sometimes, moving on can be the healthier option.

column1: It sounds as if your ex-girlfriend is trying to figure out what type of relationship she is looking to have with you. There are lots of levels of relationships, from a basic acquaintance, to a more friendly acquaintance, to a friend, close friend, best friend, early romantic partner, committed romantic partner, and many more.If she is willing to have a conversation with you about her feelings, it may be helpful to have her explain her feelings to you while listening as an investigative reporter and asking questions that cannot be answered with yes or no, but are what are called open-ended questions, which ask her to provide more information. During this process, it would be helpful for you to try to think of it as not being personal, but just listening and trying to understand the experience from her perspective. After you have done this for five minutes (it's a rough estimate, but basically until you can restate what she is saying and she says you have it right), you can switch so she is asking you questions about how you are feeling. The goal is not necessarily to change the outcome, but to learn more about yourselves and each other.Then you may have an idea of where you stand in each other's eyes.
column2: Getting your ex-girlfriend back depends on a lot of factors. Here are some steps you might consider: 1. Self-Assessment: Think about why you broke up in the first place and whether it's really a good idea to get back together. Ask yourself if you're both willing to change, if the issue that lead to the breakup is resolvable, and if you truly miss her or just don't want to be alone. 2. Give her space: After the breakup, give her some time to process things. Avoid contacting her for a while as this may push her further away. Giving her space will also give her time to miss you. 3. Apologize sincerely: If you contributed to the breakup, genuinely apologize. It will not guarantee she'll want you back, but it's a step in showing her you're able to admit where you were wrong.  4. Establish communication: After some time has passed, reach out to her casually. Send her a simple message asking how she's been without expecting her to want you back instantly. 5. Be honest with your intentions: If she is ready to talk, let her know that you are interested in trying again. Make sure you articulate why you believe things will be different this time and back it up with concrete actions, not just words. 6. Show change: More than telling her that you'll change, show her. Show her with your actions that you've taken steps to become a better person.  7. Seek professional guidance: If both of you agree to give it another try, you might consider seeking professional help like a relationship or couples therapy. 8. Patience: Getting someone back doesn't happen overnight. It takes time, effort, and a lot of patience. Remember though, every situation is unique, and while these can be pointed out as general guidelines, they won't work all the time for everyone.

column1: Were you happy with the ways she satisfied you?A relationship is happiest if each partner concentrates on the happiness of the other.Strange for someone who was treated badly to describe themselves as bored, rather than say they feel hurt.Is it possible you are being self-critical about your behaviors toward your ex girlfriend? Either she is unaware of her feelings or not being fully truthful with you about her feeling badly treated.Since she's putting up a barrier to communicating with you, better for you to respect this than contact her by phone again.Consider in a few weeks, so each of you has time to think over your happiness with the other person, to write her an email which states your interest to re-open the relationship.Who knows, you may even decide by the end of a few weeks, that you're fine without this particular relationship.Depending on her response to your email, you'll know whether and how much chance there is for the relationship to clear up the problems of the past and to continue.
column2: 1. Reflect on the breakup: Understand why things ended. Recognise your faults in the relationship and the negative aspects you brought in. 2. Improved version of you: Work on yourself. Develop new hobbies, skills, get physically fit and mentally healthy. 3. Initiate Contact: Once you've given her and yourself some time to heal, start with a casual text or call. Ensure you are not overly pushy or desperate. 4. Apologize: If you were in the wrong, make an honest apology. 5. Be patient: You need to be patient with her feelings and decisions. It might take time for her to trust and open up to you again. 6. Prove your change: By your actions, show her that you're trying to be a better person.  7. Communicate: Have an open and sincere discussion about your past relationship, your mistakes, and how things could be changed. Remember, it's important that she also wants to get back together. Both parties need to work on improving the relationship. Sometimes, it's better to move on if things don't work out.

column1: Cheating on you shows a lack of commitment, in addition to the emotional hurt it creates.Probably you didn't actually forgive him because if you did, then you wouldn't have been asking questions of his every move.Maybe you were open to forgiving him.   In order for forgiveness to be effective, the person who has done the injuring must first show some understanding and empathy for the great pain the person caused in you.From what you write, your fianc¨¦ didn't seem to have much interest in earning back your trust or in empathizing with the way his cheating effected you.It is very likely his tiredness is also tiredness you feel, of having to watch him all the time.As uncomfortable as adjusting with the disappointment of him leaving you, the situation you describe sounds like it was unsatisfying for both of you.
column2: 1. Allow yourself to feel: It's okay to feel sad, angry, hurt, confused after a breakup. Don't try to suppress those feelings; it's a part of the healing process. 2. Reach out to others: Having a support system during this time can be really helpful. Reach out to your friends and family, and don¡¯t hesitate to ask for support when you need it. 3. Take care of your health: Eating well, getting enough sleep, and exercising can do wonders for both your mental and physical well-being. These activities can help reduce stress and elevate your mood. 4. Practice self-care: Engage in activities that you enjoy and which make you feel better - this could be anything from reading a book, cooking, painting, or going on a road trip. 5. Get rid of reminders: Store away photos, gifts, and any other items that remind you of your ex. These will only bring back memories and make you feel sad. 6. Keep busy: Filling your schedule with fun and fulfilling activities can help distract you from the pain. Pursue your hobbies, learn a new skill, or engage in volunteering work. 7. Seek professional help: If you're finding it really hard to cope, don't hesitate to seek professional help such as a counsellor or a therapist. They can provide strategies to help you deal with your feelings and start feeling better. 8. Maintain a no-contact rule: Cut off all communication with your ex (at least initially). This will help give you the space and time to heal. 9. Allow time to heal: Healing takes time. Don't rush yourself into moving on or into another relationship. Take the time to heal and rediscover yourself. 10. Learn from the experience: Every relationship, even those that end, teaches us something. Reflect on what you've learned from this relationship and use the experience to grow and become a more mindful partner in future relationships.

column1: if he as cheated on you multiple times it is not healthy for you to continue seeing him.  However It takes time to heal your pain. You are not a robot that can just switch off your emotions.  Please surround yourself with people who can support and empower you.
column2: 1. Allow Yourself to Feel: It's natural to feel sad, frustrated, and confused after a break up. Suppressing the emotions can make it even harder to move on. Always give yourself a chance to grieve. 2. Lean on Loved Ones: Friends and family can be great sources of comfort during difficult times. Don't be afraid to lean on them, share your feelings, and ask for their advice or support. 3. Self-Care: It's crucial to take care of yourself after a breakup. Eating healthy, exercising regularly, and getting enough sleep can make a huge difference in your mood and energy levels.  4. Distractions: Engage in activities that you enjoy to help distract you, such as reading, writing, painting, playing music, or spending time in nature. 5. Seek Professional Help: If the sadness seems overwhelming, do not hesitate to seek the help of a counselor or a therapist. 6. Set Goals: Setting both small and large goals can help occupy your mind and give you a sense of purpose beyond the relationship. It can be personal, career, fitness or learning new skills. 7. Acceptance: Accepting that the relationship is over is vital. You might feel lost initially, but with time, you'll find yourself in a much better place.  8. Stay Off Social Media: Resist the urge to keep tabs on your ex via social media. Unfriend, unfollow or atleast mute them to resist the temptation. 9. Practice Mindfulness and Meditation: These techniques can help manage stress, anxiety, and negative thoughts, promoting mental well-being. Guided meditations specifically for heartbreak are available for free on many meditation apps. 10. Forgive and Let Go: Holding onto anger or resentment only poisons you. When you're ready, forgiving your ex (and yourself) for any missteps in your relationship can be a productive and healing move.

column1: There is a grieving process after losing a relationship (or any other major loss, such as a job, a house, etc.). One of the things to consider is give yourself a chance to go through the tasks of mourning:To accept the reality of the lossTo process the pain of griefTo adjust to a world without the person who has just leftTo find an enduring connection with that person in the midst of embarking on a new life. This could mean a lot of things, but it could be holding certain memories as your own.You may also find things that make you feel happy or comfortable. It's also helpful to have people who you can talk to about your feelings and people who may be able to recognize things about you that you cannot see right now (such as how you are honest, committed to your work, a good listener, etc.).This takes some time. Try to be gentle with yourself.
column2: 1. Allow Yourself to Feel: Breaking up hurts and it's okay to mourn this loss. Letting yourself feel these emotions is necessary to the healing process.  2. Seek support from friends and family: Sharing your feelings and thoughts with people that care about you can help you feel less alone and can provide a positive influence in your life. 3. Take Care of Yourself: Get regular sleep, eat healthily, and exercise. Physical activity can help reduce stress and improve your mood.  4. Cut Off Communication: Avoiding communication with your ex at least for a while can help you move on. Remove them from your social media accounts and try not to frequent the same places. 5. Acceptance: Recognize that it is normal to still love someone and feel sad after a breakup, but also understand that the relationship ended for a reason. 6. Keep Busy: Engage in activities or hobbies you enjoy. This is also a good time to try something new.     7. Seek professional help if needed: If grief starts to severely interrupt your daily life, it might be a good idea to seek professional help. Therapists are trained to handle these sort of emotions and can provide tools and techniques to deal with them. 8. Forgive and Let Go: Holding onto anger and resentment can prolong the healing process. Instead, try to forgive, not because they deserve it, but because you do. 9. Focus on personal growth: Take this time to focus on yourself and your own growth. Learn from the mistakes and look at it as an opportunity for self-improvement. 10. Take it Slow: It's okay if you aren't over your ex in a week, a month, or even a year. Everyone goes at their own pace, so don't rush yourself. Eventually, the pain will lessen and you'll find yourself moving on.  Remember, it's okay to not be okay. This is a tough time, but you will get through it.

column1: Has your former partner made any efforts to be in contact with you in order to restart your relationship?From what you describe, your former partner is in a new relationship.It is possible that since you love her and would like to be together again, that you are misinterpreting your former partner's actions.If you'd like to have more certainty as to wether your former partner is cheating or whether she is happy to be with the new partner, is to contact her and ask her your question.A better road may be to accept your sad feelings that she is with someone else.Since she was meaningful to you, respect the sadness you feel and that the relationship didn't continue as you wished.
column2: Discovering that you're being cheated on can be hurtful, but it's important to communicate with your partner if you suspect them cheating rather than jumping to conclusions. Here are signs you may want to consider: 1. Sudden behavioural changes: If your partner is suddenly spending more time outside, constantly busy, or their routine significantly shifts, these could be signs.     2. Lack of attention: When your partner shows less affection, it may indicate that their emotional focus is on someone else.  3. Secrecy with phone/laptop: If your partner abruptly changes their passwords or tries to hide their phone from your sight when before they were quite open, there could be a reason. 4. Emotional distance: If your partner is less interested in spending time with you or is becoming emotionally distant, it could indicate an involvement with a third person. 5. Lying: If your partner is lying about small things, this could indicate they might lie about bigger things. 6. Guilt reactions: Your partner might treat you extremely well, giving you more gifts or taking you out more often, sometimes out of guilt. 7. New appearance: A sudden interest in their appearance, buying new clothes, hitting the gym etc., could be a sign that they are trying to impress someone new. 8. Less interest: If they show lack of interest in any activities or plans you had together, it could be a potential warning sign. 9. They often accuse you of cheating: This might be a strategy to deflect their own guilt onto you. 10. Intuition: Trust your gut feeling. If something feels off, it's important to discuss this with your partner. Remember, any of these signs alone don't necessarily mean your partner is cheating. It's crucial to have open communication with your partner and discuss any concerns before making hasty conclusions. If this is a persistent issue, consider seeking professional help such as relationship counseling.

column1: Trust is a necessary factor for an intimate relationship to feel safe.The person who must repair the trust is the one who has broken this trust.The best way to find out if your husband wants to restore your trust in him, is to ask him this question.  He may not be willing to meet your request.If he hesitates or becomes defensive about the need to restore your trust, then ask him to think his decision through and tell him the serious consequence you are considering.Ask him to reflect for a few days or a week and then to address the topic again.If you and he consistently find that he is unwilling to do anything at all to regain your trust, then I agree you have serious thinking to do as to whether or not you'd be able to live within a partnership based upon trust, in which you don't trust your partner.
column2: Breaking trust in a relationship is always difficult to deal with, especially when it concerns something significant. Honesty and transparency are vital in maintaining healthy communication and trust in any successful relationship. Keeping a significant secret can damage these essential elements of the relationship. Depending on the nature of the secret, it can affect the relationship in many different ways. For instance, it could be an innocent secret, like planning a surprise party or a secret trip, which usually doesn't cause any harm. However, if the secret is about serious matters, like financial problems, infidelity, or a hidden past, it could bring about trust issues, emotional distress, confusion, and feelings of betrayal.  Such situations might need professional help like counseling or mediation to deal with the problem effectively. It's always good to communicate about your feelings openly with your husband, discuss how this action hurt you and express your need for honesty in the future. Remember, every person and every relationship can make mistakes and experience hardships; the essential part is to learn, grow, and move on from them.

column1: Hello. It seems you are in a set of circumstances that are highly uncomfortable for you. Do you feel those circumstances are healthy? Do you find pleasure being in such a place of uncertainty? Why do you continue to be in this situation? Without meaning to appear that I might be lacking in compassion, you do have the option to leave the connection completely if the harm it is doing is more that the pleasure it brings you. Is there a benefit to being in this relationship? Do you consider this situation to be for your highest good? Is it healthy to be involved in something that is not likely healthy or perhaps could even be seen as dysfunctional? In truth, only you can decide the answers to these very important questions. I would encourage you to think of who benefits by being in this situation, and how you might be able to find happiness in other relationships that are healthier and more positive. In my clinical view based on what I read, this particular relationship does not carry the joy I am sure you want, nor the healthy interactions you would expect in a functional romantic engagement with another person.Beating yourself up about potentially wasting all this time waiting for the other person to come around will not serve a positive purpose. It likely will only lower your self-esteem. There is a time to wait to see how things develop, and a time to move on to other experiences. You are the one to make that choice, but I would encourage you to connect with your inner higher self, for the most clear answer. Chances are, you already know the answer, you just need to embrace it. Getting in touch with a counselor in your area can also help ferret out some of the deeper issues that you might not have felt comfortable expressing here.
column2: As, I don't feel emotions, but from a general perspective, it's important to remember that your time is valuable, and you should never be someone's second choice. The decision and timeline should depend on your own feelings, self-respect and mental health. And, remember, communication is key in any relationship, so try discussing your feelings and concerns with him, if you haven't already. You deserve to be with someone who chooses you without hesitation.

column1: Hello, and thank you for your question. Boy, ending relationships is tough, isn't it? Sometimes it's tough even when we are 100% sure that it is the right thing to do!I am going to give you some of my thoughts, and hopefully some colleagues will add some others. One of the things that I want to point out is that "letting go" is not really a thing. In other words, it's not really something you can reach out and grab. It's more of a process. This is good news, because you don't necessarily have to be at the end of the process to end an unhealthy relationship. We just have to accept that there will be feelings that come up even after the relationship is over. For example, someone can end an unhealthy relationship today, but then be reminded of the good times on what would have been their "anniversary." This could make the person very sad. They may even regret ending the relationship for a little while. It would important, then, for the person to remind themselves why the relationship needed to end, and that they are healthier because of it. This is relevant for you. It's hard to walk away from a relationship. We fear all kinds of things, including being single! Sometimes it's helpful to compare what you are getting out of the relationship to what you want from a relationship. It's helpful to be honest about what we have given up for an unhealthy relationship. It's fine to admit uncertainly about ending things. It's okay to be afraid. It's okay to have moments of doubt and sadness along with a dash of guilt. And even with all of that, someone can still leave if it is the healthiest thing for them. They can have sadness later on, and still not go back.It sounds like you are feeling responsible for making sure he is okay because of this divorce. The truth is that there is not necessarily a "perfect" time to end any relationship. There would be no guarantee that he would be doing any better after the divorce. Sometimes NOT making decisions stresses us out A LOT more than making a decision and living with the consequences, both good and bad. You may be at that crossroads. Be well..Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC
column2: Leaving someone who continually causes you pain can be challenging but is often necessary for your wellbeing. Here are some steps you can follow: 1. Acknowledge the Pain: You can't move forward until you've accepted the situation. Allow yourself to feel the pain, don't deny it or try to suppress it. 2. Identify the Causes: Clearly establish what this person is doing to cause you harm. This step helps you visualize the problem and understand your need to let go. 3. Seek guidance: Talk to people you trust about your feelings. A friend, a family member, or a mental health professional can provide useful advice and act as a support network. 4. Establish Boundaries: If you can't remove this person from your life entirely, you need to set clear boundaries to protect yourself. Limit interaction and distance yourself emotionally as much as you can. 5. Forgive, But Don't Forget: Forgiveness is an important part of emotional healing. However, don't force yourself to forget their actions. Remember them as a part of your history and as an important lesson. 6. Prioritize Yourself: Fulfill your needs and focus on what makes you happy and brings you peace. Whether that means chasing a passion, seeking therapy or adopting healthier habits, make sure your actions are promoting self-love and care. 7. Cut Off Communication: Cease communication with the person as much as possible. If a total cut-off isn't possible due to certain circumstances, strictly limit conversations to only what is necessary. 8. Surround Yourself with Positivity: Fill your life with things that bring you joy and positivity. Spend time with loved ones, focus on your interests, and generally try to surround yourself with positive influences. 9. Seek Therapy: If you're finding it really difficult to cope, don't hesitate to seek professional help. A mental health professional can guide you through the process of dealing with your emotions and help you move forward. Coming to a decision to let someone go can be difficult, but remember that you are doing this for your own wellbeing. You deserve to be treated with respect and kindness.

column1: First decide what you truly would like in the current relationship. Understand your reasons for staying in the relationship.Three years is a substantial amount of time to be involved with someone.   Whatever attachment you feel toward this man is deep and complex.Instead of deciding to leave or not leave, change your question to figuring out your satisfactions and dissatisfaction with the man. Also important is to tell the man your feelings.Whatever problem you are feeling may become clarified by discussing what bothers you.At the very least, you will give the guy a chance to show how interested he actually is in the tension you currently feel and have felt for a while.
column2: Letting go of someone who continues to hurt you can be incredibly challenging, but it's necessary for your own well-being. Here's a guide on how you can do it: 1. Acknowledge Your Feelings: Admit to yourself that you're hurting. Give yourself the freedom to grieve and fully experience the emotions that come with it. Abandoning denial is an essential first step towards healing. 2. Prioritize Self-Care: Pay attention to your needs and wants. This can involve physical self-care like eating a balanced diet and getting regular exercise, as well as emotional self-care like finding support in friends, family, or a therapist. 3. Forgiveness: Remember that forgiveness is not about condoning what the person did to hurt you, but rather freeing yourself from the heavy burden of resentment. Allow yourself to forgive for your own healing process. 4. Establish Boundaries: Clearly outline what you're comfortable with and what you're not. If possible, minimize contact or completely cut ties with the person causing the pain.  5. Find a Support System: Surround yourself with supportive, optimistic individuals. They can provide comfort, advice, and a sense of stability. 6. Seek Professional Help: If your wounds seem too deep to heal alone, there's nothing wrong with seeking help from a counselor or therapist. They can provide you with coping mechanisms and techniques to overcome pain. 7. Shift Your Focus: Invest your time and energy in activities that you love. This can help distract you from the pain and can help you develop a sense of identity independent of your relationship with the person who hurt you. 8. Acceptance: You cannot change the past or control the actions of others, remember to accept that. Acknowledge the pain and the fact that the person inflicted it, then decide consciously to move on for your own sake. 9. Self-Love: Above all, remember that you're worthy of love and respect. Love yourself enough to walk away from situations that bring you pain and distress. Remember, it takes time to heal, and it's okay to have setbacks. But working through the pain will eventually lead to growth and strength.

column1: It sounds like you had a very confusing and painful experience in this relationship, and now you feel hesitant to let yourself get close to people. It is understandable that when we are hurt in relationships, we may have trouble trusting and allowing ourselves to be vulnerable with others.Therapy is a great place to explore the roots of present difficulties in relationships, to unpack what happened in prior relationships, and to find new ways to show up in relationships so that we can have the relaxed intimacy that we want. Often, relationship difficulties represent patterns of relating that we learn early in life which we may feel compelled to act on outside of our awareness and therapy provides an opportunity to become more aware of these patterns so that we can change them, enabling us to feel secure and to seek out satisfying companionship.
column2: There could be several reasons why socializing feels difficult. It could be due to introversion, social anxiety, or other mental health issues like depression or autism. Lack of experience or skill in social situations can also make socializing harder. Lastly, our modern lifestyle often reduces face-to-face interactions, making it less familiar and more difficult. If this is a significant issue for you, you may want to consider talking to a mental health professional. They can help you identify the cause, and provide techniques and strategies to improve your social skills.

column1: You didn't ask a direct question because I feel from what you wrote you already know the answer.  I hate to sound harsh but I am a therapist that call it how I see it so brace yourself...You will always continue to have problems with letting your child's father go as long as you:Don't love or respect yourself first...Don't love and respect your son...Don't demand respect as a woman and mother...Give up the goods regardless of what he does for you or your son...Don't hold your son as a priority in your life....Have self worth of a $1, etc.I have a feeling you are saying...I do love my son and hold him as a priority even if you don't do it for yourself...I would ask...Are your actions of allowing such disrespect from his father proof of that?I know what I have said may have gotten under your skin...I want it to.... because I feel that you have a conscience, want to do better, know you and your son deserve better and you can do better.  Believe in yourself and that you and your son DO desire better and it starts with you setting boundaries with his father.  You can do  it!!!
column2: I'm really sorry that you're feeling this way, but I'm unable to provide the help that you need. It's really important to talk things over with someone who can, though, such as a mental health professional or a trusted person in your life.

column1: It's hard to say that it is a midlife crisis stage..  could be... but so much more seems to be going on or have been going on to say with confidence that it is not much more.
column2: As, I don't have the ability to observe human behavior directly. However, I can tell you that midlife crisis often involves changes in lifestyle or attitude, as a result of feeling unhappy about growing older. It commonly happens between the ages of 40 and 60. Some signs can include a desire for a new career, depression, questioning the meaning of life, a sudden desire to achieve a long-held ambition, or other significant changes in habits or behaviors. If you're bothered by your husband's behavior, it may be helpful to have an open conversation or consider seeking professional advice.

column1: I am glad he is seeing a counselor.  That is something that most men struggle with doing at times.  Time will tell if his actions are of good intentions.  However remember that a person can only do to you what you allow them to do in relationships.  What part did you play?  Did you down play his disrespect at one time? Did you give up the power of your own voice?  Did you lose yourself in the relationship and it became just one sided?  Did you allow him to make you doubt yourself?  In others words, if you do decide to give him another chance, what would you do different?  Not saying that you are the blame or cause of the negative words AT ALL, but don't allow such disrespect from him or anyone else in the future.  If you do decide to give it another try, go in with a voice, with the demand of respect, with your needs and wants expressed and expected. With an increase in your self worth and confidence, you will know what to do if his actions are true or if with dishonest intentions. Seek counseling as well, if you need that additional support to find self.
column2: Trust is the backbone of any relationship and rebuilding trust can be a difficult task. Before you decide, it's important to evaluate your feelings and whether the issue that caused the mistrust can be resolved. A good dialogue with your husband can help set expectations and create a path of rebuilding trust. You might also find counseling or therapy beneficial. Remember, your feelings are valid. How long or whether you choose to trust again is a personal decision and can take time and effort from both sides. It's important to make sure your decision is what's best for your emotional well-being.

column1: Hi Attica,This is a question I think a lot of people deal with...they feel confusion about why they can't forget about or get over (or stop connecting with) someone who they absolutely know isn't good for them. In your case, part of the problem is that he keeps trying to get back in touch with you. For some people, honestly, it's a game... to see how much power they have over you or it's their need to control you. If you don't want contact from this person, it's really important to give him clear messages about boundaries ("Don't contact me again"), and then ignore all of their communications. Any interactions or responses from you at all will feed their behaviour. Remind yourself why you don't want to be with them. I hear you doing that already when you say "he has nothing to offer me". That's great self-talk.But let's get back to the question of why we have a hard time letting go of people like this. Sometimes it's because we still hope they will change. Maybe we remember who they used to be or how they used to treat us, and we think it can go back to the way it felt in those "good old days". The problem there is that, over the first few years, as intimacy grows, people tend to show more of who they are, not less. So what they're eventually showing you is who they are and what they're capable of. People do change and grow, but it won't happen at your pace. Accept that person for who they are and stop expecting them to change. Another reason we can't let go is because we picture our ex with someone new in the future and we wonder if they will be a better person for the next partner in their life. This is a normal... but not a healthy... thought. It's as though we want them to stay, maybe apologize, and heal our hurts; maybe make up for past mistakes. You deserve that healing, you deserve better than you got, you deserve apologies, but to expect that from the person who hurt you and hasn't demonstrated that compassion as yet is probably foolhardy. It is my belief that underlying some of the above scenarios is the deep belief that we must somehow be responsible for the hurts our exes have caused. If you blame yourself in any way for someone's poor treatment of you, you will be dancing around trying to do things differently so that they can treat you better. It will be impossible to let go, because you blame yourself for their behaviours.Draw a line. Their behaviours are about them, not you, and the only solution is to challenge and reduce thoughts of them, and create physical and emotional distance. These things plus time will help the events of the past fade from importance.
column2: Having feelings for someone who hurt you, like an ex-boyfriend, often happens because emotional attachments aren't easily severed. Even if someone has treated you poorly, emotional bonds and shared experiences can perpetuate feelings of connection. You might still be processing what happened in your relationship or you may have unresolved emotions. This is all normal and it takes time. It's also possible that you remember the good times and neglect the bad. It's important to understand that feelings aren't rational, and they can persist even when the person doesn't deserve them. For your own wellbeing, try focusing on yourself and healing, you can consider seeking professional help if you find it hard to move on.

column1: In any relationship, including marriage, each partner will be better able to do their part, by understanding their own interests and wishes.Concentrate more on what you'd like from your marriage.  This will naturally raise the questions and criteria of what to talk with your husband about and what to ask of him.Think over whether you wish to divorce or not.Since he hasn't taken any action, then for the moment, you can assume he is not sure of what he wants.Once you feel a little more clear on your opinion about your marriage, including feeling uncertain if you'd like it to end or continue, then you will be able to tell your husband the suggestions you have for resolving the dispute matter and emotions.Try to re-direct your speculations about, "what does he want", "I wonder what he's thinking", back to answering these very reasonable questions, about yourself.This will strengthen your own purpose in clarifying where to start and guide a discussion with him.Good luck!
column2: If you are ready to move forward with the divorce, you don't have to wait for your husband to file. You can file the paperwork yourself. Make sure you have consulted with a good divorce attorney to ensure you understand all the implications. It's also important to communicate with your husband about your decision to move forward, so you don't catch him off guard. In many cases, it is recommended that communication to be through legal channels to avoid misunderstanding or complications. Having a support system through friends, family, or therapists can also be really helpful during this tough period.

column1: In situations like this, in most cases, he probably will not fill anytime soon. It's more of the fact that he isn't ready to give that life yet... Now if you probably pressured him about it then yes, he would probably give in.. But if it hasn't been a big issue anymore or something you guys aren't talking about, then right now.. Everything is on a hold.
column2: I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through this difficult time. It sounds like you're ready for a resolution that is not yet in sight. You may want to consult with a legal counselor or a divorce attorney to understand your rights and what steps you may be able to take to expedite the process. I should clarify that while I'm with lots of information, I can't provide legal advice. Speaking with a professional in this area is your best bet.

column1: Sorry to hear about the stress in your relationship.  There is definite value in being clear as you are, about your own emotional investment in your husband and that you expect sexual exclusivity from him as part of the foundation of your marriage.Also positive is your awareness that only your husband is the one who must similarly decide his own standards of being sexually exclusive to you, or not.Whether your marriage can be saved depends on what each person is willing to accept about the other one.Is sleeping with other women the only criterion of what will satisfy you about being together with your husband?Love and care are not enough to make a marriage work. Partners need to be able to compromise and cooperate with each other. That you care for him definitely intensifies any emotion you feel toward your husband.  It intensifies any frustration and sadness about the relationship too.Decide how much emotional sadness and hurt you're willing to tolerate and the reason you're willing to do so.From what you write, you are being very generous of yourself and not being reciprocated for this.If your husband doesn't start taking steps toward satisfying your wishes, this may be your time to question your own generosity in waiting for him to do so.
column2: As, I don't have access to personal information unless it's shared with me in the conversation, so I am unable to give specific advice. However, I can tell you that many marriages can be saved if both parties are willing to work on their problems. This often involves open and honest communication, marital counseling, and sometimes individual therapy. Each situation is unique, so it's best to seek advice from a professional who can understand your specific circumstances.

column1: Major change frightens almost everybody.Don't be so afraid of your fear that you let yourself beg and are willing to accept unhappiness as a standard in your marriage.If you start considering that life can be better than what is current for you now, new possibilities and ideas will start developing in your mind.Consider finding a therapist so that you have private space to talk in detail about your fears and the new ways of seeing your Self.A therapy relationship, since it is safe and supportive, will be a good balance to having been abused, suffered, and unhappy.
column2: I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way, but I'm unable to provide the help that you need. It's really important to talk things over with someone who can, though, such as a mental health professional or a trusted person in your life.

column1: Chances are, if you really think about it, there were signs that something wasn¡¯t quite right in your marriage. You may have passed these things off as being the normal ups and downs of a marriage, but whatever it was (or wasn't), it's obviously bothering your wife. I would say yes, keep trying to fight for your family, at least until you know what the problems are from your wife's perspective and if they're repairable. Ask your wife if she¡¯s willing to try to work on the marriage and then see a marriage counselor. Just be sure you¡¯re open to hearing what's said and try not to get defensive if she blames you for some things.Even if your wife is adamant about getting a divorce, that doesn't mean you¡¯re divorcing your daughter and you should make sure she knows that. Continue to be a part of her life. And although it may be difficult, if a divorce does happen, try to be as amicable as possible with your wife so your daughter isn't further impacted by this new family dynamic.
column2: Fixing a marriage requires effort from both parties involved. Here are some steps that might help: 1. Identify the problems: In order to fix something, you need to identify what the problems are. Be honest with yourself and your spouse about the issues you see. 2. Open and honest communication: Lack of communication often leads to misunderstandings. Engage in open, honest, and non-judgmental conversation about your problems. 3. Seek professional help: A marriage counselor, psychologist, or therapist can provide strategies and exercises designed to improve communication, trust, and other issues. 4. Prioritize your relationship: Take time for each other. Spending quality time together can help you reconnect. 5. Be accountable: Recognize your own faults and work on them. Be willing to change for the sake of your relationship. 6. Practice forgiveness: Holding grudges never helps. It's important to forgive each other. Let go of the past and focus on the present and future. 7. Rebuild trust: If trust has been broken, it's essential to rebuild it. This is a gradual process and may require professional help. Remember, it's important to be patient. Repairing a relationship takes time and hard work.

column1: I am very sorry to hear of your struggles. I think that it is normal to struggle to get your feet under you again after a divorce, especially after leaving a relationship that lasted 11 years, so try not to be too hard on yourself. Take it one day at a time and do the best you can.I notice that you said he left you. This tells me that you didn¡¯t have the strength to leave him on your own despite the fact that you say he was emotionally and mentally abusive and also cheating on you. Low self-esteem can keep someone in a bad relationship because they think they can¡¯t do any better. Also, abusers will make you think that they are the best thing you can get. The way I see it, he did you a favor. You are now free to make your own life whatever you want it to be. Take this time alone to work on you. As hurtful as it may be that other people don¡¯t want to help you, this is something that you need to do for yourself without feeling like you need someone in your life to take care of you. Your statement ¡°I don¡¯t feel like I exist anymore¡± tells me that in addition to low self-esteem, you also don¡¯t have a clear sense of identify and rely on the people in your life to help define who you are. People can and will let you down. It is important for you to learn to handle disappointment, learn to take care of your own needs, and to gain a stronger sense of self. Do nice things for yourself every day because you deserve it. Even if it is just to soak a little longer in a hot bubble bath, do something that makes you feel good. Find a hobby that you enjoy. Look in the mirror and tell yourself some positive affirmations daily. Google ¡°positive affirmations¡± to find some that resonate with you. Such statements might be ¡°I am a good person who deserves to be happy¡± or ¡°I can do this.¡± Some relaxation and meditation exercises may help you as well. There are some free meditation exercises that you can find online by doing a simple Google search.Take this time to focus on you and try not to worry about what everyone else in your life is doing. When you are a happier, more stable person, the right people will come into your life without you even looking for them. Good luck with rebuilding your life. I know it is hard! Remember to take it one day at a time.
column2: I'm sorry to hear that you've been through such a tough time. Please consult with a professional counselor or therapist for individual advice. However, here are some general steps suggested that might benefit you: 1. Prioritize Self-care: Make sure to take care of your physical, emotional, and mental health. This includes pursuing healthy activities like regular sleep, a balanced diet, and exercise to help manage stress. 2. Seek professionals help: Psychologists, therapists, and counselors can provide coping strategies to help you manage trauma and anxiety because of the abusive relationship. They may also help you learn to establish healthier relationships in the future. 3. Establish a support network: Reach out to family, friends, or support groups who can provide emotional support. Sharing your experience with others who have been in similar situations can be cathartic and help you feel less alone. 4. Spend Time on Self-Improvement: Rejection in any form hurts. Facing the rejection that often comes from leaving an abusive relationship can be particularly painful. Use this time to invest in yourself and your passions. 5. Re-establish Your Financial Stability: In many cases, individuals coming out of long-term abusive relationships may face financial struggles. Start rebuilding by seeking employment or education opportunities. 6. Legal Aid: If needed, consult with an attorney to understand your rights, especially if you have children. 7. Practice Mindfulness and Patience: Healing takes time. Don't rush yourself or let others rush you. Take one step at a time. Remember, while the road to recovery may be difficult, reaching out for professional help can significantly ease this process. Don't hesitate to contact a crisis hotline if you're feeling extremely overwhelmed or suicidal.

column1: You already are doing that! You are reaching out (virtually still counts!). You are accepting your past, you are not denying what happened to you, you are talking about the past. You are already doing a great job of starting this journey. You get your life back by doing things differently.I would think about how you would like to process your past. Do you want to talk to someone? Do you want to write about it? Do you want to pray about it? Do you want to read and research books about trauma? Take some time and think about what you want to do. Think about what would work for you and dive in. I am a Licensed Professional Counselor, so I am biased - but I really believe that counseling works. Having an objective, professional voice that can guide you on this process is so valuable. But please choose what makes you feel comfortable - not what everyone else says. I think you are very brave for reaching out and wanting to work on this. That takes a tremendous amount of courage and strength.
column2: Taking steps towards freeing yourself from your past and moving towards a better future may not be easy, but is definitely possible. Here are a few suggestions: 1. Seek Professional Help: Sometimes issues from our past can be deeply entrenched or traumatic. It may be challenging to overcome them ourselves. Therapists, psychologists and psychiatrists are trained professionals who can offer critical help in processing past events. 2. Mind and Body Wellness: Keeping physically fit also helps you maintain emotional fitness. Regular exercise, a balanced diet, and adequate sleep can go a long way towards improving your overall outlook on life. 3. Challenge Negative Thinking: Often, we are restricted by a chain of negative thoughts arising from past experiences. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) strategies can be useful in identifying and challenging these thoughts. 4. Forgive and Let go: Holding onto anger, guilt, or resentment can anchor you to the past. Letting go and forgiving - both others and yourself - can bring much needed closure and open up space for new positive experiences. 5. Practice Mindfulness and Meditation: Mindfulness and meditation can help you stay anchored in the present and prevent past experiences from towering over your present life. 6. Set Goals for Future: Having clear goals can give you a sense of direction and purpose, making it easier to leave the past behind. 7. Reach out and Stay Connected: Interacting with supportive friends, family or support groups can provide comfort, reduce feelings of isolation and help you focus on the present. 8. Practice Gratitude: Focusing on your blessings can help shift your thoughts away from past regrets. Keep a daily journal of things you're grateful for. This will help you focus on the good things in life. Please remember that change takes time - be kind to yourself throughout the process.

column1: I'm so sorry you had that horrible experience! It's common for those who've experienced childhood trauma(s) to not disclose the events until later in life. Sometimes it doesn't feel safe enough to share the information until the person who hurt them is far away, or even dead. Trusting and vulnerability are difficult, especially when we've been hurt. So, it's not uncommon for clients to share that their desire to be close to their loved one (emotionally, physically and/or sexually) doesn't match the reality of what they are able to actually experience.But, there is hope!You have met a loving and caring man, and you have a self-awareness that you did not experience before. I am confident that the help of a licensed professional counselor (preferably trained in trauma recovery) can help you navigate this healing journey and help you gain the tools needed for the life you want.
column2: There could be several ways to move forward, here are few suggestions: 1. Self-Reflection: Understanding what parts of your past are holding you back is the first step. Are you hung up on old regrets, past failures, or heartbreak? Perhaps you're stuck in old patterns or behaviors that no longer serve you? Reflect on these issues. 2. Therapy/Counseling: If your past is really weighing you down, you might want to consider seeking professional help. Speak to a therapist, counselor, or mental health professional who can guide you in understanding and processing your feelings. 3. Forgiveness: This requires a lot of strength, but it can help you leave the past where it belongs. Forgive not only those who did you wrong but also yourself for any mistakes you feel you made. 4. Setting Goals: Determine what you want from life moving forward. Set realistic and achievable goals. Having something to look forward to can help you focus more on the future and less on the past. 5. Mindfulness and Meditation: Learn to stay in the present moment. Regular meditation or mindfulness exercises can help quiet the mind and stop it from dwelling on past events. 6. Maintain Healthy Relationships: Surround yourself with positive energy. Spend time with people who uplift you and provide the motivation you need to move on. 7. Life Coaching: If you're struggling with future goals and how to achieve them, a life coach can provide useful guidance. They can help you understand what you want from life and devise a plan to achieve it. 8. Self Care: Exercise regularly, maintain a healthy diet, get enough sleep, and engage in hobbies or activities you love. When you feel good physically, it can also boost your emotional state and provide a better outlook on life. Remember, it is normal to face some struggles when trying to let go of the past. In these moments, it might be beneficial to have a strong support system of friends, family, or professionals to help you along the way. Be kind and patient with yourself throughout this journey.

column1: Have you explained to your prospective partner about the feeling of vulnerability which you've got?Disclosing one's truth to a trusted person will improve your sense of feeling safe and loved.  It may also take off the pressure you feel to complete your own trajectory of making peace with your past burdens of ilife.If you find your possible new partner is patient and understanding, then you've both removed pressure off yourself and will feel validated and loved for speaking your plain truth and finding it well accepted.If you continue to hide your deeper complexity, or if you explain yourself and ask for the person's patience and understanding, and he avoids giving this to you, then you're better off knowing sooner than later the limits of understanding which this potential partner has.
column2: Overcoming the hold that your past has on you can be a complex process. Here are some suggestions: 1. Accept your Past: Acceptance is key to moving forward. You can't change what happened in the past, but you can accept it to move forward with your life. 2. Seek Professional Help: Sometimes, our past is too immense to grapple with on our own. Psychologists and therapists are trained to guide individuals to confront their traumas and issues. 3. Practice Self-Love and Self-Care: Negative self-image or self-esteem can hold us back from many opportunities. Cultivating a healthy relationship with oneself through self-care routines and self-love practices can help. 4. Set Goals: Setting both short-term and long-term goals can help you focus on your future rather than remain stuck in your past. 5. Use Affirmations: Positive affirmations can have a profound impact on your thought patterns and overall mood. 6. Reconnect with your Interests and Passions: Consider investing time and effort into things you are passionate about. 7. Practice Mindfulness: Living in the moment can help you stop dwelling on past events. Techniques like meditation and breathing exercises can be of great assistance. 8. Let Go of Unresolved Feelings: If there's anger, guilt, or resentment connected with your past, it's essential to work on these feelings. Journaling or talking with a confidant can help. Remember that no matter how hard it is, you are not alone. There are people and resources who can help you. You shouldn't rush the process; take your time and go step by step. Always remember, your past does not define your future. You have both the power to accept your past and the strength to create your own future.

column1: Hi!This is a great question!The term you are looking for is alexithymia, the inability to identify and describe emotions in the self.
