Some people are brought up in families where it's completely normal for the children to spend time with their parents or family members as they would with a friend or partner. Others see this as overstepping boundaries. Remember, communication is key in any relationship. If something is bothering you, you should talk about it openly instead of keeping it to yourself. Explain your feelings and why you think it might not be appropriate, or why you are uncomfortable with this. Try not to be confrontational, but rather focus on expressing your feelings. At the same time, be open to hear his explanation too. There might be reasons why he does this that you are unaware of. Coming to an understanding of each other's viewpoints is the first step toward finding a compromise that works for you both.

column1: Your doubts about your dating partner need to be addressed and solved so you can fully believe him again.Otherwise how would you actually know whether he's lying to you now or not?Start the conversation with him about wanting to trust him and asking for whatever details you feel will give you confidence he is telling you the truth.If he really wants to clear your doubts then he will be willing to invest in answering your extra questions or wanting to look through his phone or whatever areas you felt were violated by him in the past.
column2: Firstly, it's important to evaluate the severity and intent behind the lies. Small white lies may be different from big, harmful deceptions. If it's the latter, it's important to confront your partner about it. 1. Evaluate your feelings: Before confronting your partner, take some time to think about how you feel. Do you feel disappointed, angry, or betrayed? Or do you feel understanding because you know everyone makes mistakes? 2. Choose the right time and place: Discussing such a serious issue deserves a proper conversation. Choose a neutral location where both of you will feel comfortable and relaxed.  3. Confront them: Honest communication is key in any relationship. Tell your partner what you've discovered and express how it makes you feel. Use 'I' statements ¨C ¡®I feel... when you...¡¯ to reduce their defensiveness and promote understanding. 4. Listen to their side: After explaining your feelings, give your partner a chance to explain. It's possible there's a valid reason for their lie, or they might admit they were wrong. 5. Make your decision: After the conversation, take some time alone to think about what was said. Is this a one-off instance or a repeated pattern? Is the relationship still satisfying? 6. Seek counsel: If necessary, consider seeking advice from trusted friends, family members or a professional counselor. They may give you a clearer perspective and guidance.  Remember, trust is a crucial element in any relationship. It's hard to rebuild once it's broken. Therefore, your feelings of security and respect are paramount.

column1: Congrats on your upcoming wedding!Have you told the thoughts you write here, to your fianc¨¦ ?This is the place to start since you clearly are unhappy with a part of his and now your life, which will be with you for quite some time.
column2: This sounds like a complex situation, so here are some steps you may want to consider: 1. Open Communication: The first step is to have an open conversation about what is bothering you. Explain how you feel, and communicate your expectations. 2. Understanding: Try to understand why your fianc¨¦ puts his family first. It could be cultural or might be due to past influences. This understanding may help tailor your conversation and approach in discussing it. 3. Counseling: If open communication doesn't work, you might want to consider relationship or family counseling. An impartial third party may help to mediate and overcome these issues. 4. Compromise: You both may need to compromise. While it's important to put your immediate family first, your fianc¨¦'s bond with his family shouldn't be neglected either.  5. Plan things together: Making plans together where both families (yours and his) are involved can ease up things and also find common ground where everyone gets time and attention. 6. It might help to establish some boundaries: This includes decisions about spending holidays, handling finances, and visits from family members. Remember, make sure that any step you take is respectful towards your relationship as well as the families involved. Relationships with in-laws can sometimes be challenging, but understanding and compromise from all sides can help to build a stronger bond.

column1: Start a conversation with him about your sincere interest to earn back his trust.Ask him what he expects from you so that he will trust you again.If you are consciously willing and do try to earn back his trust, and have periodic conversations with him on whether he feels more at ease with trusting you, then after a few months of this, both of you should feel more secure in the relationship.
column2: Regaining trust in a relationship after it has been broken due to dishonesty is a challenge and requires time and patience. However, it isn't impossible. Here are a few steps that can help: 1. Apologize sincerely: Start with a genuine and heartfelt apology. Explain to him why you lied, but don¡¯t make excuses to minimize your actions. 2. Be Patient: Understand that rebuilding trust will take time and your boyfriend may need space and time to process what has happened. 3. Be Open and Honest: Start practicing honesty in all conversations, minor or major. Be transparent about your intentions, your feelings, and your actions.  4. Show Consistency: Act consistently and do what you promise you¡¯ll do. Show him that your actions match your words. 5. Show Remorse: Show him you regret your dishonesty and are taking steps to better yourself and avoid lies in the future. 6. Understand His Feelings: Understand his feelings and validate them. It's natural for him to feel hurt or betrayed. 7. Seek Professional Help: If the dishonesty has been far reaching, consider seeking help from a counselor or therapist who specializes in relationship issues. They can guide you through the process of rebuilding trust. 8. Communicate: Keep the channels of communication open. It¡¯s important to talk about what happened, how it made both you feel and how to move forward. 9. Learn from the past: Use this incident as a learning experience to improve your behavior and communication in the relationship. Remember, trust is something that should never be taken for granted. When it's broken, it's difficult to mend. But if both parties are willing to work at it, trust can be restored.

column1: Pleasing someone certainly does feel satisfying.  If the other person does not appreciate your effort and good will then this feels dissatisfying.Offering happiness to someone does not include tolerating mean comments such as the ones you describe here.Tell the person that you are trying to please them and also tell the person that their comments are hurtful.If the person said their words with no bad intentions then next time they comment its reasonable to expect these comments to not hurt your feelings.Keep in mind that your good intentions may not be received in the way you intend them.  Some people, sometimes are insensitive or just plain not interested in being pleased by another person.
column2: Yes, unfortunately, it is possible for someone to love you and say hurtful things. There can be numerous reasons for this type of behavior. Sometimes, individuals might not realize the impact of their words. Other times, they might act out in anger or frustration. Personal insecurities can also drive people to lash out at those they care about most. However, expressing love should ideally involve respect, kindness, and understanding. If someone repeatedly hurts you emotionally, it's crucial to communicate your feelings and consider seeking professional help. Remember, love should never equate to emotional abuse.

column1: Well, then your decision is whether you want to stay in this type of relationship or not.One point to keep in mind is this.Just because he's not telling you his opinions doesn't mean he doesn't have any opinions.In the long run t is always easier to talk with someone about their differences from our point of view than to be someone who doesn't tell you what is in their mind.Short term it seems easy to have someone agreeable.Long term someone who doesn't tell you their thoughts and who disagrees with you, may potentially go about their true wishes in hidden ways.
column2: As, I don't have the specific context or details of your personal relationship to judge. However, if you find yourself frequently dissatisfied or critical of your boyfriend's actions, it may be worth having a conversation about your expectations and feelings. If you're feeling unsure whether you're being "picky" or not, it could be helpful to seek advice from trusted friends or family, or even a professional counselor.

column1: You are definitely in a frustrating situation.Your friend and the boyfriend are doing what is natural for couples who are in the early stage of their relationship.  Being almost inseparable to the point of overlooking friends, is understandable as long as it doesn't continue for long enough that friends feel hurt.If you feel you would like to one more time tell your friend that you miss your friendship with her and would like her attention, then do so.After expressing your needs as much as possible and if the result doesn't change, then the sad conclusion is that your friend is willing to give you less time and energy than you require from her.
column2: Overcoming jealousy can be challenging, but several strategies may help you manage your feelings: 1. Understand the Root of Your Jealousy: Try to figure out why you're jealous. Is it because you're secretly attracted to your best friend's boyfriend, or because you feel alone or unloved? Addressing the root cause can help you manage your feelings better.     2. Get Involved in Other Activities: Take up new hobbies or classes so that you stay occupied and not continuously think about the situation that makes you jealous. 3. Find Someone Special: If you're single and desiring a relationship, start dating. This may help to take your mind off your friend's relationship. 4. Talk About It: If comfortable, open up to another friend about your feelings. This could help you gain a different perspective. But avoid expressing these feelings to your best friend as it may strain your relationship. 5. Practice Mindfulness: Mindfulness and meditation may help you focus on the present moment and reduce negative feelings.  6. Cultivate Self-love: Improve your self-esteem and self-confidence. If you're happy with who you are, you can feel less envious of others. 7. Seek Professional Help: If your feelings of jealousy become overwhelming, there's no harm seeking a professional like a therapist. They can provide you with coping mechanisms to deal with such emotions. Remember, it's okay to feel occasional jealousy, but it's crucial that these feelings don't harm your relationship with your friend. Everyone is on a different path in life, so try not to compare yourself to others.

column1: Tell him what you know and ask why he is lying to you.  If he tells you he isn't lying and you have proof that he is, then you can either accept that he denies the truth or not.
column2: How you handle this situation highly depends on your personal feelings and the agreed-upon boundaries within your relationship. Here are some steps you could consider: 1. Gather Evidence: Before accusing him, make sure you have sufficient and correct evidence. Take screenshots or save those messages, profiles, anything that proves the point. 2. Reflect: Take some time to process your feelings. It's better to approach the situation when you're calmer so you can have a more effective conversation about your concerns. 3. Communication: One of the key aspects of a relationship is communication. Express your feelings to him honestly and openly. Show him the evidence and ask for an explanation. 4. Listen to His Side: Listen to what he has to say. There could be a misunderstanding, or he might admit to his mistake. 5. Decide: Depending on his response, decide what's best for you. If he acknowledges his mistake and if you're willing to forgive him, you might decide to work through it. But remember, building trust back takes time and effort. 6. Seek professional help: If you're finding it hard to cope with the situation, don't hesitate to seek help from a counselor or a therapist. Always remember, you deserve honesty and respect in any relationship.

column1: I would suggest possibly talking about the type of relationship that both of you want to create. For example, you may want a relationship where honesty, listening, compassion, and romanticism are major parts. You could also see what your boyfriend wants.You may also consider taking five minutes to see if he will listen to your feelings about him being on the dating site and whether he can work to learn more about what you are experiencing with asking open-ended questions (not being answered with yes or no) and restating what you are saying to see if he has it right. After that, perhaps you could switch so that you can listen to his perspective for five minutes and learn more about what he is doing by asking open-ended questions.Remember that it takes two people to have  a relationship, so the choice is yours as to whether you choose to stay in the relationship and what kind of relationship you would like to have.
column2: This is a tough and personal situation, so there isn't an exact correct course of action. However, here are some steps to consider: 1. Process Your Emotions: Discovering a partner's unfaithfulness can ignite a whirlwind of emotions. Allow yourself some time to process these emotions before you do anything else. 2. Collect Evidence: If possible, screen capture or keep some sort of evidence of what you've found. Preserve it in case it becomes necessary to refer back to during your conversation.  3. Plan Your Conversation: Plan how you want to confront him. Think about what you want to say, what questions you need answers to, and what your boundaries are moving forward. 4. Speak Calmly and Clearly: When you're ready, approach him calmly. Express your feelings honestly, using 'I' statements to express how you feel rather than accusing him. 5. Seek Understanding: Ask him why he did it. While it may not justify his actions, understanding the rationale can provide valuable insight. 6. Figure Out What You Want: Determine whether you want to repair the relationship or move on. It¡¯s important to remember that trust is a fundamental part of a relationship, and once it¡¯s broken, it can be hard to repair. 7. Consider Seeking Help: If your partner is remorseful and you both want to work through this, consider seeking help from a professional relationship counselor. Remember that everyone is unique, and the process of dealing with such a situation can vary greatly from person to person. The most important thing is to make sure that whatever decision you make, it is the best for your mental and emotional health.

column1: First off, don't blame yourself or be too quick to jump to any scary conclusions.  Human sexuality can be incredibly complex at times (e.g., what turns us on at one time may not be what turns us on the next time). There could actually be a number of things going on including him having performance anxiety...maybe he had a bad experience with a previous partner that's left him scared to try again (we call this operant conditioning).  It could also be that he puts you in a different category than previous lovers.  Sometimes I refer to this as the "hooker-housewife mentality" where a partner somehow gets the idea that when we truly fall in love, we treat that one differently; almost up on a pedestal.  Drives many partners crazy until they're aware that this is going on and give their boyfriend/ girlfriend permission to enjoy both the naughty and the nice with them. It could also be that he's not even aware that he's not doing these things. If you haven't asked him yet, you might try gently approaching the subject when you're not already in the bedroom or trying to get in on and inquire what he most enjoys about sex with you (or has enjoyed in the past, or thinks he might enjoy).  You can also share your favorite highlights of sex with him.  Give him an ego boost and tell him what he does well while then asking him if he'd be down to go downtown.  "Baby, it REALLY turns me on when you kiss me during sex."If you continue to get the impression that it's somehow only about YOU or that he's just really hesitant to talk about sex in general, you might see if he'd be cool to chat with a counselor who specializes in sexual intimacy.
column2: It's crucial in any relationship to have open and honest communication about the aspects of comfort, boundaries, and preferences. If he is abstaining from certain sexual activities with you that he has done with others previously, it could be because of a few reasons: 1. He might be respecting what he perceives as your comfort zone or boundaries. 2. He might have had negative experiences with those activities in the past. 3. His desires or perception regarding those activities might have changed. 4. The dynamics and chemistry in every relationship differ. If you feel comfortable doing those activities and want to explore them, communicate your desires with him in an open and empathetic way. Understand his thought process and respect his feelings as well. It's essential to create a safe space in which both of you feel free to express your feelings and expectations.

column1: Ask him!Having a conversation about sexual satisfaction increases emotional intimacy.Not only will you potentially feel more deeply connected from a sincere conversation about your sexual questions, maybe this increased emotional closeness will inspire the sexual closeness you wish to receive.
column2: This might be because of many reasons. It may be that he respects you and doesn't want to do anything that could be degrading or disrespectful. Maybe those things don't align with your relationship dynamic, or he didn't enjoy those experiences and decided not to repeat them. Or, maybe he's grown and matured and doesn't do those things anymore. If you feel comfortable, you can always communicate about it with him. Healthy communication is key to understand each other¡¯s comfort levels and desires.

column1: Your boyfriend and you have a separate relationship than your relationship with your mother.   By trying to control whether or not you visit your mom, unless you are in agreement with this, is building tension between you and him.Ask why he resents your interest to see your mother.If he is insecure to the point where he fears your mother will influence your opinion about him, then trying to prevent you from visiting your mom is itself creating negativity in you toward him.If something still bothers him about the problems you both had several months ago, then talking about these problems will do more to clear the air between the two of you than him trying to interfere in your relationship with your mother.
column2: It's unfortunate that your boyfriend is having a problem with you visiting your mother. You should talk to him to understand his concerns and express your views. It is important in a relationship to respect each other's familial ties. If there is a valid reason, then try to work it out. However, if there isn't any reasonable cause for this issue from his side, it might be indicative of controlling behavior, which is a significant red flag in a relationship. You should never have to choose between your partner and your family. Remember to maintain a balance and respect everyone's feelings.

column1: You are not a pedophile. You are both under 18 and your age is appropriate for a relationship. There would be a possible problem if she was 10 or younger. Pedophelia, is a whole other problem that you probably should not be worried about. I would be happy to talk with you in more detail about this.
column2: No, it's not wrong at all. In fact, it's essential for a healthy romantic relationship. Being attracted to your partner emotionally, intellectually, and physically can contribute to the quality of your partnership. Remember, attraction is subjective and can vary significantly from person to person.

column1: Nope! In fact you are NOT a pedophile. That term is reserved for older adolescents attracted to children, or adults who are attracted to children. I see an age difference as being one key factor in determining pedophilia if the older person is still in adolescence. You being only a year older than your girlfriend doesn't qualify, so go right ahead and be attracted to your girlfriend without shame!
column2: No, it's completely normal and healthy to be attracted to your girlfriend. Physical, emotional, and intellectual attraction are all part of a loving and balanced relationship.

column1: You wrote that each of you is under the age of 18.   A 15 year old cannot be a pedophile because you're not an adult.Also, if you mean "girlfriend" in a romantic way then this makes sense bc romantic relationships include physical attraction to the other person.
column2: No, it's natural and normal to be attracted to your girlfriend. Attraction ¡ª physical, emotional and otherwise ¡ª is often a significant part of a romantic relationship.

column1: No. You are not a pedophile. You are both under the appropriate age where it would be seen so. Your both only a year a part so this shouldn't a worry to you. Like Frank said below, Pedophelia is a problem that won't apply to this situation.
column2: No, it is not wrong for you to be attracted to your girlfriend. Attraction is a natural part of a relationship.

column1: No, that's perfectly normal. You're under 18, too. You're only a year older than she is. This is absolutely normal. What would be wrong is if you did anything to her against her will. Always remember that NO means NO, respect her, respect yourself, and be a normal teenager! Have a healthy relationship. Holding hands, kissing, and more should only be done when both are comfortable with it and agree to it. Although it is frowned upon by a lot of people, it's no secret that teenagers do have sex (even if their parents and perhaps religion would definitely not want them to do it). Only you can make the choice that is right for you. Just be responsible in the choices you make. Some states have laws on what age is old enough for consensual sex. You'd be surprised how young those ages are. A 14 year old having sex with a 20 year old would be against the law, but someone the same age as her, or just one year older is not. "Wrong" can be defined in a lot of different ways, though. Is it against the law? No. Is it against your religion? I can't answer that for you. You can, however, have a relationship that is not physical in any way. It's okay to just be with her and enjoy her company. You can hang out, watch movies together, go on dates, do whatever it is that both of you enjoy doing. Your relationship can be anything you want it to be.
column2: No, it's not wrong at all. Being attracted to your girlfriend is a natural part of a healthy relationship. This attraction can be both physical and emotional/intellectual, and it typically enhances your bond and connection with each other.

column1: Thanks for asking this question. I think the most important part of what you mentioned was that you do it because it makes you happy. For that reason, I would encourage you to keep doing what makes you happy.As far as telling girls or keeping it a secret, I don't really think that it's necessarily one or the other, at least not the first time that you meet. In other words, one part of your decision-making could be whether it is something that you always want to address in the first date, or perhaps something that you address after you've known each other for a couple of meetings. The answer to that question may also change depending on who you are dating. I would imagine that each person that you are with mainly due to a different decision this was when to disclose this. It sounds like this is an important part of you, so I would think that if you were going to date someone long-term, you would want them to know about the most important parts of you, including that.I also encourage you to remember that if you meet someone who is not comfortable with this, that does not mean that there is anything wrong with what you are doing, but rather something that the other person is in some way deciding not to continue learning about or choosing to have someone they are dating like to cross-dress.I'd also ask you to consider this: Are the people who you say this to expecting it? My guess is that the answer is probably not. Along with that, Are they going to have questions? I would imagine so.Are you comfortable answering questions?I wonder if you could figure out yourself or with friends (or perhaps even with a therapist) how you would answer these sorts of questions:What exactly is cross-dressing?Does that change the gender that you're attracted to?What does it mean to you?Why is it important to you?And what you want your listening person to know about you related to cross-dressing.There could even be ways that you can start the conversation by asking them to be open to listen to you and ask questions about what they are thinking before they make any quick decisions about you or the relationship.I certainly hope that you find the right person for you. I imagine that having this conversation could be stressful, especially considering the idea that you have had some negative reactions in the past. Remember that talking this through with a therapist could be very helpful.
column2: Telling someone, specifically a girl, about your crossdressing may be a sensitive topic. It greatly depends on the nature of your relationship and how accepting or understanding she might be. Here's how you can approach it: 1. Choose the right time and place: Make sure you choose a calm and private setting where you can talk honestly without being disturbed or feeling uncomfortable.  2. Be honest and sincere: Be open about your feelings because honesty is crucial in this situation. It¡¯s okay to express that you're nervous about her reaction.  3. Start subtly: Bring up the topic of individuality, and diversity, see how she reacts to it. If she seems receptive, you can proceed to talk about your crossdressing habits.  4. Communicate openly: Explain how long you've been doing it, why you enjoy it, and how it makes you feel. It's a part of your identity and she should know its importance to you. 5. Be prepared for any reaction: Understand that she may be surprised, confused or shocked - make sure that you're prepared for it. If she's comfortable with it immediately, that's great. If not, give her time and space to process this information.  6. Encourage her to ask questions: She might have many questions, try to answer them patiently and honestly. Let her know that's it's alright for her to express her feelings and ask anything she needs to get a better understanding. Remember, the most important aspect here is expressing your identity comfortably and openly. Every person has unique traits and habits, and there's nothing wrong with that.

column1: Keep doing the crossdressing since you like it.Your problem sounds more a matter of timing and reason to tell the girl about it.Not keeping a secret is a good attitude regarding meaningful parts of your life.  Usually our relationship partner is someone whom we trust as a safe person to know all about us.Once you feel at ease with your potential partner then bring up your crossdressing.  Based on their handling of this intimate part of your life, you will know more as to whether or not you feel more or less drawn to them.Secrets held within a relationship usually get worse with time.   The person who feels unsafe in truly being and stating themselves eventually will end up feeling ashamed of parts of them which prior to the relationship, felt good or at least not worrisome.
column2: Discussing something personal like crossdressing requires sincerity, honesty and respect for the other person's feelings as well as your own. Here is a guideline on how to go about it: 1. Choose the right time and place: Find a private, neutral place to talk and make sure there is no rush so you both have time to digest the information and speak openly about your feelings. 2. Make sure the other person feels safe and respected: Reassure her that your intention is to be honest and transparent, not to shock her or cause any discomfort.  3. Be honest and clear: Directly tell her that you like to crossdress, explaining what it means to you and why you do it. Make sure to be sincere in your words and reassure her it is part of your personality. 4. Expect any kind of reaction: She might be surprised, confused, and not know what to say or react immediately. It's important to understand that she might need time to process this information. 5. Allow her to express her feelings: Encourage her to share her thoughts and feelings. Be patient and be ready to answer any questions she may have. 6. Be ready for any outcome: While your honesty is commendable, it's possible that she might not react positively to the information. If this is the case, you both might have to reconsider the status or future direction of your relationship.  Remember, honesty is the best policy when it comes to relationships, and it is also important you are comfortable being your true self with your partner.

column1: It would be my professional opinion that the desire for you to keep it a secret at all, while yes I could see it as "giving you a chance with a girl," is something that might be more about a discomfort for you. If you are comfortable with your kinks and fetishes (if I may call it such, not my intention to pathologize in any way though), then be as open as you want to be. But I also don't know that you need to be announcing it as part of your online dating profile (because you do say it "bothers girls I ask out" which to me implies that that is what you're leading with.) My hope is that people don't make dating decisions based on your kinky behaviors, but more likely that they would make decisions based on your own comfort and security with said kinky behaviors.
column2: Having a conversation about personal, sensitive matters like cross-dressing can be difficult, but it is important to be honest, especially in a relationship. Here are a few steps to guide you: 1. **Choose the right time:** Have this conversation at a time when you're both relaxed and free from distractions.  2. **Prepare for the conversation:** Figure out ahead of time what you're going to say. You might even want to practice talking to a friend or to yourself.  3. **Start with positive affirmations:** Start the conversation by affirming your feelings for her, paving the path for understanding before you disclose this part of your identity. 4. **Contextualize your experience:** Explain to her when you realized this was a part of who you are and what it means to you. This will help her understand that it is not a "phase" or something you do for fun, but an important part of your identity. 5. **Be honest:** Tell her exactly what cross-dressing means to you and how often you do it. 6. **Reassure her:** Make sure she understands that this doesn't change how you feel about her, and you are still the same person she likes or loves. 7. **Give her time to process:** Even if she's supportive, it's normal for her to have some questions and need time to process what you've told her. Don't rush things. 8. **Answer any questions she might have:** She may have questions. Be open and patient in answering them. Remember, it is important that you feel comfortable and accepted for who you are in a relationship. If she cannot accept this part of you, it may be best to part ways. It's important to be true to yourself.

column1: Your happiness and healthiness is key.  I would not suggest that you hold back and keep it a secret.  You should be up-front about it, but perhaps gently bring it up on a date.  When thinking about whether or not you should stop, think about how it makes you feel.  Perhaps try to be social at more accepting affirming locations in your area.  The people who will accept you for who you are are out there.  You may not be looking in all of the places you have available to you.
column2: Conveying sensitive information requires a calm, reassuring, and neutral environment. Here's a step-by-step suggestion on how to approach this: 1. Choose the right time and place: Wait for a moment when you both are relaxed and have some privacy. A conversation of this importance deserves your full attention and hers. 2. Be open and honest: "I have something I'd like to share with you. It's really important to me and I trust you enough to talk about it." 3. Explain your interest: "I enjoy crossdressing. This does not change who I am as a person or my feelings for you, it's just a part of me that I needed you to know about." 4. Assure her it does not affect your feelings towards her: "My interest in crossdressing doesn't change how I feel about you. I still care for you deeply and my feelings are as strong as ever." 5. Show empathy: Understand that she may need some time to digest this information. Be patient and encourage her to ask questions if she wants to know more. 6. Reassure her: Specify that you're still the same person, and that this is just another part of you that she is now aware of.  Every individual is different though and will react differently, so adapt this to your specific situation and relationship.

column1: While this might not be the first thing you want to discuss when you meet someone, it is important for you to be yourself.  It's better to weed out 10 people who can't accept you to find that one who can.
column2: Discussing personal interests, especially those that may be sensitive or unconventional, can sometimes be difficult. However, open communication is vital for any relationship. Here are some helpful tips on how to approach this topic: 1. Choose the Right Time: Find a casual, relaxed place where you can talk openly without time pressure or other distractions. Make sure both you and the girl are in a good mood and open to discussion. 2. Build up Trust: Be sure there is a reasonable level of trust and understanding between the two of you. This should not be an early conversation, rather for when you've known each other for some time and feel comfortable sharing personal details. 3. Be Direct and Honest: Don't beat around the bush. Make sure you have her full attention and express yourself honestly. Say something like, "There's something I want to share with you about myself that's very personal and important to me. I trust you, and I want you to know that I crossdress. This is a part of who I am." 4. Be Prepared to Answer Questions: She might have lots of questions, especially if she has little or no prior knowledge about crossdressing. Make sure you are ready to answer her questions calmly and patiently. 5. Be Respectful of Her Reaction: She might not understand or agree with your lifestyle. Remember, she's entitled to her opinion. Give her time to process the information. 6. Reassure Her: Be sure to reassure her that your decision to crossdress doesn't define your entire identity. Say something like, "This is just a part of who I am, it doesn't change the person you've gotten to know." Remember, every person is unique, and so will be their reaction to this news. Be patient and understanding.

column1: As exasperated as you feel, and as obvious it is to you that your husband cares more about drinking than being honest with you, changing this is up to him.Does he care that you're upset with him for drinking more than he can handle?Does he care about you more than drinking?Living with an alcoholic, which is how his behavior sounds, is lonely and frustrating.Concentrate on what you like about him as he is now with his drinking.Your happiness matters.  His ignoring of what you're talking about, doesn't mean your requests are unreasonable.Be prepared to learn to live with and accept how he behaves, or not.Avoid the expectation that you can convince him to change.People change only when they realize their life can improve by changing.  He doesn't sound like this, at least now.
column2: I'm really sorry to hear that you're dealing with this. It sounds like a difficult situation. It would be helpful to communicate your feelings about this directly to him. If it gets too overwhelming, seeking professional help like counseling or a support group could be beneficial. You could also reach out to guidance counsellors, ahead of group meetings like Alcoholics Anonymous (AA), for advice on how to handle such situations. It's important to remember to take care of yourself through this process.

column1: It can be very frustrating being lied to.  The one thing that struck me was the sentence he had a alcohol addiction "in the past."  Addiction is not something that comes and goes.  Once you have addict tendencies they are here to stay.  You may be able to fight them off for awhile but the will enviably rear their ugly head again.  Some of the things that we would suggest is taking the access away.  If the alcohol is not conveniently in the house he would have to go seek it out elsewhere.  You can think about it in other terms.  If chocolate cake was your favorite food and you were a diabetic, you would not have chocolate cake lying around all the time because you know you would eventually eat it.  Remember there are no temporary addicts.
column2: I'm sorry to hear that you're going through this. It's important to approach this situation delicately because addiction is a very serious issue. Perhaps it's time for an open and honest conversation about both of your expectations and concerns. Seek professional help if things are not improving. Support groups, therapy, and medication can all play a role in helping with addiction problems. You don't have to handle this on your own.

column1: Hi Los Angeles,So your husband is giving you mixed messages. He says he's willing to cut back on the drinking, but he drinks and hides it. His behaviour is passive aggressive and immature, which puts you into this position of having to act like a disapproving parent. It sounds more like you're talking about an out-of-control teenager than your partner. Your husband's lying is sending a message. "I get to make my own decisions and you can't stop me" might be it. Underneath that, maybe it's "I want to stop but I'm ashamed that I can't and I don't want you to see my failures". Ultimately, as an adult, he gets to decide what he puts in his mouth and if you try to manage that by monitoring how many beers he has, you are pretty certain to get some fallout... pushback...backlash...  How does his drinking affect you? That's where your voice has power, rather than in counting his beers or setting him up to lie (when he's passed out, asking if he's been drinking seems confusing). You've mentioned snoring, which I guess is a legitimate complaint. If he's passing out, that's a legitimate complaint. When he drinks does he drive, act aggressively, or 'check out of' the relationship (avoid you)? All of these things are legitimate concerns, and I'd stick to talking about those rather than counting beers. My guess is he has few other ways to cope with stress, so he checks out with alcohol, and it also helps him avoid your relationship. But the problem is it makes it worse; the more he avoids you, then more you chase him with your questions.There's a conversation that would be helpful here.  It sounds like "I've tried to support you in your drinking less, and it's not working. What are your goals for alcohol and how can I support you in that more effectively?" I'd like to see you in a place where you're not micromanaging his drinking, but focusing on the things that affect you. What concrete supportive methods can you use with his agreement? Can we get the alcohol out of the house? Is he willing to seek treatment? Lay your expectations out really clearly. "I won't count your beers, but I can't tolerate lying". You have to decide what's more important; is it really the number of beers, or is it something else. What do you need to happen in order to want to remain in the marriage? What does he need? Does he let you know what isn't okay with him? He might have trouble saying these things. The drinking is only a part of the complex dynamic in your marriage. A qualified therapist can assist in pulling this apart, understanding it, and changing the way you relate to each other.
column2: I'm really sorry that you're going through this. It must be incredibly frustrating to endure betrayal from someone you trust. It's important to communicate with your husband about his drinking habits and expressing how his dishonesty affects you. If he's not already getting help for his addiction, you might want to consider suggesting therapy or rehabilitation services. Remember, it's vital to prioritize your own emotional wellbeing too--seeking the help of a professional counselor or support groups may provide you with the strength needed throughout this journey.

column1: I'm sorry to hear of your problem.First step as always when a possible medical explanation exists, go for a urology check up to either your internist or a urologist.Once you know there is no medical reason which would prevent an erection, then we can consider the psychological and emotion based factors.Maybe you're nervous about your sexual performance or that your gf may be disappointed in your performance.Men often mistake their own fears of performance failure with the assumption that their partner thinks about sex as a performance.Talk with your gf about whatever is on your mind which may inhibit you from enjoying sex.The reasons are endless.What matters is to have a heartfelt dialogue with each other.The emotional support which comes through such an intimate conversation may very well be the catalyst for a more relaxed and satisfying approach to sex w your gf.
column2: This could be due to a number of reasons such as: 1. Psychological issues: Stress, anxiety, depression, low self-esteem or relationship problems can all contribute to erectile dysfunction (ED). 2. Physical conditions: Certain medical conditions such as diabetes, heart disease, obesity, high cholesterol, or low testosterone can lead to ED. Also, it can be a side effect of certain medications. 3. Lifestyle factors: High alcohol consumption, smoking, drug misuse, lack of exercise, or unhealthy diet can affect your ability to get an erection. 4. Performance anxiety: This is especially common in new relationships or if you have had a previous sexual failure. It would be advisable to consult a healthcare professional to understand the underlying cause. They may suggest lifestyle changes, therapy or medication if required. It¡¯s nothing to be ashamed of and is often treatable so there is help available.

column1: First off, I want to acknowledge the emotional pain you must be experiencing about not being able to experience an erection -- you're not alone. And, it took a lot of courage for you to post your query here. Below you will find excellent advice from skilled clinicians regarding your question and concern. If you haven't done so already I'd encourage you to checkout the Mayo Clinic's website on this very topic (http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/seasonal-affective-disorder/basics/definition/con-20021047).Once you've ruled out any medical-organic issues with either your PCP or Urologist I recommend you work with a Certified Sex Addiction Therapist (CSAT) and/or Certified Sex Therapist (CST) and do some psychotherapy around attachment/family-of-origin, intimacy, self-image, trauma history, sex history, pornography, etc. ). There is hope.
column2: There could be a variety of reasons why you're having difficulty getting an erection. They can be broadly classified into physical and psychological causes. 1. Physical causes: Erectile dysfunction can occur due to medical conditions like heart disease, diabetes, obesity, hormonal imbalances, or any damage to nerves and arteries responsible for erections. Certain medications, alcohol, smoking, and drugs can also affect the erection. 2. Psychological causes: Stress, anxiety, depression, relationship problems, and performance anxiety can all lead to erectile dysfunction. It's advisable to consult with a healthcare professional who can help identify the underlying cause and recommend appropriate treatment.

column1: This is something I have had to address with individuals often since working with couples is one of my practice's focuses.  The answer can depend upon several reasons all which tend to be explored while in session.  If you or your counselor utilizes an integral approach, in which one of the main premises makes sure to check the four irreducible perspectives (subjective, intersubjective, objective and interobjective ¨C also known as the four quadrants) in determining where the challenges are, it then becomes possible to identify what might be contributing to or causing the challenge as well as offering up ways to address the situation.In this case, from the upper-right or behavioral and physical perspective, we would want to make sure there is no physical limitation or ailment meaning that you would need to visit your doctor and have the basics checked (such as blood pressure.  We would also look at particular behaviors to see if you are doing something with is effecting performance (such as masturbating often or being influenced by pornography). Next we would look at the upper left quadrant (thoughts, cognitions, identity, feelings) to look at what is going on here both during sexual activities and at other times.  If you are worried about your job, your family or under immense pressure to perform at work or while intimate, this can contribute to your situation.  From there we would turn to the lower left quadrant (cultural rules and tools) to see who you have learned to interpret challenges that come up during sex and look for ways to shift, update and/or reshape the way you view sex and its challenges.  It would be here that we would see whether one is even comfortable using a service like counseling based upon how your family/culture of origin views the profession. Finally, we would need to account for challenges that show up in the lower right quadrant (systems, laws, rules of society) such as your economic ability to try services and products as well as whether such services and products were even available.  Once we have rolled through these areas it then becomes possible to look at which aspects might need to be looked at further in a more meaningful way to help you change a perspective or if just getting a blood pressure medication is all you need.To sum your question then of why you can¡¯t keep an erection we would need to look at your thoughts (look at your actual thoughts during the act as well as before and after), look at your behaviors, look at your physical body for issues, look at where you picked up your rules and tools (culture) and look at your ability to access goods and services.  They all contribute equally and need to be taken into account.  So - as you can see, there is no one possible answer to this, but several.  I hope this helps.
column2: There can be various reasons for this. Some of them might include: 1. Stress or Anxiety: Whether it's related to performance, financial, work, or personal issues, stress and anxiety can play a part in the inability to get or maintain an erection. 2. Depression: Having feelings of extreme sadness or feeling down can cause erectile dysfunction. 3. Medical Conditions: Conditions such as heart disease, diabetes, high blood pressure, or even low testosterone can contribute to erectile dysfunction. 4. Alcohol or Drug Use: Both can affect your ability to achieve or maintain an erection. 5. Medications: Certain medications can cause erectile dysfunction, such as antidepressants or high blood pressure medications. 6. Relationship Problems: If there's a lack of communication, trust, or emotional connection in your relationship, it can impact your sexual relationship as well. Remember, it's normal to sometimes have difficulty getting or maintaining an erection. However, if this is a consistent issue, it's important to discuss it with a healthcare professional or a counselor. They can help you discover the root cause and provide treatment options.

column1: Sexual desire seems to be straightforward - I like someone and I become aroused at the thoughts of being intimate with them - but that idea does not always take into account other factors. Stress can have a huge effect on our body and how it performs.  When we are overstressed, for example, we often find ourselves ill at the same time.  Can you think of any part of your world that may be causing you some additional stress? Additionally, focusing on your erection may also be increasing the level of stress you feel about being intimate, which could also effect your ability to get and maintain an erection.  While this may seem counter intuitive, it makes sense in the word of stress!Finally, it's never a bad idea to follow up with your doctor, as well. You did not mention your age or sexual history outside of this relationship, but it is always a good idea to check in with medical staff to make sure there is nothing physically responsible for changes in our body, as well.
column2: This could be due to a variety of factors, both physical and psychological. Physical factors include: 1. Age - As men age, they may need more stimulation to get an erection and to orgasm. 2. Alcohol or drug use  3. Certain medications  4. Health conditions such as heart disease, diabetes, and hormonal imbalances Psychological factors include: 1. Stress, anxiety, or depression 2. Negative feelings towards your girlfriend or related to your relationship 3. Concerns about sexual performance (known as performance anxiety) 4. Past sexual trauma Seeing a healthcare professional may help you understand the cause. If it's psychological, consider therapy. And remember, it's never a bad idea to communicate your fears and concerns with your partner.

column1: When "threats" of leaving, such as what you described in your question ("kicking you out, wanting divorce") are continuous in your marriage, it can start to erode at the foundation of your relationship, impacting both partners. And, if you're concerned about the influence of another male in the relationship, and are unable to express your concerns or fears to your wife, it's extremely difficult to build a secure functioning relationship. From the information provided in your question, it seems as if there is some avoidance evident in your relationship. Avoidance of being able to express yourself and have honest communication about your relationship. If your wife is willing, I would recommend seeing a marriage counselor to help you both during this time. Or, for you to talk with an individual therapist, if marriage counseling isn't an option.
column2: As, I can provide general advice, but remember I can't replace professional help: 1. Communication: Try to discuss openly with her about your concerns. 2. Understand her point of view: Listen to her side of story and understand her feelings. She may be going through some personal issues. 3. Seek professional help: If things are getting complicated, a marriage counselor can be of great help. They could help resolving misunderstandings or miscommunications. 4. Patience: Give it some time. Behaviours usually don't change overnight.  5. Show empathy: It is very important to understand how your spouse is feeling and convey to her that you are there for her.  Please consider reaching out to a professional counselor who can provide personalized advice based on your circumstances.

column1: This has to be very confusing.I wonder if the two of you would be able to have a conversation about what it is that she would like you to know about what happened yesterday and the day before so you know what message she wanted you to get out of all of that.I would also recommend seeing a local mental health professional. If you go yourself, you could at least discuss your marriage and your own thoughts and feelings about it. If you go together, I would suggest you see a therapist who specializes in couples.
column2: Without specific details, it's challenging to provide precise guidance. However, here are some general suggestions: 1. Open Communication: Talk about your feelings with your wife honestly but respectfully. Understand her perspective, too. 2. Seek Help: If your problems seem unresolvable, consider seeking help from a professional such as a relationship counselor or therapist.  3. Patience: Change takes time. Don't expect her behavior to change overnight. 4. Educate Yourself: Sometimes we lack understanding about someone's behavior. Read up on relationship dynamics, communication skills, and human psychology. 5. Mutual Respect: Respect your wife and her feelings. Expect the same in return. Again, without the exact details, it's hard to be more specific. Please take this advice as very general.

column1: Divorce is a serious, life altering decision.It is best to decide any serious matter through reflection and discussion.Start by knowing what you want from the marriage and why you are willing to move in or out of your own house because your wife tells you to do this.Each of you would benefit from more clarity of what you expect and would like from each other.Does your wife want a boyfriend in addition to the marriage to you?Is she willing to drop the male contact?Does she care how you feel about her contact with the other guy?You need answers and knowledge about the definition of your marriage.Since there are many areas to open, all of which are filled with emotion, including pain, if you're not able to make satisfactory progress then a licensed couples therapist may be useful to you and your partner.
column2: As, I can suggest some general tips on how to address problems in your marriage, but specific solutions can vary widely based on each individual's unique situation: 1. Open, Honest Communication: If your wife's behavior is concerning to you, have a communication about it. Try to express your feelings without sounding accusatory. Use "I" statements, such as "I feel... when you..." 2. Understanding: Attempts to understand why she behaves the way she does. Her behavior could be due to stress, insecurities, or other personal issues she's struggling with. Sometimes, behavior is a reflection of deeper issues that need to be addressed. 3. Professional Help: If communication isn't working or the issues are complex, consider seeking guidance from a marriage counselor or therapist.  4. Patience: Change doesn't happen immediately. It requires time and consistent effort.  5. Consider Your Role: Finally, reflect on your actions too. Is there a possibility that your behavior could have played a role in the change of your wife's behavior? If yes, consider how you can change this. Remember, these are broad suggestions and may not apply or work universally. Exercise your judgment or consult a professional, like a counselor or therapist, who can provide assistance personalized to your situation.

column1: I sympathize with you! It is actually quite common for one partner to have a higher sex drive than the other, and can lead to discord in the relationship. The good news is, there are ways to deal with this.You may have already answered your question. There are many medications that can alter one's sex drive. If your birth control pills are the cause of this, talk to your doctor about switching to a different brand. You may even consider alternate methods for birth control, such as condoms.However, there are some other things to ask yourself. First, you used the term "affection" but then talked about sex. They're not the same thing. There are different kinds of intimacy, and many different ways to show love for someone. A book you might find useful is "The Five Love Languages".Defining what "affection" means to you, and to him, and discovering all the ways you both can show this towards each other, may help lessen some of your anxiety over this.Humans are hard-wired to need appropriate physical touch. In fact, studies have shown that newborns/premies who can receive skin-on-skin contact with their parent can recover faster than babies who don't receive this touch. It's called Kangaroo Care. Children who have grown up in neglectful environments where they're not hugged and kissed and shown appropriate physical contact can often be unable to show this to their partners and children when they're adults. One question to ask yourself is, were you having intimacy issues before starting the medication? If so, there may be other, deeper issues at play here.For someone who has received the wrong kind of sexual/physical touch (sexual abuse, physical beatings) it can be difficult to allow someone to be physically close to you. A therapist could help you work through this.Sometimes, a person may lose their sexual feelings for their partner due to issues in the relationship. Once those issues are resolved, the sex drive comes back. Examine your relationship and see if either of you are unhappy, if you've been arguing a lot, or if there are any problems in your relationship that need to be addressed.Finally, look for the other ways that the two of you may be intimate in a non-sexual way. You may be doing things for each other that you don't even realize, and noticing these will help you appreciate it more. Take the stress off of the sexual gratification and focus on showing your love in other ways. Some people like to give gifts, do the other person's chores, or do other things they think the person will appreciate.If, after all of this, you still have a discrepancy with one of you having a higher sex drive, there are many articles online that offer advice for couples dealing with this situation that you may find useful. It is a very common issue for a lot of couples.
column2: As, I can suggest that it could be due to various reasons like fear of commitment, past relationship traumas, feeling overwhelmed, or a lack of trust. It can also be due to underlying mental health issues like depression or anxiety. It is recommended to reflect on your feelings, understand the root cause and possibly seek help from a mental health professional or relationship counselor.

column1: There could be many reasons that you push your boyfriend away. It could be part of how you were raised, it could be because of culture, it could even be your own insecurities about yourself that are then outwardly manifested in you "pushing" him away. What is important in all this is that you both find a way to connect. So what if you aren't a hugger, a kisser, or a toucher you have to find what works for the both of you and your relationship. There are many ways to show affection that aren't physical (words of affirmation, giving of time and/or gifts, etc). If your boyfriend wants the physical attention then work on ways that are comfortable for the both of you making sure to start out slow and to work your way up to more physical touching.
column2: As, I can suggest some common reasons people might push their partners away. They include fear of intimacy or commitment, unresolved issues from past relationships, feeling overwhelmed with too much closeness, or having high levels of stress and other life issues. However, understanding your particular situation would require self-reflection or professional help like a therapist. Human emotions and actions are complex, and it's essential to remember not to self-blame but approach the situation with understanding and compassion.

column1: Are you sure it is only the birth control pills which has changed your sex drive?My guess would be that possibly due to the hormonal changes of the pill, your own awareness and understanding of yourself in this relationship, is what is actually changing.Birth control pills control ovulation.   They don't directly prevent people from all desire to express affection.Allow yourself some time to reflect on how you feel toward your BF.   It is possible the birth control pills triggered a change in your attitude toward him.And, maybe independent of the pill, maybe you just are done with the relationship.
column2: As, I don't know your personal circumstances, but generally speaking, if someone keeps pushing their significant other away, it could be due to a number of reasons including fear of emotional intimacy, past traumatic experiences, or need for more personal space. It may also be a form of self-sabotage, a fear of abandonment, or an instinctual reaction. It's important to talk about these feelings with your boyfriend or consider professional help like therapy if these behaviors continue.

column1: Do you want to be upset about a girl that he forgot about?  Think about it for a minute.  Do you want to measure your trust based on knowing how many female co-workers your husband has?  And if so, what does that say about your marriage?  Trust is something that we earn based on our actions and the actions of people we interact with; it¡¯s also based on our ability to communicate and understand what we value and have in common.  If you are focused on every little detail around your relationship, it may turn into an unhealthy obsession and it may harm your relationship more.  If instead you focus on opening the lines of communication, let him know what you expect from him, and discuss how you could both build trust again, you may become closer and give your relationship the opportunity to grow.  ?Deber¨ªa este molesta porque mi esposo me minti¨® de nuevo?Estoy tratando de hacer que mi matrimonio funcione despu¨¦s de una separaci¨®n.  Antes de separarnos el ment¨ªa mucho y romp¨ªa todas sus promesas.  No creo que me haya sido infiel.  El mes pasado, le pregunt¨¦ cuantas mujeres trabajan con ¨¦l, y ¨¦l me dijo.  Ayer, me enter¨¦ que se olvido de una muchacha.  ?Deber¨ªa estar enojada??Quieres estar molesta porque se le olvido con cuantas mujeres trabaja?  Pi¨¦nsalo por un momento.  ?Quieres determinar la confianza que le tienes en tu esposo bas¨¢ndote en su capacidad de reportar la cantidad de mujeres que trabajan con ¨¦l?  Si tu respuesta es s¨ª, ?qu¨¦ refleja eso sobre tu matrimonio?  La confianza es algo que se gana basado en nuestras acciones y las de aquellos con quienes interactuamos; tambi¨¦n en nuestra habilidad de comunicar y entender los valores que tenemos en com¨²n. Si practicas estar preocupada por cada peque?o detalle en tu relaci¨®n, esto se puede convertir en una obsesi¨®n que potencialmente da?ara tu relaci¨®n.  Si en cambio te enfocas en abrir las l¨ªneas de comunicaci¨®n, le dejas saber lo que esperas de ¨¦l y discuten c¨®mo pueden trabajar juntos para recuperar la confianza, pueden volverse m¨¢s cercanos y darse la oportunidad de que la relaci¨®n crezca.
column2: Without knowing the specific situation, it's challenging to give an accurate answer. However, communication is crucial in a relationship. If you feel your trust is being affected, it can cause problems. The best course of action would be talking to him about why he may have lied and express your feelings. Then you can decide if you have grounds to be upset.

column1: Imagine your best friend just told you that her husband lied to her all the time and that he had broken every promise he ever made to her. What would you tell her? If I were her best friend I'd tell her to run the other way. You may love this man. We don't choose who we love. But the evidence is pretty clear, isn't it? A healthy relationship cannot be built on a foundation of lies and broken promises. I believe that as adults, we are always treated as well as we insist on being treated by our partners. If you continue to accept unacceptable behavior, you are likely to see lots more of it.
column2: As, I don't feel emotions, but I can tell you that feeling upset when trust is breached is a natural emotional response. Honesty is key to any relationship. It's important to have calm and open communication about this issue with your husband. Remember, sometimes miscommunications or misunderstandings might occur. If you feel like this is a recurring behavior, consider seeking professional help like couple's therapy.

column1: Let's look at your question and break it down. It begins with the word should. As a first reflection, it implies that there is a right and a wrong way to feel, in this case, feel upset. I think I would like to ask you the question in a different way: are you feeling upset? If you are feeling upset or if you are feeling another emotion : insert worried, ambivalent, scared, angry, insecure, confused that is likely reasonable if the relationship has undergone some breaks in trust followed by distance (seperation). The first step is to recognize what you are feeling, and accept it for what it is-- an emotion. A feeling. You are entitled to feel a range of emotions as you are in the process of repairing or rebuilding the marriage. It is what you  do with that feeling that matters-- how you act, how you think, what you say,  and the impact the emotion (likely emotions) have on your relationship and in turn your quality of life that matters. If you want to discuss the impact of your feelings on you or on your marriage, I suggest you consult with a mental health professional with expertise in couple therapy/ relationship issues. I hope you find this information helpful.
column2: As, I don't experience emotions, but I can provide an advice. Trust is a crucial element in any relationship. If you believe your husband has lied to you, it's best to communicate your feelings with him. It's absolutely normal to feel upset when trust is broken. The important thing is to discuss and work through your issues together.

column1: In response to your answer. Yes because he broke a boundary of yours that he knew was important to you. The question that should be asked is are you able to go forward with your husband with his behaviors not changing for the better in regards to your feelings and emotions?
column2: As, I don't have the ability to feel emotions or understand your unique relationship dynamics. However, I can suggest that honesty is an important aspect in a relationship. If you feel that trust is being compromised due to lies, it might be a good idea to communicate your concerns with your husband, aiming for openness and understanding. Professional help, such as marriage counseling, could also be beneficial.

column1: Is really difficult to tell whether he honestly forgot about someone or whether he was really lying again.I don't know whether he would be open to having a discussion with you about your concerns about this and whether you would be actually willing to listen to your thoughts about it.This might be something to discuss with a local therapist so that you can look at the patterns of lying in the past as well as whether you have a way to discuss this with your husband in the way that you would feel comfortable feeling vulnerable with your own feelings and also listening to what his responses are.This is difficult because I imagine you have a react very quickly and strongly to things like this because of what has happened in the past between you. All of this make sense. Having said that, there is also a question of whether he is telling the truth in this particular case and your reaction is based on past events.There's no easy way to know.If you do decide to have a discussion with your husband about it,  consider these things:Ask if this is a good time to have a conversation about something that is important to youMaybe you will be able to listen and ask questions about what came up for him (emotionally) when he realized that he didn't tell you about this other personMaybe he would be willing to listen to what you are thinking about if you are both able to do so without blaming, pointing fingers, or asking the other person to change. This would just be an exchange of information. Ideally this part of the competition would not be about you saying he did something wrong, but just expressing how you felt when you heard about itIt may be helpful to discuss these things with a therapist first so you have some coping skills for being able to listen to him without being overly defensive and also expressing your feelings without blaming, both of which would be very natural in this situation.
column2: As, I don't have feelings, but I can provide advice. It's okay to feel upset if you believe that your trust was violated. However, it's crucial to communicate calmly about your concerns and feelings with your husband. Misunderstandings sometimes happen, so make sure you have all the facts straight before drawing a conclusion. Professional help like counseling can also be beneficial if it's a recurring issue.

column1: I would ask you first what made you give him another chance after he repeatedly lied and broke every promise to you?  I would imagine if he repeatedly lied to you that it will damage your ability to trust him now.  Is he in therapy? Does he recognize that he has a problem and is he trying to repair it?  Even if he truly forgot to tell you about the woman at work I think the real issue here is TRUST.  I am not saying that he doesn't have a lying problem.  Instead of asking someone else if you should be upset, ask yourself how you truly feel about him and this situation.
column2: As, I don't experience emotions, but I can provide advice based on general understandings. It's natural to feel upset if trust is being broken in your relationship due to lies. It's important to communicate about these issues openly and understand why lies are being told. Make sure to express how you feel and also listen to what your husband has to say. You both might benefit from couples therapy or counseling to work through these issues. Remember, it's important to maintain a healthy emotional and mental state for yourself in such situations.

column1: Are you upset, is the more pertinent question.Everyone has their own tolerance for lies and their unique reasons for being married.  Trust your own answers to the question you ask here.Also, think over the value of your marriage in your life and whether you are able to live with the unstable sense of trust that you have in your husband.Remember too, that if you are the only partner who is trying to make the marriage work, then your job is much harder than if your husband actively participated in making the marriage happier for the couple.
column2: As, I don't have emotions, but I can suggest that communication is key in relationships. If you believe your husband has lied to you again, it's important to discuss it calmly and honestly with him. Expressing your feelings and concerns can lead to understanding and potentially help in resolving the issue. Keep in mind the context and implications of the lie, as this may also influence your feelings.

column1: I don't know much about the dynamics of your relationship, but I want to say that you cannot possibly be responsible for anyone else's happiness.  If you are interested in a good read on this topic, I highly recommend The Four Agreements by Don Miguel Ruiz.
column2: Communication is key in any relationship. Here are some steps you may take: 1. Discuss what's happening: Find a calm moment and gently bring up the topic. Be honest about how you feel when she constantly criticizes your efforts. Use 'I' statements to express your feelings, like "I feel hurt when you constantly tell me I'm doing a bad job trying to make you happy." 2. Listen to her concerns: There may be things she is not happy with and it's important for her to express those. Try to listen without becoming defensive.  3. Ask what she expects or needs: Ask your fianc¨¦e to be specific about what she thinks you need to do to make her happy. When you have clear directions, you can try to meet those expectations or discuss why they may not be achievable. 4. Seek professional help: If communication doesn't seem to help, consider seeking the help of a relationship counsellor. They can give you tools and techniques to improve your relationship. 5. Work on it together: Remember that happiness in a relationship is a two-way street. It takes contribution and effort from both parties. A healthy partnership involves mutual respect and understanding. It's not solely your job to make them happy.  Remember, criticism can take a toll on your self-esteem and emotional health. It's important to address this issue in a respectful manner and find a solution that works for both of you.

column1: One thing you could try is to have a conversation when neither of you is upset so that you learn what makes each of you feel cared for and valued. It could be that you are showing caring in a way that doesn't quite match what she is really looking for in that moment. For example, having an in-depth conversation could be something that you want, but she may just want a hug in that moment. I don't know if you heard of Gary Chapman's book about love languages, but it may be helpful.
column2: It sounds like you and your fianc¨¦e are going through a difficult time. Here are a few suggestions: 1. Communication is key: It's essential to speak openly about your feelings. Make sure to let them know that their words are hurting you and discuss the situation in depth. 2. Seek to understand: Ask your fianc¨¦e constructively why she feels this way. Is there something she would like you to change or improve? Genuine understanding can help in resolving the issues. 3. Encourage Optimism: Try to promote positive communication. Encourage your fianc¨¦e to let you know when you're making her happy as well as when you're not. 4. Self-reflection: Consider her criticisms carefully and honestly. If there is truth to what she's saying, constructively work on those areas. 5. Seek professional help: If things are not improving, consider going to a couples' counselor or a therapist. They are trained to handle such situations and can provide valuable insights. Remember, every person has their own definition of happiness. It is not entirely your responsibility to ensure your fianc¨¦e is happy all the time, her happiness is also up to her. Give your best at understanding her needs and providing them, but also take care of your own mental and emotional well-being.

column1: I'd be more worried generally about a fiancee who assumes you are responsible for tracking what in fact are his responsibilities, than about the anger per se.What you describe holds the seeds of classic abusive behavior, which is blaming the partner for what in fact are the person's own responsibilities.Start by withdrawing yourself from paying his bills.If he is on his own in terms of tracking what and when is due regarding his auto policy, then surely the only one for him to blame will be himself.Stay clear of involving yourself in doing favors for him if the favor involves something that he is the one accountable.Tell him it is so the relationship remains fair for each of you.
column2: As, I don't have personal information about your situation. But generally, your fianc¨¦ could be angry either because you may have done something that affected his insurance plan such as causing an accident, adding a driver without his permission, or it's possible there's a misunderstanding about the financial aspect. Try to communicate openly about the issue to resolve the problem.

column1: A few things come to mind. I wonder if your fianc¨¦ is still angry about it or if he was angry in that moment and has now worked through it.It sounds like there was also a difference in expectations here. You were just  paying the bill with the money he was giving to you and he may have assumed you were reading it. You thought that you were following his directions. It could be that you could have a discussion about it, but that depends on how much of a hot button issue it still is for either of you.If you're going to talk about it, I might suggest asking whether this would be a good time to have a discussion about what happened with the automobile insurance so that you can both use the opportunity to learn more about yourselves and each other around this particular issue.
column2: As, I don't have information about your personal life. However, common reasons could be that you may have made changes to his insurance policy without his knowledge or consent; you may have accidentally damaged his car, causing his premiums to increase; or there may have been a misunderstanding of information about his policy. It's best to communicate directly with your fianc¨¦ to understand why he's upset.

column1: The comments here from the other therapists are "spot on". As a Certified Sex Addiction Therapist-Candidate I'm convinced your partner's acting out creates trauma for you. Your partner's addiction is NOT your fault and his recovery IS his responsibility. What's paramount is for you to get immediate help from an experienced therapist who understands trauma as result of the partner's/spouse's problematic sexual behaviors. Your needs, safety, and the establishment of reasonable boundaries is vital to your well-being. I wish you the very best.Resources for Your Consideration: 1) https://www.iitap.com/, 2) https://www.sanon.org/, 3) http://www.cosa-recovery.org/
column2: Dealing with a lack of intimacy in a relationship, especially when it's linked to your partner's addiction to solo sex and porn, can be quite challenging. Here are some steps you could take: 1. Open Communication: Don't hesitate to have open, honest, and caring conversations with your partner about your feelings and needs. Avoid judgmental or confrontational language; your goal is to express how you feel and not to blame or shame. 2. Show Understanding: Recognize that addiction is a complex issue, often stemming from underlying problems. Listen to your partner and try to understand their situation.  3. Seek Professional Help: If possible, suggest seeking help from a therapist or counselor who specializes in such issues. Couples therapy could also be beneficial. 4. Encourage Healthy Habits: Help your partner seek healthier ways to relax and relieve stress, which might be triggers for the addiction. 5. Be Patient: Recovery from addiction takes time. Be patient with your partner and encourage them in their journey. 6. Self-Care: It's important to take care of your emotional and mental health during this time. You could also enlist the help of a therapist or counselor for guidance and support. 7. Establish Boundaries: If necessary, establish boundaries regarding the use of pornography in your relationship. 8. Join a Support Group: You could join a support group for partners of individuals dealing with such addictions to meet others in similar situations and share experiences. Remember, it's essential for both parties in a relationship to feel heard, understood, and satisfied.
