If your partner's behaviors aren't changing and are harming your mental health, consider taking a break or re-evaluating the relationship.

column1: There is a lot of information out there right now about how porn is harmful...to a person's brain chemistry, to a relationship and one's ability to love, and to how men see women and sex in general. Your partner demonstrates a clear disregard for your needs. There is evidence, as you suggest, that there is addiction here. I recommend seeing a therapist who can help you sort out where to go from here.
column2: Dealing with a lack of intimacy and a partner's addiction to solo sex and porn can be challenging. Here are a few steps to guide you: 1. Open Communication: Start by having an open, honest, and non-judgmental discussion with your partner about your concerns and feelings. Listening is as important as expressing yourself, and try to avoid blame.  2. Understand the Problem: Addictions often have underlying emotional, psychological, or physiological reasons. Try to understand your partner's reasons for withdrawing from intimacy and using solo sex as a substitute.   3. Professional Help: If your partner's behavior persists and appears to be an addiction, consider seeking professional help. Therapists, counselors, and sex addiction specialists can offer strategies, techniques, and programs to help overcome such problems.  4. Education and Understanding: Learn more about sex and porn addiction. This will help you have compassion and understanding for your partner while also helping you understand what they're going through. 5. Focus on Relationship: Try to spend quality time together and reconnect. Prioritize non-sexual bonding and closeness to slow down the pace and allow for more profound intimacy. 6. Self-Care: Even though you might be focused on your partner's needs, don't forget about your own emotional wellbeing. Joining a support group, seeking your own therapy, and setting healthy boundaries can be beneficial. 7. Patience and Persistence: Overcoming addiction and rebuilding intimacy doesn't happen overnight. It requires consistent effort, kindness, and patience.  8. Encourage Healthy Habits: Shared activities like exercising, eating healthy, and prioritizing sleep can help foster wellbeing which can in turn help with addiction. Remember, every person and relationship is different, so what works for one person may not work for another. Be willing to adapt your approach as needed, and continue to show your partner love and support as they work through their issues.

column1: It sounds like your in quite a rough place, my recommendation just based on what you type might warrant a visit to a psychotherapist to resolve what may be going on, I am not entirely sure but it sounds like he might have a bit of a sex addiction problem. One thing you need to ask yourself is "Am I happy?", "Do I feel loved?", these are deep questions, but the answers to those questions will give you a direction to travel in.
column2: Dealing with a partner's addiction to solo sex and porn can be a sensitive and complex issue that involves addressing different aspects like communication, understanding, and professional help. Here's how you can approach it: 1. Open Communication: Talk about the issue openly, but non-confrontationally. It's important not to make your partner feel ashamed or guilty about their behavior, as this could lead to further issues. 2. Express Your Feelings: Talk about how this addiction is affecting you and your relationship. Let them know you miss the intimacy that you once shared and still crave for. 3. Understand Their Perspective: Try to understand why your partner is turning to porn and solo sex. It could be due to stress, underlying mental health issues, or dissatisfaction with the sex life between the two of you. 4. Seek Counseling: If the addiction continues to persist, consider seeking help from a trained professional, such as a sex therapist or a counselor. They can provide strategies and exercises to help you and your partner reconnect and rediscover intimacy.  5. Set Boundaries: While every individual has their own privacy, it becomes a concern when it starts affecting your relationship. You both need to set boundaries and respect each other's needs. 6. Self-Care: Look after your own emotional health. You may not be able to solve this issue alone or quickly, so ensure you are not neglecting your own needs in the interim. 7. Research: Understand the effects of pornography addition on relationships. This will help you empathize with your partner's struggle and be more prepared when discussing it. 8. Patience: Change won't happen overnight. It will take time, patience, and persistence.  9. Education: Encourage your partner to learn about the harms of porn addiction and the benefits of real intimacy. They may be more inclined to understand and act on the information if they come across it themselves. 10. Support Groups: Join related community or support groups. Normalize the conversation around such issues.  Remember, every person and relationship is unique and there are no one-size-fits-all solutions. It's important to do what feels best for you and your partner.

column1: Feeling rejected and frustrated is a reasonable reaction to your experience with your husband. I want to encourage you that his actions may have little to do with you, and regardless of outcomes, I hope you find the help you need to process through your pain and still have hope for your marriage.   If your husband was to work with me I'd explore with him his understanding of, and experience with, intimacy in relationship with others. Furthermore, like other male clients of mine, I'd challenge your husband to secure an updated full medical exam from his PCP (primary care physician) and/or urologist in order to identify or rule out any organic issues which may be causing his apparent lack of desire for sexual intimacy. If there are no physical issues, per se, I would encourage your husband to process further his family of origin story-line regarding rules, roles, sex, and sexuality along with working through his sexual and trauma histories.
column2: There can be various reasons for this. It might be helpful to have an open conversation with your husband about it as he might be facing issues, such as health problems, work stress, low libido, or other personal concerns. Sexual frequency can vary greatly from couple to couple and it's important to understand each other's needs. You might also consider seeking professional advice from a couple's therapist or a sex therapist to help navigate the situation. It's important that you express your needs and concerns but also listen to his. Clear and respectful communication is key.

column1: This could have many different origins. Have you tried asking him about it? Sometimes starting with asking whether he would be open to having an important discussion can be a good beginning. If that starts well, perhaps continuing with something like "I've noticed that we haven't been together intimately (or whatever phrasing works for you) as much lately. Can you tell me more about what it's like for you?"When asking questions like this, it usually helpful to not overuse (and perhaps try to avoid using) the word "why." That word tends to trigger really strong emotional reactions in people. Try starting with "what makes" Instead. For example, "what made you choose not to do that?"
column2: There can be many reasons why a spouse might reduce frequency in physical intimacy. It could be due to stress, low libido, health problems, emotional disconnect, or even a schedule that's too busy. It's best to have an open and honest conversation with your husband about what you're experiencing. Sharing your feelings and concerns can help to clear misunderstandings and find a solution. A marriage counselor or sex therapist could also provide strategies to rekindle intimacy. However, it's crucial to show empathy and understanding to your partner's feelings and thoughts during this process as well.

column1: Every area in a relationship, including intimacy, experiences a decline after the initial honeymoon period.  Couples have to work to maintain the spark.  Find a moment to talk to your husband about your concerns, and suggest ways to rekindle your sexual life, be open to listen to his concerns and demands as well.  But don¡¯t forget that sex the fun part of being with someone, play, flirt, joke and keep looking for ways to continue falling for each other.  Mi esposo solo tiene relaciones conmigo una vez al mes o menos.  Me siento rechazada y frustrada.  Esto no es nuevo.  El primer mes que estuvimos juntos, ten¨ªamos sexo casi todos los d¨ªas. Luego se redujo a una vez por semana. Amo a mi esposo, pero esto me causa dificultad.Todas las ¨¢reas de una relaci¨®n, incluyendo la intimidad, sufren altas y bajas luego del periodo de la luna de miel.  Las parejas tienen que trabajar para mantener la chispa.  Encuentra un momento para hablar con tu esposo sobre tu preocupaci¨®n, y sugiere maneras de reencender su vida sexual, est¨¢ atenta a escuchar sus preocupaciones y sugerencias al igual.  No olvides que el sexo es una de las partes m¨¢s divertidas de una relaci¨®n, jueguen, coqueteen, bromeen y contin¨²en buscando maneras de enamorarse otra vez.
column2: That can certainly be frustrating. There could be many possible reasons for this, such as stress, low sex drive, or medical issues. Communication is key. It's important to express your feelings and needs with your husband from a place of understanding and patience. If necessary, consider seeking professional help from a sex therapist or marriage counselor.

column1: Have you said anything to your husband about the way you're feeling?Start with this.Sex is after all, a two person enterprise.If he would like to talk about the way you're feeling, great and wonderful.  The two of you already are continuing to grow trust in your communication and relationship.If he doesn't want to talk about how you're feeling, then you're facing a different problemYour feelings are real and need to be handled.If you end up facing your feelings of frustration about your husband not wanting to have sex with you, on your own, then does your husband give you a truthful sounding reason as to why not?Ask what explains his disinterest in having sex with you.If he doesn't want to address this question, then you are a little further down the rung of trust and care about you.Depending on how satisfied you are with his answers, will guide you on how much dissatisfaction you can live with and why, longterm.
column2: There could be a variety of reasons why this is happening. It might be due to stress, loses in libido, physical health issues, or emotional reasons. Whatever the cause, it's crucial that you find a way to talk about it openly with him. Communication is key in any relationship. If you both are comfortable with it, you might even consider seeking professional counseling or therapy to navigate this issue. Maintaining a healthy sex life is highly crucial in any relationship and should be addressed when problems arise.  Remember, it¡¯s completely normal for sexual desire to fluctuate over time due to various life changes and stressors. Don't feel discouraged if you aren't on the same page right away, as long as you are both willing to work towards a solution.

column1: I wonder if both you and your boyfriend could have a conversation about what you both want, wish for, and desire from one another right now. That doesn't necessarily mean that your partner will give everything that you ask for, but this is one of the ways that he can learn more about what would help you through this and you can learn how you could support him, since traditional medical treatment is not something he wants.You may also consider using some open-ended questions (not yes or no answers) to talk about what you're feeling about both about his cancer and about your relationship. Both of you may discuss different ways that you would like support from one another.I would also see if he was comfortable with you disclosing this to one or a few of your close friends (with him considering doing the same) so that you both have support that includes each other and also includes others because there may be days when you both have a negatively emotional day at the same time and would benefit from talking with someone else.It may also be a matter of conversation to discuss what makes you happy together and use those positive moments to help move through more difficult ones.
column2: I'm assistant, and while I don't have personal experiences, I can provide some general suggestions that could be helpful for you and your boyfriend during this difficult time. Please always consult with professionals in health and mental care for personalized advice. 1. **Seek Medical Guidance**: Rely on the knowledge and skills of professionals. Follow the treatment plan provided by the oncologist and don't hesitate to ask any questions or clarifications. 2. **Emotional Support**: It's vital to be patient, compassionate, and understanding with each other during this difficult time. Encourage each other, offer reassurances, and be there for emotional support. 3. **Communication**: Talk about fears, concerns, feelings openly. Letting your boyfriend know about your concerns while also giving him space to share can encourage a healthier emotional environment. 4. **Maintain Regular Routine**: As much as possible, try to keep a normal routine. This can include maintaining regular meal times or doing small activities together such as watching TV, reading, etc. 5. **Seek Therapy/Counseling**: It can be helpful to talk to a psychologist, counselor or a mental health professional who specializes in helping people cope with illnesses like cancer. 6. **Support Groups**: Joining support groups can be immensely helpful. Connecting with people who are undergoing or have undergone similar experiences can provide insight and comfort. 7. **Healthy Lifestyle**: Maintaining a healthy lifestyle through balanced diet, regular exercise (as advised by the doctor), and adequate sleep can help in improving overall wellbeing. 8. **Take Care of Yourself**: As a caretaker, it's crucial you also take care of your own mental and physical health. Self-care is important and it's okay to ask for help when you need it.  Remember, it's okay to have days where everything feels like a lot. Just try to be there for each other in the best way possible.

column1: Hello, and thank you for your question. I am very sorry about this life-altering situation that both you and your boyfriend are going through. To be sure, this is a devastating and lonely road for both of you. I say lonely because when things like this happen we often don't know what to say to each other, and so we suffer in silence with little support.Here are a few thoughts that I am having, and perhaps others will add things, too:1. By the sound of your main question, it seems like you have every intention to be there for your boyfriend during this difficult time. I am not sure if he is willing to talk about his health situation, but letting him know that you want to support him and also need his support may be helpful. 2. If it is possible, see if he would be willing to go to a counselor with you. There are many things that a counselor could focus on that may help your relationship, but also help you both cope with what is happening.3. If he refuses to seek support, you may want to consider going on your own. If you can't afford it, sometimes hospice organizations offer support groups and other services. It is very important not to neglect yourself. Be well,Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC
column2: I'm sorry to hear that your boyfriend is dealing with cancer. It's a challenging time, but there are steps you can take to manage the situation. 1. Learn About the Condition: Understand the type of cancer your boyfriend has, the stages, its treatment options and side-effects. Knowledge is power and can help in making informed decisions.     2. Communicate Openly: Be open with each other about fears, feelings, and coping mechanisms. From the diagnosis to treatment, open communication will ensure that you both support each other effectively. 3. Focus on Living Healthy: Healthy food, regular exercise, adequate rest and reducing stress can go a long way in enhancing overall well-being. Going for walks, practicing yoga, preparing meals together, meditating are some useful activities. 4. Attend Doctor¡¯s Appointments: Accompany your boyfriend to doctor's appointments whenever possible. Apart from offering emotional support, you can also help remember important medical information or ask key questions.  5. Seek Professional Help: Your boyfriend may need help dealing with emotions and stress. Consider seeking help from professional therapists and counselors who are trained to help cancer patients and their families. 6. Support Groups: Join a cancer support group. It can be very beneficial to talk to other people going through the same situation.  7. Take Time off: Give yourself permission to relax and do the things that you enjoy. It's important to recharge your own energy to effectively care for your loved one. 8. Recognize Grief: It¡¯s natural to grieve in times like these. Don't shy away from crying or feeling sad. Supporting each other through grief is important too. 9. Build a Support Network: Share the burden with friends, family or a caregiver. Don't feel obligated to handle everything on your own. 10. Get Financial Holistic Support: Cancer treatment can be expensive. Understand your insurance policy, seek financial support from charities if needed. And remember, these are suggestions. Every situation and every person is unique, so find what works best for you and your boyfriend. You should also consult with a healthcare professional for advice tailored to your specific situation.

column1: It may be important to look at this as getting through something rather than "getting over it." If you're aware of the reasons why you are jealous, I don't know if they relate to this relationship or a previous one, but you could remind yourself of the differences if your feelings of jealousy relate to something from your past.Also, it may be beneficial to have a conversation with your child's father if you are both open to having a discussion about this in a way that you summarize what each other is saying so you are sure that you are understanding each other, at least to some degree.Also, consider what you may want from your child's father to assist you with this. You cannot make him do anything to support you with this, but you can certainly ask.What is something you could start or stop doing to move you toward your goal?
column2: 1. Analyze your feelings: Do your best to understand why you're feeling jealous. Is it due to a lack of trust, or a feeling of inadequacy? Figuring out the root cause could be the first step to overcoming any feelings of jealousy. 2. Improve Self-Esteem: Often jealousy stems from feelings of insecurity or inadequacy. It's crucial to work on your self-esteem and learn to value yourself for who you are. 3. Communicate: If you're feeling jealous in a relationship, open communication can help you feel more secure. Share your feelings with the other person in a calm and constructive way without sounding accusatory. 4. Trust More: Jealousy often comes from fear or mistrust. Learn to trust your partner and take their words at face value. Developing trust in a relationship can help you keep your jealousy at bay. 5. Practice Mindfulness: Mindfulness exercises can help you identify your feelings of jealousy and then let them go. This could be as simple as recognizing that you're feeling jealous, then consciously choosing to focus on something else. 6. Seek professional help: If you're constantly feeling jealous and struggling to manage it, seeing a counselor or therapist could be beneficial. They can provide you with tools and techniques to manage and overcome your feelings of jealousy. 7. Stay Positive: Maintaining a positive outlook can help you to approach situations in a better light and would eventually help you deal with jealousy. 8. Lessen comparisons: One of the major sources of jealousy are unfair comparisons. Every person has unique strengths and weaknesses and comparisons seldom solve any problem. 9. Practice Gratitude: Focus on what you have instead of what you don't have. Practicing gratitude can help you feel more content and less prone to jealousy. 10. Self-Care: Take care of your mental and physical well-being. Exercising regularly, sleeping well, and maintaining a healthy diet can boost your confidence and keep feelings of jealousy at bay.  Remember, overcoming jealousy is a process and it takes time. Be patient with yourself.

column1: My first thought was that I wondered what changed recently. Is he open to having a discussion about this so you can ask questions such as that one?It's possible that he does not understand the degree to which it hurts you.Try asking if there is a time that would be good to have a discussion that is important. I don't know how well the two of you have communicated over the last year, but if you are concerned about this turning into an argument, you may consider asking him to just listen to your point of view and see if he is able to summarize it correctly. Then you can listen to his side of the concern.
column2: First, it's crucial to understand that everyone should be treated with respect and dignity. Hearing insults about your body from your boyfriend can be incredibly hurtful. There are few courses of action you can take: 1. Have a serious conversation: Approach your boyfriend when you're both calm and explain to him how you feel about his insults. Try to use "I" statements such as "I feel hurt when you make fun of my body". 2. Set boundaries: Make it clear what kind of behavior and communication is acceptable and which isn't. Saying negative things about your body shouldn't be tolerated. 3. Involve a counselor: If he doesn't respect how you feel, it may be helpful to involve a relationship counselor who can provide professional advice and facilitate communication between the two of you. 4. Consider a break or break-up: Continuous insults can greatly damage self-esteem. If your boyfriend doesn't change his behavior even after discussing it with him or involving a counselor, you may need to rethink the relationship for the sake of your mental and emotional health. Remember, your worth isn't determined by anyone's opinion about your body. It's essential to love, respect and care for your own physical and emotional wellbeing.

column1: Hello, and thank you for your question. I am very sorry that you are experiencing this. To be honest, this kind of behavior is really emotionally abusive, and you likely know that already. The unfortunate truth is, there is very little we can actually do to change another adult's behavior if they are not interested in changing it. Many people who behave in this way actually feel justified in saying what they say, or even believe that they are "helping" in some way by telling you how to improve yourself. What is actually going on is an attempt to control or change something about you by being coercive and abusive. It is important to know that this kind of behavior doesn't necessarily show up right away. That is why I am not surprised that you are a year in to this relationship and are just now noticing these behaviors. Some people actually don't see them until they are already married! You didn't mention that there has been any physical abuse, but I would warn you that this is sometimes a possibility once a person has already begun to be emotionally abusive. Other things to watch out for is your boyfriend trying to control who you hang out with, what you do and how you dress, etc. These are just more examples of emotional abuse and control. Here are some things to consider and some ideas:1. You could talk to your boyfriend about this behavior, if you believe it is safe to do so. Perhaps he will recognize that his behavior is not okay, and change. If not, then you may need to decide what you want to do about this relationship, given the fact that you cannot force him to change. 2. You can call a local domestic violence program. They do not only work with people who have been physically abused or have been married. They are trained to talk about emotional abuse, also. It may be a good thing for support. Your calls are confidential. 3. Check out the wheel in the link below. On it you will find some other common ways that abuse can happen in a relationship. If any of these are happening to you, or begin to happen, talking to a domestic violence program, a trusted friend or family member, or a counselor would be a good idea. http://www.domesticviolence-wilm.org/Portals/97/Images/violence_wheel.gif  Be well.... Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC
column2: Communication is key in any relationship. If your boyfriend's comments about your body are making you feel uncomfortable or hurt, here's what you can do: 1. Speak Up: Let him know how his comments make you feel. He may not realize how much his words are affecting you. Try to communicate these feelings when both of you are calm and not arguing. 2. Be Direct: Clearly express what you will not tolerate. There's no need to be aggressive, but being assertive can be helpful. 3. Seek Counsel: Both personal or professional advice could be beneficial. Speak to a trusted friend, family member, or seek professional advice from a counselor or therapist. 4. Make decisions: If your boyfriend continues his disrespectful behavior even after you've communicated your feelings, it's worth considering whether this relationship is healthy and respects your self-worth. Remember, it's important to be in a relationship where you are respected and valued. You don't have to settle for anything less.

column1: Talking about it would probably be helpful if you're both in a place where you can decide when is best to talk about something that is important. It may also be helpful to ask if you could talk for two or three minutes to make a point and then have space for her to talk for the same amount of time. You can adjust the timing for what works for both of you. After one of you is talking, perhaps you could restate what you have heard the person say. This can lessen confusion.I know you say that she avoids it. It might be a good place to start talking about it ¨C to see what makes her avoid it. It could be that she thinks any discussion about them is going to lead to an argument or you saying that she can't talk to them. I don't know how you typically react when you are jealous, but if you can discuss talking about this in a way that you are both open to hearing what the other person is experiencing, that may be helpful as well.
column2: Opening up to your girlfriend about your anxieties related to her exes can be difficult but it can also bring you both closer by improving the communication between you. Here are a few steps you can follow: 1. Pick the Right Time: Make sure you are choosing a calm and comfortable environment, free from distractions to discuss such sensitive issues. Avoid doing this when either of you is tired, stressed, or rushing to do something else. 2. Be Honest and Open: Clearly express to her what you're feeling. You may be feeling insecure, threatened, or uncomfortable because of her past relationships. These feelings can be normal, but it's important to discuss them instead of keeping them bottled up. 3. Use ¡®I¡¯ statements: To avoid sounding like you're accusing her, express your feelings by saying ¡®I feel¡¯ or ¡®I think¡¯. For example, instead of saying ¡°You talk about your ex too much¡± say ¡°I feel uncomfortable when you talk about your ex frequently.¡± 4. Don¡¯t Demand or Compare: It¡¯s important to clarify that having a past doesn¡¯t necessarily mean she has done anything wrong. Avoid comparing yourself to her exes as it might stir up more anxiety and could also be a turn-off for her. 5. Ask for Reassurance: State your fears and ask her for comfort. You may want to hear from her that she is committed to you, and her past relationships are just that - in the past. 6. Be Receptive: Be prepared to listen to her perspective as well. She might have feelings about this that you've never considered. 7. Seek Help: If this anxiety continues despite talking, you might want to consider professional help. A counselor or therapist can help you work through your insecurities and fears in a healthy way. Remember, it's completely normal to have such concerns in a relationship. The trick is to communicate with each other effectively and work through these issues together.

column1: Sexual attraction is often discussed on a continuum. If you are saying that you are not attracted to your girlfriend, you could try changing what you do during sexual intimacy. You could also try slowly using nonsexual touch and discussing what you each like and would prefer to do more of compared to what is not as desirable. After doing this for nonsexual touching, it can also be used with sexual touching. Looking at more of what you like or would like to feel may be of help.
column2: Loss of sexual attraction in a long-term relationship is not uncommon and can often be a symptom of other issues like stress, complacency, lack of intimacy, disagreements, etc. Here are some steps you might consider: 1. Self-Reflection: Try to understand why you're feeling the way you are. Is it lack of attraction or something deeper like fear of commitment, stress, depression? 2. Communication: Depending on your relationship, you may want to discuss this issue with your girlfriend. It can be a sensitive and difficult conversation, but honesty is essential in a healthy relationship.  3. Seek Professional Help: A skilled therapist or counselor may help you understand your feelings better and guide you on the best course of action. 4. Work on Intimacy: Find ways to reconnect emotionally and physically. This could include more quality time together, trying out new activities, or reigniting passions that may have diminished. 5. Appropriate Expectations: People change over time, and so does physical attractiveness. It's essential to have realistic expectations regarding this. 6. Health & Fitness: Working out not only improves physical appearance and health but also boosts self-confidence and sex drive. Remember, it's okay to feel this way and seeking professional help is highly recommended. Whether this means the end of the relationship or not will depend on many factors and ultimately, what's best for you and your partner.

column1: Probably what you should do is decide whether you can continue having a romantic and sexual relationship with someone to whom you don't feel like having sex.Five years is long enough to know that the way you feel toward your partner is more than likely going to remain this way.Talk with your gf about your feelings because she may not wish to be in a relationship in which her partner is not sexually attracted to her.
column2: Working through sexual issues in a relationship can be tough, but it's an important process if you value the relationship. Here's what you could do: 1. Self Reflection: Reflect on when and why this lack of attraction began. Has she changed physically or is the change that you¡¯re noticing in your feelings more emotional or intellectual? This kind of self-reflection is crucial to understanding what the real issue is. 2. Open Communication: Be open about your feelings with your girlfriend if you feel it's necessary, doing so with sensitivity and tact. Avoid blaming her for the changes in your feelings. 3. Professional Help: Consider seeking advice from a therapist or a relationship counselor. They might help you understand what's happening and give you strategies to deal with it. 4. Relationship Assessment: You need to assess the entire relationship. Are there other issues, which are making you less attracted to her? Often loss of attraction is a symptom of other relationship problems. 5. Explore Intimacy: Try to explore different facets of intimacy. It¡¯s not always purely physical. Emotional and intellectual intimacy can be just as important. 6. Consider Alternatives: If you find that the physical attraction is a priority to you and it can't be revived, then you might need to consider ending the relationship. It is not fair for either of you to be in a relationship where you can't give your 100%. 7. Health and Lifestyle: Shift in attraction can be related to depression, stress, or other mental health concerns. Considering a healthier lifestyle for both of you might help. Remember, attraction can wane and wax in long-term relationships. Make sure to have patience with yourself and the process.

column1: I wonder if you are having some of these thoughts related to something that has neither happened directly to you in your past or to someone that you care about. This can often change the way that we look at different situations. Try to look at what feelings, for you when you notice that someone is "checking her out," and perhaps when you have felt these feelings before.If you trust your girl enough to have an open conversation, perhaps you could ask her whether she is willing to talk about something that is important to you. Then you could talk about feelings that you're having.
column2: Feeling like your partner is cheating on you might be due to several factors such as past experiences, self-esteem issues, anxiety, or trust problems. It's important to communicate about these feelings with your partner. If it's causing you significant distress, you might also want to seek advice from a mental health professional.

column1: First things first!  Friendships that develop in times of struggle may be a great emotional support, but also become confusing there's sexual attraction. And entertaining a tough is only going to make it a stronger target.  Careful with that friendship! You do not want to fill your marriage's void with another person.  Even when you are in a friend zone and not having intimacy with this person, you may be developing a special bond, sharing interest and activities that may lead to a deeper connection.  Ask yourself how you would feel if your spouse was having a friendship like that.Then try to refocus on your marriage. I suggest being transparent and talking to your wife about your feelings and concerns.  Ask her what you could do to reconnect, make some suggestions and dedicate time to practice them.  Make time in both of your schedules, make an effort to have lunch together, or to text during the day.  Remember that a marriage is like a very good friendship with benefits, but sometimes the responsibility kills the fun.?C¨®mo puedo volver a enamorarme de mi esposa?Mi esposa trabaja tarde casi todos los d¨ªas, la amo con todo mi coraz¨®n, pero no siento la intimidad como antes.  Ya no tenemos sexo, lo cual me molesta tremendamente.  Me he acercado a una amistad del trabajo, lo cual no ayuda.  Nada pasara, pero hay pensamientos al respecto.Primero lo primero! Las amistades que se desarrollan en momentos de crisis pueden ser un gran apoyo emocional, pero tambi¨¦n pueden convertirse en algo nebuloso cuando hay atracci¨®n sexual. Entretener pensamientos al respecto solo lo va a hacer un reto m¨¢s grande.  ?Ten cuidado con esa amistad! No quieres llenar el vac¨ªo que deja tu matrimonio con esta nueva persona.  Aunque no est¨¦s teniendo intimidad con esa persona, puedes estar creando una conexi¨®n especial, compartiendo intereses en com¨²n y actividades que los unen m¨¢s aun. Preg¨²ntate como te sentir¨ªas si tu esposa tuviera una amistad as¨ª.Intenta reenfocarte en tu matrimonio.  Sugiero que seas transparente con tu esposa y le dejes saber tu preocupaci¨®n y como te sientes con el distanciamiento.  Preg¨²ntale que le gustar¨ªa hacer para reconectarse, sugi¨¦rele algunas ideas y dediquen tiempo a las mismas.  Hagan tiempo en sus agendas para ustedes, hagan un esfuerzo para almorzar juntos, y comunicarse durante el d¨ªa, aunque sea con textos.  Recuerda que el matrimonio es como una muy buena amistad con beneficios y muchas veces las responsabilidades matan la diversi¨®n.
column2: Rekindling love in a relationship often requires time and effort from both parties. Here are some tips: 1. Open Communication: This is the key to any successful relationship. Talk about your feelings, fear, dreams, and needs. Try to understand each other's perspective. 2. Create Quality Time: Set aside some time just for the two of you. Whether it's a weekly date night, a weekend away, or just an hour at the end of each day, make it a priority. 3. Recall Good Memories: Often recalling the past can revive feelings of love. Remember why you fell in love in the first place - this will help you re-establish your emotional connection. 4. Show Affection: Small acts of affection make a huge difference. Holding hands, a hug, a kiss, or just saying ¡°I Love You,¡± can show your partner you still care. 5. Be Patient: Rekindling love takes time. It's a process ¨C not a race.  6. Seek Professional Help: If you're finding it difficult to reconnect, seeing a relationship counsellor can help provide tools and strategies for improvement.  7. Understanding and Forgiveness: If there's something in the past that's affected your relationship, it's time to forgive. This can bring you closer together and enable you to start fresh. 8. Show appreciation: Show genuine appreciation for the little things your wife does. This can easily reignite love in a relationship. 9. Try new things together: Find a fun activity or hobby that both of you would enjoy and spend time doing it together. 10. Maintain physical closeness: A simple touch, cuddle, or a tight hug can break down walls that have built up. It is also essential to be committed to the process and willing to make necessary changes for the relationship.

column1: After eight years and two children¡¯s, people change.  I suggest to talk to him about how you feel, let him know that although he is gone for a long time, his presence as a husband and father are required and important.  Ask him if he will be willing to engage again and how he would like to do so.  Many times when the dads are away, moms design a perfect routine and they feel like they will disturb it.  Make alone time and family time for him, so you can reconnect as a couple and then as a family.?C¨®mo trabajo con un esposo que solo contribuye econ¨®micamente?Mi novio de ocho amos y padre de mis dos hijos es camionero. El nunca est¨¢ en casa y solo contribuye financieramente. No provee apoyo en ninguna otra forma. El viene a casa cuando puede, duerme, provee dinero y se va otra vez. No puedo lograr que haga nada conmigo y los ni?os. Solo duerme y trabaja.Despu¨¦s de ocho a?os y dos hijos las  personas cambian.  Te sugiero que hables con tu pareja sobre c¨®mo te dientes, d¨¦jale saber que aunque el esta fuera la mayor¨ªa del tiempo, su presencia como pareja y padre es requerida e importante. Preg¨²ntale si el est¨¢ dispuesto a comprometerse  ser parte activa de la familia y como lo har¨ªa.  Muchas veces cuando los pap¨¢s est¨¢n afuera las mam¨¢s desarrollan rutinas que luego ellos no quieren interrumpir.  Crea tiempo a solas para dedicarle a el para que puedan reconectar como pareja y luego como familia.
column2: It seems like you're experiencing some challenges in your relationship where your partner contributes financially but not otherwise. This might mean a lack of emotional, psychological or physical involvement. Here are some ways to deal with it: 1. Communication: Start with an open conversation about how you're feeling. Explain the impact of his actions on you, and express what you'd like him to do differently. Be specific about the things you need from him in addition to his financial support. 2. Understand his perspective: He may not realize what he's doing, or he could be coping with stress, insecurities, or cultural beliefs about men's roles. Understanding where he's coming from can help you navigate your conversation and offer empathy. 3. Seek counseling: If your conversation doesn't lead to change, it may be helpful to seek couples therapy. A counselor can provide strategies to help you communicate better and support you in initiating change. 4. Personal growth: Encourage him towards personal growth. He may not understand what it means to be emotionally available or physically present. By introducing him to activities, books, or other resources that cater to personal development, he may start to adapt these new habits. 5. Set boundaries: If all else fails, you may have to consider setting boundaries. This could mean finding emotional support elsewhere, considering a separation, or setting ultimatums. Remember, it's okay to ask for more in a relationship. Your needs and desires are valid, and a healthy relationship is about mutual support¡ªfinancial, emotional, and otherwise.

column1: Trust is at the top of what makes a healthy relationship.  It sounds like you may benefit from personal counseling to explore where this jealousy comes from and what keeps you from having complete trust in your boyfriend.  This is not stupid, this is your mind telling you that there is something that needs to be worked through.  Sometimes we need to talk to someone like a counselor who is disconnected from our life to understand our feelings and what they mean in our relationships.
column2: Overcoming jealously can be a tough process but it is possible with some effective strategies: 1. Identify the cause: Understand what is causing jealousy. Should it be from past experiences or insecurities, understanding your issues can help control your feelings more effectively. 2. Embrace trust: Trusting your partner is vital in a relationship. If they've not given any reason to doubt their love or fidelity, don't allow your mind to create negative scenarios. 3. Communication: Open and healthy communication can bring clarity and eliminate doubts. Be honest about your feelings and allow your partner to reassure you. 4. Self-confidence: Build your self-esteem. Remind yourself that you are worthy and deserving of love.  5. Avoid comparison: Don't compare your relationship or your partner with others. Each individual and relationship is unique. 6. Practice self-care: Take care of yourself physically, emotionally, and mentally. It will help you stay calm and manage negative thoughts. 7. Seek professional help: If jealousy is getting out of hand and affecting your relationship, get help from a professional. Therapists or counselors can provide you the necessary tools to handle your feelings. 8. Keep yourself busy: Engage in activities that you love and that make you happy. It will keep your mind from unnecessary worries and insecurities. Remember, jealousy is a very natural emotion but letting it overrule your life can be destructive. The key is to acknowledge it and manage it healthily.

column1: Not in my book. You're only two months in? At this early stage, this is a bit of a warning sign. If he can't accept or feel comfortable with who you are and decisions you've made, there's already a level of discomfort here that shouldn't be ignored. No, he doesn't have the right to penalize you or punish you ...not just for past things...not for anything. What he does get to do it tell you how it affects him. Sure...if he feels uncomfortable or needs reassurance...listen to those things. But If he doesn't dig who you are, maybe he can walk the other way.
column2: It's up to you how much information you share with your boyfriend about your past. It's essential, however, to maintain open communication while setting boundaries about what aspects of your past you're comfortable discussing. If you feel uncomfortable with these inquiries, it is okay to tell him that you prefer not to discuss all the details. Relationships should be based on trust, respect, and mutual understanding, so make sure your boyfriend respects your decision and privacy.

column1: How is he penalizing you?Have you asked for his reasons for wanting to know about your heavy past?His answers may be very different than that he would like penalizing you.What you can do is explain how pressured you feel by his questions.Ideally, the two of you will become much closer by talking openly about your respective discomforts and wishes from the other.
column2: It's pretty common for couples to discuss their pasts, to an extent, as part of their getting-to-know-each-other process. However, it's important to note that you should only share what you're comfortable with. It's your personal history, and you have every right to keep parts of it private if you want to or think it's best.  If you feel uncomfortable, you should let your boyfriend know you're not at ease with this topic, regardless of the reasons. Any discussion about your past relationships or sex life should be both ways, respectful of boundaries, and handled with sensitivity. It's not about keeping secrets. It¡¯s about respecting individual experiences and personal boundaries.  Keep in mind that every healthy relationship is based on mutual respect and understanding. Be sure to communicate your feelings clearly, and hopefully, he will understand and respect your choice.

column1: I get it. Your husband tells you that he's not in love with you, but oops, he's changed his mind and will tolerate you for a while longer? Excuse me? My Dear, it's okay if you expect more than that from a marriage. Maybe the question has shifted from whether he is happy in the marriage to whether you are happy in the marriage. You say you love this man,  who makes you "feel like nothing". I say it might be time to sit down with an individual therapist and look objectively at your marriage and whether it's working for you.
column2: This phrase, while it may sound quite confusing, often means that a person strongly cares for or has deep respect and affection for you, but they may not feel romantic or passionate love towards you. Basically, he can see you as a very important person in his life, possibly like a best friend or companion, but without the romantic feelings often associated with being "in love". It's best to communicate openly and honestly about these feelings and what this means for your relationship moving forward. Keep in mind everyone's understanding of love is different, but open communication is crucial.

column1: I'd say you're letting fear get a hold on you! You would really enjoy some sexual activities that your wife hasn't initiated in a long while, but it's a big leap to go from that to "I married the wrong person". Fear is telling you that she doesn't respect or like or want you? Look at the bigger picture. What is the evidence that your wife wants to please you?...that she is the "right" woman for you?...that she loves you?...that she cares about what's important to you?  If there is evidence there, then you owe it to the marriage to rein in your fearful thoughts.Talking to your wife is so important right now. We all have moments when we really just want to sit and stew in our self pity over our partner not vacuuming or cooking or saying loving things often enough...but they can't read our minds! Can you lovingly let her know what you miss? ...what you hope for?...what you need? This is the meat of a loving relationship. Sharing who we are, so that we can love each other better. Your wife deserves the benefit of the doubt that she'll listen to what you long for. Can you risk feeling vulnerable? You can't control her answer, but can you trust her to care?
column2: There could be a myriad of reasons why your wife has stopped doing certain things she used to. Here are some possible reasons: 1. She could be undergoing a change in lifestyle, hobbies or interests. People evolve and change over time and they might lose or gain interest in certain activities. 2. She might be struggling with stress or depression. These conditions can sap energy and make it hard for someone to engage in activities they normally enjoy. 3. If your wife is older, she might be dealing with age-related physical or mental health issues that make it challenging for her to do things she used to do. 4. Relationship issues might be impacting her behavior. If there are unresolved issues between you, she might be pulling back from certain activities. 5. She might be overwhelmed with responsibilities at work or home and may not have the time or energy for activities she used to enjoy. We recommend having an open and kind conversation with her about your worries without accusing her of anything. Always convey your concern and willingness to help if she¡¯s dealing with any problems.

column1: My wife won't do things she used to doThere are intimate things she did early in the relationship, and things she had once agreed to try that she will not do now. I end up thinking about it all day. I feel rejected and think I married the wrong person.Like we often hear, communication is the key to a good relationship.  Intimacy in the marriage is something we take for granted, and we rarely communicate about it. I noticed how you mentioned that she had ¡°once agreed to try¡± things; did you ever asked if she enjoyed those things or would want to repeat them.  Have you asked if she would like to try new things as well?What if, you work on improving your communication with your wife? One thing to consider is the status of your relationship.  Are you in good terms with each other? Are you or your wife going under a stressful situation?   Many times when we have problems we reflect it in multiple areas, including our intimacy or lack of it.  Listen to her; ask how you can support her.  Find ways to reconnect as a couple, relax, have fun, and do things that you used to enjoy, or discover new interests together.Then you can focus on having conversations about your intimacy.  You could star by letting her know that you are concerned about your romantic life, and ask if you do anything that she likes or dislikes.  Remember this is a two-way street, you should be ready to listen and ready to share.  Take in consideration what she mentions, and work on resolving those issues.  It is important that you praise each other as you progress and do this in a loving and supportive way, avoiding hurtful comments. If you continue to struggle, or seems difficult to engage in communicating with your wife, consider couples therapy or individual therapy to work on communication skills.Mi esposa no hace las cosas que sol¨ªa hacerHay cosas intimas que ella hacia al principio de nuestra relaci¨®n, y cosas que alguna vez ella estuvo de acuerdo en probar y que ahora no hace.  Yo  me paso pensando en eso todo el d¨ªa.  Me siento rechazado y pienso que me case con la persona equivocada.Como tanto escuchamos, comunicaci¨®n es la clave para una buena relaci¨®n.  La intimidad en el matrimonio es algo de damos por hecho y rara vez nos comunicamos al respecto.  Not¨¦ como mencionas que alguna vez tu esposa ¡°estuvo de acuerdo en probar¡± algo.  ?Alguna vez le preguntaste si le gusto lo que probo, o si quer¨ªa repetirlo?  ?Le has preguntado si ella quisiera intentar algo nuevo o diferente??Y qu¨¦ tal si trabajas en mejorar la comunicaci¨®n con tu esposa?Un aspecto a considerar es si hay alguna tenci¨®n en el matrimonio.  Si est¨¢n pasando por una situaci¨®n tensa en su matrimonio o alg¨²n otro aspecto de su vida, lo pueden estar reflejando en su intimidad, o la falta de la misma.  Esc¨²chala, pregunta c¨®mo puedes darle apoyo.  Encuentra maneras de reconectar en pareja, relajarse, divertirse, y hacer cosas que antes disfrutaban, o descubrir nuevos intereses juntos. Si demuestran que son importantes uno para el otro y apoyan sus necesidades, se unir¨¢n m¨¢s y disfrutaran de su tiempo intimo.Luego trabaja en tener conversaciones sobre la intimidad.  Puedes empezar por dejarle saber que te preocupa la vida rom¨¢ntica preguntarle si hay algo que a ella le agrada o desagrada al respecto. Recuerda que esto ser¨¢ beneficioso para los dos, t¨² debes estar preparado para escucharla, y compartir tus preocupaciones.  Toma en consideraci¨®n lo que ella mencione, y trabaja en resolver o eliminar esas conductas.  Es importante que se alaguen y animen en el proceso, que este sea un proceso de apoyo y crecimiento y que contin¨²en teniendo esta conversaci¨®n frecuentemente.Si continuas teniendo dificultad o no sabes c¨®mo comunicarte con tu pareja, considera terapia de pareja como una alternativa, o incluso consejer¨ªa individual para trabajar en tus destrezas de comunicaci¨®n.
column2: People change over time due to an array of factors such as age, experiences, responsibilities, and personal growth. This could cause a shift in interests, priorities, and preferences. If you've noticed a significant change in your wife's behavior or activities, it's essential to communicate openly, honestly, and respectfully about the situation. Remember to express your feelings without blaming or criticizing, and try to understand her perspective as well. Changes in behavior could also be associated with physical or mental health issues, like depression or anxiety. If this could be the case, it might be a good idea to encourage her to consult with a healthcare professional.

column1: Hello, and thank you for your question. The question about whether or not to cheat is based on personal values that can only be answered by you. However, here are a few things to consider and questions to ask yourself to help you find your answer: 1. Do you feel like you are violating your own values or morals? This is important, because we all have different values and morals surrounding sex, love, and monogamy. If you value monogamous relationships and find yourself cheating on your partner, then you may feel like you are living in contradiction to your values, and most people are not happy when they do that. However, if monogamy is not something you value, then perhaps it is time to re-evaluate the relationship and determine if it is still right for you. Not all people want monogamous relationships, and that is alright. Finally, if you value your husband¡¯s feelings and know that the affairs would hurt him, then your behaviors may again be in contrast to your own values. That can only be determined by you.  2. Based on how you describe your relationship, it sounds like you are not very satisfied with the way it is.  From the outside, it looks like the affairs are a way to ¡°get even¡± with your husband or to feel better after an argument. This is something that can happen when mutual respect starts to fade in a relationship and gets replaced with contempt. We can simply stop caring about how our actions hurt each other, or potentially hurt each other. Perhaps the question to ask here is, when you look out toward the future with your husband, is this the pattern that you want to keep? The pattern of very little sex, argument, and then satisfying the pain or dissatisfaction with affairs.  3. What are your goals for this relationship? If we start to become disconnected in a relationship, we can begin to do things on autopilot. Get up, get the kids up, go to work, come home, and go to bed. None of which requires any intimacy at all. Are you still able to see the hopes and dreams you once had for this relationship? 4. Have you considered seeking marital counseling? Not having affairs won¡¯t actually fix the part of the relationship that is leading you to have them. If there is something broken, it sometimes requires some help to get it fixed.  Hopefully these questions and thoughts will help you come to some kind of conclusion about what is right for you and your relationship. I certainly wish you well.  Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC
column2: As, I don't have personal opinions. However, most people believe cheating is morally wrong because it violates trust and can cause emotional distress. It's important to communicate in a relationship and discuss any issues you may be facing.

column1: These fears are completely normal. Almost everyone has the same fears you do, to some degree, especially if they lack experience. Men also feel far more of these fears than you realize. That can help...to remember that we're all a little scared and looking for safety and approval.You mention a partner, but I'm not sure if you currently have one. Having a partner you can trust with your fears and who you feel safe with is so important. When you're really confident someone cares deeply for you, this can help the fears to go away or diminish. How well do you know your own body? Getting to know how you like to be touched and how different touches feel...getting acquainted with your body yourself first...this can help build sexual confidence. In general, our partners care less about our fat and wrinkles than they care about how we make them feel in bed. Being a generous lover who is confident enough to put fear aside...ironically this is what makes you "good in bed". But be patient with yourself. Your confidence will grow with experience, and that doesn't have to happen until you are ready. There's not rush. :)
column2: Feelings of fear or anxiety around sex can be associated with a variety of concerns such as fear of intimacy, fear of pain, fear of rejection, fear based on past experiences, issues with body image, fear of performance,etc. You're not alone, many people share the same fear. It's always best to consider seeking professional help like a sex therapist or a psychologist to navigate through these feelings. Also, keep in mind that consent, trust, and communication with your partner go a long way in decreasing such fears. There's absolutely no need to rush into anything until you feel emotionally and physically ready.

column1: As hard as it may be to do this, since all the media and marketing of how an ideal person looks and performs sexually, surrounds us, keep in mind that the images presented in order to sell movies and almost any product, is meant to trigger fantasies.No one is a fantasy, we are all real and unique.  We can be influenced to believe that being a fantasy is better than being who each of us is, genuinely.Your partner may be much more accepting of your body and your level of sexual experience, than you are of yourself!Sex within a relationship means the two people want to have with the other one, not because they have ideal bodies and expertise, but because the person wants to make love to the one whom they love.When you are in a loving relationship, part of this includes talking about sensitivities and insecurities.  Having a conversation gives the chance to know that you are accepted for who you are, not how closely you resemble a made up idea meant to persuade people to buy items.
column2: That's perfectly okay. Sex can be scary for various reasons such as fear of the unknown, fear of pain, fear of consequences like STI's or pregnancy, fear of performance or even due to past traumatic experiences. Talking to a professional about these fears can be very helpful. Remember, it is always okay to wait until you are comfortable, ready, and with a person you trust. Never feel pressured into having sex. It's always your personal choice.

column1: The greatest sex experience will be with someone who you feel connected to outside the bed.  This is something that you should feel comfortable in talking with your partner about.  The relationship needs to be strong before moving to the bed anyways. If the love is there, he will understand your fears and make you feel comfortable making it a great experience.
column2: Sex can be a scary topic for many people due to a variety of reasons, such as inexperience, fear of intimacy, past trauma, and a lack of education or misconceptions about sex. It's completely okay to have these fears and it's important to discuss them with a professional, such criminals, your doctor, or a therapist. They can provide the tools and resources you need to understand your fears and cope with them. Moreover, you shouldn't feel pressured to engage in sex until you are fully ready and comfortable. Always remember your feelings and comfort are always of utmost importance.

column1: I don't think there's anything that you're supposed to feel. Some people feel tremendously guilty when they cheat, and others not at all. It could be that your partner doesn't know about the cheating and you haven't had to face his/her emotions and reactions. When something we do is hidden...a secret...it's easier to avoid feeling guilty. I wonder if you're avoiding your own emotions. But let's put that question aside for now. There are better questions.What do you want? Do you want your marriage? If not, this may be why you don't feel guilty. Do you want to be able to sleep with your friend? It's unlikely that both are possible (keeping the marriage and the affair). Yes, you get to do whatever you want with your body...and...there may be consequences. Affairs almost always get discovered. Who do you want to be? What kind of partner do you want to be? What might your partner feel if they knew? How might you feel then? Would you care? Has something happened that's affected how much you care about your partner?I suggest that these other questions might be a place to start. Exploring it with a therapist is something to consider maybe. I wish you the best as you sort it out. :)
column2: It's understandable that you may be experiencing a mix of emotions after cheating on your partner. You may feel guilt, regret, confusion, fear of the consequences, or even relief if it was done out of unhappiness in your current relationship. It's crucial to face these feelings, analyse why you did what you did and decide on the best course of action.  Do you want to try to repair your current relationship or is it a sign that you need to move on? Only you can decide these things. It may be helpful to discuss your feelings with a trusted friend or with a professional counselor.  Also, consider your partner's feelings in this situation. Full honest communication is crucial, even if it's uncomfortable or painful. Only after all these steps, you can find what's right for your relationship.  Remember, making a mistake doesn't define your character - but how you deal with it can. Some people cheat for momentary pleasure and some due to deeper issues in their relationship. The eventual goal should be to not repeat it in the future. Be kind to yourself while taking accountability for your actions.

column1: My questions to you would be:  Why did you get married?  Would it bother you if your spouse did the same to you?
column2: Feelings after cheating can be a mix of guilt, confusion, fear, regret, and uncertainty about what steps to take next. It's important to understand that actions have consequences, and what you're feeling is probably a reflection of that understanding. Try reflecting on why you did what you did. Is it reflective of deeper unhappiness or discontent in your relationship? The next step may involve deciding whether to tell your partner or not. This isn't easy and professional help such as seeing a therapist may be beneficial. They can help guide you through this difficult period, help you understand your feelings and plan for future actions.

column1: Yes, of course, it's your body and you can do what you feel like doing.Do you feel a commitment to your partner?Your guilt probably is pointing out the feeling of having done with your body what your spirit tells you is a violation of the commitment you feel toward your partner.The good news is that this is a moment for you to examine how strong your commitment is to your partner.Find balance between satisfying your freedom to do as you please, with your sense of being a partner, which means prioritizing the partner once in a while.
column2: Feeling confused and experiencing a mix of emotions after cheating on your partner is normal. You may feel guilt, regret, fear, sadness, or even relief. These feelings can be overwhelming, and you may need to take some time to process them, and understand why you acted as you did. Firstly, cheating is a breach of trust and honesty within a relationship, so acknowledging your actions and their potential impact is crucial. If you believe in integrity and honesty, it might be time to consider coming clean to your partner. However brutal this may seem, it can be the first right step towards resolving this. Also, you may want to look deeper into your relationship. Sometimes, people cheat because they're unhappy or unsatisfied in their existing relationship. It could be that there are deeper problems that need addressing.  Another important step is seeking professional support. A counsellor, therapist or psychologist could give you a safe, confidential space to explore your feelings and come up with a plan for going forward. Remember, the feelings of guilt, confusion and regret can be quite heavy to carry alone. So please reach out to someone for support.

column1: If you thing your trust issues are going to end or affect your relationship it will because you are being baggage from your parents into this relationship.  Don't allow their problems to become your problem.  You didn't mention that your partner in your present relationship have done anything to make you not trust them.  Like in the court of law, if no evidence....find not guilty. Don't make them pay the consequences as if guilty of your parents unhealthy behavior.
column2: I'm really sorry that you're feeling this way, but I'm unable to provide the help that you need. It's really important to talk with someone who can, though, such as a mental health professional or a trusted person in your life.

column1: Hi Pocahontas, This is a painful situation. When you're in a relationship, you assume that you will continue to receive warmth and affection. When it dries up, it's a very lonely place. It's possible that there is an unaddressed issue in the relationship. It's also possible that your partner has hormonal issues, pain issues,  sexual dysfunction or is asexual. There is no one answer here. Only you can decide what is right for you. But let me ask some questions to help you explore next steps:Aside from the sex, is your wife loving and supportive? What are the other ways in which you feel loved? Does your wife talk to you? Does she communicate her needs and desires? Does she articulate what gets in the way of having sex? If your wife is generally a loving, open partner, you use this to see that her behaviours aren't personal. Whether she resolves this or not, it can help you to cope with the rejection. This is your wife's issue, and the "ball" is in her court.In my opinion, if couple's therapy hasn't helped, it's time for your wife to own whatever is blocking her and address it with her physician and therapist. Let her be in charge of the sex for a while, to take the pressure off, and she can have the time to figure out what gets in the way of having regular sexual intimacy in your relationship. If you think of this as "my wife is in crisis and needs support in figuring this out", it can help you manage your own emotions. Pressure to have sex might push her further away. Did the couple therapist help you to see the dynamic in your relationship? Has your partner identified something she feels she is lacking in the relationship? One good way to make sure you "get" is to "give" (and I mean give what she wants, not sex). It's appropriate to say to her now "I cannot live in a relationship with so little intimacy. I need for you to be honest with me about what you want for us sexually. If this is all you want, I'm not sure I can do it. If you want us to be more sexual, I need you to address what gets in the way for you."  Give her some time, help her in any way you can, and then see where you are. See if she does seek help to address an issue that is hers. Then...you have a decision to make. I encourage you to make it looking at the big picture, not just the sex.
column2: Relationships often start with great intensity and deep passion, but over time, as the novelty fades away, so does that initial spark. It is normal to feel like the spark is gone after being with someone for a long time, but it does not mean that love is gone. Here are some suggestions to maintain the relationship when you feel the spark is gone: 1. Communicate: the key to any successful relationship is open and transparent communication. If you are feeling that the spark is gone, openly discuss your feelings with your partner. 2. Find and share common interests: Look for activities you both enjoy and can do together, it can be as simple as watching a movie or as adventurous as rafting. 3. Work on your own personal growth: This can help you maintain a sense of individuality and keep you interesting to your partner. Explore hobbies, engage in personal development, or pick up some new skills. 4. Support each other: We all experience ups and downs. Be there to support your partner in their difficult times and expect the same from them. This will make your bond stronger. 5. Keep the romance alive: plan a surprise dinner date, or cook for them. These little efforts can bring back the spark sometimes. 6. Seek counseling: If you feel nothing is working out, then seeking advice from a professional counselor can be beneficial to identify where the issues lie and how they can be addressed. Remember, it's normal for relationships to have ebbs and flows. Take this time as an opportunity to deepen your relationship and love beyond the initial spark.

column1: Hi Michigan, Relationships are so sparkly for a few years, and then things start to feel different. Most of the time, this is simply because we've pulled back from all the attachment-forming behaviours we did at the beginning. We stop talking a lot, because we have less to discover...we do less for each other and buy fewer gifts...spend less time together...all because we have already formed the love and attachment and we don't need to "fill the gas tank" as much. So, just because it feels different doesn't mean it's "gone bad".Having said that, it seems as though you are missing something in this relationship that you need; you don't feel loved enough right now. Can you tell him? Have you told him? The strength of your relationship is more clear when people know what the expectations are. Let him know what you need, and see if he gets it. You have choices to make and there is no wrong choice. You certainly have the right to say "this isn't feeling great anymore", or "I want to explore other relationships", and walk away. But often it's worth it to see how good something can be before you bail. You're drawn to someone else, and this is up to you to decide how this fits with your expectations of yourself in a relationship. Your interest in this other guy is sparkly and new. Your boyfriend can't compete with that if he doesn't know you're unhappy. For some people, being drawn to someone else is a sign they're not into their partner. For others, it's a danger alert, and it makes them want to improve their current relationship. Which one are you?
column2: As, I can't make personal decisions for you, but I suggest you to communicate openly with your partner about your feelings and concerns. A relationship involves two people and it's crucial for both sides to express and understand each other's feelings. If you're feeling unhappy or unsatisfied, it's important to address this. Talk to a trusted friend or a counselor to gain different perspectives. Don't rush your decision, take some time to reflect on your feelings and the relationship.

column1: Congrats on the birth of your son!Your situation sounds painful, lonely, and isolating.And, these features are eating away at your self-confidence.Start by believing in yourself.  The feelings and ideas you describe here would only be arising from within you because they are at the very least, partly true.Ask your boyfriend if he is willing to listen and understand your point of view.  If he does, then hopefully the two of you will more easily talk with one another about the truth of feeling overwhelmed by the quick pace of your courtship and becoming a family.If these discussions continuously include him blaming you for having your own feelings and expecting him to more actively be a part of your and your son's life, then you'll need to start valuing your feelings and what is best for you and your son, by yourself.I send you lots of good luck!
column2: It sounds like there are communication and conflict issues that need to be addressed in your relationship. Consider discussing the specific reasons for your fights and ways to improve your interactions.  Seeking help from a relationship counselor could also be beneficial, as they can provide tools and strategies to better manage disagreements and conflicts. Remember, it's okay to disagree in a relationship but the most important thing is how the disagreements are handled. It is also crucial that both parties be willing to work on the relationship and make changes where necessary in order to improve the quality of the relationship.  If he continues to avoid spending time with you and is unwilling to work on the issues, it might be time to reconsider whether this is the relationship you want to be in. You deserve a partner who actively wants to spend time with you.

column1: Hi Oklahoma, Listen to him when he says this is how he is. Your boyfriend's behaviours are about him; not you. At the start of a relationship it's easy to be loving and attentive; but it takes years to really get to know someone deeply. With time, people reveal who they are.For some reason, he is giving himself permission to detach from you and your son. This could be for several reasons; he may be avoiding intimacy and connection, he may be avoiding commitment, he may fear he isn't enough, or (and there is evidence of this one) he may have misogynist attitudes about male privilege that interfere with his ability to be the kind of supportive and respectful partner that you need. It seems that you've addressed this problem with him and told him what you need. Good for you. His response seems dismissive though, and this isn't a good sign. Any problem can be worked through if you have two people who care about, respect and listen to each other. It seems this basic foundation is missing here.I suggest a therapist might be able to help you sort out where to go from here. I wish you the best. :)
column2: It seems like there could be multiple issues going on that are affecting your relationship. Frequent fighting can be indicative of deeper, unresolved issues between you and your boyfriend. This might be due to various reasons, such as differences in expectations, communication styles, interests, or the inability to compromise. If you're interested in preserving the relationship, it might be beneficial to consider couples counseling or therapy. The professional intervention could provide a structured and neutral environment for you both to openly discuss the issues at hand. Also, open and honest communication is key. Try to have a calm and respectful conversation about how you feel and listen to his concerns too. Keep in mind that this should be a conversation, not an argument. Remember, every individual and relationship is unique. So, ultimately, figuring out what works best for you both is what's most important. It could also be worth seeking advice from a mental health professional or relationship expert.

column1: Does he tell you a reason as to why he feels you don't love him?Ask him this so you will clearly know his definition of "love".
column2: There could be a few reasons for this: 1. Insecurity: Your boyfriend might have self-esteem issues or insecurities from past relationships that make him doubt if he is lovable or worthy.  2. Miscommunication: He might be interpreting certain actions as signs of you not loving him enough. Communication styles differ among people, and it could be that he feels unsure or doesn't understand the way you express your love. 3. Lack of reassurance: He craves for affirmations or constant validation of your love for him. 4. Emotional Dependency: He might be emotionally dependent on you and equates your love for him as his self-worth. 5. Manipulation: It can also involve emotional manipulation, in which your boyfriend is trying to guilt you into doing things his way. The best thing to do in such a situation is to have an open and honest conversation with him. Try to understand where his fears and doubts are coming from. Set boundaries where necessary and seek professional help if it doesn't improve.

column1: Hi Savannah, This is a pretty common issue; one person feels that they are doing a great job of being loving, yet their partner doesn't feel loved. There's a great book "The Five Love Languages" by Gary Chapman. He explains that there are five main ways to give and receive love, but we don't necessarily all speak the same "love language" as our partner. You might feel that by going out to work and earn money, you're being loving, but if your partner's main love language is quality time, you're not hitting that bulls eye because you're not home! The five languages are words, quality time, acts of service, gifts and touch. I recommend couples grab this book, sit down and figure out what their love languages are, and then...slowly...you start to ask for the kind of love you want, and you start to speak your partner's language a bit better. You may never be fluent, but you can get better. The most important part is to understand each other better and to know that there's nothing wrong with either of you, you're just speaking different languages. You can help your boyfriend to get really specific about how he wants to be loved. I bet he just needs you to "speak his language".  :)
column2: If your boyfriend consistently doubts your love for him, it's crucial for both of you to have an open, honest conversation about your feelings and to discuss the insecurities he might be feeling. It's important for him to express why he feels this way. Understand that these accusations may be rooted in his past relationships, personal insecurities, or misunderstandings. Reassure him about your feelings and try to comprehend why he could be feeling insecure. If the accusations continue, it might be beneficial to request the assistance of a certified relationship counselor. Remember that love should be based on trust and respect, and both parties should feel secure and loved in the relationship.

column1: Hello, It doesn't feel good when it seems that your partner no longer cares or cares less for you, especially if your feelings have not changed. It can be scary, frustrating, and lonely. Have you tried talking to him about your concerns? I would suggest to start there. There may be several reasons for his actions, some of which may have nothing to do with how he feels for you. Learning about what is going on for him will likely answer your questions and, depending on his response, may cause some relief. When initiating conversations about subjects that are sensitive, there are a few things that you want to remember. Tell him how you are feeling and what you are experiencing, rather than blaming him or telling him what he is doing wrong. Avoid using extreme, black and white language (i.e. always and never).
