column2: It's normal for the sexual aspect of a relationship to hit lows and highs throughout time. However, it's important to evaluate why you're both feeling this way. Are you tired physically, emotionally, or is it just the monotony of the act?  Could it be due to stress, health issues, or other external factors affecting your sex drive? If so, it's advisable to seek professional guidance, like a therapist or a healthcare professional. Try different ways to ignite the spark - try new things in the bedroom, role-play, change up the environment, introduce sex toys, etc.  On the other hand, if it's due to a lack of emotional connection, take some time to reconnect emotionally without the pressure of sex. Go on dates, spend quality time, focus on each other's needs, practice open communication, and even seek out couples counseling. Remember, it's perfectly OK if your sexual desires fluctuate - it's a part of being in a long term relationship. But ensure you both are on the same page and focus on maintaining open and easy communication about your needs and feelings.

column1: Sustaining passion in marriage is tough stuff. It's a relatively modern dilemma you are facing with perhaps unrealistic expectations of what marriage "should" be. It sounds like your definitions of love and sexual passion have merged together, that's both common and confusing! Intimacy and sexuality within your marriage are bound to ebb and flow. Resparking your passion will involve growing. Using your sexual drama and fantasies as windows into discovering your needs (security) and wants (desires). Marriage is a people growing process; you mature into one another and to achieve fulfillment your continued development will be required.
column2: It sounds like you're going through a tough time. It's normal to have moments of doubt and confusion in a relationship, but if these feelings persist, it may be helpful to seek guidance from a marriage counselor or therapist to navigate your feelings and determine the best course of action. Honest communication, although difficult, is also very necessary. Remember, it's important to take care of your emotional and mental well-being.

column1: This is difficult to answer because you don¡¯t tell us what the fetish is.  I do understand that this is something that is bothering you though. The first thing to ask yourself is if this is something that is illegal or not.  If this is illegal to engage in, then you need to seek counseling help immediately to control the urges.However, if your fetish is not something illegal and you just feel that it is something odd, a therapist could still help you deal with these feelings.  You may find that it is something very common and not something to be ashamed of.  You may find other people have the same interest as you.  Find a therapist that you can trust and tell them.  Don¡¯t hold back with your therapist.  Trust me, they have heard and seen it all by now, and they can help you either stop the behavior that is causing you distress, or help you come to terms with accepting the behavior as part of who you are.  There is no need to suffer with this alone.
column2: 1. Self-Acceptance: The first step is to accept yourself and your fetish. Remember, as long as it doesn't harm, manipulate, or exploit anyone, it's acceptable. 2. Research: Look for information online to understand more about your fetish. There are various communities and groups for almost all fetishes, where you can learn from other people's experiences. 3. Seek professional help: If your fetish is causing you distress or impacting your daily life, consider speaking to a counselor or therapist. They can provide guidance, support, and help you navigate any feelings of embarrassment or shame. 4. Communicate: Once you're comfortable with your fetish and ready, communicate it to your partner with love, respect, and understanding. It's crucial to discuss consent, comfort levels, and boundaries. 5. Don't rush: It's vital not to rush into experiencing your fetish. Take one step at a time; this will allow you and your partner to process each stage, creating a safe environment. Remember that everyone has unique preferences and desires. It's important not to allow yourself to feel ashamed or strange about your fetishes.

column1: I am sorry to hear of your relationship struggles. One thing I wonder is did you volunteer the information about your past or is this something that he asked about? In the future, it is probably best to leave details out of conversations like this. I think it is common and natural for partners to ask about the sexual history. For one thing, it is a good idea to be checked for STD¡¯s before entering into a sexual relationship with someone, and it is fair to share that information with each other. Partners usually want to know how many you have been with and what kind of sexual preferences you have or if there is anything you don¡¯t like to do. This gets into a gray area for some people. I don¡¯t necessarily want to know how many people my partner has been with and I certainly don¡¯t want a whole lot of details. Sometimes that is an image I just don¡¯t want in my head about my partner. Vague details are usually enough.However, I understand that your partner has the details and is not happy with your past. This is a reflection on him, not you. This shows insecurities on his part. You cannot control how he will react to information that you provide to him and you cannot control how he feels about the information. The past should remain in the past and not be held against you in the present or future. If he cannot handle your past then it is going to cloud your relationship. You can offer couples counseling to him and see if he will go with you. I have seen relationships recover from some very serious problems such as infidelity. It takes two people who both want it to work to make it work though. If your boyfriend cannot get over your past, you may have to let him go. Don¡¯t keep yourself tied to someone who is not right for you. Constantly holding your past over your head and holding that against you is only going to bring you down and eventually you may start having insecurities or low self-esteem due to this type of treatment. I don¡¯t see that you have done anything wrong. If you aren¡¯t cheating on him now and you answered his questions about your past honestly, how he handles that information is on him. Ultimately, relationships have a tendency to come and go. Don¡¯t fight to hold onto someone who is not right for you. It is okay to be single and enjoy being the best you that you can be. In time, the right person for you will enter your life.
column2: If your boyfriend can't get over your past, you might want to consider the following steps:  1. Have a Heart-to-Heart Talk: Begin with an open, honest conversation. Explain that your past is just that ¨C the past. 2. Show Understanding and Patience: His feelings may be rooted in insecurity, fear or jealousy. Empathize with him and be patient.  3. Seek Professional Help: If it becomes a significant issue, consider seeking help from a professional counselor. They can provide techniques to help overcome such problems.  4. Give It Time: Over time, he may get over your past as he gets to understand you more and your relationship deepens.  5. Consider Your Own Feelings: If despite your efforts, he remains stubborn, it could be damaging to yourself and the relationship. Consider if it is healthy for you to continue in such a situation. Always prioritize your mental well-being.  Remember, everyone has a past and it's part of who we are. It's important to stand up for yourself during these situations and communicate that your past doesn't define your present or future.

column1: I¡¯m sorry to hear about your current situation. My heart goes out to you during this time.First of all, it is of vital importance that you discuss your symptoms with your doctor. Regardless of whether you are able to mend your relationship with your husband, you need to address the physical issues you are experiencing. More than likely he/she will be able to help you relieve some of these symptoms.Secondly, you must be upfront and honest with your husband. Intimacy is a large part of a relationship and it is unfair to your husband that you did not disclose how you were feeling. I think he would appreciate knowing that it was your medical problems causing the lack of sexual desire as opposed to the reason being him.If you explain to him that you are addressing your sexual issues with your doctor in order to enhance your relationship, he may be more willing to see that you are serious in wanting to mend the relationship. The conversation will be hard to explain to your doctor and your husband since it is of such a personal nature but it will be extremely beneficial. And please note that the reason for the feelings you were experiencing (or lack thereof), was not your fault.Best of luck to you and your husband!
column2: I'm sorry to hear that you're dealing with this issue; it can put a lot of strain on relationships. Here are a few tips that might help: 1. Open Communication: It's really important to communicate openly and honestly about your feelings with your partner. Discuss how your lack of sex drive has been affecting you and your relationship and see if you can come to a mutual place of understanding. 2. Medical Check-up: Our desire for sex can be significantly influenced by different medical conditions like hormonal imbalances, depression, certain medications, and more. If you haven't already, consider having a check-up with a healthcare professional to rule out or identify any potential medical reasons for your low sex drive. 3. Counseling: Counseling or therapy can be extraordinarily helpful for unpacking feelings or anxieties you might have about sex. This can be done with or without your partner. 4. Lifestyle Changes: Changes in diet, exercise, and maintaining a healthy body weight can all influence your sex drive. So can reducing stress and getting enough sleep. 5. Consider Working with a Sex Therapist: They specialize in helping couples overcome sexual difficulties and they can provide suggestions, exercises, and strategies tailored specifically for you. Remember, you're not alone in struggling with this issue, and there are many resources and professionals available to help.

column1: It is challenging to see one's parents age and to cope with the new demands.  Your mom means a lot to you, and that is why you get easily frustrated.  I'm guessing that it is not that she is making you do work or that her expectations are non-important to you because if that were the case, you would not feel any guilt.  Accepting the new stage will help you cope with the changes.  Take a deep breath every time you feel frustrated and think of the good times you shared with your mom before her getting Alzheimer's.  Remember that your mom as she was is no longer and that she has reverted to a more delicate phase.  Also, schedule time for yourself and do things that help you relax.  Caretaking of an elderly parent can take a toll on you, and it is essential to incorporate self-care.  Finally, look for an Alzheimer's support group in your area that will help you connect with other people going through the same thing.  You are a good daughter, and your mom is lucky to have you in her life.Sincerely, Mirella~Image and Likeness Counseling
column2: This sounds like a challenging situation to deal with. The feeling of constant criticism from a parent can be emotionally draining. One approach might be trying to have an open and honest conversation with your mom about how you're feeling. Explain that her constant critiquing is causing you distress and ask her if it might be possible for her to approach your actions with more positivity and encouragement. If this doesn't work or isn't possible, speak to another trusted adult about your experience for additional guidance and support. Try to remember that everyone has their own flaws and insecurities, and sometimes these can cause them to project criticism onto others. Try your best to separate your worth and abilities from the negative feedback you're receiving.

column1: There is some great advice here that can really help, but you need some direct support.  Please find a caregiver support organization, a grief group and an individual therapist to help you during this trying time.  Your mom may not know what she is saying, or mean the awful things she says, but that doesn't make it hurt less.  Please take care of yourself and gt some help!
column2: It's tough when we feel like we can't meet our parents' expectations. It's possible that your mom isn't intentionally trying to put you down, but rather offers criticism as a way to "help you grow." However, it's also essential for your emotional health to feel valued and appreciated. In this case, open and honest communication might help. Let her know how you feel - you could surprise her, she might not be aware that her comments are affecting your confidence and happiness.

column1: It's a good question man, and it must be terrible to see your mother in the state she's in.Understand that Alzheimer's is due to under-performing function of kidneys, adrenals, and connective tissue strengtheners; all of which may be corrected with appropriate protocols that are inexpensive and generally simple to follow.Imagine it like a flower that is not fed properly:  A once, beautifully blossom flower APPEARS to be wilting, but it's life-force, spirit, and essence remain fully there and present.  And your mom hears you.Let's clean her out, and see her smile return.
column2: That sounds really challenging. It might help to have a conversation with her about how you feel. It's also important to remember that sometimes people project their own fears and insecurities onto others. This is not necessarily because of anything you're doing wrong. It could be more about your mom's own struggles. Try to stay strong and believe in yourself. Also consider consulting with a counsellor who can provide useful strategies for managing this kind of situation.

column1: Make sure that you continue to treat your Mom with respect. However, you also need to make sure that you have time away from her so that the stress of caring for her doesn't overwhelm you. Balance is the key!
column2: It's understandable that you feel frustrated and perhaps even hurt when your mother seems to constantly criticize your actions. The reasons behind her behavior may be complex, including a desire to propel you to improve or her own insecurities being projected onto you. However, it's normal for you to feel upset about it.  To manage this, try having a calm and respectful conversation with her about your feelings. Explain how her constant criticisms are affecting you. It's important to listen to her side as well, she might not even realize the impact of her behavior. Remember, it's not always about changing others, but understanding them and learning how to cope with them. If her criticisms continue, consider seeking advice from other family members or professionals such as counselors or therapists who can provide valuable strategies to handle criticism and improve your relationship with your mother. Try not to take her criticisms too personally, focus on your achievements and the positive aspects of your life.

column1: You have the answer already. It is not your mom's fault. Always remember that in spite of the disease, that human being you call mom is still there. To cope with the feelings of frustration, anger, and guilt, practice accepting what is at this time. Bring peace to these feelings and commit to move on to provide your mom love. If you can, use mindfulness meditation to stay focus and calm your brain.
column2: This seems like quite a difficult situation for you to have to deal with and it's understandable why you might be feeling this way. The overall issue seems to be a lack of communication or understanding. Consider talking to your mom about how you're feeling and see if you two can come to a mutual understanding. You may find that she's not even aware that she's doing this. In the end, what's important is not to take the criticism personally and remember that our growth often comes from overcoming different types of harshness.

column1: It is very difficult to move from being the child to be the care giver as in your situation. Your mother's behavior as you describe it is a part of this disease. As the disease progresses and she is less aware of the present including her surroundings and who she is speaking to. Your response of anger and frustration are understandable. It is also a part of the grief process as you see you mother slipping away mentally. In the moment that you feel the anger step away, take some deep breathes and give yourself time to calm down. Then return to whatever you were doing with her. Caregivers of Alzheimer's patients need a lot of support themselves. There are support groups  as well as respite services available in many areas that will help you understand the process that each of you is going through. You can get more information about Alzheimer's disease and local resources by going to www.alz.org
column2: This sounds really frustrating. It's important to remember that parents often want the best for their children and may criticize as a way to push them toward success, even if it doesn't always feel helpful. However, it may also be necessary to have a conversation with her about how her constant criticism affects you. Parents are human too, and sometimes they may not realize the impact of their words or actions. Try talking to her openly and honestly about how you feel. It could also be helpful to speak to a counselor or therapist for additional support.

column1: When you feel the frustration and anger building inside you have that be a trigger for you to remember a feeling that you want to experience instead of anger, frustration and guilt, for example understanding. Then say that word to yourself as you take deep breaths. But know that this is normal for caregivers/family members to have these reactions because it is also an emotional roller coaster for you. Even though it is normal it is still good to try to respond differentyl and I commend you for doing that. You also may want to look for a Caregiver Support group which will help you hear from others who also respond this way.
column2: It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of criticism from your mom. This can be really tough to deal with. One way to navigate difficult conversations with your mom is to respond respectfully but assertively about how her criticisms make you feel. You might say something like, "Mom, I really value your opinion, but sometimes it feels like you're more focused on what I'm doing wrong than what I'm doing right. This makes me feel really discouraged. Could we find a better way to communicate?" Remember, it's also possible for parents to overstep their boundaries and their criticism could stem from their own insecurities. Always remind yourself that you're doing the best that you can and seek advice from trusted individuals or professionals if it's overwhelming.

column1: Let me first say that I am sorry you are going through this. Yes, this is a symptom of an ugly disease, but that does not make experiencing it any easier. If your mother was a sweet and understanding lady, I am sure this change in personality feels awful! On the other hand, if your relationship with her has always been difficult this can definitely open up old wounds and anger. I have walked alongside many families as they care for a loved one with Alzheimer's disease. It is unfortunately common to see mothers become cruel and mean toward their daughters. In your case, it sounds like she is not directing her anger at just you. While this may feel less personal, I am sure it makes finding supportive care for her very difficult. I have several quick tips that might help you cope with this situation. 1. Stay tuned in to your level of anger and frustration. If you can limit the amount of time you or anyone else is with your mother you can limit the caregiver burnout. It is completely NORMAL to feel what you are feeling!! However, these are the feelings that can lead to acting out and abuse when not acknowledged. It doesn't sound like this is the case for you, but healthy boundaries and exercising respite will help with your feelings of guilt as well. So, rotate care as much as possible.2. If you find yourself arguing with your mom, STOP. Don't worry, we have all been there before. No need to feel guilty, but this only serves to agitate someone. None of us enjoys being wrong and getting into an argument. For those of us who are able to logically engage with others, sometimes this type of interaction is necessary. Alzheimer's disease has robbed your mother of her logic, therefore arguing with her will only make matters worse. Try redirecting her instead. For tips on how to do this check out Teepa Snow (teepasnow.com)3. Take care of yourself and seek support. Support groups and counseling are a great way to tend to your needs during this long journey. Caregiving can be overwhelming, lonely and heartbreaking. You don't have to go through this alone. Check out Alz.org for support groups in your area.
column2: It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of criticism from your mom, which can be very hard to handle. It's crucial to remember that this type of behavior speaks more about her than you. She might be dealing with her insecurities and reflecting it on you.  Meanwhile, try focusing on building self-confidence. Reflect on what you know are your strengths and achievements, and be proud of them. You also might consider talking calmly to your mom about your feelings when it's an appropriate time. She may not be aware of the impact of her words and actions on you. Use "I statements" to express your feelings, for example: "I feel upset when you criticize me, because I am trying my best." Remember, the most important approval is the one you give to yourself. If none of these strategies work, you might want to consider seeking help from a professional counselor or therapist who can provide techniques for managing your situation.

column1: From your initial description, I would say that your mother is "Maloriented". In this stage of Alzheimer's individuals tend to be blaming and difficult to deal with. They may often hide or throw things away and then blame family members for this. In addition, if they are incontinent, they may blame a leaky roof or something else when they are wet. You are correct that this is not her fault, but often for family members this does not make it any easier for you to cope. I strongly suggest that you learn communication strategies that will help you to communicate with your mother in a way that lets her work through the difficulties associated with the disease. I always suggest Validation techniques to family members.In addition, you need to give yourself some kind attention and take time out from your circumstances as needed. You need to be able to center yourself and come to acceptance that this is your mother's illness that is the problem, not her and certainly not you.
column2: It might be due to your mother's standards or expectations which might be higher than normal. She may not be doing this intentionally. Communication is key in any relationship. Openly discuss with her about how you feel when she consistently criticizes. But remember to stay composed and respectful throughout the conversation. It will help her understand the impact of her actions on you.

column1: Yes, certainly your mom's difficulty in having meaningful conversations with people results from the Alzheimer's disease process which weakens her brain function.Feeling a sense of guilt in relation to a parent, is pretty common for everyone.This is because as little kids and babies, we had a strong reliance on a parent and believing every word they sad and wishing to follow each action they ask or demand, was for the benefit of our own survival.One way of coping with your feeling of guilt is to examine it.Ask what it is you're feeling guilty about?Chances are that your sense of guilt is less due to what you're currently saying or doing to help your mom.Very likely, your guilt feeling is awakening the sense of obligation that you and all of us feel toward a parent simply because parents seem to have unquestionable power when we are very young.After all, you're thoughtful enough to write a question, so chances are great that you're already actively involved in caring for your mom.
column2: It can be tough feeling like you're always being judged or criticized, especially by a parent. It's important to remember that often, parents criticize out of a desire to help their children improve or avoid mistakes. That said, constant criticism can feel a lot like nagging and can be quite distressing.  Try discussing these feelings with your mom honestly and openly. Express how the constant criticism makes you feel, and ensure that you approach the conversation respectfully. Also, keep in mind that everyone might have areas they need to improve, including you. So consider her criticism and if you think they're valid, use them for your own growth but if they're not, don't take them to heart. Remember that it comes from a place of love. You're never defined by what someone thinks of you, even if it's your mom. Instead, you're defined by who you are and what you do, your values and principles matter.

column1: Good observation on your part, to distinguish that your feelings in relation to your mom are not necessarily connected to the way she handles her part of the relation toward you.Has your mom usually ignored your opinions and wishes in relating to you?If prior to the onset of Alzheimer's, she never examined her way of relating to you, and if both of you have never had an open conversation about your sense of feeling hurt by her attitudes and manner with you, then the relationship between you and your mom will change in ways other than rational dialogue.She may continue ignoring or overlooking your wishes because she's been stuck in this attitude for most of your life.The good news for you about this is realizing that who you are and your way of relating to your mom, has very little to do with the way she relates to you.This is a more profound disappointment because it shows that her disconnect from you has been for longer than when the Alzheimer's began.You can however, feel a little more free knowing that you're not deserving of being ignored.
column2: Approaching this sensitive topic with your elderly mother might need careful consideration. Here are some guidelines: 1. Choose the right moment: Choose a quiet, relaxed and peaceful moment to bring up the topic. Avoid moments when she's already feeling stressed or upset. 2. Be gentle but firm: Express that you love her and remind her that your inability to stay for long visits doesn't change your concern for her. 3. Explain your reasons: Clearly communicate why you can't stay for long. Whether it's due to work, personal commitments, or health reasons, explain it to her. Being honest will help her understand your situation better and see things from your perspective.  4. Acknowledge her feelings: She might feel disappointed, lonely or rejected. Listen to her feelings and reassure her. Show empathy and let her know it's okay to share her feelings. 5. Offer alternatives: If you can't stay for long, propose other ways to remain connected. You could arrange frequent shorter visits or setup video call sessions, you can write letters or send messages. If it's possible, connect her with social activities and people nearby. 6. Follow up on your promises: Once you decide upon your new visiting schedule or alternative ways to connect, stick to it. It¡¯s important to validate your words with actions. Remember to act in a way that shows your love and respect, even if you can't always be physically present for long durations. An example of what you could say:  "Mom, I've been wanting to talk to you about something. I want you to know how much I love spending time with you, and how much I value our visits. Recently, though, it's been a little difficult for me to manage staying for very long visits due to my work and other commitments. I wanted you to know this so you don't feel like I'm trying to avoid you¨C that's not the case at all. I'm thinking we could maybe start doing some video calls during the week, and I can come for shorter visits when I am able. Would that be okay? This way, we can still spend time together, even if it's not for as long as we're used to. I understand if you're disappointed, and I want you to know that I am here for you, even if I can't always be there physically."

column1: There are many conflicting emotions and tasks that arise when one becomes a caretaker for their parent. Expressing positive emotions to her (i.e. "Mom, I love and care for you, and enjoy our time together. I'm sorry I can't stay long"( may help re-frame your thoughts and have a fresh perspective on the situation. Additionally, Visual cues like pictures and notes can also be helpful for those who suffer from disorders like Alzheimer's and Dementia, as it offers a "Trigger" for memory, helping to ease the doors to communication. Finding support in other family members, or a therapist familiar with elder care issues may be helpful as well.
column2: When dealing with such sensitive issues around elderly parents, it's important to approach the conversation with empathy, compassion, and honesty. Here's how you can address the situation: 1. Choose the Right Time: Make sure she isn't preoccupied or distressed when you bring it up - it will make it easier for her to process what you're saying. 2. Be Gentle, and Use the "Sandwich" Method: Start with something positive (we love spending time together), tell her what you need to (I can't stay for long visits), and then end with something positive (but I'll make sure to visit often). Example: "Mom, I really enjoy our time together, but due to some work commitments, I am unable to stay as long as I wish. However, I promise to visit you often and make our moments meaningful." 3. Explain the Reason: Be frank and explain why you're unable to stay for long visits. If it's about work, personal responsibilities, or health issues, she may understand better. 4. Reassure: Ensure her that you still love her, care for her, and your decision is not due to any negative feelings towards her. 5. Provide Alternatives: You could suggest alternative ways of communicating when you can't be there in person, such as phone calls, video chats, or emails.  6. Listen: If she expresses disappointment or tries to argue, listen to her feelings and understand her perspective. You can also talk to some other family members or a family therapist for assistance.  Remember, the goal is to make her understand your limitations but also to ensure her that she is not neglected or unimportant. Always keep the communication line open and provide emotional support as much as possible.

column1: If the only way the relationship you have with your mother feels "okay" is when she is the only one who makes decisions concerning your life, then this only seems ok.In fact it is not okay for one person to be the authority for another person unless the one for whom this is being done, does not have their own ability to think for themselves.Separating your own wishes and way of handling life matters, from your mother's point of view, may be difficult.First, realize you need to get familiar with feeling at ease with the idea of deciding matters for yourself.You'll need practice until you feel comfortable.Unless, if you've been thinking through decisions you'd like to make and the idea of your mother's anger is the only point which stopped you, then you may almost instantly start living in a liberated way of running your own life.Basically, it is right and fair for you to have the chance to live your life the way you feel is best.  Be prepared that your mother may disagree with you and that her disagreement is not a reason itself to not do what you believe is in your best interest.
column2: That's great to hear! Making your own decisions helps you develop confidence, gain life experience and become more independent. Consider weighing the potential outcomes, asking for advice when you need it, and understanding that it's okay to make mistakes along the way. These are valuable aspects of making decisions for yourself.

column1: ABSOLUTELY.  Having someone who's outside the situation and, even more so, with knowledge and experience in human behavior and relationship dynamics such as a counselor can do wonders in helping us feel less alone in frustrating situations like the one you're currently stuck in with your mother.  A professional can also assist you in finding some assertiveness techniques, communication strategies, and coping skills to help you find your voice and stand your ground in a way that feels most authentic to you.In a healthy parent-child dynamic, there comes a normal developmental shift when, as the child reaches each new stage of maturity and responsibility, the parent backs off to provide a more supportive role instead of directive role.  We call this "redefining relationships." (We also do it with our friendships and colleagues here and there over time as needed). It's absolutely vital. Sounds like your mom may have missed that memo. Like many parents, she may feel your behavior and choices is a direct reflection of her. Or that her role as your mother allows her greater latitude than it should.  Or like many other people in general, that her way is the ONLY way. Regardless, this is YOUR life.  And as far as we know, it's not a dress rehearsal. You certainly don't want to wake up some 50 years from now regretful or resentful. That being said, there are certainly ways to show her love and respect while doing what makes you happy. I would encourage you to Google therapists near you whose bios resonate with you and what you're looking for and start on a the journey towards a new chapter of freedom and hopefully a deeper, more satisfying mother-daughter relationship for both of you.Warmest regards,Tamara Powell, LMHC
column2: That's the spirit! Independent decision-making is a crucial skill in life. Start with small decisions, such as what to eat for breakfast, and gradually work up to bigger ones, such as career and life choices. But remember, it's okay to ask for advice and opinions when you need it. Making your own decisions doesn't mean you have to do it alone.

column1: Hi Lincoln,It can be very difficult for children who have lost a parent to then see their other parent moving forward with anyone, so I understand how this change is even more upsetting to you. And...your father and your friend have clearly established a friendship and fallen in love. Did you see this coming? I hope they didn't hide it from you. If they did, maybe this is the issue? It would be a legitimate one.But in the end, your father, and your friend, are adults who are free to fall in love with whomever they wish and hopefully they can count on the support of people who trust and love them. Could there be blessings here you haven't seen yet? It seems you love this person who is like a sister; could it be a good thing that her place in your life is more permanent?Ask yourself these questions... "What is the worst part of this?" "What do I fear losing?" "What do I fear at all?" "What is the evidence that this will happen?" The answers might surprise you. Your children will follow your lead. If you are supportive of their grandfather, they will follow suit. Hopefully you can grieve the change, know that your mother would likely want both of them to be happy, and embrace the blessings that come with having this woman close to you in a new way. I wish you the best.
column2: Discussing your feelings to your father regarding this situation requires an open, calm and honest communication. Here's a helpful guide: 1. Choose the right time: Talk to your father when he's not busy or irritated. Find a moment when you and he can sit down and talk without distractions. 2. Be straightforward: Communicate your feelings directly, but respectfully. It might have been uncomfortable or unexpected, but it's important to be clear about how you feel. You could say something like, "Dad, I feel a need to talk with you about something that's been bothering me. I feel uncomfortable about your relationship with my best friend." 3. Be calm: Expressing emotions is natural, but getting angry or upset can make the conversation unproductive. Stay as calm as possible and speak in a composed manner. 4. State your reasons: Explain why you're not okay with him dating your best friend. You can state reasons like it creates awkward situations, affects your friendship, or it's inappropriate due to the age difference. 5. Clearly say what you want: Let your father know what you expect. You can say, "I would appreciate it if you would consider not dating my best friend." 6. Be ready to listen: After you've said your piece, give your father an opportunity to share his thoughts. There may be aspects of the situation you hadn't considered, just as there are aspects he probably hasn't considered. Remember to be understanding and compassionate towards him while having this conversation. You may need to give him the time he needs to process and understand your feelings.

column1: How are you measuring whether or not your dad understands your wish?Your dad understanding your wish does not mean he will necessarily follow through with what you want.Based on what you describe about your relationship to the woman in question, your discomfort with the idea of your dad marrying your friend, is reasonable.Have the conversation with your dad that includes your viewpoint, and also ask him for his impression of your feelings.Its even possible he already has considered your feelings and hasn't yet told you.It is also possible that a conversation on the subject, as well as your dad following through with his decision to marry your best friend, may develop in a very positive way.Part of the current uneasiness you feel may be from fear of how a change in circumstances and introducing new relationship dynamics might feel.Given that the person who died was your mom, maybe your emotions are not yet ready seeing your dad with a replacement spouse. Try to see the situation from the point of everyone, including yourself, who is involved in this major change.  Maybe having a family discussion about acceptance and readiness to accept a new partner for your dad, would open new empathy for all of these family members.
column2: Expressing these feelings can be challenging and uncomfortable. Here are some suggestions on how you may approach it: 1. Find the Right Moment: Look for a quiet moment where you both can talk, free from distractions or interruptions. 2. Be Direct: Politely, yet firmly explain your feelings about his relationship with your best friend. Use "I" statements to express your feelings, such as "I feel uncomfortable about your relationship with my best friend."  3. Explain your reasons: Specify why you feel this way. Maybe it's because you think it's inappropriate, or that it could harm your friendship, or that it makes you feel uncomfortable.  4. Be Respectful: Even though it's your father, remember to respect his views as well. Be calm, and listen to his point of view too.  5. Offer Alternatives: Suggest him to date someone more appropriate or who is not directly involved in your life. 6. Honest: Be completely honest whatever are your feelings. Hiding your true emotions could lead to resentment. 7. Seek Outside Help: If the conversation doesn't go well or if your father doesn't understand your point of view, it may be helpful to involve a third party, such as a trusted family member or a counselor. This person can facilitate the conversation and help both of you understand each other more clearly.  Remember, maintain open lines of communication and be prepared for potential outcomes. At least you have shared your feelings, which is the most important aspect.

column1: That's intense. This person moving from a friend of yours to both a friend of yours and, in  a sense, your step mom is a lot. I wonder if you have let your dad know what's going through your mind with this and how it is affecting you. I can imagine that could feel awkward and emotional. Still, getting him to understand might be as simple as letting him know, in your words, how this feels from your view as well as what you wish. It may not change the outcome (he may still marry her), but your thoughts will not go unsaid and opens it up for conversation. Best luck!
column2: Firstly, this must be a complex and difficult situation for you. Here are a few suggestions on how to address this: 1. Set a Time and Place: Choose a calm, neutral setting to have the most constructive conversation possible. Then, ask him to set aside some time for a serious talk. 2. Speak Clearly and Directly: Be honest but respectful. Make sure you clearly express your feelings. 3. Express your Feelings: Start your conversation by stating that you need to talk about something that has been bothering you. Tell him honestly how you feel about him dating your best friend, but make sure not to put him on the defensive. 4. Use "I" Statements: This type of statement is a way of speaking that puts emphasis on the speaker's feelings and thoughts rather than on the recipient's actions. For example, saying "I feel uncomfortable when you date my best friend because it blurs boundaries in my relationships." This takes the blame off your dad and hence, he's less likely to react defensively. 5. Explain your Concerns: Detail why you think it's inappropriate and uncomfortable for you. Also, explain how this affects the relationship between you and your friend. 6. Ask for Empathy: Request that he puts himself in your shoes and imagines how it would feel if he were in your position. 7. Listen and Respond: Allow your dad to speak his mind too. He may have his own reasons or might not even know that this situation is upsetting you. 8. Maintain Respect: Above all, maintain your respect for your dad. This will help keep the conversation productive instead of it turning into an argument.  Check with a psychologist or a guidance counselor for a more guided approach. It might also be helpful to discuss this with your best friend and share your feelings about it.

column1: It is understandable that it's very hard for you to hear daily complaints from your mother regarding the caregiving of your niece. You cannot change your mother's feelings and responsibilities, which could create feelings of frustration and helplessness. It must be equally hard for your mother to assume full responsibility for your niece at a time where your sister cannot take care of her. This type of responsibility usually produces an enormous amount of stress and pressure because your mother and niece would both need to adapt to this new relationship, living situation, and the feeling of being "abandoned." Not knowing the history of your relationship with your mother and how you respond to each other in times of need, it may be difficult to fight the right recommendation on how to deal with this situation. Nonetheless, it is not easy to have to face daily complaints and you may have to set a healthy balance between empathy and boundary setting with your mother and some personal boundaries for yourself. It is likely that your mother's "complaints" may be her desperate cry for help because she does not know how to cope with stress or how to ask for the right kind of support. In this case, you could calmly and respectfully tell her the next time you hear her complain, "This must be very difficult for you because I hear the stress in your voice almost everyday. It's very hard for me to hear you feeling so overwhelmed. I feel helpless in this situation and would like to suggest that it might be helpful for you to seek some professional help and support to deal with such a big matter of importance." When empathy and understanding is communicated, recipients are usually more open because they hear and feel the caring behind it and are more likely to seek additional help.After sharing this message of empathy and encouragement to seek help, the next step is to protect yourself by explaining to your mother where your limits are so that she understands what she can expect from you. This means that you can decide the kind of support or help you are willing to give your mother and/or niece that is within your ability to provide without feeling overwhelmed. This could involve inviting them to dinner occasionally, taking them out to see a movie or inviting your niece over to give your mother respite. You could then say to her if she complains again, "I cannot change the way you feel in this situation and I encourage you to seek professional advice about that but what I could do is .........(explain what you could do to help)."www.PsychologyResource.ca
column2: 1. Set Boundaries: This is the first and most important step. Establish and communicate your limits to them about what topics or behaviors are off-limits.  2. Change the Subject: If they try to bring up a topic that stresses you out, be ready with potential topics to switch to. 3. Limit Interaction: Limit your interactions with those family members, whether that means seeing them less frequently, speaking to them less on the phone, or not responding immediately to their messages. 4. Practice Self-Care: Make sure you are taking care of yourself both physically and mentally. This can help you better cope with the stress members of your family may cause you. 5. Emotional Detachment: Detach yourself emotionally from any drama, arguments, or negative situations. You have control over your own emotional state and you do not have to let their actions or words affect you. 6. Seek Support: Turn to supportive friends, a counselor, or therapist to help you navigate through your feelings. 7. Move Out: If you are living with these family members and the situation is too stressful, consider moving out and living independently if it's possible. 8. Digital Limitation: Limit your social media interaction with these family members. They might be stressing you out there too. 9. Practice Assertiveness: When all else fails, be assertive with your family members. Let them know they are causing you undue stress and ask them to respect your feelings.  Remember, it's okay to put your mental health first, even if it means setting strong boundaries with family members.

column1: Then one day when life between you and mom feels calm, tell your mom that you aren't able to listen to her complaints about your sister.The truth exists whether or not it is acknowledged.   Bu acknowledging what feels real and necessary in your life, you are helping your mom see what she may not like to see and what nevertheless is right in front of her.There is no good reason or good to come of hiding your own truth about not wishing to continue listening to your mom complain.
column2: 1. Set Boundaries: The first and most essential step towards avoiding family members who stress you out is by setting boundaries. Make it clear to them about your 'me space' and when you need your own time to relax or spend alone.  2. Take Time for Yourself: Whenever you feel stressed, give yourself a break. Listen to some soothing music, go out for a walk, or continue any hobby that gives you joy.  3. Communication: If the stress is due to some past issues or misunderstandings, it's sometimes essential to clear the air and communicate with the family member. Explain to them how their behaviour is affecting you.  4. Avoid Conflict: If it's an ongoing disagreement or argument, try to avoid getting involved in conflict as much as possible.  5. Seek Professional Help: If things are going out of control, you may consider seeking help from a counselor or therapist. They can provide you with strategies to cope with stress and help improve your relationship with your family member.  6. Limit Contact: If a family member continues to stress you out despite your attempts, you may consider limiting your contact with them. You don't have to entirely cut them off (unless it's necessary), just limit your interactions and conversations.  7. Choose your Battles: It can be essential to choose your battles wisely. Not every argument or disagreement needs your engagement.  8. Practice Stress Management Techniques: Meditation, deep-breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, and yoga are some of the stress management techniques which can help you stay calm.  Remember, it's essential to take care of your mental health. You are allowed to protect your peace by avoiding stressful family dynamics.

column1: This sounds stressful.You mentioned that you want to learn how to avoid them. I'm not sure whether you want to avoid them overall or if you would like to ask your mom to maybe only talk to you about it for a few minutes about your niece in each conversation that you have.Maybe you can connect your mom with some support. It sounds as if she has lost part of herself and/or is very stressed out and in talking with you about it because she trusts you enough for you to be someone she can speak openly, you are becoming stressed because of things that you cannot directly change. This is the presumptive based on the amount of information that you posted, but it sounds like there is a bit of a circle of stress here.I also wonder who you could talk with when you are stressed.It may be helpful to see a local mental health professional to help redefine some boundaries so you can have the type of relationship with your mother that you want without necessarily feeling stressed out by it every day.
column2: Avoiding stress from family members can be a tough task but there are several strategies you may use: 1. Set Boundaries: Clearly define what topics or behaviors are off-limits, such as discussing controversial issues or criticizing your choices. Let them know if certain things stress you out. 2. Distance Yourself: If possible, limit your time around them or choose to meet them in group settings where their presence will be diluted. 3. Communication: Express your feelings using "I" statements (e.g., "I feel stressed when...¡±) instead of blaming them. This is a non-confrontational way to express your feelings. 4. Always Have an Exit Strategy: Plan ahead when you know you will be in an environment with them. Have a list of reasons ready for why you might need to leave early. 5. Seek Professional Help: If the stress is unbearable, seek advice from psychologists or therapists. They are experienced in dealing with family stress and can provide valuable advice. 6. Practice Self-Care: Regular exercise, a healthy diet, enough sleep, mindfulness, and relaxation techniques can help you manage stress. Remember that everyone has the right to remove themselves from a situation or relationship that is harmful or stressful. Do what is best for your mental and emotional health.

column1: Both you and your mom are in a tough spot.  She has returned to parenting after she thought she had raised her kids, and while I am sure you'd like to be supportive, you recognize that listening to her complaints really does not help her and drains you.  In addition to that, it sounds like Mom's complaining has become "the" conversation she has with you, leaving other, more fulfilling conversations out of your relationship.Think about what you want instead with your mom.  More time with just her?  A chance to offer true help,not just listen to complaints? When you have some idea of what you want, tell her.  You can do this kindly and respectfully, with a concern for both her and your relationship with her.  It might go something like this..."Mom, you really have your hands full.  Sis dumped your grandbaby on you and I bet this isn't how you imagined grandparenting would look.  It's got to be hard and I am not sure how I can be helpful.  Beyond that, I really miss talking to you about other things.  So, Mom, is there something I can do that would be helpful?  If not, let's talk about something else".In addition to that, if your mom is open to other resources, help her find them - she needs some emotional support from a non-family member.Good luck to you both - and to your niece.  It is a hard situation for you all.
column2: 1. Setting boundaries: Make it clear to them what subjects you would rather not discuss, what behaviors make you uncomfortable or stressed out. If they love you, they will respect that. 2. Minimize contact: Try to minimize the time you spend with them or only see them at large family gatherings. 3. Communicate: It's important to let your relatives know how you feel, as some people might not know they're causing harm. Opening up can lead to changes and better relationships. 4. Avoid trigger topics: If you know some topics or activities will cause an argument or stress, try to avoid those situations. 5. Learn stress management techniques: Activities such as yoga, meditation, or deep breathing techniques can help you relax and deal better with stressful situations. 6. Seek support: If it's getting overwhelming, don't hesitate to discuss the situation with a friend, a counselor, or join a support group. 7. Be patient: It takes time to change old habits and dynamics, so don't expect an immediate change. Remember to prioritize your mental health over any obligation you might feel towards your family members. It's important to surround yourself with positive influences.

column1: It is difficult to implement healthy boundaries when the person is a parent or family member. I would encourage you to identify how it makes you feel after talking with your mother. Work on establishing healthy boundaries where you do not feel obligated to engage the complaining daily. Maybe setting a time limit to talk with your mother and practicing how to be assertive and not disrespect or aggressive. Helping your mother understand how you feel using  "I" statements  i.e  ( I feel _____ when you call to talk about my sister). Maybe asking your mom how can you be supportive of her during this time other than listening to her vent. It may also be helpful for your mother to get connected with support groups to help her cope with this life change.
column2: 1. Create Boundaries: Make sure you clearly define your emotional and physical space. Set rules about topics that are off-limits or specific times when you would prefer not to be disturbed. 2. Increase Communication: If you're comfortable doing so, communicate to them about how you feel when you're stressed by their actions. They might not be aware of the impact they have on you. 3. Learn to Say No: It's perfectly okay to decline invitations or requests from family members that stress you out.  4. Avoid Triggers: If there are certain topics or situations that usually lead to stress, try to avoid them as much as possible. 5. Seek Support: Speak to a counselor, psychologist, or support groups - they can provide tools and advice on handling the stress. 6. Practice Self-Care: Prioritize your mental health. Activities like meditation, exercise, or just taking "me time" can help reduce the stress. 7. Plan for Shorter Visits: If spending a lot of time with certain family members stresses you out, try to plan shorter visits instead. 8. Limit Contact: If necessary, you can limit the amount of contact you have with that person. This could mean reducing the number of texts, calls, or in-person visits.     9. Get Others Involved: If it's too much for you to handle on your own, involve other family members. They might be able to help reduce the stress. 10. Seek Professional Help: If these strategies aren¡¯t enough, you may want to seek professional help. Therapists can provide strategies tailored specifically to your situation.  Remember it's OK to prioritize your own well-being even if it means distancing yourself from certain family members at times.

column1: Buy the book "Boundaries: Where You End and I Begin." Read it. Apply it.Seriously, I'm not joking. You're not wrong to "not want to hear it anymore" but if you don't maintain healthy boundaries, you will allow your family to make you feel guilty for "not wanting to hear it anymore". That's not fair to you.Give a copy to your mom, too. No, I didn't write the book nor do I have any affiliation with it - I simply recommend it because it's a wonderful book and it helped me out a lot. I recommend it to a lot of people. It should be required reading!
column2: 1. Set Boundaries: Make sure your family members understand when you have your own personal space and time.  2. Minimize Physical Interaction: Limit your physical contact with them. Instead visit or call them in intervals. 3. Be Direct: Let them know how they make you feel. This should be done delicately, but firmly. 4. Seek Therapy or Counseling: A counselor or therapist can provide you tools to cope better with the stressful family members. 5. Distraction Tactics: Engage yourself with other activities or hobbies to take your mind off stressful people. 6. Focus on Stress Management: Learn stress management techniques, like meditation, exercise, deep breathing, and yoga. 7. Stand up for yourself: Don't allow anyone, even family, to disrespect or manipulate you.  8. Be Less Reactive: Try to work on having a detached, neutral response in order to avoid fueling the stress. 9. Evaluate: If it becomes too toxic, you may need to consider minimizing contact or cutting ties completely in extreme cases.  Remember, it is important to ensure your own well-being first.

column1: This sounds like a possible boundary issue. Boundaries are important in relationships. They are invisible lines that we will or will not cross. It is up to us to create and hold them. We have the ability to rethink them and change them as needed. It sounds like you have thought it through and would like to makes changes in the relationship between your mother and you. In the main question, you want to avoid the family member, however in the following comment, it sounds like you may just want the avoid that conversation, not so much your mother. Once we review the issue and decide what we need (create the boundary), I suggest opening talking with the person when everyone is calm (not in the middle of a stressful moment when we often are unable to focus and hear the other person). Always understanding that we had time to think about this issue and the other person has not (catching them off guard). State clearly your need. Such as "I am not comfortable with hearing about my sister. It stresses me out. I would appreciate it if you would not bring it up anymore. If you do, I will not respond and I will change the subject " It is important to use "I" statements. I feel" this way". I will "do this". We only have power over our actions. Also when we use "you " comments, the other person can become defensive and unable to hear what we are saying. Once we let ourselves know what we need, then let the other people know our new boundary, then it is up to us to follow through. We will make mistakes. Not follow through every time with our boundary. That is okay. Start again. It gets easier with practice. It is also appropriate to reconsider and change your boundary as needed. Just let the others know when you need to change it. Remember, they can not read our minds. I wish you much strength and hope the best for you and your family.www.parishhealthandwellness.com
column2: Avoiding family members who stress you out can feel challenging, especially without causing more family drama. Here are some strategies: 1. Set Boundaries: Clear boundaries are essential in every relationship, including those with family members. If certain topics always cause stress, try to avoid them. If they force these unwanted conversations, politely express your discomfort. 2. Limit Connection: If your family constantly stresses you out, reduce the amount of time you spend with them, at least temporarily. Limit your phone calls, text messages, and visits. 3. Get Togethers: Consider spending time with your family only during special family gatherings, maintaining a low profile and try to avoid engaging in stressful conversations. 4. Make Your Visit Short: If you have to meet, make sure your visits are short. This will decrease the possibility of encountering a situation that stresses you out. 5. Spend Time with Supporters: In a group gathering, spend time with those who lift your spirits and avoid those who sap your energy or put you down. 6. Seek Professional Help: A counselor can provide you with tools and techniques to deal with stress and have healthier interactions with family members.  7. Practice Self-Care: This is a way to safeguard your mental health. Exercise, meditation, and getting a good amount of sleep are all ways to reduce stress. 8. Be Assertive: Stand up for yourself in a calm and positive way. Express your feelings, needs, and ideas to your family members without reducing their significance. Remember, it's okay to have space from anyone who causes you constant stress, even if they're family.

column1: It can really be difficult to listen to someone constantly complain and it can take a lot of emotional energy to be the listening ear to someone struggling. Perhaps having a conversation with your mother about making the communication more productive in nature. It seems like your mother is obviously having some difficulties and she is stuck, therefore making you stuck listening to complaints on repeat. Explain to her the impact it has on you to listen to the complaining and not working towards changing things or coming to a level of acceptance or even making the conversation mutual, such as her being there for you. This may or may not help her to come around, but at least it can open up the conversation and be an effort towards initiating a change.
column2: 1. Limit your interactions: Minimize the time spent in their presence as much as possible. If it is a family gathering, engage yourself in different activities. 2. Set boundaries: Make clear what topics or behaviors are not acceptable to discuss or tolerate. Be assertive, expressing your feelings and needs clearly and directly. 3. Practice self-care: Engage in activities that help you relax, such as yoga, meditation, exercise, etc., to handle the stress better. 4. Seek Support: Talk to someone you trust about your experiences. This could be a trusted friend, counselor, or another family member. 5. Learn to say 'No': Avoid situations that make you uncomfortable or stressed. You have the right to protect yourself from unhealthy interactions. 6. If possible, take breaks: If the situation allows it, you could take breaks from seeing them. This can help to reduce the amount of stress you feel. 7. Seek professional help: If your family member's behavior is becoming too much for you to handle, do not hesitate to seek help from a mental health professional. Please remember, each family and situation is different. It may take some time to find the approach that works best.

column1: These are common challenges that involve setting healthy boundaries with family, as well as friends and co-workers.  Therapy can help you to define, establish and enforce boundaries between self and others by being assertive.  This involves determining what things make you uncomfortable and how to communicate that with assertive, not passive, not aggressive, actions and language.
column2: 1. Establish Boundaries: Clearly communicate your needs and expectations to your family members. Let them know if you are unwilling or unable to participate in certain conversations or activities that cause you stress. 2. Prioritize Your Mental Health: This might mean limiting your time with certain family members, or even distancing yourself for a period of time. This is not about punishing them, but about ensuring your own well-being. 3. Find Support: Confide in a friend, counselor or support group about your situation. They can provide a listening ear, valuable advice and encouragement. 4. Practice Self-Care: Taking care of your physical, mental and emotional health will give you the resilience to handle family stress. This could mean getting regular exercise, proper nutrition, enough sleep, and practicing stress-reducing activities like meditation or yoga. 5. Plan Your Interactions: If avoiding certain family members entirely is not possible, plan your interactions with them. Limit the duration or frequency of your visits, avoid sensitive topics and have an exit strategy ready in case the conversation becomes too overwhelming. 6. Seek Professional Help: If the stress caused by your family members is significantly affecting your life, seek the help of a mental health professional. A therapist can provide you with strategies and tools to effectively manage and cope with stress related to family issues.  7. Keep Things in Perspective: Understand that everyone has their own issues and everyone is dealing with something. Try your best to empathize and not let their negativity affect you.

column1: It is important to set boundaries with those that stress you out. I encourage people to validate the other persons feelings by saying "I am sorry you are going through this." Then, to set the boundary bye stating what you need from them or what you are trying to do with your life to destress and that you can't be a listening ear right now. This will need to be a repeated conversation, but over time you will notice less stress.
column2: 1. Be Honest: Communicate to your family members about how they are making you feel. But be respectful in the way you convey your feelings so that they understand and respect your emotions. 2. Set Boundaries: This is essential to avoid any form of conflict. Set a limit of when and how family members can interact with you. 3. Limit your Interaction: It may not be possible to completely avoid your family members. But reducing the amount of time you spend with them can help. You can make yourself less available to them. 4. Engage in Activities: Do something that you enjoy, which can keep you away from your family members. This can be a hobby, a side job, or volunteering. 5. Seek Therapy: Discussing your feelings and emotions with a professional can help you handle the stress that your family members are causing. A therapist can give you strategies to cope with the situation. 6. Stay Healthy: Engage in physical activities, meditate, eat healthily, and get adequate sleep. These can help you manage stress. 7. Plan your Escape: if your family members are consistently causing stress and making you feel uncomfortable, you may have to consider moving out to your own place if you have not done so already. 8. Learn to Say No: Sometimes, all it takes to avoid unnecessary stress is the ability to say "no" to certain requests or demands from family members. Remember, it is important to maintain a level of respect and care for your family members. However, prioritizing your mental health is essential too.

column1: Sounds like it is time to set some boundaries with your mom.  You can do this by letting her know that you understand how she is feeling and you understand that she is under a tremendous amount of stress.  Validate her feelings and words.  After you do that, tell her how hearing about it daily is affecting you let.  Let her know that it is hard for you to hear how stressed she is, how hard it is you to have these daily calls.  Let her know that you are feeling stressed about her own well being.  You can then suggest that she find a therapist to speak to about how she is feeling and what she is going through.  I suggest writing out what you want to say, before you say it.  Practice saying it a few times so that it flows naturally when you do have the conversation with her.Also, when you start setting boundaries with people they don't usually like it.  They give some sort of push back either by expressing disappointment or anger towards you.  This has nothing to do with you.  This is them having a hard time hearing and accepting the boundary you are setting.  The other thing people tend to do when you set a boundary is to test it.  In this situation it might look like your mom calling you the next day as if the two of you never had the conversation.  In this situation it falls on you to set the boundary again, by having the same conversation again with her.  Over time she will accept the boundary and she will be OK with it.
column2: Dealing with family members who stress you out can be challenging. Here are some suggestions to help manage those interactions: 1. Limit your exposure: Limit the amount of time you spend with family members who stress you out. You don¡¯t have to avoid family functions entirely; just reduce your exposure. 2. Establish boundaries: Let the stressful family members know what topics or behaviors are off-limits to you. Be firm in enforcing these boundaries. 3. Use indirect communication: If face-to-face contact is too stressful with specific family members, opt for phone calls, emails, or text messages as means of communication. 4. Get support: Seek out other family members or friends who understand your circumstances, or consider joining a support group. 5. Stress management techniques: Prior to your interactions, use techniques like deep breathing, meditation or going for a walk to prepare yourself and stay calm. 6. Seek professional help: If you're unable to cope, it might be helpful to speak to a counselor or therapist who can provide you with strategies and techniques to deal with family stress. 7. Choose your battles: Sometimes it¡¯s okay to let things go. Engaging in every argument or confrontation might just lead to more stress. 8. Distractions: Use activities to keep yourself occupied and avoid getting entangled in lengthy, stressful conversations. 9. Standing up for yourself: Politely but assertively stand up for yourself if someone crosses your boundaries. 10. Practice self-care: Make time for yourself and do things that relax you and help you maintain a clear, positive mindset.  Remember, it¡¯s okay to prioritize your mental health. If a family member repeatedly causes you stress or anxiety, you have a right to distance yourself.

column1: This sounds very stressful.  Setting boundaries is important to maintaining a peace of mind.  If you have not communicated your feelings to your family member, that would be a good first step.  Communicate with the intent of simply expressing your feelings and your expectations going forward.  Do not blame or shame because that will blur your intent.  Going forward, consistently stick to your new boundaries.  That may mean not picking up your phone for each call.  Soon enough the message will be clear.  Good luck.
column2: Managing stress from family members can be challenging because you usually can't avoid them as easily as you can avoid others who stress you out. Here are some strategies to help you: 1. Establish Boundaries: Establish your boundaries and communicate them clearly. Limit the topics that cause stress or arguments.  2. Limit Contacts: Reduce the frequency and duration of your interactions with them.  3. Utilize ¡°I¡± Statements: When communicating about problematic behaviors, use ¡°I¡± statements to express how their actions affect you, without blaming or criticizing them directly.  4. Change the Setting: Try meeting in neutral, public places where everyone is more likely to be on their best behavior. 5. Practice Self-Care: Make sure you're taking care of yourself physically and emotionally. This includes getting regular exercise, eating healthy meals, and getting plenty of sleep. 6. Seek Support: Talk to others who understand your situation, such as friends, or a counselor. You might also consider family therapy to address systemic issues causing the stress. 7. Learn Stress Management Techniques: This can include physical activities such as yoga or walking, or mental techniques like meditation or mindfulness. Remember, it's okay to take time for yourself and prioritize your mental health.

column1: I just want to understand before I answer. Who exactly is complaining?
column2: 1. Prioritize Alone Time: Set aside some time for yourself each day where you can relax and unwind without any interruptions.  2. Set Boundaries: Make sure that your family members know and respect your personal space and time.  3. Avoid Trigger Topics: If certain topics lead to arguments or stress, try to steer clear of those when conversing with your family members.  4. Learn Stress Management Techniques: This can help you deal with stress in a healthier way. Techniques may include deep breathing exercises, yoga, or other forms of physical exercise. 5. Change Communication Style: Instead of responding to provocations, try to express your perspective calmly and reasonably. 6. Seek Professional Support: If stress is significantly impacting your life, consider seeking support from a counselor or therapist. 7. Limit Visits: If the situation allows it, try to limit your interactions with family members that stress you out. 8. Use Supportive Resources: Use resources like friends, online support groups, books on the topic, etc. 9. Try Mediation: In some situations, a neutral third party can help to mediate between yourself and your family members. 10. Develop a hobby or activity: This distracts your mind and gives you a break from stressful situations. Remember, everyone's situation is unique and there is no one-size-fits-all solution. Take time to identify what works best for you, and do not hesitate to ask for help when you need it.

column1: Hello, and thank you for your question. I am very sorry that this was your experience with your family. I truly wish I could give you some things to say to them that would change their reaction, but unfortunately I can't do that. Their acceptance of you is a journey, just like coming out is a journey for you. Sometimes families initially respond this way, but after time they become more accepting and even supportive. Unfortunately, there is no way to know for sure if that will happen. So, here are a few things I would suggest:Surround yourself with people and things that remind you that you really are okay as you are. That won't take the place of your family's acceptance, and I won't even pretend that it would, but it may help during those days when it hurts the most. And that is really important. Patience is not something that many of us are really good at, but this type of situation sometimes forces you to have some. When families first learn something like this, they may go through a period of shock. And then sometimes even grieving. They may even be worried if they are of a particular religion where being bisexual is forbidden. These things can take time for them to reconcile, so it may just take some patience. If it is safe for you, try to talk to them, but if it becomes painful or hurtful then you have the right to walk away. I do recommend setting up some personal boundaries for yourself, and perhaps learn some assertiveness skills if you feel you struggle with them. The reason I feel that this is important is that people sometimes take a lot of abuse from family members and friends in times like you're describing. They may want to be accepted so much that they put themselves in hurtful positions over and over again hoping that their families will come around. They may, or they may not. And if they don't, you deserve to live a life free of abuse and to feel confident and assured of who you are. To be surrounded by folks who remind you of that. If you start seeing this pattern and you are struggling, chatting with counselor may be a great idea. I am bias probably, but I think chatting with a counselor is ALWAYS a good idea. :) Hope this helps. Be well. Be you. Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC
column2: I'm sorry that you're going through this difficult time. Here are some tips to help you address this situation: 1. Education: Family members might not accept you due to lack of knowledge about bisexuality. Help them understand that being bisexual isn't a choice and that it is simply part of who you are. Provide them with reading materials and encourage them to join support groups or therapy sessions where they can learn more about bisexuality. 2. Open dialogue: It¡¯s important to be open and honest about your feelings and to create an environment where your family members can voice their concerns, questions, and feelings too. Always keep communication lines open and non-defensive. 3. Patience: Changing ingrained beliefs or attitudes can take time. Stay patient and strong, giving your family time to process and adjust to this new information. Sometimes, they may just need time to absorb what you've told them. 4. Seek Support: It's important to have a support structure to lean onto. Friends, support groups, or LGBTQ organizations can be an excellent resource for you.  5. Get professional help: If you're dealing with a particularly difficult situation, it can be helpful to engage the services of a therapist or counselor experienced in LGBT issues. 6. Assert yourself: If your family remains unaccepting, it may be necessary to assert your identity and establish boundaries for your personal well-being. Their resistance does not negate your identity. Always remember, you are not alone and there are many resources and communities available to support you. This is a very personal journey, and there's no one-size-fits-all solution, but hopefully, you find these tips helpful.

column1: I am sorry to read that this happened to you. If your family is not supportive of you, this can be a huge challenge. Are you dependent on them in some way (financially, etc.)? This could affect choices you make at this point. Make sure you connect with a supportive community or people and organizations that are afforming of you and your identity. If you are unable to receive support from your family, you can lean on them if necessary. If you feel your family needs more information you can always refer them to appropriate websites and organizations that can help them to understand that this is natural and normal and learn the negative effects of non-affirming people in the life of LGBTQ+ individuals.
column2: Handling a situation where your family isn't accepting your sexuality can be challenging. Here are a few steps you might consider: 1. Educate Them: Many people might not be accepting due to lack of understanding or exposure. Share some information about bisexuality or even introduce them to literature or media which features positive bisexual representation.  2. Be Patient: Changing attitudes and views might take time. Be persistent but also patient with your family. 3. Reassuring Love: Ensure your family knows that your sexuality does not change your love or respect for them. 4. Seek Support Outside: Build a network of friends or communities who understand and support you, to help strengthen your confidence and self-esteem. 5. Communicate: Regular, open, and effective dialogue about your feelings and experiences can slowly improve understanding and acceptance over time. 6.
