This does not mean that you have to identify as "transgender," but researching that term may help you to find both national and local resources.As far as telling your dad, if that is particularly concerning for you, I suggest either talking through the details with a local therapist or considering if you have a trusted friend or family member (one who will respect your privacy with regard to who you would like to know about what you are experiencing at this time) so that you can talk with some people to have support. This may help with two things: allowing you to find some support for yourself as you work through the changes that you are going through now and also possibly talking with someone who knows your dad and may be able to talk with you regarding how or when to tell him.One thing that I tell anyone who wants to discuss something that is very important to them is to ask the person they want to talk to whether this is a good time for an important conversation. That way, you have greater chances of having the person's attention and/or not needing to end the conversation quickly. Also, please remember that you know yourself best, as each of us does.
column2: Coming out as transgender to your parents or loved ones can be a difficult and emotionally charged process. However, it is an important step towards living as your authentic self. Here are a suggestions on how to approach your dad: 1. Plan Your Conversation: Think about what you want to say beforehand. It can help to write your feelings down on paper to help organize your thoughts and concerns. 2. Choose The Right Time and Place: Find a quiet, comfortable place where you won't be disturbed. Make sure it's a time for a calm conversation, not rushed or anxious. 3. Be Honest and Direct: Explain that you've been going through a deep personal struggle and have come to the realization that you identify as a male. You can tell him that you've been questioning your gender for a while and after a lot of introspection, you're sure about it. 4. Explain What it Means: Describe what being a transgender male means to you. Remember that for people unfamiliar with the topic, it might be hard to understand that gender identity and sexual orientation are different things. 5. Talk About Binding: Explain why you want to start binding. Describe the feelings of dysphoria that you're experiencing and how binding can help align your physical appearance with your gender identity. 6. Provide Resources: Give him resources that he can read or watch to better understand what being transgender means. You could provide him with articles, books or videos related to the topic. 7. Be Ready for Questions: He might have a lot of questions. Some of them may seem intrusive or inappropriate, but remember that he's trying to understand too.  8. Be Prepared for Different Reactions: Some parents may understand and be supportive right away, but others might need time to process this new information. It's natural if he feels shocked, scared, or confused at first. 9. Be Patient: Understand this might be new to him and can take time for him to process, especially if he doesn't know much about transgender issues. 10. Suggest Family Therapy: If your father has difficulty coming to terms with your decision, suggest family therapy. A therapist who specializes in transgender issues could help facilitate a better understanding between you and him.

column1: Hello, and thank you for your question. This is certainly a tough spot. I have a few thoughts and perhaps some colleagues will add some things. You may want to spend a few minutes calling to mind any conversations that you have had with your father about transgender issues, or if you have ever heard him talk about it. That may give you a small clue about how well he may accept this news from you. For example, if he has been watching the news lately, transgender rights is something that is being talked about a lot. Has he had an opinion? This won't tell you for sure if he would be okay with learning you are transgender, but at least you would know if there is hostility toward transgender people. To tell you the truth, the best way to tell your dad is whatever way feels right to you. There is no right or wrong way, best or worst. If you want to tell him when you are by yourself with him? That's perfect. Want to have a friend with you for support? Equally perfect. Whatever thing you need to do. And, of course, there is always the option of not telling him anything until you are comfortable doing so. Unfortunately, the response from your dad can't be predicted. Some parents are totally cool.... others not so much. This is one reason why having someone with your for support is sometimes a good idea. If things get heated, you have someone in your corner. There are therapists who specialize in affirmative therapy, and they may be very helpful to you in working out how you want to tell him. You can also Google some stories about how others came out.I refer many people to the www.letsqueerthingsup.com blog. It is a popular blog written by a trans man that I know. He writes on many topics related to trans issues. Hope some of these suggestions help. Be well... be you.. and good luck!Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC
column2: Coming out to parents can be a challenging and emotional process, so prepare yourself both mentally and emotionally. Here's a guideline on how to navigate that conversation: 1. Pick a Good Time: Choose an appropriate time where you both can talk without any interruptions. Consider doing it face-to-face, or if you feel uncomfortable, you can do it in a written form; a letter, email, etc. 2. Be Direct and Honest: After brief introductions and ensuring the atmosphere is right, be direct, clear, and honest. Start by explaining what it means to be transgender. You can say something like, "Dad, I need to share something important with you. I've been doing a lot of self-discovery and I've come to understand that I identify as male, despite being born female." 3. Explain Your Feelings: Try to make him understand how you feel. Be clear about your gender dysphoria (if you have it), how long you've felt this way, how these feelings affect you, etc.  4. Talk about Binding: After discussing your identity, move on to the topic of binding. Explain what it is and why it's important for you. You can say, "For me to express myself authentically and feel comfortable in my body, I wish to start binding my chest." Make sure to share that you're aware of the safety measures involved. 5. Provide Resources: Give him some resources (books, websites, articles, etc.) to learn more about what it means to be transgender and the binding process. This step can be very helpful, especially if he's not informed about trans issues. 6. Be Ready For Different Reactions: There is no sure way to predict how he will react. He might react positively, negatively, or need time to process the information. Be patient and remember it's also a huge piece of information for him to digest. It may take time for him to cope with or understand fully. 7. Offer a Conversation: Allow him to ask questions and provide clear answers. Open communication can help both of you to understand each other better. Make sure to reassure him that you're still the same person he knows and loves. Remember, you know your dad better than us. If you think that a different approach might work better based on his personality, go with that. And remember: safety first.

column1: Have you ever tried talking with her about this when she's not angry? While I hear you saying that it feels like she doesn't love you, there could be a lot of other pieces to this. Have you ever told her about how much she means to you (when she's not angry)?
column2: I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way, but I'm unable to provide the help that you need. It's really important to talk with someone who can, though, such as a mental health professional or a trusted person in your life.

column1: It's hard to tell from the way you described it. Do you think he would be open to an honest discussion? It could be that his comments about your outfit are designed to make you feel good or to help them show how much he cares about you as his stepdaughter. As far as scanning you from head to toe, I can think of reasons that parents might do that. I also think that talking about it is probably very important so you really know what his intentions are. That way, it removes the guesswork and you have the opportunity to know what he is thinking and feeling and he can also know what your reactions are.
column2: As, I don't have personal insights or specific information about your relationship with your stepdad. However, it's important to know that the "normal" in any relationship may vary for everyone. Generally, it implies mutual respect, understanding, safety and healthy boundaries. If you are worried about your relationship, it's okay to seek help from a trusted friend, family member or professional.

column1: You could be protective because of things that happened in your past or in the past of the people that you are protecting. A lot of us have natural instincts that we do not want other people to be in pain. For other people, conflict is just hard to watch and/or listen to.As for having a tough time trusting them, that could also relate to past events between you and these other people or it could relate to the conflict that you mentioned. It can be difficult to trust someone deeply when you don't know when the next big fight or argument is going to start.The next time you step in for someone, consider asking yourself what is making you do that? What are you feeling in the moment?
column2: This could be due to a variety of factors, including: 1. Survival Instincts: At the most basic level, we have an instinct to protect those we love and care about. This could be seen as a survivor instinct trait, where in the past, protecting your family and friends meant the survival of your genetic line. 2. Empathy: Empathy is the ability to understand and share the feelings of others. When you feel empathy toward your friends and family, it's natural to feel protective toward them.  3. Past Experiences: If you have experienced a situation where your friends or family were hurt or threatened, this could lead to you being more protective of them in order to prevent similar situations from happening in the future. 4. Love and Affection: The love and affection that you feel towards your friends and family could lead you to be protective of them. Love can often manifest as the desire to protect and nurture.  5. Responsibility: As a friend or family member, you might feel a sense of responsibility to ensure the safety and well-being of your loved ones.     Remember that being protective is a good thing, as long as it is in reasonable limits and does not infringe on the independence or personal growth of the person being protected.

column1: Breaking the patterns of relating to family members, is difficult work.In the situation you describe, both you and the family members who ask for your intervention, will be affected by any change you decide to make in the way all of you handle family disagreements.Always, it is best for any two people who have a disagreement, to talk directly with each other.   A third person distracts from the content and reasons for disagreeing.Maybe knowing that by pulling yourself away from mediating family arguments, you will in the long term be doing good for your family, helps you do the actual work of separating yourself from their arguments.Definitely, the fact that you're writing about the problem, shows you feel like doing something which feels better than how you feel currently.It is very healthy for you to listen to your gut intuition telling you to pull out of the mediator role you are in currently.You may feel guilty, your family members will most likely do everything possible to persuade, convince,  and push you back into their arguments.This doesn't make them right in what they're doing, it only makes your job harder of trying to let them have their fights on their own.
column2: Feeling protective of your friends and family is quite normal and often stems from a combination of love, care, and instinct. It's often believed to be associated with survival instincts, dating back to when humans needed to protect their 'tribe' from external threats. In today's social context, caring for the well-being of those we are closest to strengthens our bond with them and increases our sense of purpose and satisfaction in relationships.

column1: It sounds like you are hating some of the things that your mom does rather than hating her.Something you may be able to do is call the area agency on aging for the county where you live and ask for information about having other people help to care for your mom. I don't know how old your mom is, but if she is younger, they would probably have resources to other ways that you could have help. If you are both open to the possibility of someone else helping out, this may help with some of the difficulties between you if you are not spending quite as much time together. Do you think your mom is able to actually recognize how what she does and says affects you?From whom do you have support during all of this?
column2: It's okay to have negative feelings and disagreements with family members, including your mom. It's important to remember that everyone, including parents, are human and make mistakes. It's not uncommon for teenagers or young adults to have difficult times with parents due to different viewpoints or expectations. However, sustained feelings of hatred might point to deeper issues. If you feel your emotions are affecting your well-being or the relationship is abusive, it's beneficial to seek help from a trusted adult or professional therapist.

column1: I don't know how old you are, but depending on that, you may be able to talk with them about spending some time in both places. Even parents who live in different states can do that sometimes. It's not as frequent as spending one week at one house and the next week and the other, but I know that it happens.If you can talk with both of your parents about how you would like to live in both places, maybe you can all work out some kind of agreement.
column2: Deciding which parents' house to live at can be challenging, especially if both are eager to have you. However, the choice largely depends on several factors. Here's how to navigate this choice: 1. Comfort and Compatibility: Assess where you feel the most comfortable. Which parent do you communicate and get along with better? Where do you feel more at peace? 2. Location: Consider the location of each parent's house. This includes the proximity to your school or workplace, access to public transportation, and even social amenities.  3. Living Conditions: Consider the living conditions of both homes. This includes the actual physical condition and size of the home, whether you have your own room, the cleanliness and organization of the house, etc. 4. Rules and Expectations: Each parent might have different rules and expectations. Think about which suits your lifestyle and values best. 5. Siblings or Step-siblings: If you have siblings or step-siblings who will also be living in the house, consider your relationship with them and how it might affect your day-to-day happiness. 6. Stability: Which home offers you more stability? This can be in terms of financial, emotional, or living situation stability. 7. Opportunities for Growth: Which environment offers more opportunities for personal and academic growth? 8. Your Gut Feeling: Sometimes, despite all of the logical considerations, your gut feeling might be the strongest indicator of where you should stay.  Remember this is about your comfort and wellbeing. It's okay to have a preference. Try to talk to your parents openly about this as well. If you're too young to make the decision independently, or if there are legal implications involved, you'll need to involve an adult or legal adviser.

column1: It seems like you are going trough stages of grief, since the inability to see your father causes you similar feelings as if you had lost him.  Perhaps you could send him letters expressing your feelings and hopes.  But do understand that if he is under the influence of drugs he might not be able to empathize with your feelings or react in the way that he would have done so in the past.  As the issue evolves find a therapist or counselor to help you work on letting go of that anger and stress, which may affect you negatively.  Find forgiveness so you can have a relationship with him in the future. ?Qu¨¦ puedo hacer con mi padre usuario de drogas?Mi papa est¨¢ usando drogas muy malas, y no estoy autorizada a verlo por lo que me puede hacer a m¨ª y a mis hermanos.  Esto afecta mi vida tremendamente.  Me causa coraje  estr¨¦s.Parece que estas pasando por estados de luto, ya que el no poder ver a tu padre causa sentimientos similares a cuando hay una perdida.  Tal vez puedes escribirle cartas expresando tus sentimientos y esperanzas.  Pero comprende que si el est¨¢ bajo la influencia de drogas puede que no sienta empat¨ªa o te responda como lo sol¨ªa hacer.  Mientras el problema se resuelve busca un consejero o terapeuta que te ayude a trabajar en resolver los sentimientos de coraje y estr¨¦s, trabaja tambi¨¦n en perdonarlo para que puedas tener una relaci¨®n con ¨¦l en el futuro.
column2: I'm sorry to hear that you're dealing with this challenging situation. Here are some steps you might consider: 1. Educate Yourself: Learn about the specific substance(s) your father is using. Understand the risks, short and long-term effects, withdrawal symptoms, and treatment options. This knowledge can be a tool when discussing the issue with him. 2. Seek Professional Advice: You can reach out to professionals like psychologists, counselors, social workers, or a local substance abuse hotline who can guide you on how to handle the situation. The Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) has a national helpline that is available 24/7: 1-800-662-HELP (4357).  3. Talk to Him: When you feel ready and safe, talk to your father about your concerns. Express your feelings without blaming or accusing. Use "I" statements like "I feel worried when..." instead of blaming him. 4. Don't Enable: Don't protect your dad from the consequences of his drug use. It can reinforce his denial about the problem. 5. Protect Yourself: This situation can be emotionally draining. Make sure you care for yourself physically, emotionally, and mentally. Seek out support groups, counseling, or therapy to help manage your stress and emotions. 6. Plan an Intervention: If your father can't acknowledge his problem or refuses help, you might consider planning an intervention with the help of a professional. Remember though, every situation is unique and handling it should be based on your specific circumstances. You should always ensure your safety and consult professionals before making any decisions. In legal perspective, if you are a minor and your safety is at risk, please contact Child Protective Services or a trusted adult immediately.

column1: Focus more on your own life and less on the very heavy descriptors you wrote to describe your mom.All the words you wrote represent psychological conditions which are either lifelong or take a lot of motivation and effort to change.Since the only person who can change how your mom handles her life, is your mom, and you are the only one who can do the same for yourself, devote more energy and time to living your own life fully, despite the emotions you feel regarding her.
column2: Dealing with a narcissistic, codependent and ill mother is challenging and emotionally draining. Here are steps you can take to free yourself: 1. Recognize the Problem: The first step to solving a problem is realizing there is one. It may feel hard to accept, but your mother's behavior is not your fault and it's okay to accept that she has a personality disorder. 2. Seek Professional Help: Therapists, support groups, and counselors are available to help you cope with the emotional burden and provide you with strategies to manage your situation. 3. Set Boundaries: This is crucial. Narcissists often fail to recognize the personal boundaries of others. Establish clear boundaries and as far as possible, stick to them.  4. Limit Contact: Depending upon the severity of your relationship and your personal emotional well-being, you may want to consider limiting or even completely cutting off contact. 5. Practice Self-Care: It's very important to take care of your physical and emotional health. Regular exercise, healthy eating, having a good night's rest, and taking time for activities that you enjoy can help maintain your wellbeing. 6. Build a Support Network: Find friends or loved ones who understand what you are going through and will provide emotional support. 7. Work on Healing: Once you've created some space from your mother, take the time to heal. This could involve therapy, meditation, yoga, or anything else that brings you peace and helps you regain control. Please remember there is no "one size fits all" solution, every person and situation is unique. Seek professional advice tailored to your specific situation and needs.

column1: How can I get my mother to listen to me without her freaking out?Communication with our loved ones can be tricky, but it is the key to maintaining a healthy and functional relationship with them. At times, it seems difficult to communicate with our family because many feelings and ¡°undercover¡± messages are attached. Especially with our mothers, who often provide advice and feel responsible for us, it may feel like they are making everything about themselves as they express their worries and concerns.So what to do? First will be important to practice active listening skills, to ensure that you are receiving and understanding the message, without filtering it trough your own emotions or preconceptions of the person who speaks.  Second, learn and practice assertive communication skills.  Those will help you to communicate a message clearly and in pieces.  It also emphasizes using I-statements to express how you feel at times when emotions become affected by the interaction.  Third, you should practice, by writing your I-statement or role playing with your counselor.  The trick with communication skills is that we need to practice them as often as possible until you to master them.  You can also contact a family therapist to improve those skills if it becomes challenging, or contact a mediator if more issues arise.?C¨®mo puedo lograr que mi mam¨¢ me escuche sin alarmarse tanto?La comunicaci¨®n con nuestros seres queridos puede ser dificultosa, pero es la clave para mantener relaciones saludables y funcionales con ellos.  A veces, nos parece aun m¨¢s dif¨ªcil comunicarnos con nuestra familia, porque hay muchos sentimientos y mensajes envueltos en la comunicaci¨®n.  Especialmente nuestras  madres,  pueden hacer parecer que est¨¢n convirtiendo el asunto en algo personal, cuando se sienten preocupadas y responsables por nosotros y nuestras acciones.?Y qu¨¦ hacemos?  Primero debemos aprender a escuchar activamente, para asegurarnos de que comprendemos el mensaje, y que no lo estemos filtrando a trav¨¦s de nuestras emociones e ideas de la otra persona. Segundo, aprende y practica comunicaci¨®n asertiva.  Esto te ayudara a comunicar un mensaje claramente y en pedazos.  Tambi¨¦n te ayudar a aprender expresiones del Yo, para identificar sentimientos afectados durante la interacci¨®n.  Tercero, es importante que practiques estas destrezas, ya sea escribiendo o con tu consejero.  El secreto est¨¢ en practicar las t¨¦cnicas de comunicaci¨®n cuantas veces sea posible, hasta que las uses espont¨¢neamente.  Si tienes dificultad aprendiendo estas t¨¦cnicas, o el conflicto con tu mama es uno muy dif¨ªcil de resolver, puedes contactar un consejero o mediador familiar para que te asista.
column2: Communication is key to any relationship, and sometimes it can be tough, especially when dealing with parents. If you want your mother to listen to you without freaking out, here's what you could try: 1. Choose the right time: Make sure it's a time where she is calm and will be able to listen attentively. Avoid discussions when she is preoccupied or stressed. 2. Be respectful: Try to explain your views politely and respectfully. Avoid using a tone that she might perceive as disrespectful or confrontational. 3. Be clear and concise: Explain what you need her to understand with clear and straightforward statements. Avoid being too vague or complex. 4. Use non-confrontational language: Use ¡°I¡± statements to express your feelings. For example, instead of saying ¡°You never listen to me,¡± you could say ¡°I feel unheard when I try to express my views.¡± 5. Listen to her: Make sure to listen when she talks and let her finish before responding. Interruptions can escalate the situation and make her feel you¡¯re not interested in her opinions. 6. Ask for her opinions: Let her know that you value her views. Ask what she thinks about your issue. This might make her more willing to listen to you. 7. Show maturity: Behaving maturely in the conversation can help to win her over and make her more willing to listen. 8. Seek help if needed: If the issue persists, it could be helpful to seek counsel from a neutral third party like a family therapist or counselor. Remember, patience is crucial. It may take a few conversations before she begins to truly listen and understand.

column1: Could you tell her ?  What would happen if you said "Mom, I love you and I really want to share myself with you, but often I you get upset and I don't want that to happen. I really want to be able to talk to you."
column2: Communicating with parents can sometimes be a challenge, especially if they tend to become anxious or upset easily. Here's some advice for improving communication with your mother. 1. Choose the right time: Try to choose a time when she's not stressed or busy. She's more likely to listen calmly if she's not distracted. 2. Be calm and collected: Before starting the conversation, take a moment to calm yourself. Avoid raising your voice or losing your temper. Despite your frustrations, aim for a peaceful and productive conversation.  3. Express your feelings: Use "I" statements to talk about how you feel, instead of blaming or accusing her. For example, "I feel upset when you won't listen to my perspective," instead of "You never listen to me!"  4. Be clear and specific: Be as clear and as specific as you can about what you need from her. If you need her to just listen without offering advice, say that. If you need advice, then ask for it.  5. Validate her feelings: Let her know that you understand her feelings and worries. This will make her feel respected and more open to hearing what you have to say.  6. Ask for her opinion: After you've expressed your feelings or needs, ask for her opinions or thoughts. This shows that you value her inputs and this may soften her reactions.  7. Show Appreciation: Showing gratitude can go a long way. Thank her for listening to you or providing advice.  8. Seek help if needed: If communicating with your mother continues to be a problem, you might want to consider talking to a school counselor or a therapist. They can give you more strategies for communicating with your mother, or they can facilitate a meeting between you and your mother to help improve communication. Remember, it might take time to adjust communication habits so be patient with yourself and your mom. It won't likely change overnight, but with consistent effort, it can get better.

column1: You are very wise for a young person. You have already figured out that other people's behaviours...how they treat you...it's not about you...it's about them. I love that you don't blame yourself for your mom's behaviours. It's not your fault. She's getting upset because she doesn't know how to manage her emotions, and these emotions have to do with her past and her present stress. You're just the trigger. Yes, this is normal, but it's not necessary. She can find another way to manage her "stuff".Unfortunately, you can't help your mom a whole lot or even help her recognize this. But for yourself... remembering that her behaviours are her issue is the biggest piece of "dealing with it". You can always try some new strategies when you talk to mom...you can say "I'll listen you better if you don't bring up past stuff", or "I'm worried about you mom. You seem stressed", or even "I don't like the way you talk to me". Good luck!
column2: It depends on the circumstances. Stress, fatigue, illness, personal issues, hormonal changes like menopause, or mental health issues like depression or anxiety can all contribute to irritability or mood changes. If the anger is excessive, frequent, causes issues within relationships, or is associated with physical violence, it might be a sign of a more serious issue like a mood disorder. It's crucial to communicate with her about your concerns, with respect and understanding, to show her that you care about her well-being.

column1: Anger is a normal emotion, and yet it is a really hard one... how much is too much? and how do you express it without damaging those around you? yes mom's get angry, sometimes too easy... but its their responsibility to manage their anger-- get their own support and put themselves in time outs when they cannot handle it well.  Since you are the kids, you shouldn't have to fix or calm down mom's anger. Maybe in a calmer time when you guys are being silly talk with her one on one? Tell her  you are feeling sad and hurt that she gets upset at you girls. Ask her if there is 1 thing you can work on this next month to help her. Ask her if she would work on 1 thing for you this month-- not yelling? taking a time out? telling you before she blows her top so you can exit the room? Also for you, check out a library book on anger so you know how to handle yours, and one on parents and anger. Number one to remember, if you don't feel safe, if she is calling you names, or hurting you, breaking things etc. make sure you go to a trusted adult--school counselor, neighbor, aunt, church friend as soon as possible. You are much too important to be hurt and if mom is out of control, someone else needs to be --caring for you.
column2: It can be normal for someone to become irritated or upset quickly, depending on factors like stress, sleep deprivation, or underlying health conditions. However, if this is a constant issue, it might be beneficial for her to speak with a health professional about her concerns. It's important for everyone involved to practice understanding and patience, and seek help when needed.

column1: Hello, and thank you for your question. Being bisexual can be particularly difficult because it is often misunderstood, even by people who are ¡°supposed¡± to be part of your own community, such as lesbians and gays. It happens so often that there is actually a term for it ¨C bi-erasure. This is simply something that happens when people deny that bisexuality is a real thing, or discriminate against bisexuals due to beliefs like your parents seem to have.  The unfortunate truth is that you can never be sure of how you parents may take this kind of information. It sounds promising that they are accepting of other sexual orientations, and it may simply be that your parents lack education about bisexuality. With accurate information, they may come around, but there is no way to be sure.  Some of my colleagues have already given you good information. Here are some more things that you can consider and questions you can ask yourself before making the decision to tell them: 1.  If they don¡¯t respond the way you want them to, have you developed a support system to support you through it? This is very important. The truth is that all the friends in the world won¡¯t prevent pain or sadness if your parents don¡¯t respond as you hope, but they will at least be there to remind you that you ARE okay as you are. And that is critical for you to remember.  2.  There is great information on the internet about bisexuality that you can offer your parents if you think it would be helpful. It may be important for them to know the kind of damage that is being done to bisexual adults and young people because of the myths surrounding bisexuality. Here is an article from GLAAD about bi-erasure: http://www.glaad.org/bisexual/bierasure 3.  Coming out to people is obviously deeply personal and should only take place when you are ready. Sometimes people get pressured from friends, media, and even people they are romantically involved with to come out before they are ready. It really is up to you. If you are feeling pressure from others, don¡¯t feel bad about setting your boundaries and telling them that you will come out on your own time. Intimate partners should respect you enough to understand this.  4.  Something else to think about is your own comfort in being bisexual. Just because someone is LGBTQ doesn¡¯t mean that they necessarily want to be. Many people struggle with this. Having your own doubts or insecurities may also play a part in how comfortable you are in telling your parents. So, perhaps do some self-exploration about your feelings toward yourself.  Sometimes people take friends with them when they decide to come out to their parents. This is something you may want to consider. The important thing to remember is that you are okay. Really. If your parents don¡¯t respond well, that doesn¡¯t mean that they never will. Some start off upset, but then work their way through it.  Best of luck to you.  Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC
column2: That is completely understandable. Coming out can be a challenging process and it's normal to feel scared or anxious. Remember, there is no rush and it's important to do this when you're ready. Perhaps try to gauge their attitudes towards bisexuality first to better prepare yourself, and seek out support networks if possible, such as friends or online communities who may have similar experiences. Knowing you have others' support can help reduce fear and anxiety. Ultimately, this is your journey and you should navigate it in a way that feels most comfortable for you.

column1: Coming out to family members can cause a lot of anxiety. However,  although I cannot promise what their reaction will be, the benefit is that you will no longer have to hide who you are. Perhaps researching or getting information on bisexuality can help your family understand what it truly is to be bisexual. Many times,  people are just not educated on certain things.
column2: It's completely normal to feel scared or nervous about coming out, especially to family members. It's a big step and it's important to be in a safe and supportive environment when you do. Here are some things you could consider: 1. Educate Yourself: It's important that you're able to answer any questions your family might have. Remember, their initial reaction might not be positive due to lack of understanding. However, this may change over time as they educate themselves more about bisexuality. 2. Choose the Right Time: Make sure you choose the right time to talk to them. It should be when everyone is calm and open to a serious conversation. 3. Be Honest: It's crucial to be honest about your feelings. Let them know how long you have felt this way and make sure they understand this is a fundamental part of who you are, not a 'phase' or a choice. 4. Support: Consider bringing a supportive friend or family member with you. They can provide emotional support and serve as a mediator if things get heated. 5. Patience: Be patient with them. It might take time for your family members to fully understand and accept your sexuality. Remember, their initial reaction might not be permanent. 6. Seek Help: Consider seeking support from LGBTQ+ communities, both online and in person. They can provide you with helpful advice and resources.     Remember there is no rush, take all the time you need to ensure you are ready for this important conversation.

column1: Perhaps you are not ready to come out to your parents.  Often times our readiness is not dependent on what others' will say or how they react. But more so dependent on how emotionally prepared we are to deal with others' reactions.  It may be beneficial for you to play out each possible scenario and conclusion (eg. your parents being supportive vs. your parents being disappointed and so on). How are you prepared to deal with the outcome?  You may also seek help through counselors, support groups and/or individuals you know that have dealt with similar situations to help you prepare to discuss this with your parents. All the best!
column2: It's very understandable to feel anxious about coming out, as it is a deeply personal thing to share, and reactions can be unpredictable. It's important that you do it in your own time, when you are ready and feel safe. Here are some tips: 1. Information: Have resources on hand that your family might find useful. Websites like Human Rights Campaign or PFLAG have resources to help to educate your family about what it means to be bisexual. 2. Support System: Do you have close friends that you are out to? Having a supportive community can be very comforting and empowering during challenging times. 3. Counselor/Therapist: If you feel overwhelmed, you could consider talking to a counselor or a trusted adult about it first. 4. Practice: Rehearsing what you want to say can help boost your confidence. You can also write a letter if that feels more comfortable. 5. Be patient: It may take time for your family to process this information. Some may not understand or find it difficult to accept; however, give them time. Remember it's not necessary to label your sexuality at all if you don't want to, it's your choice how you choose to identify and disclose that. Make sure you¡¯re in a safe environment and the people around you are supportive. Reach out for help if you need it as well, there are several organizations willing to help.

column1: Hello, and thank you for your question. This is one of those times when you wish you could assure someone that everything will go perfectly, but unfortunately I can't do that. There is no way of knowing how parents might respond until you tell them. The truth is that people have come out to their parents in many different ways. Some have told their parents directly, some drop hints, some have had others tell their parents, etc. The only "right" way to come out is the one that you choose. The one that feels right to you. That is the best way. Some people decide not to come out, and some wait for a very long time. Both of these things are okay. Coming out is deeply personal, and there can be real consequences to someone's emotional health and safety if they tell the wrong person. That is why it should only be done when you are ready. When you feel that you have the emotional and personal support that you need to take the risk. Sometimes people can feel pressured to come out, but I encourage you to do it in your own time. The truth is, there is a spectrum of how people's parents react to this kind of news. On one end, you may have the parents who shut a person out and are abusive, and on the opposite side you may have parents that are totally okay with it and throw you a "Coming Out" party. Most parents are going to fall somewhere in the middle. It is important to remember that their feelings may change over time. Many parents struggle at first, but they love their kids and get better with it over time. If you decide to tell them, consider taking someone along to support you. Plan ahead on what you want to say. It can be an emotional time, so do what you need to do to take care of yourself. If you need to, leave. You don't have to stay anywhere where someone is being cruel to you. I wish you well, and good luck.Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC
column2: Coming out to your parents about your sexuality can be challenging and nerve-wracking, but it's also a very personal process. Here are some suggestions on how you might approach this conversation: 1. Be Confident: Before anything, you must be confident about your identity. Accept yourself and appreciate your worth. You shouldn't feel guilty about being who you are. 2. Check Your Assumptions: Don't assume how your parents will react. They might react unexpectedly and pleasantly surprising you, or they might not. Either way, it's important to approach the conversation with an open mind. 3. Timing: Choose a quiet, comfortable and calm time to talk to your parents. Avoid choosing a moment when they are already stressed, so they have a better chance of reacting calmly. 4. Prepare Yourself: Plan what you want to say in advance. Write down your thoughts if it¡¯s helpful. This will help you to express yourself more clearly. 5. Language: Use simple and direct language. Explain that you are still the same person, and this is just one aspect of who you are.  6. Be Honest: It's essential to be honest about your feelings and tell them how important their support is to you. 7. Reassure them: It can be helpful to reassure them that being gay is not a choice and it's not something you're going through as a 'phase'. Let them know that you've spent time thinking about this and it's not a rash decision. 8. Seek External Support: If you're afraid of a negative reaction, consider coming out in the presence of a counselor or trusted adult.  9. Give Them Time: You've had time to accept this about yourself, so be patient and give your parents time to process the news. It might be a shock at first, but with time they need to understand.  10. Provide Resources: It can be useful to provide your parents with resources to better understand what it means to have a homosexual child. There are online resources, books, and support groups that might answer any questions they could have.  Remember, every person's coming out experience is unique. Take each step one at a time and do what feels right to you. Keep yourself safe and don't rush the process.

column1: This is a common issue. You grow up gradually, and parents often forget to shift their habitual responses according to your newfound level of maturity and growing need for freedom and independance. I'm all for helping you find new ways to cope and interact with your mom. Ultimately, you only have control over yourself, so that's the place to start. You can remind yourself that Mom's behaviours don't mean that she doesn't trust you or love you; it's just that she has habitual ways of talking to you that seem stuck in the fourteen year old range. If you can see her responses as habits, rather than a reflection of how she feels about you, then you can keep yourself calm. The more calm you are, the more she will buy into it when you invite her into a different sort of relationship. Take a look at the picture from her perspective. She may feel overwhelmed with finances (are you in college?), and feel burdened by the mundane tasks in life that she doesn't know how to recruit help for. I bet your mom spends a lot of time picking up after you, cleaning, cooking, doing laundry...all those thankless mom tasks. Take a look at how she talks to you... is she nagging about chores? Can you see that underneath the nagging there's a pretty overwhelmed and powerless person who needs assistance?  Okay, so my guess is that you both have a legitimate beef. She wants help. You want respect. Let's talk about how you get both.I propose that you sit down with mom and negotiate out a different sort of dynamic. "Mom...I see us as stuck in how we interacted when I was fourteen. Can we do this differently in a way that we both get what we want?" Sell it as "win-win". Then you write down some things that end up forming a contract. The first part is stuff that's your business and your business alone: things you want your mom to respect, like your room, your school, your job, your personal relationships and hygiene.... Mom's voice has no place in these arenas, unless you are storing food in your room and it's a health hazard. This is a "Mom says nothing about" list. The second part is about what Mom needs from you. What are her expectations about your role in the home as an adult. Does she want you to contribute to rent? Buy your own food? Do your own laundry? What items can we put in your control that would take some burden off of Mom? How will these things be enforced? What will happen if you don't follow through? Write it all down so it's really clear. It has to all be mutually agreed upon.The third part of the conversation is about how she talks to you, and how you talk to her. You can let her know that you don't want to be told what to do or when to do it; that doesn't work when you're 20 years old. Listen to what she wants too. Beyond the contract you've just written up, anything else you want from each other is a request, it's optional, and whether and when you do it is at your discretion. My guess is that if she spoke to you with more respect, you'd be more willing to help out. AND, I think if you participated a bit more she would nag at you less. Go for the win-win. I wish you well as you negotiate a new relationship with Mom. :)
column2: Dealing with the stress of a parent can be challenging, but there are various ways you can go about it. 1. Communication: Speak to your mother about how you're feeling. She might not even be aware that she is causing you stress. Approach the conversation with kindness and respect, and aim to express your feelings without accusing or blaming her. 2. Therapy: Professional help can be extremely beneficial. A therapist can provide you with strategies to cope with your stress and can even act as a mediator between you and your mother in sessions, if that's something you feel comfortable with. 3. Boundaries: Establishing healthy boundaries can greatly reduce stress. You do not have to endure behaviors that are causing you undue stress. It might be hard setting these boundaries, but preserve them for the sake of your mental health. 4. Self-care: Ensure that you're taking care of your physical, mental and emotional health. Physical activity can help reduce stress, as can activities you enjoy, like reading, listening to music, or spending time with friends.  5. Support Groups: It might be helpful to join support groups with individuals who are experiencing similar issues. This can help you feel less alone and provide you with strategies they've found helpful. 6. Practice Mindfulness: This can be achieved through meditation, yoga, tai chi, or simply deep-breathing exercises. They can help you stay calm and can enable you to react better when faced with stressful situations. 7. Seek Help from Close Friends and Family: Discussing your stress and frustrations with other loved ones can provide a sense of relief. They might be able to offer advice or provide a fresh perspective. Remember, you're allowed to take space and care for your own mental health, even if that means distancing yourself from your mother. If the stress becomes too much, seeking professional help is a very good option. It's OK to ask for help.

column1: You undoubtedly are carrying a huge weight on your shoulders. Stressors come in many forms and you are engulfed in a few of the major ones as it relates to dealing with the declining health of your father, family conflict, as well as trying to balance a work and school schedule. Stress, if left unchecked has many negative health related implications. First and foremost I would recommend going to see a counselor at your college/university. Most colleges have counseling centers for students that usually allow for 5-6 free counseling sessions (your tuition actually pay for these sessions so take advantage of them). Secondly I would advise you to take a minute and breathe. When confronted with overwhelming life issues it is common to busy ourselves in an attempt to distract ourselves from the drama, but sometimes that can compound our stress. When dealing with stress it is important that you engage in self care. In other words find time to engage in activities that bring you a sense of peace, enjoyment, and fulfillment in order that you may get a momentary release from your daily hectic life. Even with a normal life there is no way to escape stress, it is inevitable and a part of life, but how you deal with stress, as well as how you take care of yourself in the midst of these whirlwind events will determine your quality of life. I hope this helps...
column2: There are a number of different methods you can use to manage and reduce stress: 1. Regular Exercise: Physical activity can help you relax and reduce your stress levels. It also promotes better sleep, reduces fatigue, and boosts your mood. 2. Mindfulness and Meditation: These practices can help you maintain a moment-by-moment awareness of your thoughts, feelings, bodily sensations, and surrounding environment. 3. Healthy Eating: Maintaining a healthy diet can boost your energy, lower your stress levels, and trigger a positive feeling in the body. 4. Adequate Sleep: Lack of sleep often aggravates stress. Aim for 7-9 hours of sleep each night to ensure your body is well-rested and less susceptible to stress. 5. Deep Breathing and Relaxation Techniques: Deep breathing, yoga, and other relaxation techniques can help reduce stress by slowing the heart rate and lowering blood pressure. 6. Socializing and Having Fun: Spending time with friends, indulging in a hobby, reading a book or listening to music can help take your mind off stressors. 7. Limit Caffeine and Alcohol: Too much caffeine or alcohol can increase stress levels. It's best to limit consumption of these substances. 8. Time Management: Prioritize your tasks and break down your to-dos into smaller, manageable parts to avoid feeling overwhelmed. 9. Professional Help: If you find your stress is too much to handle, don't hesitate to seek help from a psychologist or a counselor who can equip you with more specialized techniques for managing stress. Remember, what works for one person might not work for another. It's crucial to find what methods work best for you and practice those techniques regularly.

column1: You as the child in the middle of your parents' problems is the worse position to be in.  I can only imagine your hurt, pain and confusion on what to do.  Honestly, this is a hard question to answer without knowing your age, your parents' ability to handle hearing information from you and your maturity to handle what may happen in the end.  One thing I would like to note....your parents may be in the same house but if your mother is cheating, they have already gone their separate ways.
column2: Discovering that a parent is cheating can be quite an emotional shock. Here are some steps you could consider: 1. Process Your Feelings: It's vital to allow your emotions space. It's a confusing and hurtful situation, and you're allowed to feel these emotions. You might feel angry, shocked, sad, or torn between both parents. Talking to a close friend, relative, or professional counselor could help you process your feelings. 2. Evaluate the Situation: Understand the complexity of the situation before taking any hasty steps. If you're absolutely sure or have solid proof, then you may decide to confront your parent. 3. Confront your parent: Find a calm setting and express your concerns honestly with your parent. Be prepared, this might lead to a tense conversation, and you may not get the answers you¡¯re looking for immediately.  4. Encourage transparency: If you decide to confront your parent, encourage them to be open about their actions. They should consider having this difficult conversation with their spouse. 5. Seek professional help: If the situation seems overwhelming, it might be a good idea to involve a professional counselor or therapist. They can guide your family towards constructive dialogue and help manage the crisis. Please remember these steps are not universal solutions. They are broad suggestions that could be beneficial, but the final decision depends on the specifics of your situation, individual relationship dynamics, and your comfort level.

column1: Hi Troy, I totally get this. It's a dilemma; you want your dad to know how he's hurting you but you don't feel safe enough to say anything to him. Your reaction is understandable; it's his responsibility as a parent to work harder than you to create that safe place for you to be open. But that's not who your dad is. Your dad is your dad, and waiting for him to change won't really help. Nothing you do can change your dad, but...there are things you can do for yourself and your relationship with him. While your response of avoiding him is understandable, I wonder what effect it has on your dad. It's possible that he's feeling frustrated, rejected and punished by your withdrawal. You may think he knows that you're feeling hurt, but he probably doesn't. So this is the squirrel chasing its tail: your dad is rude, so your habit is to be silent, then he maybe feels abandoned and frustrated. His frustration comes out as more rudeness, which makes you want to withdraw more, and the cycle starts all over again. You can't change his part of the cycle but you can change yours.Are you willing to take a risk? Can you be honest about how you're feeling? What's the worst thing that could happen if you said to your dad "You know why I avoid you? I stay silent because when I talk to you say rude things. So if you want me to talk, I need to know you can listen." I imagine it would come out differently because you're a few generations younger than me, but put that into your own words.I don't know the level of your dad's 'rudeness'. If he is abusive, then a better plan is to see a therapist alone or talk to someone about this. I don't want to put you at any risk. But if you don't worry your dad will hurt you, maybe give honesty a try.My point is that, as rude as your dad may be, checking out of a relationship by being silent is also rude. It's powerful...your silence. Your dad can't read your mind, and if you want things to be better you will need to get in that ring with him.And, if you're both open to it, seeing a therapist together can be really helpful. :)
column2: Being open and honest with your dad might feel difficult, but it's the key to establishing a mutually respectful relationship. Here are some steps to follow. 1. Trust: Trust your dad with your feelings, ideas, dreams, and worries. Believe that he will understand and support you. It will be difficult if you¡¯ve had situations where he didn't, but try to give him another chance. 2. Have Confidence: Be confident in expressing your feelings and thoughts. Accept your individuality and your right to have your own perspectives. 3. Keep Calm: When discussing serious or sensitive topics, avoid getting frustrated or angry. Practice body positivity and remain composed. If you feel the conversation is getting heated, take a break, and resume once both parties are calm. 4. Be Direct: Be clear, specific, and stick to the point you want to convey. Ensure your dad understands your perspectives and why you feel a certain way.  5. Use the right time and place: Choose the right moment to speak up. Ensure it's a peaceful environment where your dad is relaxed and open to conversation. 6. Write: If verbal communication seems too difficult, write him a letter. It allows you time to arrange your thoughts logically, reducing the chance of miscommunication. 7. Seek Guidance: If you find it challenging, seek advice from a counselor or a trusted adult. They can offer you methods to communicate your feelings effectively. 8. Build it Over Time: It's not a one-day process; it'll take time. Start with smaller concerns and gradually proceed with severe matters. This helps you to gain confidence, and it also gives your dad time to understand and adjust. 9. Show Gratitude: Show appreciation whenever your dad makes an effort to understand you or helps you in any way. This encourages him to do it more often. 10. Speak the truth: Always tell the truth, it improves your credibility and makes your dad trust your viewpoints in the future. Remember, your father might not respond positively immediately. Don¡¯t get discouraged and continue expressing your feelings honestly. Eventually, he will likely understand and appreciate your courage to speak up.

column1: Congrats on your upcoming grandchild!Does your daughter want you to break news of her pregnancy, to the family?Talk with your daughter first, whether or not she would like you to tell other family members.Also, given the other facts you mention in your post, if household and financial management are areas you feel your daughter is vulnerable, then bring up these topics too.Stay open minded about your daughter having views which are different from yours.
column2: Breaking news of this type to family members can often be a sensitive matter, so it's important to approach it with care and thoughtfulness. Here's a possible approach on how you can do it: 1. Discuss with your daughter: Before telling anyone else, confirm with your daughter how she wants the news to be shared. She may want to be the one to announce it, or she might prefer you to do so on her behalf.  2. Respect her feelings: Your daughter might be going through a lot of emotions herself. It's therefore necessary to consider her feelings before sharing this news with everyone. Do not try to "sugarcoat" the reality but also don't present it as if it's a problem or something negative. 3. Pick your time and place: Choose an appropriate time and place where you can discuss without interruptions. Making such an announcement casually or in passing might give the impression that it's a smaller matter than it is. 4. Be direct and straightforward: When you share the news, be candid. You might say, "I have some news to share. [Daughter's Name] is pregnant. She's not married, and she's going to keep the baby. She's happy about it, and I hope for your support and positivity in this new chapter of her life." 5. Allow room for questions: Family members might have questions or concerns. Be patient and allow them to express their thoughts. Actually, this can be a good chance for them to show their support. 6. Keep Positive: Frame the news positively. While it might not be a traditional situation, it's still the arrival of a new family member, which is something to celebrate. Remember, all families are different. Use methods that would mean best-catering to the needs of your family whilst supporting your daughter.

column1: Hi New York, There is no need for shame here; no one's done anything wrong! A pregnancy is a glorious gift to be celebrated. I wonder what gets in the way of you celebrating your daughter's pregnancy? Are they excited about it? I bet they are. They've been together for seven years. Even if it caught them off guard, the best thing for them and this new baby is to celebrate the joy of this new little person and their growing family. If you are happy for them and help spread their joy, how marvelous would that be for them as a family?New York, I will be honest with you; I hope that's okay. I sense that maybe you are feeling judgemental towards them. Do you dislike or judge his struggle with mental illness? Do you see him as less than worthy because he hasn't worked? I don't know for sure, but I imagine maybe his anxiety and depression get in the way of working. Maybe he's on a social disability? Mental illness doesn't make someone less lovable or valuable as a partner. He's getting help for himself and that's wonderful. If your daughter loves him and is happy with him... If he is her chosen man, then they absolutely need your support, not your judgement. And if they struggle as a couple, you know what...they will need it even more!Is this your first grandchild? If not, then I don't have to say this, but if it is...you are in for the most amazing adventure of your lifetime. You will fall in love so deeply with this child. S/he needs that...this baby needs your love and support.So, you say to your family... "I have amazing news! My daughter is expecting a baby! I'm going to be a grandparent!! I can't wait".
column2: Sharing such personal news with family depends entirely on the nature and dynamics of your family, but here are some suggestions you might find helpful: 1. Respect her wishes: Before you reveal her pregnancy to the family, ensure this is something your daughter wants. She might want to share the news herself, or she might prefer privacy. 2. Set the tone: If you are the one sharing the news, the way you present it can greatly influence how the family perceives it. If you present it as something positive, the family might also see it in the same light. 3. One-on-one conversations: This might be a better approach if you think some of the family members could react unfavorably. You can discuss the news personally with each of them, which will give them an opportunity to express their emotions directly and ask any questions. 4. Understand their views: Be prepared for mixed reactions, but remember it's essential not to take these personally. It's a significant piece of news and they might need some time to absorb it. 5. Support: Regardless the reactions, make sure your daughter knows that she¡¯s loved and supported. As a family, it's essential to navigate this change together, focusing on the new family member who is soon to arrive.  6. Be Honest: Honesty tends to be the best policy. If the family respects the honesty, it will help in managing the reactions.  7. Letter or Email: If face-to-face discussions sound overwhelming or if your family members are spread out, writing a letter or sending an email is also a practical approach.  In a nutshell, sensitivity, respect, and understanding are the keys to breaking such news. Remember, it's your daughter's journey, so make sure she is comfortable with every step taken.

column1: Hi Morristown,There's a saying that goes "hurt people hurt people". It's possible that your aggression towards your friends is connected to your mother's behaviours. When we are treated poorly, especially as children, it affects how we ourselves, others, and the world. It's also powerful modelling of aggressive behaviour. The good news is that you have this lovely awareness and I think a desire to learn about yourself and grow in your ability to be respectful to people you care about. I recommend you consider sitting down with a therapist and exploring these ideas and moving forward on that path you seem to want to be on. Good luck!
column2: Yes, a person can potentially become mean towards others as a reaction or defense mechanism to being treated poorly themselves in the past. This is not justifiable and not the only response to poor treatment, but it does happen. However, it's crucial to understand that each individual can choose their behavior and strive towards treating others with kindness and respect, regardless of their own personal experiences.

column1: How someone feels when they forgive another, is at peace with themselves and their understanding of what went wrong, who was responsible for what in the situation, and clarity on their own motivation, actions, emotions including pain, regret, resentment, sadness.These steps ideally allow a new door to open in order to develop new paths in the existing relationship or accept that this will not be possible due to either person's way of handling themselves.The long answer would be that you're not yet through with this process.I commend you on being truthful with yourself about yourself.You're on the right track by expecting to feel resolved when you've reached resolution, and not before.Finding patience with the unpredictable amount of time needed to thoroughly examine all the details of the incidents you mention, sometimes is a frustration of its own.Keep up your good work of knowing your own life.It is a worthwhile endeavor!
column2: Feelings after forgiveness can vary greatly from person to person. Some may feel relief or a sense of peace, having released the burden of resentment or anger. Others may feel lightened, unburdened, or even empowered. Forgiveness can also bring about feelings of compassion, understanding, or empathy. Some people may also feel unresolved feelings, like fear or discomfort. It's different for everyone and there's no 'right' way to feel. It might also take time for these feelings to surface and for you to feel the full effects of your forgiveness.

column1: Hi Cleveland, I think I get what you're feeling. You're scared that if you forgive your mom, that would mean it wasn't so bad, or she'll think it's okay to do it again, or she won't realize how hurt you are. I invite you to look at forgiveness in a different way. Forgiveness doesn't have to mean what she did was okay. Not at all. Forgiveness can mean "I accept what she did, and I don't want to live in her worst moments constantly. I want to put it down and move past it because I want her in my life, because fear and resentment interfere with my relationship with her, and mostly because I'm tired of carrying them (fear and resentment) around constantly."You can forgive your mom for yourself, not for her. If there is evidence that your mom wants to respect you moving forward, then it might be worth it to risk putting down the resentment and the grudge that you think you need to protect yourself. Your ability to draw boundaries with her in the present is your biggest protector; let her know in the present what hurts you, and notice her responses.You don't have to say it to her face. Saying it to yourself is more important. Again, forgiving your mom helps you...it reduces your own burden of fear and resentment, leaving space for better things.
column2: It varies from person to person but generally, forgiving someone can bring about feelings of relief, peace, and a sense of freedom from the burden of resentment or anger. However, it's important to remember that forgiveness is a process and initially, it might not lead to immediate happiness or tranquility. Over time, it can lead to emotional healing and personal growth. You may still feel hurt or upset after forgiving someone and that's okay. Forgiveness is about letting go of the negative emotions for your own peace of mind, it doesn't mean forgetting the hurt caused or reconciling with the person.

column1: The best way to work on a relationship is for both people to engage with the problem and start communicating with each other more effectively.  One of the hardest things about this, however, is getting both people within the relationship to recognize that they are both responsible for the successes and failures within the relationship and remove all the all-or-nothing blame. The best style of communication is open and asking for clarification; why not try asking your mother why this particular fight/situation is eliciting such an angry response.  Often, the simple act of expressing that we don't understand the other person's point of view can open the doors to better levels of communication. The hardest part is trying to remain humble as we seek out that clarification and avoid the blaming language we are so used to using in such times.
column2: 1. Open Communication: You need to establish an open line of communication where both of you can share your thoughts, feelings, and opinions without the fear of judgment or criticism. 2. Spend Quality Time: Look for activities you both enjoy and do them together. This not only creates happy memories but also strengthens your bond. 3. Show Respect: Always show respect to your mom. Treat her with kindness, understanding, and patience. No matter your disagreements, she is still your mother. 4. Listen: Oftentimes, we are so eager to express our feelings that we forget to listen to the other person. Listening shows that you value her opinions and thoughts. 5. Show Appreciation: Compliment her cooking, thank her for her support, or simply tell her you love her. Small gestures of appreciation go a long way. 6. Understand Her Perspective: Try to see things from her point of view. Remember, she's experienced more of life than you have.  7. Handle Disagreements Calmly: You won't always agree on everything. Stay calm and patient when disagreements inevitably happen. Look for a compromise or solution. 8. Be Honest: Always be truthful, as hard as it may be. Lies can harm your relationship and lead to mistrust. 9. Show Maturity: Treat her like an equal. This shows that you're growing up and are capable of making responsible decisions. 10. Ask for Advice: Let her know that you value her guidance and experience. She'll probably be more than happy to share her wisdom with you.

column1: Hi Zionsville. It's so sweet that you have a special relationship with your brother. You will ALWAYS have that, you know? He's doing what's natural at his age...spreading his wings and looking for love. You may be heading into that zone soon too, but I get that it's weird that he's there before you, and you miss him.Try to respect your brother's autonomy, wish him well, be friendly with his girlfriend, and it's also okay to say "Hey, bro, I'm still here. When can we hang out!?"
column2: I'm really sorry to hear that. It's tough when people we care about seem to drift away. Try to communicate with him, express your feelings without blaming him and suggest to do things you both enjoy together.

column1: It is always hard when we feel as if we are losing somebody close to us. Feeling sad over these losses are normal. While there may be some things you can do to remedy this situation, it is important that you try and understand that part of life is change. The fact that your brother doesn't spend as much time with you doesn't mean that he loves you less or doesn't care about you. It most likely means that he is having to split his time between different people and priorities. I suggest that you communicate with him how you feel. Perhaps, ask him if he would be able to set up times that the two of you can hang out, without anyone else present. Addionally, it wouldn't hurt for you to also find some other ways to spend your time away from him. Now might be the perfect opportunity to pick up a new hobby or hang out with different peers. Keeping yourself distracted in healthy ways and processing your feelings of sadness will likely help with lifting your mood. Good luck to you!
column2: It's normal to feel upset or left out when someone we care about doesn't spend as much time with us as we'd like. Here is some advice on what you can do: 1. Communicate: Speak honestly with your brother about how you're feeling. Use "I" statements, such as "I feel upset because we don't hang out as much as before." 2. Invite Him: Plan for activities that you both enjoy and invite him. This not only gives you time together, but also common grounds to spark conversations. 3. Understand His Perspective: He might be too busy between work, school, and other responsibilities, or just going through some personal issues. Try to understand his perspective and give him some space if needed. 4. Patience: People go through phase, he might need some time alone. Be patient, continue to show love and care, he'll eventually come around. 5. Bonding: Try to build common interests. Perhaps involve him in your activities or take interest in his. This will increase bonding and give more reasons to hang out together. Remember, everyone needs their own personal space and it's okay if your brother is needing some. Communication is key in any kind of relationship. Voicing out your feelings might make him realize what he's missing.

column1: Hi Florida,I get the sense that, aside from this relationship, you're quite isolated in general. It's sad that you're feeling excluded at Christmastime and family events. While I would suggest that you don't really know what he or his family are thinking or feeling (you assume they're against you, and that he doesn't care), he is certainly behaving in a very distant, excluding manner and it's understandable that you would feel rejected and hurt. How long has this part been happening? Has he always acted this way, or is it more recent? Did something happen recently? You mentioned doing "stupid things to yourself", and I don't know what that means. If you are engaging in self-harm he may be confused about what to do and he might need some time to think and be separate but is having trouble talking about this. Part of the problem, of course, is that you don't know what's going on for him. Certainly, you deserve the truth, and if he doesn't want to spend time with you, I would hope he would be honest. Have you been open to hearing the truth from him? Is there any reason for him to hesitate to tell you why he's being distant? Maybe you could ask him, if you are ready to hear.I'm glad to hear that you believe that you deserve a full, loving relationship, although it seems that moving forward might be difficult for you. Is it possible your happiness is a bit too dependant on this man? I'm just guessing, based on what you've said here. It seems that it's possible your situation has led to some depression, and I would recommend a session with a qualified therapist to help you sort this out. You will need support, even if the relationship is repaired. Best of luck.
column2: Feeling excluded from the family is a significant issue. Take out time to communicate your feelings to your husband. You two need to sit down together in a comfortable environment and have a heart-to-heart discussion about your feelings of being left out. Use "I" statements to communicate how you feel, like "I feel left out when..." instead of the blaming "You" statements. If your situation doesn't improve after this conversation, you might consider seeking help from a marriage counselor or a neutral third party. Please remember, you deserve to feel included and important in your family.

column1: Do you have a close friend or relative who's opinion you trust? Ask them for their honest feedback and if they see you like your cousin does. If they don¡¯t see these qualities in you, then it may be your cousin¡¯s issue and she¡¯s taking it out on you. You can always ask her what would be the best way to communicate plans with her so you know, specifically, what she is expecting. Then if you meet these expectations and she still blames you and comments on how inconsiderate you are, it's her issue and she is not coming from a place of love.Even if you do resemble her comments, the way it sounds like she approaches this problem is not out of love. The fact that you're introspective enough to consider your own behavior suggests the problem is not with you.
column2: Communicating your feelings is essential in such a situation. Here's a general guide on how to approach this: 1. Self-reflection: Identify and understand exactly what actions or words from your cousin make you feel this way. This will help frame your conversation with them. 2. Choose a good time to talk: Choose a comfortable location and a time when both of you can converse without being distracted, rushed or interrupted.  3. Use "I" statements: This puts the focus on how you feel about the situation and can come across less confrontational. For instance, "I feel belittled when you make those comments about my job." 4. Be calm and assertive: It's natural to feel emotional while talking about such issues, but try to stay calm and composed when you speak to them. 5. Set boundaries: If certain topics stir negative feelings or arguments, tell your cousin what topics are off the table during conversations. 6. Seek help from other family members: If your cousin continues to disregard your feelings, you may want to involve other family members or have this discussion in a family setting where other people can advocate for you too. 7. Professional Help: If the situation worsens, you might want to consider seeking advice from a professional counselor or therapist who can suggest more nuanced ways to navigate this situation.  Remember, you have the right to feel comfortable and secure. If your cousin refuses to change their behavior, it may be in your best interest to distance yourself from them.

column1: It sounds like you are feeling pretty criticized by your cousin and at the same time you are wondering whether or not there is some truth in what she is saying. It also sounds like you would like to see if you can find a new way to relate to your cousin, so that your relationship can be more satisfying. If you can find a competent therapist to work with, there may be a great deal of opportunity to learn more about how you relate to people in the world and to learn strategies to show up in your relationship with your cousin in a way that feels right to you.
column2: 1. Reflect: Firstly, take some time to reflect on your feelings. Is your cousin really belittling you or are they simply making light-hearted jokes that you are interpreting as an attack? Sometimes, due to personal insecurities, we may misinterpret the intentions of others.  2. Communicate: If you are sure they are trying to put you down, talk to them. Let them know that their words or actions are hurting your feelings and affecting your self-esteem. They may not even realize the impact of their actions and it could make a big difference. It¡¯s easier for them to reconsider their behavior if they are fully aware of how it's affecting you.  3. Seek Help: If directly speaking with your cousin does not help in changing their behavior, you may want to involve an adult or someone else in the family that both of you trust. That person might be able to facilitate a productive conversation or mediate a conducive solution that ensures your cousin understands the harm they are doing. 4. Maintain Boundaries: Try to enforce strict boundaries if your cousin continues to belittle you. Limit your interaction with them and distance yourself whenever possible until their behavior changes.  5. Seek Counseling: If these situations make you feel extremely insecure or hurt, it may be helpful to seek professional help such as a therapist or counselor. They can give you strategies to deal with these feelings and possibly teach you some assertiveness skills.  6. Self-confidence: Work on building your self-confidence. If you are secure with who you are, then the negative comments from your cousin will not have the ability to harm your self-esteem. Remember, you have control over how you respond to others. So it's important that you take actions to safeguard your mental and emotional well-being.

column1: I understand that this can be difficult when you care about someone. Have you had a discussion with your mom as to why she does not want you and this boy to see each other, and what her concerns are? It sounds as though you and your mom may be able to use some help with communicating, and compromising. It is understandable that you do not to feel comfortable having  to lie to your mom. It  would be helpful if she could understand that you having to lie to he is getting in the way of you being able to go to her with any issue and  feel she will hopefully understand or try to understand where you are coming from.
