You want to spend time with your friend but your boyfriend  may feel betrayed by you spending quality time with another man you have been intimate with. There may be a way for you both to get your needs met. Maybe you only spend short periods of time with your friend, not a whole weekend. Or you check in with your boyfriend  periodically when you see your friend. It really depends on the two of you. If it becomes too difficult, you may need a neutral party to help you establish appropriate boundaries around this issue. Good luck!
column2: It's normal for people in relationships to feel insecure or unsettled at times. Here are a few tips on how to handle the situation: 1. Communication: Talk to your boyfriend and understand his feelings. Ask the reason behind his discomfort. His feelings may stem from insecurity, jealousy, or misunderstanding. 2. Openness: Be open about your relationship with your guy friend. Don¡¯t hide any interactions to avoid suspicions. Include your boyfriend in interactions when possible. 3. Reassure him: Make sure your boyfriend knows where your heart lies. Remind him that he's your significant other and that your friendship with the other guy is just that ¨C a friendship. 4. Set boundaries: It's equally important to set certain boundaries with the friend in question. Avoid creating situations which might make your boyfriend uncomfortable. 5. Compromise: It's essential to reach a compromise. Perhaps your boyfriend just feels left out and would want to spend more quality time with you. 6. Bring them together: Try to create an environment where your boyfriend and your friend can interact. This way, they can understand each other better.  Finally, relationships are built on mutual trust. Both of you need to trust each other for a successful relationship. If these steps don't improve the situation, consider seeking help from a relationship counselor.

column1: It's completely understandable that you would have male friends and that you would want to spend time with them.  When you cross over from friends to a relationship, it does change things.  Some people are very easy going and wouldn't feel threatened by what you did  Others would be upset.  If your boyfriend is upset by you spending time with this male friend, then you need to talk about it.  Each of you needs to express your feelings about the situation and listen to the other with patience and respect.  Then you can make a decision on what is best for you and your relationship.  Maybe he wouldn't be upset if you saw this friend while you were with your boyfriend.  Or maybe your boyfriend would feel better if he got to know this person better and could trust him.  Most likely you can come up with a situation that will make both of you comfortable going forward.  You didn't do anything "wrong" because it doesn't sound like you intended to hurt your boyfriend.  But if you really care about your boyfriend, then you probably care about making him upset.  Instead of looking at this issue as a problem, try to look at it as an opportunity to connect.  If you can both listen to each other and understand each other, your relationship can become even closer.
column2: Jealousy in relationships is quite common, but it's important to handle it with empathy and care. Your boyfriend might be feeling insecure or threatened by your friendship with another guy. Here are some ways you can ease his mind : 1. Communicate: Talk to your boyfriend about his concerns. Keep the conversation open and make sure it's a two-way street. Listen to his feelings and assure him that he's your priority. 2. Reassure: Reaffirm your love and commitment to your boyfriend. Show him that your relationship with him is solid and he has nothing to worry about. 3. Establish boundaries: If your friendship with this other guy is completely platonic, you should still establish appropriate boundaries such as not spending too much alone time with him or discussing intimate topics. 4. Include your boyfriend: If possible, hang out together with your boyfriend and your friend. This inclusion can help your boyfriend feel more comfortable and less threatened. 5. Seek professional help: If jealousy issues persist and are causing strain on your relationship, consider seeking assistance from a relationship counselor. Remember, it's important that both of you feel assured and secure in your relationship. Respect for each other's feelings and relationships outside the couple is key.

column1: Two paths are possible.You're not overreacting and instead are genuinely sensing that something feels unsettled within your girlfriend.You are overreacting because you have difficulty accepting how safe and loving your relationship is with this person.The only way to find out is to start conversations with your girlfriend on how you feel.This will allow new light to open an answer as to the truth.Once you know what truly is going on between the two of you, your self-trust naturally will grow stronger. Self-trust will give you an accurate read of what and whom you are able to safely trust.
column2: As assistant, I don't have personal emotions. However, from an analytical perspective, lack of trust in your partner could be due to different reasons: past experiences with betrayal or dishonest behaviors, fear of being hurt, low self-esteem, or issues unrelated to the partner like anxiety or fear of vulnerability. It is crucial to communicate these feelings with your partner and, if necessary, seek professional help.

column1: Remember that all relationships center around 3 simple values: HonestyTrustand Respect......in that order, too...If you are unable to trust, then you are fundamentally dishonest about something in yourself;Moreover, whatever you do not honestly experience, you do not honestly express out to another;To be honest with oneself is where most people fall down... and, when you do fall down, pick yourself up... and get back on the horse :)
column2: As, I don't know your personal history, but trust issues can often stem from past experiences including past relationships, childhood experiences, or trauma. You might fear vulnerability or getting hurt. If this is affecting your well-being or your relationship, it could be helpful to speak with a professional counselor or therapist. It's important to remember that everyone deserves a relationship built on trust and respect. Communication with your partner about your feelings can also be an essential step.

column1: What's most important is that you recognize that what you've been doing is off base - that what you've been feeling is "overreacting," that you have "insecurities," and you suspect your actions and reactions are connected to your own past and not to the current situation or to your partner. That's an excellent first step because without recognizing these things about yourself, it's unlikely that you would change.That said, you sound as if you are really ready to start some therapy to work on your own personal growth... not because there is something "wrong" with you, but because you're ready to learn more about yourself and make some creative changes in your behavior. Yes, there are lots of self-help books and courses, but we humans often make the most progress when we have support in real-time from another human being who can sit with us, point out our blind spots, and teach us some skills that are hard to learn on our own.
column2: Trust issues can originate from past experiences or insecurities. If you've been hurt before, you might be afraid of getting hurt again. It's also possible that you perceive certain behaviors or actions from your partner to be threatening, even if they're not intended that way. Additionally, low self-esteem can make you question your partner's sincerity and authenticity. If trust issues persist, consider seeking advice from a counselor or therapist to understand and manage them.

column1: I can only imagine how hard that must have been to hear. On one hand, most of us would say we want our partners to always be honest with us, but on the other disclosures like this can lead to feelings of worry and inadequacy if we're not careful. So let me first of all say that it is very normal for human beings, even very committed and happy partners to have moments where they notice an attraction for someone else. Quite honestly, the brain can't help it. It sees something good looking and it pays attention. And when we pay attention to something good, our brains send out neurochemicals associated with that happy thought...and we get a rush of what your girlfriend is labeling "a crush." The difficulty here is deciphering whether she was just attempting to honor her commitment to you by sharing this feeling OR if she is continuing to feed those feelings. I would encourage you to thank her for being honest if you haven't already, and ask her to further describe the nature of these feelings and what she'd like to do from here. As weird as it is to say, at the end of the day, what helps the most is typically reassuring yourself that you WILL be okay not matter what! That it is worth it to invest in your relationship and give it your all and if someday, god forbid, this woman chooses to walk away, then she is not the one. Will it hurt? Of course. But is it the end? Hell no! There are 7.5 billion people on the planet and I firmly believe statistically speaking alone, there are at least several hundred thousand that could be AMAZING partners for you. Cheering you on,Tamara Powell, LMHCP.S. You might enjoy this excellent book by Esther Perel for further inquiry into the fascinating world of love and mating behaviors: "Mating in Captivity¡±
column2: 1. Acknowledge Your Feelings: It's okay to have a crush even if you're in a relationship. It doesn't mean you don't love your partner anymore. Realize that it's normal and accept your feelings without feeling guilty. 2. Don't Act On It: This is quite important to remember. Just because you have a crush, it doesn't mean you should act on your feelings. Respect your current relationship and partner.  3. Limit Your Interaction: Try to limit your interaction with the person you have a crush on. If they are a co-worker or someone you see regularly, this could be a bit difficult but try to establish boundaries. 4. Open Communication: If your relationship allows for open communication about feelings, discuss it with your partner. Being honest can actually strengthen your relationship and you can work through it together. 5. Nurture Your Relationship: Rather than focusing on your crush, put that energy into your relationship. Work on improving it and remind yourself why you love your partner. 6. Seek Professional Help: If the crush is affecting your relationship and causing you distress, it may be helpful to seek professional help such as a counselor or therapist to manage your feelings. 7. Self-reflection: Look into why you have a crush on this person, what is missing or needs improvement in your current relationship that attracted you to someone else? Use this as an opportunity to understand and better yourself. Remember, a crush is a temporary feeling that will eventually fade away. How you handle it will reflect on your commitment and respect towards your existing relationship.

column1: Hi! It sounds like you are stuck in a difficult place. You do not want to appear to jealous and yet, it's hard not to be, when you hear about "the crush". It's only natural to feel a little insecure and you're doing a great job by asking how to cope better. First of all, long-distance relationships are very hard. Is this situation likely to continue for a long period of time? The old adage that "absence makes the heart grow fonder" simply isn't true. It requires a lot of work to keep the fire burning. Are you, guys, talking to each other a lot? Visiting each other relatively often? Making common plans for those visits or your future together? Do you manage to have fun together, despite the distance (e.g., laugh on the phone, have "shared" experiences such as watching a movie simultaneously at your different locations, perhaps having phone sex)? All of the above are good ways to ensure that your bond stays strong and there will be less space left for interest in other people. Based on the fact that  your girlfriend told you about the crush t I would guess that she thinks it's innocent enough - nothing too threatening. Try to talk to her about your feelings and brainstorm together ways you can increase your intimacy, which will likely improve your sense of security in the relationship but also help her get over the crush. Good luck! Zofia
column2: Dealing with a crush while in a relationship can be confusing and stressful. However, it's completely normal to occasionally find other people attractive. Below is some advice on how to handle these feelings: 1. Acknowledge Your Feelings: Suppressing feelings is not going to help. Accept that you have a crush on someone else. It doesn't mean that you love your partner any less. It's completely natural to find other people attractive. 2. Evaluate Your Relationship: A crush might just be a fleeting feeling. However, if you frequently find other people attractive, it may be a sign that something is lacking in your current relationship. Maybe you're not getting the attention, appreciation, or satisfaction you need. This could be a good time to evaluate and discuss your relationship with your partner. 3. Don't Act On It: Having a crush is something you don't have control over but acting on it is definitely in your control. You may feel a momentary rush if you act on your crush but remember that you might be putting a long-term relationship at risk. 4. Talk About It: If you feel comfortable, you may want to discuss your feelings with your partner. Honesty often helps to build a strong relationship.  5. Limit Interaction: If possible, try to limit your interaction with the person you have a crush on. The more you see and interact with this person, the more you are likely to dwell on your feelings for them. 6. Try To Shift Your Focus: Instead of occupying your mind with the crush, try to invest more quality time in your relationship and focus on why you fell in love with your partner in the first place. 7. Seek Professional Help: If this crush is causing distress and you're not able to manage it on your own, there is no harm in seeking professional help. A counselor or therapist can help you understand your feelings better and give you useful strategies to cope.

column1: Long distance relationships are very difficult to maintain, not just for the lack of communication, but also because of the lack of intimacy that comes along with it. Even if you have spectacular communication while in a long-distance relationship, it is difficult to maintain intimacy because you are lacking in the physical contact aspect of intimacy. Here, we are not talking about sex, but about the emotional connection that happens along with physical contact. It is also hard to have shared experiences when the two of you are in separate places. These are the challenges that you face, but there are some ways to improve your odds. The first thing to remember here is that dating is all about finding a person that you want to eventually dedicate your time, resources, and self to. If either of you finds that the relationship is one that you are not necessarily committed to, it is better to find out and have the opportunity to date others before a commitment is made. The second thing to remember is that open communication is a good sign in a relationship. That being said, I do not believe that sharing details about your "crushes" is the best thing for a relationship. Instead, I would recommend working on improving the relationship as best you can. It is a wonderful thing when we can feel that we have given our best efforts on something, especially something as important as the act of loving. Here are a couple things that you can do to improve even a long-distance relationship. Start by downloading the Gottman Card Decks App here https://www.gottman.com/couples/apps/. While on the phone or video chat, try asking each other some of these questions so that you can build a deeper knowledge of one another. Some may seem silly, but they help you know the other person more intimately. It is also helpful to make sure that you are having regular communication with each other. Some situations make it very difficult to communicate, but if at all possible, daily communication via phone or video chat would be best. Even if it is just for 30 minutes a day, really dedicate your time and attention to each other during those calls. Next, it can be helpful to know each other's love languages so you can show each other how much you really care. Take the assessment for the 5 Love Languages and talk about the results together. You can find the assessment here: http://www.5lovelanguages.com/profile/Attraction to other people is completely normal and involves biological processes. Intimacy, on the other hand, creates real connection and dedication to each other. Learn about each other, spend time together, and you will create intimacy.
column2: 1. Acknowledgment: Understand and admit that it's completely natural to have crushes or to find other people besides your partner attractive. Admitting to yourself about the crush is the first task to tackle. 2. Open communication: If you're comfortable and it's appropriate, you might want to share these feelings with your partner. Honesty may hesitate the unnecessary tension. However, your partner's comfort has to be the foremost consideration. 3. Prioritize your relationship: Realize the value of your existing relationship and focus on it. Spend more quality time with your partner to elevate the feelings for them. 4. Distancing: Try to create a distance with the person you have a crush on. Seeing them less could give you the opportunity to focus on your relationship more. 5. Give it Time: Time is a healer. As time passes, you might realize that the crush you had was momentary and insignificant to your relationship. 6. Self-analysis: Analyze your emotions thoroughly. Understand the reasons behind your crush. Is it because of the physical appearance, personality, time spent together, or because you're missing something in your relationship? 7. Avoid comparisons: It's essential not to compare your partner with your crush. Such comparisons can only create confusion and resentment.  8. Understand that "The grass is greener where you water it¡±: The principle states that you should focus on improving your relationship rather than seeking satisfaction elsewhere. 9. Seek professional help: If your feelings are too strong to handle by yourself or cause stress, seek professional help, like a counselor or therapist. Remember, it's normal to have a crush while you're in a relationship but acting on it is not. It's essential to separate these feelings from your commitment to the person who's really important to you. Be committed and endeavor to make your relationship stronger.

column1: Thanks for writing in. Several things come to mind:I don't know how you are communicating, but there is a great deal of difference between communicating through videoconferencing compared to text message when discussing subjects like this. Being able to hear and/or see each other will help you to be able to gauge a lot of the emotions connected to what is going on.Are you in a place where you can ask your girlfriend questions about this crush and actually listen to her answers? If you can listen non-defensively and ask questions about what is actually going on (kind of like an investigative reporter might), you are likely to hear about her experience, thoughts, feelings, etc., so you can actually see what the crush is like for her and how you want to react to that.Then you could see if she is willing to listen to your questions and answer them for you.Another tip: Find out when is a good time to have this conversation. If you are talking to your girlfriend after she just worked a 10 hour shift and she is frustrated about that, it is likely that the emotion will transfer to the conversation that you are having even though it doesn't have anything to do with that.Find a way to keep yourself grounded and centered during the conversation. Notice your feet on the floor or your hips in the chair. Mindfully play with an object or something like a paperclip or a pen. Doing this mindfully (by being aware of your senses) will help you to not feel so overwhelmed during the conversation.After you have more details, communicate about what it is that you want or wish for. It is often easier to hear and discuss as opposed to talking about something that you need.Remember that while anger is a very real emotion, there is always something else under it. Be aware of what else could be there: hurt, disappointment, betrayal, fear, etc.
column2: Experiencing a crush in a relationship can be a tricky situation, but it doesn't necessarily mean the end of your current relationship. Here are some steps you can take to address it: 1. Awareness: Recognize the feelings you have and be honest with yourself without feeling guilty. It's okay to have feelings for others, but acting upon them can lead to consequences.  2. Analyze the Significance: Consider what is causing you to have this crush. Is it because there's something lacking in your current relationship? Maybe you're unhappy, or perhaps this is just an innocent, temporary infatuation. 3. Open Communication: If you believe it's necessary, discuss your feelings openly with your partner. This can be a delicate topic to navigate, so ensure you approach it with care and respect for your partner's feelings. 4. Put Distance: Limit your contact with the person you have a crush on. This can help to minimize feelings and regain focus on your current relationship. 5. Refocus your Energies: Invest time, attention, and energy into your current relationship. Try to rekindle the flame of love and make your partner feel more appreciated. 6. Seek Professional Help: If these feelings persist and become disruptive to your current relationship, you may want to seek help from a relationship counselor or a psychologist. Remember, it's perfectly normal to notice other attractive people even when you're in a committed relationship. But it's important not to act on these feelings and harm your current relationship. However, if this crush is becoming stronger and stronger it might be an indication of issues in your current relationship and an opportunity to reflect.

column1: Often, communication is the key within relationships. When faced with our significant other telling us about a ¡°crush¡±, it can create or highlight feelings or thoughts that can promote feelings of insecurity. Talk to your partner about their crush and use the conversation to strengthen your bond.
column2: Building a crush while you're already in a relationship can be confusing and challenging to tackle. Here are some strategies: 1. Identify the Reason: Recognize the issues that trigger this crush. Are you feeling unsatisfied or restless in your current relationship? Is it because you're having a rough time with your partner or feeling neglected? Identifying the cause will help you address it in a better way. 2. Communicate: Discuss your feelings with your partner. Though it might be uncomfortable, communication forms the core of any relationship. 3. Limit Contact: If you're having a crush on someone within your work or friend circle, try keeping safe distance. Reduce your interactions and focus more on your partner. 4. Invest Time in Your Relationship: Focus on the good parts of your relationship. Recognize what your partner does for you, and try to reignite the spark by doing things you both love. Date nights, physical intimacy or surprise gifts can help in this. 5. Seek Professional Help: If you're struggling, consider consulting a relationship counselor or therapist. They can provide you with strategies and techniques to cope with your feelings. 6. Separate Feelings from Actions: Understand that it's completely normal to feel attracted to other people, but acting upon those impulses would be wrong.  7. Focus on Your Crush's Negative Traits: Ignore their attractive qualities and focus on their negative traits. This technique might help you lessen your attraction towards them. Remember, having a crush while being in a relationship doesn't make you a bad person. It's how you handle it that counts.

column1: No one can tell you how to deal with your own relationship, even a therapist. But, you should absolutely give your girlfriend the respect of believing both of those statements she gives you: development of feelings and it being a "crush." If that makes you feel a certain way (mistrustful? no difference in feelings) then that is what is most important to understand. When you understand exactly how YOU feel about hearing this news, then we can know how you should deal with this.You have every right to be in the relationship or to leave the relationship. But if trust is broken, first and foremost it needs repairing. What that repair looks like varies (but can often involve couples therapy, which may be complicated because of the long-distance nature of the relationship.) Otherwise, staying in a relationship that has become mistrustful for you, and not prioritizing the repair, is a recipe for disaster.
column2: Maintaining a relationship requires a lot of commitment and understanding. If you find yourself having a crush on someone else while in a relationship, there are a few things you can do: 1. Self-Reflection: Understand what this crush signifies. Is it because there's something lacking in your existing relationship or it's just an infatuation? A crush may indicate issues in your current relationship or it might simply be a fleeting attraction. 2. Communication: Communicate with your partner about your feelings if you think it's needed. Being honest with your partner can prevent miscommunication or mistrust in the long run. 3. Keep Distance: Minimize your interaction with your crush. The more you come into contact with this person, the stronger your feelings may grow. 4. Focus on your Relationship: Invest more time and effort into your existing relationship. Remind yourself of the love and bond you share with your partner. 5. Counselling: Seek help from a professional if you feel the need to. They can provide you with methods to deal with your feelings and help you understand what you're experiencing. 6. Patience: Crushes during a relationship are normal, they come and go. Be patient with yourself and don't rush into any decision that might affect your relationship negatively. 7. Distract Yourself: Engage in things you love to do. Try picking up a new hobby, spending more time with friends, or doing anything that helps you focus your mind elsewhere. 8. Manage Your Feelings: Accept your feelings without acting on them. Remember, it's the actions that matter at the end, not the fleeting emotions. Always remember, it's completely normal to have crushes even when in a committed relationship. The key is how you handle it. It¡¯s important to never use your crush as a reason to cheat or hurt your partner.

column1: Long distance relationships have the addition strain of being far away.  It sounds like you and your girlfriend overcame the initial challenges considering that you¡¯ve been together for over a year and she was honest in telling you about her crush.  These are some clear strengths in your relationship.  Now moving forward, continuing to have honest conversations about your relationship will help ensure you two are on the same page.  Explore with her how this crush came about and what her feelings are about this relationship.  Be prepared for the answers and express your feelings as well.  You¡¯ve invested over a year in this relationship, it may be worth figuring out how to mend it.  Ignoring this issue will potentially lead to other issues.
column2: Developing feelings for someone else while you're in a relationship can be a confusing situation to navigate. Here are some ways how you could deal with it: 1. Understand your feelings: Is this just physical attraction? Do you admire them? Is it because they are new and exciting, unlike the monotonous routine in your current relationship? Understand the nature of your feelings before taking any steps. 2. Open communication: If you feel comfortable and believe it would be beneficial, speak to your partner about your feelings. Honesty can strengthen a relationship, but remember to be tactful and reassure them about your commitment. 3. Avoid unnecessary contact: Distance yourself from the person you're developing feelings for. It's easier not to nurture a crush when you're not in constant contact with the person. 4. Reflect on your relationship: Try to figure out if there are any gaps in your relationship that are causing you to develop feelings for someone else. Maybe you and your partner need to put in more effort to keep things exciting. 5. Focus on your partner: Instead of focusing on the person you have a crush on, try to emphasize your feelings for your partner. Think about why you fell in love with them in the first place. 6. Seek professional help: If your feelings continue to confuse you, it may be beneficial to seek help from a professional therapist to explore them better. 7. Decision-making: After assessing your feelings and your relationship, you may have to make a tough decision. Do you want to continue with your relationship or do you think your crush could be a potential partner? Remember, it's completely normal to have a crush while in a relationship, but it's crucial to handle it properly to prevent hurting anyone involved.

column1: Did your girlfriend tell you her reason to tell you about the new person?Your feelings of insecurity is natural because you don't know where the crush fits into her life.Since any long-lasting relationship in which both people thrive, means each partner freely speaks their mind and will be listened and responded, then your current situation is a good one to start these foundations of talking with one another.Tell your girlfriend whatever is on your mind regarding her crush.   As your trusted partner, theoretically she would like to know all about how you feel.Keep the expectation that talking about anything at all, is the best sign of closeness.Once you learn more about this crush you can decide what, if anything to do differently in your relationship.
column2: Dealing with a crush while being in a relationship can be challenging. Here are some steps to help: 1. Acknowledge your feelings: It's important that you understand that it's normal to have crushes, even if you're in a relationship. The key here is not to act upon these feelings.  2. Analyze your feelings: Are you feeling ignored or unimportant in your current relationship that made you have feelings for someone else? This could be a sign that something needs fixing in your relationship. 3. Communicate: If you're feeling distant from your partner, try talking to them about it. Open communication is key in a relationship and will give both of you a chance to work things out. 4. Limit contact with your "crush": Spend less time with the person you're crushing on, especially in scenarios where you might be tempted to flirt. Even if it's harmless, it can lead you down a path you don't want to go down. 5. Refocus your emotions: Instead of fantasizing about the person you have a crush on, remind yourself of all the reasons why you love your partner.  6. Seek professional help when needed: If your crush is affecting your relationship profoundly and you're unable to deal with it, consider seeking professional help like a therapist or a relationship coach. 7. Practice Mindfulness: Try and stay in the present and avoid thinking about your crush, it's a way of training your brain to eliminate extreme feelings gradually.  8. Strengthen your relationship: Spend more quality time with your partner, strengthen your bond with them. It can help you shift your attention from your crush back to your partner. Remember, experiencing a crush when you're in a relationship doesn't make you a bad person. It¡¯s how you handle it that counts.

column1: Those words must have been extremely difficult to hear or read. It sounds like you are both having difficulty with the distance, and I can only imagine that you have both been coping with this distance as well as you can. There are a few scenarios that I think would have pretty radically different paths for your own mental health, and I would like to explore them separately. The first scenario is that she has this crush, but still chooses you and wishes to stay with you. Keeping the value of her choice in mind, and the bravery she has shown in admitting this crush, handling her gently in that vulnerable place will pay off. You may find it worthwhile to explain your feelings about it, to share how it is hurting you to know of this, and what she means to you. Explaining those feelings will help you to not act out in your with emotions to cover up by becoming angry or withdrawing. Acting in this way will help assure her of her choice in you, and sharing these emotions and feeling supported by her may help you cope with this.The other scenario is that she has a crush on this man and she is wanting to leave the relationship with you to have one with this other person. As before, it would be useful for you to share your feelings with someone. It can be difficult to process through these emotions, as they are intense and often overwhelming. In this scenario, it may be too difficult to share these feelings with your girlfriend, but it is still important that you acknowledge this loss and allow the associated emotions to have its place. Grieving the end of this relationship could be a great source of personal growth.I hope this has been of some help.
column2: Dealing with a 'crush' while in a relationship can raise several emotional dilemmas. Here are some methods on how you can deal with this issue: 1. Recognize Your Feelings: It's completely normal to have a crush on someone else, even while you're in a relationship. But inability to recognize your feelings can drive you into guilt. A feeling of guilt can affect both your relationship with your partner and your mental health. Recognize your feelings; it is the first step to dealing with the problem. 2. Evaluate Your Relationship: A crush outside your relationship might suggest your needs aren't being met in your current situation. Look at what is lacking in your relationship that the new person fulfills. It could be emotional connectivity, passion, excitement, etc.  3. Prioritize Your Relationship: Spending quality time with your partner and recreating the romantic moments can help you deal with a crush. The more you invest in your relationship, the less likely you're to pay attention to the new crush. 4. Establish Boundaries: If your crush is someone you're associated with on daily basis, establish boundaries. It could be restrictions like avoiding personal conversations, limit communication outside of work/school, or even cutting ties if necessary. 5. Therapy and Counseling: If you're still unable to deal with the situation, consider seeking professional help. A therapist will not judge you, rather they'll provide unbiased guidance which can help you and your relationship. 6. Honesty: If your crush begins to affect your relationship, you might want to consider talking to your partner about it. This approach is risky and depends largely on the level of understanding between you and your partner. At the same time, this honesty can help improve your current relationship. Remember, having a crush is not equal to cheating. It's a natural human emotion and varies from one individual to another. But, it's essential to deal with your emotions responsibly so it doesn't affect your current relationship negatively.

column1: If I understand you correctly, this "maybe-boyfriend" has done a partial break up, and wants to maintain a partial relationship.  Is that ok with you?  And, if it is, what does it cost you?  He says he's "done" but still wants the connection.  That seems to leave him free to explore other options, but it doesn't allow you to do the same. Break ups are painful, and I know you'd like to avoid that.  I get it that you feel attached to him - you have been in a relationship with him for 4 years, so that makes sense.  However, loving him appears to be costing you a lot, without much in return. If you wait for him to define what he wants, you could be on hold for a long time.Please don't wait another year to advocate for yourself.  See a therapist who can help you figure out what you need out of relationships and why you have allowed yourself to be on "pause".   It is possible that once you get clear, you will be able to have a true relationship with him.  If not, please don't settle for this. Take good care of yourself.
column2: It seems like he might be struggling to let go or is unclear about what he wants from the relationship. Communication is key here. It's important that both of you have a clear understanding of where you stand. Put forward your concerns, share how you feel and encourage him to do the same. Make sure you are looking after your emotional well-being first.  If he is unable to clarify his intentions or continues to give mixed signals, then it might be worth seeking advice on how to move forward, or even consider taking some time apart to re-evaluate the relationship.

column1: That does sound very confusing...and hurtful.  You do not have to tolerate someone treating you in a way that hurts you.  It may be helpful to decide where the boundaries are for you and to stay true to them in your interactions with him.  You teach other people how they are allowed to treat you.
column2: It sounds like you're dealing with mixed signals and this can be quite confusing. There could be multiple reasons behind this. Maybe he's conflicpycted about his feelings or perhaps he's uncertain about ending the relationship.  However, the key thing to notice here is the inconsistency, which can lead to stress and emotional turmoil. Communication is important; consider having an open conversation about his actions so that you could determine the best course of action for your own emotional well-being.  Remember, it's crucial to focus on what's best for you. If maintaining this ambiguous relationship status is causing you stress or discomfort, it might be best to create some distance and allow yourself space to heal and establish boundaries.

column1: Have you brought up the topic as to the way you're feeling?The best way for someone to understand us or to understand someone, is to directly talk about  the specific problem.To start the discussion w your partner, understand your own reasons for continuing the relationship.Given his stated disinterest in the relationship, your mood is probably affected by this.Once you are clear on how the range of your feelings, especially any fears on being alone, suggesting you may be staying w this guy simply to avoid such fears, then you'll be ready w your self-knowledge, to start a conversation w your partner about your relationship.
column2: There can be several reasons for this. His feelings might still be strong, he might be confused, he may not know how to act around you, or he might not be ready to let go. Whatever the reason, it's essential to have open and honest communication. If what he's doing is making you uncomfortable or confusing, let him know and ask him to clarify his intentions. Stay patient and give each other some space to process the breakup and transition into a new phase of your relationship or friendship.

column1: This can be difficult and confusing.If you think your boyfriend would be open to having a discussion, try asking him for a time when he is willing to have an important discussion. When that time matches with a time that is good for you, try discussing the type of relationship that you each want to have and what you can start and stop doing to get there. He may want to be really good friends. He may also be trying to figure out what he is feeling. If you end up talking over one another, try letting one person be the one who is talking about their feelings for about five minutes and during that time, try having the other person asked questions to gain more understanding of their experience. Then you can switch. Also consider asking questions that cannot be answered with yes or no, but lead to more explanations.Questions that start with the words how, what, when, who are usually better than questions starting with "why" because they can be emotional triggers for some people.If this is difficult to do between the two of you, consider seeing a therapist who specializes in couples.
column2: This situation can be very confusing and hurtful. People often show mixed signals due to their emotions and confusion. Here are a few reasons why your ex might be acting this way: 1. Not Ready to Let Go: They might not be fully prepared to let go of the relationship or the emotional bond, even though they've decided it's best to end things.      2. Comfort: They might still feel comfortable with you and it's hard for them to instantly switch to behaving like you're no longer a part of their life. 3. Guilt: If your ex feels guilty for ending the relationship, they might try to soften the blow by acting as if you're still together. 4. Uncertainty: They may still have feelings for you and they are unsure about their decision, so they become inconsistent. 5. Manipulation: Some people keep their exes on their hook intentionally. They might like the attention, comfort, or control. It would be best to have an honest conversation about your feelings and the signals you think he's sending. Make it clear that his mixed signals are causing confusion and hurt - it's possible that he's not even aware that he's doing it. If necessary, consider setting boundaries that can help you both to move on.

column1: What an important question, and the fact that you're asking it is a big step in the right direction. To answer in detail would require having quite a bit more information about what "relationship problems" have occurred  that woke you up to the fact that you're not listening as well as you could and that you're running the risk of losing her.Given that I don't have all that information, I'll offer one simple suggestion. Your girlfriend is the expert on what she needs and wants in relationship. You could simply say to her that you know you still have a lot to learn about how to have a good relationship and you realize you're not yet understanding what she needs and you really want to. Then take a deep breath, settle down, and listen. Don't argue, don't interrupt, don't judge... listen. Let her know what you understand and that you're open to hearing more, learning more if you're not quite getting it yet... and then listen some more. Be present and curious about this person you love dearly and don't want to lose. This is the first step toward intimacy.
column2: That's great; working on self-improvement is always a noble goal! Here are a few suggestions: 1. Practice Self-Reflection: Regularly take some time to think about your actions, your motives, and your overall happiness. Be honest with yourself and try to identify any areas that could use improvement. 2. Cultivate Kindness: Invest time in helping others. It could be as simple as assisting a friend with something, or volunteering for a charity. Not only can it help to make you feel good, but it will also help you to become a more empathetic and understanding person. 3. Improve Communication: Effective communication is key to building and maintaining healthy relationships with others. Learning to effectively express your feelings, listening actively and practicing good body language are all necessary. 4. Pursue Knowledge: As the saying goes, 'knowledge is power'. Continue learning new things, be curious, and never stop growing mentally. 5. Stay Physically and Mentally Healthy: Good physical health translates to good mental health. Regular exercise, eating a balanced diet, and maintaining a regular sleep schedule can all contribute to this. Also, don't be afraid to seek help if you're struggling with mental health issues. 6. Foster Relationships: Make building and maintaining meaningful relationships a priority. Whether it's with family, friends, or a significant other, good relationships can provide a support system, a source of joy, and a sense of purpose. 7. Accept Responsibility: Knowing when to accept responsibility for your mistakes or failures can help improve your character significantly.  8. Practice Patience: Being patient is key. It reduces stress and allows decisions to be made from a mindset of clarity and not impulsiveness. 9. Have Goals and Dreams: Having clear goals and dreams gives you something to strive for, and pushing yourself to achieve those goals can lead to significant personal growth. 10. Be Honest: Honesty, with yourself and others, is key to trust. Trust is optimal in all relationships and can lead to greater happiness.  Remember, change doesn't occur overnight. It's a process. Stay consistent and patient with yourself, and never hesitate to seek support around you when needed.

column1: Hello, and thank you for your question. First, I want to say that it is great that you are are willing to admit that you share some responsibility in some of the relationship problems you are having. This isn't always easy to do, but it sure is important if you want to see improvement. It does sound cliche, but communication really is the bedrock of relationships. And not just intimate partner relationships, but really any relationship that is significant to us. It sounds like you are saying that you have a difficult time really listening to what your partner is telling you and then responding in a way that is helpful. I want to tell you that you are not alone. Good communication skills are not really something you are born with, we actually have to learn them. The good news is that there is great information available to help you do that. Ultimately, some people must seek professional help through couple's counseling in order to get help with this process. This is because some of the hurt and anger could be at such a level already that you may need help setting boundaries, creating a plan, learning new skills, and staying on track. If that is not something you can afford or can do right now, here are a few suggestions that may help. Personally, I am big fan of Dr. John Gottman. He is an expert in relationships and wrote a really great, easy-to-read book called The Seven Principles for Making Marriage Work. Dr. Gottman discusses the kind of communication that healthy couples seem to have, which can be helpful and worth trying. You can buy Dr. Gottman's book on Amazon for under $9. It's a good deal. There are a variety of websites that have good information that may help you build your communication. Here is one that I found that has a few good tips. http://www.helpguide.org/articles/relationships/effective-communication.htm You can try them and see if they are helpful. ***It is important to remember that like all new skills, communication requires practice and we surely fail several times before we start getting good at it. If you were ever a pitcher in baseball, then you know you have to throw thousands of pitches before you really start hitting your strike zone consistently. Allow yourself to make mistakes, own them, and start again. I hope these suggestions help, and good luck.Robin Landwehr, DBH, LPCC
column2: Becoming a better person involves improving oneself in various aspects, mentally, physically, emotionally, and spiritually. Here are a few tips for you: 1. Self-awareness: Know yourself better, understand your strengths and weaknesses. 2. Honesty: Be honest to yourself and others. This allows you to trust yourself, and it also builds trust with the people around you. 3. Compassion: Show empathy towards others, try to understand their feelings and emotions. 4. Improve communication skills: Effective communication is the key to any successful relationship. 5. Self-improvement: Always strive to learn and grow. This could be through reading, attending workshops, seminars or any form of education. 6. Mental health: Take care of your mental health, stress management and inner peace is extremely important. 7. Physical health: Regular exercise and a balanced diet are important for maintaining good health. 8. Respect: Treat others with respect, it gives them a sense of worth, and also increases their respect for you. 9. Apologies: Learn to apologize when you¡¯re wrong. Admitting your mistakes shows maturity and humility. 10. Avoid negative habits: If there are habits that you recognize as negative or harmful, such as smoking, drug abuse, excessive drinking, or other abusive behavior, seek help. 11. Maintain bonds: Having healthy relationships is a vital part of being a better man. Maintain good relationships with family, friends, and important people. 12. Generosity: Do acts of kindness, help others, give to charity, prefer to give rather than receive.  13. Patience: Learn to control your temper and maintain your calm in tough situations.   14. Goal-setting: Set meaningful goals for your life, both short and long term, and work towards them consistently. 15. Practice Gratitude: Be thankful for what you have. 16. Practice forgiving: Learn to forgive others, it gives you inner peace and resolves conflicts. 17. Cultivate a Positive Mindset: Positivity leads to happiness, self-satisfaction, and success in life. 18. Create and maintain a work-life balance: This balance allows you to achieve success in your professional life while maintaining joy and contentment in your personal life. 19. Nurture a Love for Nature: Engage with the outdoors frequently. This can range from gardening, hiking, traveling, or just general appreciation of nature. 20. Develop a Fastidious Approach to Life: Always do your best and strive for quality in everything you do. Above all, remember that change is a process that happens over time. Be patient with yourself and continue to strive for progress and personal growth. Practice makes perfect.

column1: Thanks for your question. Becoming a good listener is an essential piece in being a better communicator. Being an effective communicator will almost always improve the quality of your relationships. What stands in your way of listening to her? Do you find yourself becoming defensive when she brings up issues? Do you often find yourself thinking of what you want to say next? Do you take her words personally, preventing you from having the ability to problem solve?Here are some tips that may help you with being a better listener:1. Concentrate on what you are hearing, not on what you will say next.2. Ask questions if you need clarification or don't understand.3. Summarize what you're hearing after every couple of minutes to make sure that you're not missing anything.4. Ask your partner what she needs from you. Is she expecting advice or does she simply need to vent?5. Keep eye contact and avoid using non-verbal cues that demonstrate defensiveness or irritation such as eye rolling or crossing your arms.6. Remember that it's okay to disagree and, if this is the case, then decide as a team, how you want to move forward.I hope this helps. Good luck to you!
column2: 1. Self-improvement: This is the first step to becoming a better person. You should continuously strive to improve yourself, whether it be your personality, your behavior or your knowledge. 2. Empathy: Try to put yourself in other's shoes. This can help you understand their feelings and actions, which in turn can make you a more compassionate person. 3. Honesty: Honesty is the best policy. Being honest not only with others but also with yourself is important. It allows you to accept your flaws and work to improve them. 4. Respect: Show respect to everyone you interact with. This includes not just your seniors, but also your peers and juniors. 5. Responsibility: Accept responsibility for your actions. If you make a mistake, own up to it instead of trying to shift the blame onto someone else. 6. Patience: Patience is a virtue. Try to keep your composure in situations that test your patience. 7. Generosity: Be generous, not just with material gifts, but also with your time, your attention, and your help. 8. Care for others: Look out for the people around you. Show kindness and compassion to everyone, regardless of who they are or what they have done. 9. Pursue your passion: Life is too short to spend it doing something you don¡¯t love. Pursue your passion, and you¡¯ll find that this gives you happiness and fulfilment, which in turn makes you a better person. 10. Communication: Good communication skills are a must. Whether it¡¯s a personal or professional relationship, good communication helps to solve a lot of problems. 11. Positivity: Try to maintain a positive outlook on life. This is not always easy, but positivity can make you and the people around you happier. 12. Healthy lifestyle: Exercise regularly, eat healthy food and get enough sleep. A healthy body contributes to a healthy mind. 13. Commitment: When you commit to something, stick with it. Whether it¡¯s a job, a relationship or a personal goal, showing commitment is a sign of a strong character. 14. Be a Lifelong Learner: Embrace the fact that learning is a lifelong process. Continually seeking knowledge and growth will allow you to become more open-minded and well-rounded. 15. Practice Forgiveness: Holding onto anger or resentment only hurts you in the end. Practicing forgiveness, whether for others or yourself, brings peace and allows you to move forward.

column1: The best tool for becoming a better listener that I know of is called Imago Dialogue. It consists of 3 steps:1. Mirroring what she says (without judging, commenting, refuting, defending, arguing, or scoffing--just listening, no matter the content) and repeating it back, word-for-word. Continue to ask if she has more to add until she doesn't.2. Validating. You tell her you you understanding why she feels this way. (If you don't understand, then find a way.) You can also say, "That makes sense" or "I hear you" or "I get that."3. Empathizing. Tell her how you think she must feel about what she's telling you. Your job is to try and feel what it feels like to be her.This is a very different way of communicating than we're used to. My guess is that the arguments, discussions, and debates you've had with her have been counterproductive because you're both trying to win. With Imago Dialogue, you both win. She gets to be heard and you get to hear for a change.At the end of the exercise, switch roles. For more info: http://imagorelationships.org/pub/about-imago-therapy/imago-dialogue-101/
column2: That's a commendable decision and a goal that requires consistent effort and determination. Here's some steps to guide you: 1. Recognize and Accept Mistakes: No one is perfect. It's crucial to accept responsibility for past mistakes, apologize if needed, and make things right if possible. 2. Practise Honesty & Integrity: Be truthful and responsible for your actions. Also, being a man of your word is a non-negotiable principle. 3. Be Respectful: Respect everyone irrespective of their status, race, or gender.  4. Embrace Empathy: Understand others' feelings and perspectives.  5. Communicate Effectively: A man who can express himself clearly gains the respect of others.  6. Develop Emotional Intelligence: Be in control of your emotions, understand others' emotions, and respond appropriately. 7. Practise Self-Discipline: Discipline in various aspects of life, including diet, exercise, work, and relationships, is important. 8. Learn From Others: Look for good qualities in others and try to adopt those.  9. Develop a Strong Work Ethic: Be committed to your work, always strive to give your best, and take pride in what you do. 10. Constantly Learn and Grow: Constant self-improvement means you are open to change, willing to learn new things, and eager to improve. Remember, it's a journey with some days being better than others. Don't be too hard on yourself, have faith and patience in the process.

column1: I love that you are so thoughtful and proactive about this!  If only every client came in as solution focused as you, my job would be so much easier. I would second Robin's suggestion of reading ANYTHING by Gottmann. He's fantastic. Other favorites of mine are:¡°Getting Together and Staying Together: Solving the Mystery of Marriage¡± by Dr. William & Carleen Glasser¡°Eight Lessons for a Happier Marriage¡± by Dr. William & Carleen Glasser¡°Hold Me Tight¡± by Dr. Sue Johnson¡°Divorce Busting: A Step-By-Step Approach to Making Your Marriage Loving Again¡± by Michele Weiner-Davis, M.S.W.¡°The Five Love Languages¡± by Gary Chapman¡°The Flight from Intimacy: Healing Your Relationship of Counter-Dependency ¨C the Other Side of Co-Dependency¡± by Drs. Janae & Barry WeinholdI'll also add to Miriam's assertion that your partner is the expert on her. You can help things along by becoming a better expert on you as well. What is it that you are craving and likely trying to get your need met in potentially unhelpful ways from your girlfriend or in ways she doesn't understand or vibe with?  If you can better explain your own needs while trying to understand hers, you all have a recipe for great success! When both partners seek to serve one another and stay curious about each other in the process, intimacy abounds!Best of luck my friend! And if you get stuck, of course seeking help from a professional is always a great idea too. ;)
column2: That's a great attitude! Here are some steps to help you: 1. Self-Awareness: Understand your strengths, weaknesses, and triggers. Reflect on your past mistakes and contemplate on how you can learn from them. 2. Set Goals: Set specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, and time-bound (SMART) goals. This could involve improving your skills, maintaining a healthy lifestyle, contributing to society, etc. 3. Emotional Intelligence: Try to develop empathy, manage your emotions, and improve your social skills. This would not only help you maintain strong relationships but also lead a balanced life. 4. Education: Constantly learn and grow. Education isn't just about earning degrees. Self-growth and self-improvement resources are widely available. 5. Kindness & Respect: Treat everyone with kindness and respect. Engage in random acts of kindness and respect others¡¯ thoughts and opinions. 6. Responsibility: Be accountable for your actions, fulfill your duties and don't blame others for your mistakes. 7. Integrity: Be honest and maintain strong moral principles. Do what is right, even when no one is watching. 8. Health: Engage in regular physical activity and maintain a balanced diet. Mental health is equally important ¡ª try meditation, yoga, or even self-care routines to help manage stress. 9. Practice Gratitude: Develop the habit of being thankful for what you have. This doesn¡¯t mean you should stop striving for more, but acknowledging your privileges can boost happiness and optimism. 10. Seek Feedback: Regular feedback from friends, family, or mentors can keep you grounded and helps identify areas of improvement.  Remember, it's a step by-step process and changes won't occur overnight. Be patient, consistent, and persistent in your efforts.

column1: The first step for making this sort of change is being motivated to change and it sounds like you have that, so you are already on the right track.As far as learning how to listen, try some of these steps:Ask whether a certain time is a good time for your girlfriend to have an important conversationIf she has a subject that she would like to discuss, consider listening to her as an investigative reporter and asking questions that help you to gain more understanding of her experience. These questions usually begin with words like who, what, where, when. Questions starting with the word why can sometimes make people very uncomfortable because they may not explicitly know why they are asking for something or feeling a certain way. You can try communicating this way for just five minutes or so on until you feel as though you can restate what your girlfriend is saying and have her agree that you are recapturing the essence of what she is trying to communicateThen you can switch so she is listening to you trying to understand your experience. You could also start by talking about something that is important to you.Remember that stating that you follow or hear something that she is saying doesn't mean that you agreeAlso, try sticking to one subject at a time. It's difficult to really understand one topic if you are on to the next within just a minute or twoTry to use the word want or wish instead of need. Saying that you need something (or if your girlfriend would say that) that is not a need for safety or something like that can make whatever you are asking for sound like an obligation. That takes away from that whole motivation to change from inside the partner who is agreeing to change or try to changeSomething else to try would be using some sort of timeout. Consider this:Discuss the idea of using timeout before you actually need it and before the discussion starts. Timeout is a way to give each of you a way to calm down for five, 10, 15 minutes, or maybe even an hour. When there are a lot of emotions happening, each person gets wrapped up in protecting themselves from the emotions they are feeling and can lose track of what is actually going on in the conversation as compared to what they are perceiving.When using timeout, say to your girlfriend (or she can say to you) "I need an hour before we can go back to this." Then actually come back to the discussion.Some people are very afraid to use this technique because in the past not talking about something right away meant that it never was returned to and was never resolved in any way. This is why the agreement is important before you need it.While it may be helpful to ask your girlfriend what it is she may want from you, it is you that would be in charge of deciding whether you want to make that change and putting it into practice.Try to remember that part of being in a couple is holding onto your own wants, wishes, and desires while recognizing those of your partner.As one final idea, consider spending about 15 minutes a week together where you are not problem-solving about anything, just connecting with one another.I encourage you to see a therapist who specializes in couples if you would like some more specific ideas for what is happening within each of you and between you.Best wishes!
column2: That's a commendable goal. Here are some steps you can take to achieve this: 1. Self-awareness: Start by realizing your strengths and weaknesses. Be honest with yourself and acknowledge your flaws. 2. Set clear goals: Outline what areas in your life you want to become better in. Is it in your career, relationships, health? Concrete goals will guide your path towards becoming a better man. 3. Keep learning: Never stop educating yourself. Whether it's about communication skills, emotional intelligence, conflict resolution or professional skills, always strive to learn more. 4. Practice kindness: Be kind to others and yourself. Treat people with the respect and understanding that you would like to be treated with. This includes being considerate of people's feelings, being helpful and giving back to the community. 5. Stay healthy: Physical health is as important as mental health. Exercise regularly, eat a balanced diet and get enough sleep.  6. Cultivate positive habits: Regularly engage in activities that you love and that contribute to your growth. This could be reading, meditating, painting, hiking - anything that brings you joy and peace. 7. Show gratitude: Appreciating what you have in life brings contentment. It also makes you mindful of others' roles in your life and inculcates humility. 8. Be responsible: Accept responsibility for your actions and understand that every decision has consequences. 9. Nurture relationships: Show appreciation and love for your family and friends. Invest time and effort in maintaining strong, healthy relationships. 10. Seek professional help: If you feel overwhelmed or unable to manage on your own, it's okay to seek help from a professional such as a life coach or a therapist. They can provide guidance and tools to help in your journey.  Remember, the goal is progress, not perfection. Take one step at a time and be patient with yourself. This is a lifelong journey. Your ambition to become a better man is already a step in the right direction.

column1: Let go of your ego, the ego tends to get in the way of things, be a man and listen, do not react so uch to life around you. life is not out to get you, just listen and work on how your reactive to people and sitations around you. C
column2: That's a noble goal. Here are some steps you can take: 1. Practice self-awareness: Be conscious of your actions, words and thoughts. Reflect on how they affect others around you.    2. Build emotional intelligence: Understand and manage your emotions. Practice empathy and understanding towards others.     3. Improve communication skills: Good communication is key to every relationship. Make efforts to speak clearly, confidently, and thoughtfully.     4. Show kindness and respect: Treat people with kindness and respect regardless of their status. A man of quality doesn't fear equality. 5. Be responsible: Take charge of your decisions and actions. Admit your mistakes and learn from them.     6. Practice patience and tolerance: Maintain your calm even in stressful and frustrating situations.  7. Strive for self-improvement: Continuously aim to improve yourself. Set new goals and work hard to achieve them.     8. Cultivate healthy habits: Look after your physical health through regular exercise, a balanced diet, and adequate sleep.     9. Develop a positive attitude: Try to see the positive aspect of things. Negativity can bring you and others down.     10. Honesty and integrity: Always be true to your words and maintain your principles and standards in all situations.     11. Seek help if needed: Do not hesitate to seek help, professional or otherwise, if needed. It's a part of self-care and there's no shame in that.     12. Follow through with commitments: When you make a commitment, stick to it. This shows a reliability. Remember, it's not about being "perfect". It's about striving to be better than you were yesterday.

column1: I'm glad to read about your willingness to develop new ways to invest yourself with your partner.The easier way to fix a relationship is when both people are helped to recognize the ways the couple dynamic falls short of what each person would like.Couples therapy is exactly this.Still, relationships can change if one person changes since changing one part of a system will change the system itself.Besides starting to work with a therapist on what you can do differently, reflect within yourself on the situations when problems arise between the two of you.See if you can figure out what you wanted and what you partner wanted in that particular moment. Was one of you trying to help the other and the person felt insulted by the suggestion of needing help?This is only an example of how intentions are misread or not welcome by one partner from the other.Also keep in mind there is a limit to everyone's flexibility.Reflecting and self-awareness are the first step.The second step is to know when you've reached the end of possibilities to change yourself and not be accepted for who you are.This raises the question of whether the two of you are far apart in similarities in order to be happy together.Good luck in enjoying the changes you will try to make!
column2: Becoming a better man is all about personal growth and improvement. Here are some tips: 1. Prioritize Integrity: Always be honest, transparent, and reliable. Treat people with respect and fairness.  2. Practice Empathy: Try to understand and share the feelings of others.  3. Be Responsible: Honor your commitments, accept the consequences of your actions, and don't try to shift the blame onto others. 4. Maintain Healthy Relationships: Whether it's with a spouse, children, friends, or family, make an effort to build strong, positive, and healthy relationships.  5. Improve Communication Skills: Effective communication is important in all aspects of life. It can help you connect with others, express your ideas, and solve problems. 6. Self-Care: Taking care of your physical health is just as important as mental and emotional health. Regular exercise, good nutrition, enough sleep, and reduced stress are essential for overall well-being. 7. Continuous learning: Never stop learning, because life never stops teaching. Learn from your mistakes and experiences. 8. Show Gratitude: Be thankful for what you have and express it freely. Gratitude helps build positive relationships and a good state of mind. 9. Respect Others: Regardless of your personal views, always respect others' rights to their own beliefs and lifestyle choices.  10. Be Generous: Practice giving without expecting anything in return. It can be your time, skills or resources.  Remember, becoming a better man is a journey, not a destination. It requires regular self-reflection, and it's done at your own pace. Never compare your growth to that of others. Everyone's journey is unique. Keep striving to improve, take one step at a time, and eventually, you'll get there.

column1: Hard to say a whole lot without knowing more. However, if you focus your attention on her, what she's saying, what she's feeling instead of trying to make yourself heard and understood first, that's often a good step. Also, work on building win-win agreements with her, and follow through on them. Those are the areas I see men fall short on most often. Hope that helps!
column2: That's a very noble goal. Here are a few steps to help you achieve that: 1. Cultivate Self-Awareness: Understand who you are, your values, beliefs, and purpose. Acknowledge your strengths and weaknesses, and your impact on others. 2. Practice Kindness and Empathy: Try to put yourself in others' shoes, understand their feelings, and respond with kindness. Do something nice for others without expecting anything in return. 3. Be Respectful: Always show respect to others, no matter their status or differences. Respect others' opinions and learn to agree to disagree. 4. Be Honest: Always tell the truth but find a polite and kind way to do so.  5. Learn to Communicate: Good communication starts with listening. Learn to actively listen without formulating your reply even before the other person has stopped talking. 6. Learn and Grow: Never stop learning. Read books, listen to podcasts, or take courses. Always work to become a better version of yourself than yesterday.  7. Have Healthy Habits: Eating healthy and exercising regularly not only makes you feel and look good, but it also cultivates discipline.  8. Accept responsibility: Take responsibility for your actions and decisions. Step up, admit when you're wrong, and do what you can to make things right. 9. Cultivate Patience: Instead of getting frustrated when things don't go as planned, try to see it as an opportunity to practice patience. 10. Surround Yourself With Good People: The people around you can either lift you up or bring you down. Choose your circle wisely. Remember, becoming a better man is a process, not a destination. It takes time, effort, and constant self-evaluation. Remember not to be too hard on yourself.

column1: Both options seem reasonable.  Seeking individual therapy will help you to cope with the mood changes that come with bipolar disorder, will give you a space to vent your negative thoughts, and will allow you to find the coping mechanism to address life and relational challenges.  IF your boyfriend is interested in attending couples therapy with you, it will assist in identifying the problems in the relationship that pushed him to the breakup and will give both of you the tools to communicate and resolve conflicts.I am a Licensed Professional Counselor in Texas, currently providing individual, couples, and family therapy services in West Houston.  You may reach me at 787-466-5478 to schedule an appointment.  ?Deber¨ªa buscar ayuda yo sola o junto con mi novio?Mi novio me dejo recientemente por ser mal hablada.  El piensa que soy una p***a.  Yo s¨¦ que soy bipolar y que puedo ser ego¨ªsta.  El me llamo hoy para decirme que no puede continuar separado.  Yo estaba destruida y no quer¨ªa que nos dej¨¢ramos desde el inicio, pero se lo horrible que puedo ser a veces y que no lo puedo evitar.  Es como si estuviera en guerra conmigo misma.  ?Qu¨¦ piensas?Ambas opciones son razonables.  Buscar terapia individual te ayudara a manejar los cambios de estado de ¨¢nimo que son partes del desorden bipolar, tambi¨¦n te dar¨¢ espacio para ventilar los pensamientos negativos y encontrar herramientas para enfrentar problemas relacionales y de la vida diaria.  SI tu novio est¨¢ interesado, tambi¨¦n pueden asistir a terapia de pareja para poder identificar las razones de la separaci¨®n, y obtener las herramientas apropiadas para  comunicarse apropiadamente y resolver conflictos.  Soy Consejera Profesional Licenciada en Texas y Puerto Rico, veo clientes en el este de Houston y proveo servicios de tele terapia.  Para una cita puedes llamar al 787-466-5478.
column2: As, I don't have enough context to give a personalized advice. However, the decision depends largely on the problem you're facing. If it's about personal mental health, seeking individual counseling might be better initially. But if it's about relationship issues, couples therapy could be beneficial. Sometimes, doing both could be helpful. Always consult with a professional for a sound advice.

column1: Well, as disappointed as you may very well feel from hearing this guy's answer, you know he doesn't want a relationship.What type of move would you like him to make?If you mean you'd be happy to have sex with this guy and not a relationship, then wait for as long as your patience allows.To wait for him to change his mind that he does want a relationship, doesn't have a very strong base on which to stand.Its possible to do this only consider the emotional price of your frustration to wait for someone to change their mind.
column2: As, I don't know the specifics of your situation. However, here are a few things to consider. Reflect on your feelings and evaluate how patient you can be with him. Check if there is enough indication that he's interested in you. You could also try communicating openly with him about your feelings. In the end, only you know what's best for you.

column1: Attraction is important but sometimes over-rated. I'm curious about your comment that you are not as attracted as you "should be" - What is your measuring stick is for what you are supposed to feel in terms of attraction in a relationship? Do you want to be sexually intimate? Do you enjoy having sex with him? Are you satisfied with your sexual relationship when you are with him? The fact that there is lust for other more attractive men does not necessarily mean anything. There will always be attractive men and more attractive men than your partner and these attractive men will be even more appealing when you are in a long-distance relationship far from the arms of your partner. Loving someone does not mean that you stop being a sexual being who no longer notices and desires attractive men. Attraction results from a number of factors beyond appearance - including the degree to which you feel emotionally open, safe, and connected and how in tune you are with each other's bodies. It sounds like you think very highly of this man "everything else is perfect about him". Maybe it is worth spending some more time together in the same place if that is possible before deciding on marriage or that you are not truly in love.
column2: Attraction is a very complex thing and is not always based on someone being the 'perfect guy'. There are many layers and elements to attraction, some of which include physical attraction, intellectual attraction, and emotional attraction. If you are not attracted to this person it could be for several reasons. It might be that you don't find them physically attractive. Alternatively, you might not feel an emotional or intellectual connection to them. Or it could be that you're just not ready for a serious relationship right now.  Being attracted to someone is so much more than their looks or personality traits. It's about a connection that is difficult to explain and often comes with spending time with the person and really getting to know them. If you're not feeling this connection, it's okay and perfectly normal. Attraction can't be forced and it's important to listen to your gut feeling. Remember, just because he is perfect on paper doesn't mean he is perfect for you. Trust your feelings and do what makes you happy.

column1: The basic guideline for relationship satisfaction, is to know what you can and cannot live with and without.  And, since you are considering marriage, for how long do you imagine yourself being satisfied living with and without certain qualities of your partner.There is a hard wired dynamic between two people that defines the basic structure of the relationship.While life is filled with surprises and can change in an instant, the basic way in which the partners of a couple, connect.Do you understand why you are not attracted to your partner?  Whatever the reason, now is a good time to state this about yourself.  He may be quite willing and interested in developing new ways of sexually stimulating you.  Maybe he is just as shy about talking about this topic as you are.  On some level he must know that he doesn't satisfy you.  He may be relieved to hear you bring up the topic!As always, remember that if discussing a relationship matter feel hard to start, consider utilizing therapy services with a professional, credentialed and licensed therapist.
column2: Attraction is a complex aspect of relationships. He may be perfect on paper, but if there's no chemistry, it can be a significant challenge. Sometimes emotional attraction can grow over time, especially if you share common interests and enjoy each other's company.  However, if you've been trying for a while and still aren't feeling it, it might be best to talk about this situation with him. It's not fair to either of you to stay in a relationship where you're not fully invested. Honest and open communication is the key. If even after these efforts, there is still a lack of attraction, it's okay to step back. You can't force yourself to feel something that is not there. By doing so, you could end up prolonging your unhappiness and causing more heartbreak in the end.  Always remember, it's okay not to be attracted to someone even if they seem 'perfect.' Your feelings are valid. And it is important to choose a partner that you naturally feel attracted to.
