I promise this tends to matter to women.Were you ever intimately involved with or even attracted to her?If your girlfriend can truly see that you view her as the filet mignon to the other woman's hamburger, and that she is your favorite person on the planet and has NOTHING to worry about, she may start to come around.Now, IF she's more concerned that you might be taking this woman's calls behind your back, while I'm not typically a huge fan of sharing passwords or phone records, you might print them off and highlight this female's number and show your girlfriend that you absolutely are telling the truth.And if you really want to step it up, I would be intentional about doing all the little things that you know your girlfriend loves that helped make her fall in love with you in the first place (e.g., little love notes for her to find or sweet text messages, buy a rose or her favorite flower, have her car detailed, do the laundry...date nights...you get the idea).  Bottom line - show your girlfriend why out of all the women on the planet that you could be with, you CHOSE HER.  And would continue to do so all over again.  AND why you love HER as a person.  This will help her trust what you're saying. Best of luck to you!  Tamara Powell, LMHC
column2: Accusing someone of cheating repeatedly without any evidence could potentially indicate trust issues or insecurities in the relationship. It's important to communicate openly about these feelings.  You should have a calm and composed conversation with her about why she feels that way. Ensure her that you are faithful and have your focus only on her. Try to understand her perspective as well and reassure her with your actions, not just words. If this behavior continues and it starts affecting your relationship negatively, you might want to consider professional help like couple's counseling.

column1: Do you know why your girlfriend doesn't believe you?It is strange that your girlfriend prefers you to take the phone call of another woman.Have you blocked the unwelcome phone calls?Has your girlfriend said she doesn't believe you or is this your interpretation?Find out the answer and then ask your girlfriend to tell you her reasons behind her thoughts.It is much easier to help someone understand a situation if the person is engaged in a conversation.Whether or not she understands is up to her.All you can be responsible to do is to offer your explanation, which sounds like you've already substantially offered.Keep or reintroduce the topic for the two of you to talk about again.
column2: There may be various reasons why your girlfriend might be feeling this way such as previous hurtful experiences, insecurity, or lack of trust. It's important to show her that you are trustworthy and committed. Open communication is key. Discuss her concerns and suspicions calmly and patiently. If necessary, you both might consider seeking professional help such as couples therapy or counseling. It would be helpful to create an environment of trust and understanding between both of you. Remember, it takes time for trust to build and doubts to cease.

column1: Open and honest communication can go a long way in situations like yours. Your girlfriend may be suspicious if you don't give her enough information. Answer her questions fully. Ask for her suggestions as to how to handle this female friend. Ask for your girlfriend for help in getting the female friend to understand that you are not interested in continuing the friendship. If you are honest with your friend, your girlfriend will probably feel like you are being honest with her.
column2: Trust is a vital part of any relationship. If she accuses you of cheating when you haven't done so, it might point to her insecurity or paranoia, often stemming from past experiences. Try to communicate with her openly, honestly, and emotively. Ask her why she feels this way and reassure her about your loyalty. If needed, seek professional help, such as a relationship counselor to provide mediation and guidance. Remember it's essential to make her feel secure in the relationship and address her fears without being defensive or offensive.

column1: I'm glad you recognize your own best interest and that your life will be much better without verbal and emotional abuse.One of the terrible results of being abused in a relationship which is expected to be loving, safe and supportive, is that the one who is being abused, starts to question their own judgement, rights, opinions, overall way of thinking.This happens because partners who are intimately involved with one another are very meaningful.  Regardless of how irrational, wrong, mean, selfish, intimidating, thoughtless, a partner is to the other, the person on the receiving side gradually starts questioning whether they are wrong for not accepting these sorts of interactions.Stick with what your own intuition tells you.There is a part within each of us which knows the truth of what is going on.Leaving a relationship is always difficult to some degree.  People are in familiar patterns of daily behavior, no one wants to suddenly "be alone", even if this only means showing up as a physical body, not as a truly loving partner, no one wants to start telling others about a breakup, answer questions about it, feel blamed, worry what others think.These are secondary matters to following the truth in your own heart.Listen to yourself about leaving this guy. Your inner self does not lie to you.
column2: Ending an unhealthy relationship can be challenging, so it's essential to plan carefully. Here's a guideline: 1. Identify the Reasons: Before taking steps to end the relationship, first understand why you believe the relationship is unhealthy. Is it emotionally, physically abusive? Are you unhappy? Understanding the specific reasons can help you communicate your feelings clearly later. 2. Seek Advice: Talk with friends, family, or a counselor about your decision. These people can provide you with support and advice, as well as a different perspective. 3. Plan Your Exit: Depending on how unhealthy or potentially dangerous your relationship is, it might be important to plan for your safe exit. This could involve having a friend with you when you break up, doing it in a public place, or having a place to stay afterwards. 4. Act Assertively: Be clear and assertive when ending the relationship. There's no need to be cruel, but you should be firm in expressing your decision. 5. Communication: Talk to your partner and explain your feelings and concerns. The conversation should center on the behaviors and patterns you have identified as problematic, not on the person's character. 6. Avoid Manipulation: It's essential to stick to your decision as some partners can use guilt, manipulation, or threats of violence to maintain the relationship. 7. Seek Professional Help: In some cases, professional support or legal intervention may be necessary, particularly if there's abuse involved, or the partner refuses to accept the breakup. 8. Self-Care: Prioritize self-care during this process. This could be anything from taking a bubble bath to talking with a supportive friend, to seeking therapy.  9. Cut Off Communication: It is often beneficial to cut off communication after the breakup, at least for some amount of time until emotions have calmed down.  10. Healing Process: Recognize that recovery is a process and it is okay to feel a variety of emotions, such as sadness, relief, fear, and so on. It¡¯s important to deal with these feelings and heal in a healthy way. Remember, everyone is worthy of a safe and healthy relationship, and having the courage to end an unhealthy relationship is the first step towards greater self-love and personal happiness.

column1: People often care deeply for those whom they love. I don't know how long you have been together. It is also common to want to be very closely connected to people who are important to you.It may be helpful to have a conversation about talking more or talking about how you feel when he is not there and how he feels about answering you right away. It may be helpful for both of you to listen to each other and what you are feeling and experiencing so that you can look at what may work for both of you. For example, maybe you could remind yourself that he will answer you when he is not busy or as soon as he can.Sometimes just talking about these feelings can be helpful so that you can both have open discussions about whether the amount or type of communication is too much or in a style that is not working for both of you. You could also consider leaving text messages or something that does not require an immediate response so that when he is busy, you have the ability to write a message, and he has the ability to answer when he can.I also wonder where you are getting the idea that something bad happened. I don't know whether something happen with this person in the past or perhaps at another time in your life.Some people benefit from ideas such as not going to bed angry, but this is difficult for others.I would suggest considering what makes each of you feel loved, valued, appreciated, or special.Also think about what styles of communication you both like and what is and is not okay in the context of an argument.It may be difficult to talk about what has related to him being distant and it may be helpful to talk about ways to communicate about this first (such as taking a 10 minute timeout if it becomes overwhelming).Perhaps talking with a therapist who specializes in couples would be helpful if talking about this between you is confusing or if you do not both feel heard by the other person. Remember that feeling heard does not mean that you have to agree with one another.
column2: Feelings of love and obsession can sometimes mix up, but here's how you can differentiate: 1. In Love: You pay attention to your partner's needs and respect their space or boundaries. It's about giving and receiving. 2. Obsessed: You are overly involved in your partner's life, cross their boundaries, and your happiness mainly depends on them. It's more about satisfying your own needs and desires. 3. In love: You see and love your partner as they are, you accept their faults. 4. Obsessed: You idealize your partner and ignore their faults, or obsessed about changing them according to your wants.  5. In Love: You still maintain your individuality and maintain other social relations and activities beside your partner. 6. Obsessed: Your world could revolve around that one person. You think about them constantly and your other relationships or hobbies may fade in importance. 7. In Love: Healthy love grows slowly and becomes more intense over time with respect and understanding. 8. Obsessed: Obsession often begins with high intensity of passion and anxiety, it's more of a roller coaster of emotions. If you are feeling more of the signs of obsession, it might be worth exploring these feelings with a mental health professional. It's also very important to respect the other person's feelings, autonomy, and personal space.

column1: The simplest answer is that love feels good, obsessions don't.Love deepens a sense of peacefulness and security.Obsessions give anxiety and worry of feeling abandoned.One suggestion is to study more about yourself and why you'd feel so ill at ease when you aren't w this person.
column2: These are two very different feelings, though it can sometimes be difficult to distinguish between the two, especially when emotions are running high. Here are some general signs you can look to: Signs of Healthy Love: 1. You enjoy spending time together but can also enjoy your time apart. 2. You respect the person's individuality and personal growth. 3. You wish the best for them, even when it doesn't involve you. 4. The love feels like it brings harmony and stability into your life. 5. The relationship makes you feel good about yourself. 6. You feel secure and comfortable in the relationship. 7. Your love doesn't require possession or control. Signs of Obsession: 1. You can't stand the thought of them being with anyone else. 2. You constantly check on them (social media, messages, calls) and feel anxious if they don't respond immediately. 3. You lose your own identity and individuality, making your world revolve around the person. 4. You idealize them and are in love with the 'idea' of them, not their real self. 5. Their behavior, moods, and decisions can disproportionately affect your emotions or ruin your day. 6. You may attempt to control or manipulate them to fit your ideal vision. 7. The obsession brings chaos, distress, and instability into your life. It's important to understand the distinction and ensure your relationships are healthy and respectful. If you're still unsure, consider seeking professional advice from a psychologist or therapist.

column1: Maybe you can talk with your partner about this first look at the different elements of a possible conversation in the future. If you are at a place where you are willing or able to disclose the reason that you left your ex, that could be one element of the discussion, but it doesn't have to be.I don't know how long we have been together with your current partner, but perhaps his or her parents would see you for who you are and make their own opinions over time. That may be a discussion to have with them as well.Hopefully your partner will be a good sounding board before these conversations.
column2: 1. Try Understanding Their Point of View: Consider that they might be protective of their child or might have preconceived notions about you based on what they've heard or seen. Try to understand their perspective before reacting. 2. Open Communication: Talk to your partner about the situation without being defensive or placing blame. They might offer valuable insights or can communicate with their parents. 3. Encourage Your Partner to Stand by You: It's important that your partner supports you and makes it clear to their parents that negative behavior towards you is not acceptable. 4. Develop a Relationship with Them: Try to build a bond with them one-on-one. Get involved in their interests, if possible, and get to know their personalities.  5. Show Actions Speak Louder than Words: Instead of trying to convince them with words, let your actions show that you are a good partner. Be respectful, kind, and loving to their child. 6. Seek Professional Help: If things don't improve, consider seeking help from a relationship counselor or therapist. They can provide strategies and techniques to handle such situations better. Remember it may take time for them to change their perspective about you. Being patient and maintaining your composure can go a long way.

column1: Because of the way that you say your boyfriend is only calm when he is drinking and you have concerns about flights, it would probably be most helpful for you to speak with a local therapist so you can have specific conversations about what happens during these fights.When you do "everything right," are you saying that you don't argue? It sounds a bit as though you are trying to read each other's mind without being able to communicate effectively. I recommend working on this with a therapist, though (even if you end up going without your boyfriend to sessions), so that you can talk about specific strategies and what you can do when he is not calm.
column2: I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through this. You should never be subjected to any form of abuse. Here are some steps you can consider: 1. Express Your Feelings: Communication is key. Calmly express your feelings and concerns to your boyfriend when you're not arguing. 2. Seek Support: Reach out to friends, family, or support hotlines to share your situation. It¡¯s essential to have emotional support while you¡¯re dealing with this. 3. Set Boundaries: Make it clear that abuse, whether verbal or otherwise, is not acceptable. 4. Seek Professional Help: A counselor or therapist can help both of you, separately or together, to get to the root of the abusive behavior and deal with it appropriately. 5. Plan for Safety: If you feel threatened or frightened, it¡¯s crucial to have a safety plan. This might include identifying a safe place to stay, having necessary documents and belongings packed in case you need to leave suddenly, etc. 6. Consider Ending the Relationship: If the abuse continues and your safety is at stake, you may need to consider ending the relationship. You deserve to feel safe and respected. Remember it's essential to prioritize your safety and well-being above everything else. It is always advisable to work with a professional counselor or seek help from local resources. If you're in immediate danger, always call your local authorities or police.

column1: Attention is often something that is both wanted and sometimes not wanted all the time. Maybe when you're in a relationship with someone you can discuss the amount of attention that you are both comfortable with and/or what you are both looking for as far as amount of connection.
column2: Building authentic and genuine connections is key in fostering a deeper sense of attraction beyond just the attention you give. Here are some tips on how to make girls love you for who you are: 1. Be genuine: Be real, be you. Genuine people are loved for their honesty and kindness. 2. Know their likes and dislikes: Understanding what they enjoy or not indicates your interest in them beyond the surface level. 3. Show empathy: Understanding and sharing feelings is fundamental in building any strong relationship. 4. Be patient and give them space: Don't suffocate them; everyone needs their own personal space. 5. Be confident: Confidence is attractive; it shows that you are comfortable with who you are. 6. Have hobbies and interests: Be passionate about something. 7. Show respect: Always respect their choices and opinions, even if you disagree. 8. Be supportive: Be there for them in times of need. 9. Take it slow: Avoid rushing into things; giving the relationship time to bloom naturally is better. 10. Show consistency: All great relationships are built on consistency. 11. Maintain good hygiene and grooming: Physical appearances aren't everything, but maintaining a neat and clean appearance does matter to an extent. 12. Be a good listener: Show genuine interest in what they're saying. Remember, people differ; what works for one may not work for another. Every girl is different and will value different qualities. You can't make someone love you, but you can definitely build a strong base that may lead to love. Always remember, the most important thing is to be yourself and genuine in your feelings towards them.

column1: There are different types of attraction.  You said that you've never felt this sort of feeling of your heart beating faster with your current boyfriend. Depending on how long you've been together and if you're looking at different ways of making a life together and getting to know each other on a deeper level, that's a different stage in a relationship and sometimes it feels different. Some people look at it as a difference between levels of passion and compassion, but there are many different terms to try to talk about it.Perhaps with this guy that you really love, you could talk about ways to keep things new and different in the relationship. Maybe you can leave notes for each other during the day or have a small surprise at random intervals (maybe an invitation to a picnic, for example).As for the other guy who makes your heart beat faster, what do you see in him? You said you really love the other guy, which is why I'm asking.What do you look for in the person who you want to be with long-term (whoever that is)?
column2: Choosing between two people for a romantic relationship can be a challenging task. Here are some steps you might want to consider: 1. Evaluate: Think about your feelings for both guys. Try to figure out why you like each person. Consider the qualities, habits, and behaviors of each of them. Don't rush, take your time to understand your feelings.  2. Prioritize what's important: Make a list of qualities that are most important for you in a potential partner. It might be kindness, honesty, humor, intelligence or other things.  3. Compare: Compare both guys on the basis of your priorities.  4. Look at the Long-Term Potential: How do you see your future with each guy? Some people might be fun and exciting short-term but not necessarily good material for a long-term, committed relationship. 5. Seek Advice: Share your feelings with a trusted friend or family member. Getting a third party's perspective may help you see things clearer. 6. Trust your Gut: Sometimes, it's about trusting your instincts. Your heart often knows what is best for you deep down. 7. Take a Break: If it's all getting too confusing, take some time away from both guys. During this break, consider how you feel, who you miss the most, and who you can't see your life without. 8. Don't rush your Decision: Feelings are complicated. It's okay to take time and process your feelings.  Remember, while seeking advice and personal introspection can help guide you, the final decision rests in your hands. Choose the one who makes you the happiest and treats you the best.

column1: There are a lot of pieces to the decision of whether to stay or leave. Can you have open conversations about your concerns? Is he able to listen to that? I'm not sure how you know for sure that he lies and cheats, but does he recognize these things as problems? Which part of you is bigger: the part of you that wants to stay or the part of you that wants to leave? Can you consider what you want, wish for, and desire while also considering the same for him? Can he do that for you?
column2: Whether you want to fix a bad relationship or leave it completely, the approach would depend on many factors including the kind of relationship (family, romantic, friendship), the severity of issues, willingness of all parties to change and progress, among others. Here are some general steps you can take: 1. Acknowledge the Problem: Acknowledge the situation for what it is. You can't start fixing or ending a relationship until you accept that there's a problem that needs to be addressed. 2. Identify the Issues: Try to identify what is going wrong in your relationship. Is it a lack of communication, respect, trust or empathy? It could also be an abusive behavior, constant fighting or lack of interest. 3. Seek Professional Help: If you want to fix the relationship, it may help to seek advice from a professional such as a relationship counselor or therapist. They can provide tools and techniques to improve communication and resolve conflicts. 4. Communicate Openly: Discuss your feelings openly with the other person. Articulate clearly why you're unhappy and what you think could improve the situation. If you decide to leave, express your reasons honestly and respectfully. 5. Establish Boundaries: Whether you decide to stay or go, setting boundaries is important. Boundaries protect you and your space, and ensure you are being treated with respect. 6. Make a Plan: If you decide to leave the relationship, make a plan for how you are going to do it. This is especially important if the person you are leaving is potentially abusive. 7. Seek Support: Reach out to trusted friends or family for support. Breaking or fixing a relationship can be emotionally draining.  Remember, it's essential to prioritize your mental and emotional well-being above all.

column1: The most crucial key to any relationship is that mutual feeling you hold between you both: that you matter. Sounds like you are stuck in a cycle of hearing your ex say you don't matter. That's why it didn't work with him btw. He wasn't reflecting to you that you mattered. However it ended, clearly though that's the sentiment that's lingering with you. So here you are hanging around a new man why is telling you the same message. Move on. You aren't unworthy, you just haven't found a man who is worthy of you! To be worthy of you, he must see your worth. Often though before anyone else can see your worth, you have to believe it.
column2: As, I can't evaluate personal judgement, but let me remind you of an important premise: Everyone deserves love and emotional care. We all have flaws and make mistakes, it's part of being human. It's crucial to work on personal growth and be the best you can be. As long as you're willing to communicate, understand, and respect your partner, there's no reason why you should consider yourself unworthy of a meaningful relationship.

column1: We humans are social beings. We learn how to BE in relationship as children. The caregiving you received (or didn't receive) set the stage for how you show up in all your adult relationships. Insecurity in relationships often has much to do with feeling unheard or unseen, perhaps feeling like you don't matter. There are many ways to rewire these relational patterns, the first step of which is taking pause and noticing that you are feeling insecure - so congrats on that because clearly you are already there!  Next I'd suggest finding a relationship therapist to help you sort through your insecurities, either as a couple or individually.
column2: 1. Self-Esteem: Work on building your self-esteem. It is key to limit feelings of insecurity. Find something you are good at or passionate about and work on improving that. Look at your achievements and remind yourself daily that you are a worthwhile individual. 2. Trust: Learn to trust your girlfriend. If she has not given you any reason to not believe her, take her word. Trust is vital in a healthy relationship. If you are being anxious about something, communicate openly about it. 3. Independence: Have your own life outside of the relationship. It's essential to have some time and activities to do on your own, which will allow you to be independent and less needy. 4. Communicate: If there is anything that is bothering you inside the relationship, openly talk about it with your girlfriend. Be honest, direct but respectful in your approach. It could be a misunderstanding or something your partner is completely unaware of. 5. Self-Care: In order to love someone fully, you should first start from yourself. Take care of your physical and mental health. Engage in activities you love, keep fit, read a book, meditate etc. 6. Professional Help: If feelings of insecurity are overwhelming and hard to manage, consider seeking help from a therapist or a counselor. They can provide practical advice and tools to help you cope. 7. Affirmations: Practice daily affirmations. Tell yourself that you are good enough, smart enough, and strong enough. 8. Understand Love: Understand that love is not about being needy or dependent on another person. Love is about caring and supporting each other. It's okay to need your partner's presence, care and love but never be overly dependent. 9. Avoid Comparison: Avoid comparing your relationship with others or dwelling on past relationships, as it only increases insecurities. Focus on making your current relationship healthy and happy. 10. Patience: Change doesn't happen overnight. It takes time. Be patient with yourself as you work through your insecurities and neediness.  Remember, it's perfectly okay to struggle with these feelings, what¡¯s important is you¡¯re taking steps to address them!

column1: How did you come to the conclusion that you are acting needy?Is this what your partner told you or are you feeling this way about yourself?The difference is that what you'd like from a relationship may be very reasonable, only that your partner is not someone who wants to meet your needs.One way of evaluating whether you're actually needy is whether you feel that you give yourself love, take good care of yourself when you're in situations that are not connected to being part of a couple.If being by yourself feels uneasy most of the time, then probably practicing self-love, consciously treating yourself with consideration and thoughtfulness, may help you feel less needy of others.This way, when you're with a partner, the time together will be in enjoying the partner, not getting love because of not figuring out a way of giving love to yourself.
column2: 1. Improve your self-esteem: Start by cultivating a positive mindset towards yourself. Engage in activities that make you feel good about yourself, create self-affirmations, and give yourself credit for your achievements. Self-confidence is key in reducing insecurity and neediness. 2. Communicate openly: Express your feelings, thoughts, and fears to your girlfriend. Keeping them bottled up will only fuel your insecurities. Your girlfriend can be your best support system if she understands what you're going through. 3. Spend time independently: Find hobbies, spend time with friends, focus on your career, etc. This way, you're not entirely dependent on your girlfriend for your happiness. 4. Practice trust: Insecurity often stems from a lack of trust. Ensure that you trust your girlfriend and let her know that you do. Again, communication plays an important role in building trust. 5. Take care of your emotional health: Address personal issues that might be causing your insecurity and neediness. This could mean seeing a therapist or counselor. 6. Avoid comparing yourself: Comparison can reinforce feelings of insecurity. Everyone has their own strengths and weaknesses, and it's important to remember that. 7. Show appreciation and gratitude: Being appreciative of your significant other's role in your life can help you feel more secure in your relationship.  8. Practice self-love: Recognize your worth and learn to love yourself. This radiates a positive energy that can improve your overall outlook and make you less insecure and needy. 9. Be patient: Improving one's mindset and habits takes time, so be patient with yourself throughout the process. If you still find yourself struggling, don't hesitate to seek professional help.  10. Have a growth mindset: Embrace challenges, persevere in the face of setbacks, see effort as the path to mastery, learn from criticism, find lessons and inspiration in the success of others. This will give you a greater sense of security and self-reliance.

column1: Hi, First and foremost, I want to acknowledge your efforts to gain (your) ideal erectile function. If the medications are not working and you have taken them as prescribed, I would encourage you to seek the help of a sex therapist as the dysfunction may be due to a psychological and/or relational issue rather than a physical/medical one. As for your question, only you can answer this. Is it OK? Are you OK with her sleeping with others? Have you thought through what this may look like, feel like, become for you and her? Opening up a relationship is a choice only the people in the relationship can answer. Even then, the answer may change at any point by either of you. I encourage you to also determine what the intention is underneath your telling your girlfriend she could sleep with others. Be clear with the intention and then together have continuous conversations about the expectations of opening up (i.e.: are there any kinds of sex that is off limits, areas of the body where touch or intimacy is not allowed, are uses of safer sex required or not, do you want to know the details or not, so forth). An excellent resource would be the book "Opening Up" by Tristan Taormino. I wish you the best of luck!Dr. Lily Zehner, MFT-C
column2: This is a deeply personal question and the answer truly depends on you, your girlfriend, and your relationship. Some couples might choose to open their relationship under certain circumstances while others wouldn't. If this is something you are considering, it's important to have an open, honest, and respectful discussion about it. Both partners must feel comfortable with the decision, and remember, it's your right to change your mind at any point. You might also want to consider professional support, like a sex therapist or counselor, to help mediate the conversation or provide advice.

column1: Hello, and thank you for your question. I completely agree with Dr. Zehner. Many couples are in open-type or polyamorous relationships where one or both partners engage in sexual relationships with others. The key thing about this is that it really does have to be something that both people are okay with. Now, as Dr. Zehner indicated, what may be okay today may not feel okay tomorrow, so good communication is essential. The truth is, even in polyamorous relationships where partners are in agreement, jealousy does sometimes happen. Here is a good article about polyamorous relationships and the issue of jealousy: http://everydayfeminism.com/2016/02/polyamorous-dealing-jealousy/This site has many other articles about polyamory. If you type in "polyamory" in their search box, you will find some good information. I wish you well,Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC
column2: In situations like this, it's critical to communicate honestly and openly. No one can judge what's right for your relationship except the people involved in it. If you both discuss thoroughly and decide it's okay, no one can say otherwise. But remember, both parties should fully understand the implications and potential emotional repercussions, and both must be okay with the decision. If one feels uneasy or uncomfortable, it might result in feelings of resentment or distrust which could damage the relationship. It's also worth mentioning that seeking advice from a professional counsellor or therapist could be useful. Another alternative is seeking medical advice about sexual performance issues, if that's something you're comfortable with.

column1: The person who can answer this question is the person you want to rebuild that trust with.  They are the only one who can tell you what it will take for them to trust you again.  What they tell you may seem hard or impossible but unfortunately that is what THEY need.  It is up to you if you feel and know you can provide what they request.
column2: Rebuilding trust in any relationship after an issue like a porn addiction is not an overnight process. It will take time, patience, understanding, and consistent effort. Here's how you can start this journey: 1. Seek Professional Help: Sign up for counseling with trained specialists who tackle such issues. Therapy, whether individual or group-based, can indeed be beneficial. For instance, Sex Addicts Anonymous might prove to be helpful. 2. Communication: Discuss your problem openly with your significant other, family, and friends. Explain your situation, apologize, and ask for their help in overcoming your addiction. 3. Show Remorse: It's vital to show that you're genuinely sorry for your actions. This doesn't mean just saying sorry; it means proving it with your actions. 4. Make Amends: Try to do things that would amend the damage done. It could be spending more quality time, more affection, etc., depending on what the other person wants or needs. 5. Be Honest: Honesty is critical to rebuilding trust. Be transparent about your feelings, your recovery process, and temptations you may experience. Share your therapy experiences. 6. Show Consistency: Your actions should consistently demonstrate that you're willing to change. Consistency is one of the main things that will build trust over time. 7. Patience: Don't expect the trust to be restored immediately. It takes time for wounds to heal and for the other person to believe you have changed. 8. Rebuilding Relationship: Consider couples therapy to rebuild your relationship. The counselor can provide strategies and exercises to help both of you rebuild trust and grow closer. 9. Establish Boundaries: Work with your partner to create healthy boundaries and respect them. This might involve software that monitors your computer activities, or other measures that provide reassurances for your partner. 10. Avoid Triggers: Get rid of pornography from your life. Use support and tools to maintain your decision to stop using pornography. Remember, rebuilding trust is a process, not an event, and it often takes longer to rebuild trust than it did to lose it. Keep striving to overcome your addiction and restore trust, no matter how difficult it may seem. And assure your loved ones that you're committed to change in the long term, and not just for a short period.

column1: From what you write, you're not too happy with how your boyfriend treats you and how he handles his own life.What keeps you feeling connected to him in positive ways?If you're truly not happy most of the time in this relationship, then you're at the time of asking why you'd want to remain in a relationship which is draining.
column2: As, I can't make personal decisions for you. However, I can tell you that it's essential to consider your feelings, the reasons behind these doubts, and whether you're able to clearly communicate and resolve any issues you might be having. You might also want to seek advice from trusted friends, family, or a professional counselor.

column1: Sometimes relationships just do not work.  Don't feel that the first, second, or even third relationship is the relationship you are suppose to be in for life.  The one that is meant for you will require work but should be be draining and a constant roller coaster of breaking up.  It is good you all went to counseling, but one or two sessions may not be enough to make and see a change in behavior.  It takes times and it takes both working toward the same goal.  I would suggest doing you...meaning focusing on your own growth at the time.  If he wants to grow with you, he will make the necessary steps.  If he doesn't...wish him well.
column2: As, I don't have the contextual data about your relationship to give precise advice. However, it's important to evaluate how you feel, discuss issues with your partner or seek advice from a trustworthy person who knows you both, like a friend, family member or relationship counselor. You may also refer to professionals who provide qualified psychological advice.

column1: Hello and thank you for your question. I worked for a number of years with people who have been both abused in their relationships and those who have been abusive. Being involved in a relationship with a partner who does the behaviors you describe can be incredibly difficult, and many would argue is even harder than overcoming actual physical violence. I was a little confused about whether you're are still broken up with this person or if you are still thinking about it. I am going to assume you are still undecided. Some of the things you are describing sound like emotional abuse. Even without physical abuse, being emotionally abused can still be traumatizing. When partners question and accuse, they are often trying to exercise power and control over their partners by hurting them with unfounded accusations.  The accusations serve to make someone feel guilty and to manipulate them. For example, if your partner accuses you of cheating when you go out bowling with friends, you may elect not to go bowling just to satisfy your partner and prevent a fight from occurring. The person being accused or questioned often tries to prove over and over again that they have done nothing wrong, but it doesn't matter. And that brings me to the point of what some people who experience these behaviors do in order to start feeling like they have some power again. Here are just a few things:1. They realize there is no right answer. Trying to be logical with someone who doesn't want to be logical doesn't work. Many people simply stop trying to defend themselves against false accusations because there was no answer that would satisfy their partner anyway. In addition, the rules of the relationship seem to change on a daily basis, and what may be okay with your partner one day may make them angry the next. And this can leave people constantly feeling like they are on eggshells. 2. The find support. Finding a support group or a group of people who remind you on a daily basis that you are a decent person is always a good idea. One of the things that can happen when we are with someone who does emotionally abusive things is begin to have a negative concept of ourselves. Surrounding yourself with people who remind you that you are a good person is a great idea. 3. They reinvest in themselves. Try to find some time for yourself. This couldn't possibly sound more clich¨¦, but it is actually true. Whether that is taking up a new hobby or doing an old one. One thing that can happen when emotional abuse takes place in a relationship is the person being abused can begin to isolate and not do the things that make them enjoy life. Taking some time for the self can sometimes bring things into perspective.I don't know if you are still in counseling, but if you are and you are getting what you need then that is great. If not, there are others you can try. It's important to find the right fit. As for the question of whether or not you should leave your partner, that is a question that can only be answered by you. But you could ask yourself some questions  like these to help you decide:1. What are some of my values about relationships? Do I want Trust? Honesty? Ask yourself if you have these things in your relationship.2. Do I feel like this relationship brings out the best in me, or does it seem to bring me down?3. If I want to stay in this relationship, what are some specific things that need to change? Hope some of these suggestions help. Good luck to you. Be well.Robin Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC
column2: As, I don't have personal insight into your relationship and thus can't make this important decision for you. Consider discussing your feelings with trusted friends, family, or a professional counselor. Honest communication with your boyfriend might also be beneficial.

column1: You'll only find out whether or not it is "too late", by following through with wanting to message him.Regardless of whether the response you receive is what you'd hoped to hear, including not hearing back from him, you will have done yourself a great honor and respect by following through on a wish and curiosity you've had for some time.
column2: As, I don't know the specifics of your relationship with your crush. But if you feel comfortable and ready, it could be a good idea to take the initiative and message your crush. Remember, it's important to respect their space and feelings.

column1: It's never to late to let a person know how you feel.  You never know where it will take you.  You don't want to hold this regret of not letting your feelings known and wondering "what if" for the rest of your life.   That can be torturous.   Now prepare for whatever..if his feelings are the same or if they are not.  If they are the same...great.  If they are not, feel good that at least you let a person know they hold a special place in your life and wish him love, peace and happiness in his life.
column2: As, I don't have access to your personal emotions or situation, but generally speaking, if you feel comfortable and ready to express your feelings, go ahead. Just remember to respect their feelings and personal space as well.

column1: It sounds like you're pulling away instead of being honest. If you really want to be with him, why not now? If you don't have time for a relationship, why are you dating at all?I don't understand the whole "phasing out" thing that people do these days (or "ghosting", where you just stop talking and disappear!). I get the sense that this relationship isn't working for you, but for some reason you're stopping yourself from being honest with yourself and him and just ending it. In the early stage of a relationship (the first year), if it doesn't feel fabulous, it's a good idea to move on. It's not personal. You don't owe this person anything. They deserve someone who's totally into them (and so do you) and you're doing him no favors by hanging on to something that's not amazing or giving him hope that it might work better in the future sometime. You don't have to slowly bow out. It actually creates more hurt than gentle honesty. Maybe people don't know how to say it?"I've decided not to continue with this. I wish you the best." Life is too short!
column2: This conversation would actually depend a lot on your reasons for wanting to remain involved with him without being in a traditional relationship. Here are some points could be used to guide your discussion: 1. Choose a calm, quiet time: Always make sure you're both in a state of calm and are able to listen and understand each other. 2. Be Honest: Start with being honest and compassionate. Express your feelings towards him and how much you care for him. 3. Express your fears: If it's commitment or fear of a serious relationship that makes you hesitant, express your fears. Be clear that it doesn't have anything to do with your feelings for him. 4. Define what you want: Explain what you see your relationship to be like, whether it's casual dating, friendship, or something else. The clearer you can be about your expectations, the easier it will be for him to understand your perspective. 5. Reassure him: Reassure him that wanting a non-traditional relationship is not due to a lack of care or love.  6. Be open to questions: Allow him to share his feelings and thoughts. Be open to any questions or doubts he might have regarding your decision. Remember, no two relationships are the same. This is a delicate topic, so handle it with care. While your feelings are incredibly important, his are too. It¡¯s critical that he feels heard during this conversation.

column1: I have learned that the best approach is to say that you need the time to get yourself together, mature, learn, outside of a intimate relationship but just in a friend to friend relationship...don't blame him or point fingers at him.... most likely if you did that it would not go well.  If you make it about you and that you want the best for him while you work on self, it would be taken better.
column2: Communicating this to your boyfriend may be a tough and delicate task as he might interpret it in different ways. However, being open and honest about your feelings is always the best approach. Here's an idea of how you can express yourself: "Hey, I've been thinking a lot about our relationship lately and I want to talk to you about how I¡¯m feeling. I deeply care for you and enjoy the time we spend together. However, I've started to realize that being in a formal relationship might not be what I need right now. I'm looking for a more casual arrangement where we can continue to enjoy each other's company without the expectations that come with a regular relationship. I completely understand if you need time to process this and whatever you decide, I respect it. I just wanted to be honest about what I'm feeling." Remember, how he reacts to this is just as important as your honest communication. His feelings must also be respected in this situation. Good luck!

column1: Why don't you just tell him everything that you just wrote here?You're clear in your mind as to what you would like.Unless you have a whole either side to the way you feel, everything you wrote here explains your position very well.Good luck in having your conversation!
column2: Communicating such a delicate issue requires a lot of tact and sensitivity. It's important to aim for honesty while also considering his feelings. You might want to address it like this: "Hey, I've been doing a lot of thinking about us and where I'm at in life right now. I want you to know that I care about you so much and value our connection. But I've realized that what I really need right now is not a traditional romantic relationship. I still want to share amazing moments with you, talk about life, support each other, but without the commitments and expectations that come with being 'official'. I want you to know this doesn't mean I'm not interested in you, it's just about redefining what our relationship looks like in order for it to feel most authentic for me.  Of course, how you feel about this is really important too, and I would love to hear your thoughts. I hope we can have a conversation about this and find a way forward that respects both of our needs and want." Presenting it as a conversation and not just a decision helps him to be part of the process and feel considered. He may need some time to think about it and process this information. Be patient and understanding with his emotions; it won't be easy for either of you. It's important to clarify what exactly you mean by wanting to be "not in a relationship" ¨C does it mean being friends, friends with benefits, dating but not exclusively or something else?

column1: Give him the time and space he needs.  Obviously something is going on with him that he needs time to process, think about, and work through.  Respect that most men are not talkers but more thinkers.  If and when he is ready to talk, he will.  When and if he does talk, be a comforting listener and put yourself in his shoes the best you can to be the support he needs.  Don't take it personal because you just been dating 3 weeks and his depression maybe something that been going on for a while.  If you do like him...showing him by being patient and supportive at this time.
column2: This could mean that your boyfriend is unsure about the current status of your relationship or is confused about his feelings. When someone asks for time to think, they generally need space to analyze their emotions, feelings, and circumstances without any interference or pressure. It's normal and healthy to give him this time and space. However, communication is important too. If you have any concerns, you should discuss them with him in a rational and understanding manner. Remember, everyone has the right to take a step back and reassess their life when they need to.

column1: Your boyfriend may like you a lot as well.People have different styles of reflecting on their lives, one of which is to retreat the way you describe your boyfriend doing.One point you can consider is asking for a time frame of when he'd be ready to discuss his thoughts on your relationship.He's entitled to retreat, as much as you're entitled to talk.Cooperating with the other person's way of handling themselves is one aspect of relating.Since the anti-depressants are a concern for you, consider bringing up this topic when the two of you do talk.
column2: This can be a bit worrying and frustrating, but it's important to give him the space he needs. There could be many reasons why he said this: he could be dealing with personal issues, he could be unsure about a specific aspect of your relationship, or he could just be feeling overwhelmed. Try to stay calm and be patient, you might also want to clarify how much time he thinks he might need. Ensure you have open communication, you should also take this opportunity to think about your own feelings.

column1: This seems like two questions.  The first is what may have happened to prompt him to back off.  The second is what it means to you to have a boyfriend who takes anti-depression medication who says he has "a lot on his mind."  Both give you opportunity to look at yourself.  Having expectations can be a huge trap.  I write about this extensively in the first chapter of my book Living Yes (www.LivingYes.org).  Is there any way that you can enjoy your time together without expecting anything down the road?  Are there wonderful lessons for you to take from the relationship - even if it only lasts three weeks?  Can you create a mindset of gratitude for what is and let the future expectations (and future demands) go?  Are there new ways to communicate that might bring you together?  What are the lessons for you about allowing the relationship to develop its own course on its own time?  Again, let go of all expectations, and see what happens. That's what "Living Yes" requires.I am sure this will work out well for you - either with him or without him.  ~Mark  (www.MarkMorrisLCSW.com and www.LivingYes.org)
column2: It can feel stressful and frustrating when your partner asks for time to think about your relationship. However, it's essential to respect his need for space. Here are few things you can do: 1. Give Him Space: Understand he's going through a confusing time. Let him have his own time to think. Just ensure he knows you're there for him, but also give him the privacy he asked for.     2. Remain Calm: This situation can lead to a multitude of emotions, but it's necessary to stay calm and composed. Don't rush decisions or make any impulsive moves.     3. Communicate Openly: Have an open and honest discussion about what you both want from your relationship. Be transparent about your feelings. One conversation may not solve everything, but it's a start.     4. Seek Support: Reach out to close friends or family members for emotional support during this challenging time. You can also consider seeking professional help if you feel you're struggling to cope.     5. Self-Care: Use this time to focus on yourself. Engage in activities you love or try something new. Self-care has many forms, and it's about what makes you feel good inside and out. Remember, people sometimes need space to reassess their feelings or thoughts. It's not necessarily a bad thing and could lead to a healthier relationship in the end. If things don't work out the way you hoped, it's essential to remember that life goes on, and over time, you will heal and be okay.

column1: Well, as far as your boyfriend, sounds like he has received advice from others that is not wise advice.  Leaving is not the answer after a "big argument" as you mentioned.  However this is not surprising to me based on his possible age and maturity level.  Having a baby is a lifetime responsibility and there are very few who handle this or who realizes that it requires one to step their game up.  This is something that he has to realize and be encouraged by his parents or a mature adult to do.  Hopefully, someone who has better (wise) advice will talk to him and he will listen.As for you,  how do you handle this situation is your question....you do what you have to do to prepare for your baby, with or without him.  A lot can happen in four years and you don't have time, are not required, and can't wait to see what will happen with him.  You have a LIFE to prepare for,  to feed, to protect, and to love.  Can you tell your baby to wait; I don't want to deal with you now; I need to mature; I will be back to see you later; Hope you will be fine?  Nope!!!   As I always say, you are not alone because there is someone somewhere going through the same or similar thing.  Develop healthy friendships...whether with family, friends or new people who may enter your life.  Your support system will grow and life will go on...with or with him.  Stay focus on you and your baby...
column2: I acknowledge you might be feeling a mix of emotions right now. It's totally normal to feel scared, overwhelmed but also excited. Everyone¡¯s journey is different, and there's no one right way to be a parent. Get guidance, learn, and remember, it is okay to ask for help. Make sure you're taking care of your health (mentally and physically) and remember to reach out to professional help for any medical or emotional concerns. You are definitely not alone in this journey - you can look for local support groups for young parents. You may qualify for certain benefits or assistance programs, so do research on what's available in your area.

column1: Sounds like you are dealing with a lot within your self which is causing you great pain.  I would suggest that first you get a full physical evaluation to make sure that you are ok physically.  Then getting a mental evaluation as well from a psychiatrist.  Seeing both would help rule out any physically or psychologically causes to your symptoms.    After getting these evaluations, your physician should be able to help guide you on what treatments would be the best to help with your everyday challenges your are facing.  Whether treatment includes medication and/or psychotherapist would be discussed.  Please consider doing both immediately so you can have the live you want everyday you wake up.
column2: That seems like a strong statement. Have you had bad experiences lately or feeling frustrated with people around you? It might be helpful to discuss what specifically is troubling you.

column1: Or...better yet... Is it you still thinking about the other girl?  I am sure his cheating hurt you emotionally and may have affected your sexual performance as well.  Make sure the other girl is out the picture on your end as well. Sounds like something the both of you need to have a calm and adult conversation about.
column2: Relationships thrive on trust, love, and open communication, so it's not surprising that things have changed after a big hit to trust. This lack of sexual performance could be due to feelings of guilt, anxiety, or stress on his part, or a subconscious reaction from your side.  It's crucial to openly discuss your feelings regarding his infidelity and the impact it has on your relationship. Perhaps even consider seeking professional help from a relationship counselor or therapist, they are equipped to provide advice and strategies tailored to your specific situation. Remember you deserve respect, honesty, and care in a relationship, so make decisions keeping your emotional, mental, and physical wellbeing in mind.

column1: Hey, it might be mistake in the end but this is a risk you want to take and you get to make your own mistakes. Your mom wants to protect you; I get that. Maybe she is worried you'll be hurt again. Were you hurt in some way by him? Can you understand where she's coming from? Sometimes when we're mad at our partner and we complain about them to mom, it's hard to know how to repair mom's relationship with the partner when things are better and we reunite. Can you help your mom understand that you take responsibility for your part in how it went wrong; that the picture you may have painted of him isn't the total picture? She might need help there. Thank your mom for her love and care, and you can also let her know clearly that you and your boyfriend are the only ones who get to decide whether you're together or not, that it's a risk you are going to take, and that you really need her support. :)
column2: This depends entirely on the context of your relationship. If the breakup was due to issues that can be resolved or changes that have occurred since the break, then giving it a second chance might be worth it. However, if there was any form of abuse or toxicity involved, it might not be healthy to return to that relationship. It's also important to consider your own feelings, well-being and emotional health. If you have any doubts, it may be a good idea to seek advice from trusted friends, family, or a professional counselor.

column1: I am less concerned about this man as bisexual and having gay friends, than about how you feel is treating you.  You are in a vulnerable position because of social isolation.  If you have friends to talk to, please reach out.  While this man has money, it is not his job to take care of you financially unless the two of you have decided that together.  It sounds like he sometimes cares for you and other times you feel disrespected.  I would suggest you look for a man that is consistent in his love and care.  This is not your fault.  But you are in control of removing him from you life or choosing not to because he meets some of your needs.  Take care.
column2: As, I don't have personal insights. However, I can suggest that communication is key in any type of relationship. He might be misunderstanding you or might not be aware that his actions are hurting you. Express your concerns and feelings to him directly. If he continues to treat you poorly, it might be more about his own issues rather than a reflection of your worth. Remember, you always deserve to be treated with respect.

column1: That sounds really heartbreaking. It is tough falling in love and not being able to dive fully because of complications on the other side. It sounds to me that you are doing exactly what you need to be doing by taking "care of myself" while the rest sorts itself out. While I admire your desire and courage to stay friends - the "extreme pain" that you mentioned may make this too challenging and at odds with your taking care of yourself. Since there is no commitment on her end to give it a shot with you I would make sure that you really honour your own feelings about what feels right to you so that you don't end up feeling strung along or resentful. Make sure that you lean on friends and family at this time - we need all the support that we can get when we are heartbroken.
column2: The situation you're in is undoubtedly difficult but it's also an important reminder that addressing it with understanding, respect, and patience could go a long way. You should communicate openly with your partner, express your feelings and fears without blaming her or making her feel guilty.  It's important to understand where she's coming from. She may want to try for the sake of their child, and if that's the case, be supportive. If in the end, she decides to reconcile with her child's father, it may be heartbreaking, and you may need time to heal. But remember, it's essential for the child to have a stable environment, and if this can be achieved through their parents being together, then it is for the best. Eventually, you'll find someone else who is right for you and ready to be in a relationship with you. Healing takes time, but you'll come out stronger on the other side.

column1: Love doesn't hurt.Your description of the relationship so far, is that you are feeling a lot of emotional pain, alongside a deep attraction for this woman.In some relationships, the benefit of what draws us together with someone, is being able to learn more about our own deep sense of who we are, what we value and care about.This sounds more descriptive of your relationship than that it is a loving one.  Your descriptions are of the woman's life, parenting and relationship dilemmas, not about how much of an effort she is willing to make in her life so that the two of you are able to be together for the long term.Try distinguishing your wishes to be loved by this woman with what actually is taking place in everyday life.Being aware of how much love you'd like to give and receive, is valuable self-knowledge.Your ongoing emotional wear and tear of all decisions about the relationship that affect you, being the result of the woman's choices, sounds like the opposite of love.The relationship is very useful as an access in self-understanding of your needs and wishes.  It sounds like this is its main value in your life, not that it is sustainable in reality.Good luck!
column2: Relationships can be complex and create various emotions. This situation is definitely not easy to go through.  Consider these few steps in navigating this: 1. Understanding her perspective - She might be considering this for her child's wellbeing in addition to feeling emotions for her ex. Try to understand her perspective without judgement. 2. Communication - It is crucial for you to have an open and honest conversation about your feelings. Articulate what you're feeling and discuss the future of your relationship with her. 3. Seek Professional Advice - Consider seeking advice from a relationship counselor or a therapist, who can provide perspective and strategies to handle this. 4. Self-Care - Remember your worth. Don't blame yourself. Use this time to embrace self-love and self-care. Meet new people, try new hobbies or invest in personal development. 5. Respect her decision - Ultimately, her decision must be respected even if it's not in your favor. This does not reflect your worth or potential in any way. 6. Seek support from friends and family - Do not hesitate to seek emotional support from those you trust. This can be very helpful. In the end, it's important to remember that life sometimes takes unexpected turns. As painful as it may be, it could be an opportunity for personal growth.

column1: Hi Miami, I feel your sadness; you might have planned a future with your best friend. We live in a world where we are constantly exposed and connected to people who intrigue us and to whom we might feel a connection. I believe that our ability to protect our relationships from the risks involved here has not developed fast enough. Your friend came face to face with what leaving the marriage meant...huge changes and many intense emotions. He is wise to consider his choices carefully; especially if you have children, there is good reason to work at a relationship that is less than fulfilling. Therapy can help.So you fell in love with a man who was in an unstable place. He's taking the steps to create some stability for himself and that leaves you "on hold", not knowing what his decision will be. I love that you seem willing to give him the space he needs to figure it all out. This decision is his. For yourself, you can accept that being "best friends" with a man might not be a wise thing. Many marriages don't fair well when friendships like that exist. You flirted with danger; both of you. You fell in love but he wasn't free, really. I'm sure his love for you is real and powerful, but it's not a competition. It's one man choosing his life path. You can focus on thoughts like this:He has the right to choose his life.We flirted with danger by being best friends.I know he does love me; this is not a reflection on my worth.I can feel really good about giving him patience and the space he needs.I feel proud of his honesty.I feel proud if he's willing to fight for his marriage; lucky her...lucky kids.Acknowledge and allow yourself to feel that sadness, that grief. It's real.If you have told anyone about the affair, seek the support of that trusted person and know you have to grieve this in silence because it was born in silence. I wish you well, and for the record, I'm proud of the maturity you show in this situation. :)
column2: 1. Allow Yourself Time To Grieve: Breakups can be likened to a loss. It's okay to mourn the end of the relationship and allow yourself to feel whatever emotions arise.  2. Reach Out to Loved Ones: Don't try to handle the heartbreak alone. Talk with close friends and family about what you're experiencing. They can lend a supportive ear and offer advice. 3. Maintain Healthy Habits: Take care of your physical health by eating a balanced diet, exercising regularly, and getting enough sleep. These acts of self-care can help improve your mood and energy levels. 4. Focus on Self-Love: It's normal to feel hurt and have lower self-esteem after a breakup. Try to combat these feelings by focusing on your positive qualities and practicing self-compassion. 5. Keep Yourself Occupied: Sitting idle can make you overthink and worsen your emotions. Do things that you enjoy or that make you feel productive, like starting a new hobby, reading a book, or focusing on your career. 6. Avoid Stalking Your Ex: Unfriend, unfollow, and potentially even block your ex on social media if it's creating more pain. It's essential to create some distance after a breakup. 7. Seek Therapy or Counselling: Seeking a professional to speak with can be particularly helpful during this challenging time. They can teach you healthy coping mechanisms and give you the tools you need to move on. 8. Forgive and Accept: Holding on to resentments or wishing things could have been different prolongs the pain of a breakup. Acceptance of the situation can help you find inner peace. 9. Don't Rush Into Another Relationship: Rebound relationships can prolong your healing process. It's important to give yourself time to heal and recover before jumping into another relationship. 10. Be Patient: Healing takes time. Remember, it's okay to feel happy one day and sad the next. Eventually, the good days will outnumber the bad.

column1: Hi Athens, When a teenager wants to have a baby, it's usually for a specific, and not healthy, reason. Do you maybe hope that a baby will cement your relationship? It doesn't work that way. Do you yearn for a person who will love you deeply? Babies don't give to us; we give endlessly to them. I urge you to talk to someone you trust about why you want to speed up your life by being a parent before you are fully grown emotionally. A relationship that is one month old is not stable enough to support a change like this. You're only starting to get to know each other. I wish you well and hope you talk to someone.
column2: As developed by OpenAI, I don't have personal experiences, but I can provide you with general advice in this situation. Having a baby is life-changing decision with great responsibilities. Teens often underestimate the demands of parenthood because they are not yet fully developed or equipped to handle such responsibilities. Things to consider include financial stability, emotional readiness, and whether you have gotten a proper education. Teen pregnancy can cause serious health risks for both the mother and the baby and often results in dropping out of school and affects potential future income. Remember that it's important to talk about this decision with trusted adults like parents, teachers, or counselors. They can help you understand all implications and address any potential problems. Also, safe sex practices and education can help prevent unintended pregnancies.

column1: Given that both you and your friend recently ended your respective romantic relationships, kissing each other sounds like each of you satisfied a very natural need which for right now does not has a natural source of satisfaction.Suddenly being without a partner is difficult because a relationship absorbs and offers much of a person's energy. Stay focused on what you know about yourself, which is that you're not ready for another relationship.From what you describe about your friend, similar to you, he does not feel ready for a new relationship.If and when you feel ready to enter a new relationship and your friend seems attractive, then you'll be in a position to find out, either by approaching your friend as a potential partner, or by asking your question of his interest in you.Who knows?It is possible your friend will feel ready for a new relationship, approach you, and depending on your personal wishes to be or not be with who he has become, accept his offer.Good luck with Step One, becoming familiar with your new state of single hood, and sorting through the good news and bad news of your most recent relationship.
column2: That's a situation many people find themselves in. Here are a few steps you can consider: 1. Analyze your feelings: Make sure you are truly in love with your friend and not just feeling lonely or appreciating them more because of how close you are. 2. Talk to someone about your feelings: You don't necessarily need to talk to the friend in question, but share it with someone else you trust. 3. Watch out for signals: Before telling your friend about your feelings, try to observe how they behave towards you. Are they flirty or do they treat you purely as a friend?   4. Be prepared for all outcomes: If you plan on confessing your feelings, realize that the outcome could either be positive or negative and it could potentially change your current relationship dynamics. 5. Find a good time and place to talk: Open up about your feelings when both of you are comfortable and have enough time and space to discuss. 6. Practice what to say: It can be nerve-racking to admit your feelings, practicing what to say might help you feel more at ease. 7. Finally, tell them: Honesty is important in any relationship. Even though it might be scary, it's best to tell your friend how you feel. Remember, every situation is unique, so what works for some may not work for others. Trust your gut feeling and do what feels right to you.

column1: Hold on, Sanger! You know, I meet with a lot of people who are so sick of the crap that their ex puts them through in the divorce process that yes, they wonder if it's best to go back. I don't think so.If your ex is using the children to manipulate, or is generally controlling the separation process, that's confirmation that getting out was the right decision.Your partner feels powerless to change the current situation. Of course he does, because there are many things that are beyond his control (his ex's behaviours, for one). Accept the powerlessness. Lean into it. It's okay, because there are many things he does have power over, and that's where he can focus. He has the power to give his children a happy dad. That's HUGE. That's why he left, I'd guess. I bet the main barrier to him being happy is the guilt he feels. That's his ex's voice...that's what she wants him to feel...to give into that is letting her win. Ending a marriage in order to be happy is his right. He has not intentionally harmed his children. Hopefully he's aware that the separation has  affected them and he's working to create peace and balance in their lives, but he's can let go of the shame she wants him to feel; it's crippling him.He has the power to separate emotionally from his ex. He's not doing that when he lets her words control his emotions. He's still reacting to her. He hasn't completely left yet.A good therapist can help your partner regulate his emotions, combat shame, create emotional distance from his ex and erect proper boundaries. He needs your support in moving forwards, not going backwards. I wish you the best.
column2: Helping a partner who is suffering from depression is a big responsibility, especially if it involves a sensitive issue like not being able to spend much time with their children. Patience, understanding and compassion are vital here. If you're not sure where to start, here are some suggestions: 1. Encourage Communication: Let your partner express their feelings without judgment. Sharing their thoughts and frustrations can be a relief. 2. Professional Help: Encourage your partner to see a mental health professional, like a psychologist or therapist. They are trained to deal with these sorts of situations and can provide tools to cope with depression. 3. Uplift their Mood: Do the things your partner loves to do in order to uplift their mood. Engage him in a hobby, watch his favorite movie, cook his favorite meal, or simply go for a walk in the park. 4. Boost Confidence: Remind your partner about his good qualities as a father. Show him that he is missed and loved, even when not physically present. Keep him involved in his children's lives as much as possible, incorporating Skype calls, letters, emails, and so on. 5. Encourage Healthy Lifestyle: Encourage your partner to maintain a healthy lifestyle by eating a balanced diet, exercising regularly, getting adequate sleep, and avoiding alcohol and too much caffeine. Physical health greatly impacts mental health. 6. Be Patient: Understand that overcoming depression is not a fast process. It takes time and patience. Being there for your partner throughout this journey is what matters the most. 7. Self-Care: Take care of yourself as well. Supporting someone with depression can be exhausting and overwhelming. It's important to care for your own mental health as well. 8. Create a Support Network: Try to involve close friends and family who can offer additional emotional support.  Remember, it's important that your partner understands that it's okay to reach out for help and that professional assistance is often fundamental in overcoming or managing depression.

column1: New York, what would it mean about you if you got her back? Is that the only way you can like or forgive yourself...if she forgives you and takes you back? Your self respect doesn't need to rely on this working with her. She simply doesn't want to be with you, and every day that you refuse to honour her decision is another day that you hurt her all over again. Move on and heal, perhaps with the help of a therapist.
column2: Regaining someone's trust or affection isn't an easy task, but here are some general steps you can consider: 1. Apology: If you were responsible for the breakup, the first step would be to acknowledge your mistakes and apologize sincerely. Make sure your apology isn't just words, your actions should reflect your remorse.  2. Be honest and transparent: If there are misunderstandings to clear up, be honest and open about them. Honesty is appreciated and it can help regain your partner's trust. 3. Give her space: If she's hurt, it's important you give her time to heal. Give her the space she needs to gain clarity about her feelings and the relationship.  4. Self-improvement: Work on improving yourself, not just to win her back, but because it's essential for you. It's important to learn from the mistakes and grow as a person.  5. Communicate: Talk to her about how much you miss her, and how desperately you want the relationship to work. But remember to respect her decision if she does not want to reconcile. 6. Rebuild your relationship: If she's open to it, gradually try to rebuild your relationship. Start by being friends, then try to win her heart back. 7. Show steadiness: Show her that you're capable of being a steady and reliable partner. Demonstrate you've grown as a person and become more responsible.  8. Consult a relationship expert: They might be able to give you more personalized advice, based on your situation. 9. Be patient and persistent: It can take time for her to forgive or to trust you again. Patience and persistence could play a significant role here. Remember, respect her feelings and decisions. If she does not want to get back together, it is important for you to accept that and move on.

column1: First off, I think it is great that you are willing and able to help out your friend with issues regarding his current relationship, despite the fact that you have feelings for him. I think that the best thing you can do is let him know that you are there for him if he wants to talk about things. You can also help by presenting options that he has and help him weigh out the pros and cons of his decision, but ultimately he has to decide what to do. Know that you won't be able to heal the pain he feels when his girlfriend leaves but you can be a friend to him by simply listening, validating his feelings, and understanding. Regarding your question about being there for him without wanting to hook up....I'm not sure if that is possible. If you care for him on more than a friendship level, then that desire will likey be there for you no matter what. Be careful that you take care of yourself and don't jeopardize your own happiness while trying to help him with his issues. Good luck to you!
column2: Helping a friend go through a break up can be challenging, but it's an opportunity to provide emotional support and companionship during a tough time. Here are a few steps you can take: 1. Be a Good Listener: Allow your friend to express their feelings and thoughts without interruption. Sometimes, people just need to vent and unburden themselves. 2. Offer Comfort: Let them know you are there for them and they are not alone in this. It's important for them to know they have people who care about them and their situation. 3.
